DOC.HEAD: Committee Approves Change in Presidential Primary
DOC.TEXT: California's presidential primary would be advanced from June to the first Tuesday in March under legislation approved Wednesday by a two-house conference committee of the state Legislature. The proposal, sent to the floors of both houses for final votes before their Aug. 31 adjournment, would place California's primary just one week after New Hampshire's first-in-the nation primary. California political leaders of both parties support the change, saying it would transform the primary from a political afterthought in the presidential sweepstakes to what could be the dominant early primary. ``We're trying to become a stronger player in national politics,'' state Sen. Ken Maddy of Fresno, the Republican leader in the Senate, said Wednesday. However, the 5-0 vote of the two-house committee for the early primary plan still doesn't assure its passage. Assembly Speaker Willie Brown, a Democrat, said the shift wouldn't be approved in unless it won support from all the party leaders in both house. Maddy said he and many Republican legislators prefer a plan that moves the presidential primary to March and all other primaries to September. The plan sent to the Senate and Assembly floors leaves the other primaries on the first Tuesday in June, the same date as the presidential primary. The last time the state proved crucial in the primaries was 1972, when George McGovern used his victory over Hubert Humphrey to capture the nomination at the National Democratic Convention. Barry Goldwater's victory over Nelson Rockefeller in California's 1964 primary was the last time the state played a role in picking the GOP nominee for president. The lack of influence rankles many in the state, especially because California sends by far the largest delegations to both national conventions. Supporters of the measure sponsored by Democratic Assemblyman Jim Costa say that because of the state's late primary, presidential hopefuls of both parties ignore California except for brief visits to raise money for their races in New Hampshire, Iowa and other early primary and caucus states. Opponents of the move say it would favor well-heeled presidential candidates, giving those who can raise early campaign contributions an edge in the nation's largest state. The dispute over whether to leave California's congressional, legislative and other primaries in June or shift them to September involves complicated and obscure tactical considerations. Political strategists argue about which party would benefit from shortening the period between the primary and general election from five to two months.

DOC.HEAD: Police Rally For Officer Who Killed Teen
DOC.TEXT: More than 2,500 police called for the ouster of Gov. Jim Florio and Attorney General Robert Del Tufo during a rally Wednesday supporting a white police officer who fatally shot a black teen-ager. Organizers said police are angry because the state has empaneled a second grand jury to investigate the April 10 shooting of 16-year-old Phillip C. Pannell by Teaneck Officer Gary Spath. ``We're here to send them our message, which is they have to stop using Officer Spath and (partner Wayne) Blanco as pawns in their political game,'' said Steve Librie, president of the Teaneck Policemen's Benevolent Association. ``They're trying to make Spath a scapegoat for everything that's wrong with society.'' The officers rallied outside the Bergen County Courthouse in Hackensack, chanting ``Dump Del Tufo, Dump Florio.'' They then marched several miles from Hackensack to Teaneck and congregated outside a municipal building. Meanwhile, about 40 people gathered outside a Teaneck school for a prayer vigil in memory of Pannell. ``Those 2,000 officers are walking strong with their guns,'' said Donna Jackson, a Newark coordinator for the United Youth Council, a black organization that has supported the Pannell family. ``We sit back and say, `It's not affecting me or my family.' You think that, you're wrong. Next time it could be you,'' Jackson said. After the shooting, police and witnesses offered sharply different accounts of the moments leading up to the incident. Spath and Blanco, who were responding to a complaint of a youth with a gun, have said Spath fired only when he saw Pannell reaching for a gun at his waist. Witnesses said Pannell had his hands in the air when the shot was fired. A second grand jury is to review the evidence because of a faulty autopsy report to the first grand jury by Bergen County Medical Examiner Lawrence Denson. Del Tufo said medical evidence indicates that Pannell's hands were in the air. The rallying police officers _ black and white _ chanted, ``He had a gun.'' Nutley Police Officer Steven Rogers said more than 2,500 officers attended the rally.

DOC.HEAD: Poehl, Central Bank President, Supervises Monetary Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FRA3 of 8-17
DOC.TEXT: Karl Otto Poehl, president of the mighty Bundesbank, is supervising the painful transformation of East Germany into part of a capitalist state. He assumed the job with reluctance, but appears to be the right man for it. With a keen sense of politics, the man in charge of West Germany's central bank swept his doubts aside and accepted the role thrust on him by Chancellor Helmut Kohl's decision to unite the two Germanys more quickly than anticipated. Only days before Kohl announced his plans for monetary union of West and East Germany, Poehl still spoke of it cautiously as something that would take at least a year. Insiders say Poehl was furious over Kohl's failure to consult him, but the banker saw quickly which way the political weathervane pointed. He accepted Kohl's decision and the West German mark became East Germany's currency July 1. ``During the monetary union, Poehl the politician had no trouble silencing Poehl the economist,'' said Der Spiegel, the West German news magazine. When the government and public opinion wanted monetary union, Poehl ``could not play the role of a nagging accountant,'' it said. Poehl, opposed to a 1-1 exchange rate of East and West marks, succeeded in persuading the government to limit the amount that could be exchanged at the generous rate. ``The government went along with many of his suggestions and the Bundesbank is now firmly in control of the monetary policy,'' Warren Oliver, an economist in London, said in a telephone interview. East Germany surrendered its monetary sovereignty to the Bundesbank. As guardian of the stability of the West German mark, one of the world's most powerful currencies, Poehl was concerned about the possible inflationary effect of giving East Germany's hungry consumers 25 billion marks ($15.6 billion) overnight. Keeping inflation in check has been one of Poehl's primary jobs since becoming president of the central bank in January 1980. Inflation is one of the worst economic ills to Germans because the Weimar Republic's worthless currency contributed to the rise of Adolf Hitler. Bundesbank autonomy is guaranteed by the constitution, but the government chooses its president. The chancellor gave Poehl a second eight-year term in 1987, even though the banker belongs to the left-leaning Social Democratic Party, the opposition to Kohl's center-right government. The central bank presidency is the best-paying government position in Germany _ 600,000 marks a year, or $375,000. Some officials in the more conservative wing of Kohl's coalition wanted Poehl replaced but could find no one with his experience and international reputation. Analysts agree the strength of the mark would have suffered if Poehl had not been reappointed. Poehl, 60 years old and slightly stocky, is the longest-serving central bank chief in the seven leading industrialized nations and, Oliver said, ``the most successful central banker of the last decade.'' A word from Poehl is enough to move world financial markets. From the sprawling Bundesbank headquarters on the outskirts of Frankfurt, Poehl travels regularly to Washington and other world capitals. He also is a ranking officer of the International Monetary Fund. He was born Dec. 1, 1929, in Hanover, and earned an economics degree in 1955. In seven years as an economics journalist for several publications and radio stations, he built good personal relations with important officials. After joining the Economics Ministry in 1970, Poehl became an adviser to Chancellor Willy Brandt the next year and, in 1972, the ministry's No. 2 man. While at the ministry, he played important roles in freeing exchange rates and creating the European Monetary System. He joined the Bundesbank as a vice president in 1977, three years before becoming its chief. Insiders say Poehl is easygoing and relaxed at his job and once prepared himself for the Washington heat by removing his tie and socks in the plane. He is fluent in English, loves to play golf and has a wit often laced with sarcasm. He is said to have told table companions at a Washington dinner: ``We'll probably have to feed Soviet soldiers now, but luckily their living standard is lower than that of the American soldiers.'' About 380,000 Soviet soldiers are stationed in East Germany. Oliver, the London economist, said Poehl was regarded as ``collegial, quite open. He is very cosmopolitan and is able to tolerate differences of style.'' ``Perhaps that comes from his journalistic background, and journalists tend to go to him at big meetings because they know he has something to say,'' Oliver added. ``The Bundesbank is very successful in the public relations area.'' Poehl endorses a common European currency and European central bank in principle, but has expressed doubts whether governments are ready to allow such a bank the necessary autonomy. Analysts say Poehl would be a perfect choice to head a European central bank.
