DOC.HEAD: Woman Impatient to Use Public Phone, Caller Kills Her
DOC.TEXT: A 25-year-old woman carrying her baby daughter was stabbed to death when she urged a man using a public telephone to finish his call, police said today. Local press called the killing an example of escalating crime in cities and the loss of traditional values in changing South Korean society. Police said Kang Ho-sun, 28, admitted stabbing Ahn Moon-sun in the neck Tuesday after Mrs. Ahn became angry when he did not finish his call. Mrs. Ahn died at a nearby hospital. Her 5-month-old daughter, who was strapped to her back, was unharmed. Kang, 28, was arrested immediately by police outside Seoul's Yonsei University and was charged with murder.

DOC.HEAD: Concentration Camp Composers' Music Lives On
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX6 sent Aug. 22.
DOC.TEXT: They were just four of the millions who perished in Nazi camps. But in the shadow of death, the Jewish composers created a musical legacy that has outlived the horror of their fates. Today, a musician is organizing performances of the almost forgotten pieces by Gideon Klein, Pavel Haas, Viktor Ullmann and Hans Krasa _ musicians imprisoned in a concentration camp in Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia. ``It's amazing and it's inspiring,'' says Mark Ludwig, a Boston Symphony Orchestra violist. ``Our mission is ... to make the public aware not only of the great talents of these artists but there's a spiritual resistance, a spiritual form of resistance which is also very inspiring.'' Ludwig spent two years tracking down scores from composers at the Nazi camp in Terezin, Czechoslovakia, a village north of Prague. He concentrated on the four composers, who had promising careers in pre-war Prague. Krasa's ``First Symphony,'' for example, had been performed by the Boston orchestra in 1926. Many of the scores came from the state Jewish museum in Prague and the Terezin National Monument, where they had been deposited after the war and largely ignored. Others came from survivors entrusted with the music. Some of the pieces, mainly chamber music, express ``a great deal of pain and desolation,'' Ludwig said. ``There are also others that are reminiscent of times past, good times, if you will, a way of momentarily distracting the audience from their environment.'' ``People are just so moved by the power because the soul is coming out,'' he said during a recent interview at the orchestra's summer home. ``You don't have to be so sophisticated, it just touches you, it's so deeply felt.'' The concentration camp known as Theresienstadt originally was a walled garrison town. The camp served as a way station for transports to death camps in the east and as the center of a Nazi propaganda effort. At the camp, the musical community sometimes had to keep out of sight, holding rehearsals in attics and basements of the town. After they learned of the makeshift concerts, Nazi guards at first allowed them as part of their efforts to create the appearance of a model camp. Later, the cultural activities often were forbidden as a disciplinary measure. Ullmann wrote a short allegorical opera about life in the camp, which was rehearsed, but was not allowed to be performed. Ludwig said the composer almost took the score with him when he was sent to Auschwitz, but was persuaded by friends to leave the music behind. To bring the music before the public, Ludwig founded the non-profit Terezin Chamber Music Foundation. So far, concerts have been held in Worcester and at a Holocaust memorial service at the Massachusetts Statehouse. Concerts are planned next year for Amsterdam, Boston and the Berkshires. The pieces, mainly short works such as string trios, quartets and sonatas, carry melodic Slavic influences and, Ludwig believes, are destined to become part of chamber music's repertoire. Next year's programs include music that hasn't been heard since it was first written and performed in the concentration camp _ a time when the musicians probably were never sure of their fate, Ludwig said. ``You still hold that hope. When you think about it, creativity _ that's a form of hope, too. Even in a horrendous environment, in the worst of times, if one is creating, one is expressing, there is a need, there's a hope.''

DOC.HEAD: For Fearful Saudis, Survival at Any Price
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has forced Saudi Arabia to make a fundamental and perhaps permanent change in its public approach to the outside world. The invasion forced Saudi Arabia, long equivocal about its links with the West, to publicly ally itself with the United States, despised by many Arabs for its support of Israel. The United Arab Emirates and other Persian Gulf states have followed Saudi King Fahd's lead, declaring their support for U.S. forces on their soil. For more than four decades, the Saudis have tried to conceal their close economic cooperation with Americans and the U.S. military presence in the cradle of Islam. But the Aug. 2 overthrow of Kuwait's royal family, the oldest dynasty in the gulf region, underlined the fragility of the gulf kingdoms and sheikdoms. Saudi unease had already been triggered by the collapse of the shah of Iran in the 1979 Islamic Revolution across the gulf. King Fahd had little choice in the face of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's military actions but to call in the Americans and their allies to protect his kingdom and its vast oil fields. ``The only alternative was unthinkable _ to sit back and watch Saddam overrun the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and, eventually Saudi Arabia itself,'' said an Arab diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Despite lavishing billions of dollars on sophisticated military hardware over the years, King Fahd's untested, 120,000-strong armed forces are no match against Saddam's battle-seasoned hordes. Like other Arab rulers, the Saudi royal family saw that grass-roots support for Saddam among the region's 200 million Arabs, long envious of the gulf's oil riches, was a mushrooming radical force. Since King Abdul-Aziz founded the al-Saud dynasty in the 1920s by conquering rival Bedouin clans and forging the Saudi state, his descendants' policy has been survival at any cost. Like other gulf oil states, the Saudis have long avoided discord by sheltering behind their Islamic piety and consensus politics. U.S. ties date back to 1945, when Abdul-Aziz made an unwritten alliance with the United States. The Americans, edging out the British, secured the first oil concessions in 1933, giving Washington strategic interests in Saudi Arabia. Fahd told his estimated 8 million subjects two weeks ago that he had invited the Americans to help him reinstate the al-Sabahs in Kuwait and defend Saudi Arabia against a possible Iraqi attack. Since then, the Americans have been pouring troops and materiel into Saudi Arabia. Fahd has sought to placate his Islamic critics. ``These forces from friendly powers are here temporarily ... and will leave as soon as the kingdom so demands,'' he stressed in a nationwide statement Aug. 9. He reiterated it Aug. 21. But with Saddam deploying an estimated 200,000 men in and around Kuwait and showing no sign of pulling out of the former emirate, the Americans may be around for awhile. ``Everyone accepts that there's going to be a long-term American military presence,'' said a senior gulf official, who spoke on condition he was not named. ``It's no secret that Saudi Arabia and other gulf countries willingly accept whatever it takes to ensure their stability. If necessary, they will accept an increased American presence here.'' That's a dramatic about-face for the Saudis, who have long sought to play down their Western orientation, while paying lip service to Arab nationalism and the Palestinians' struggle against Israel. The Saudi rulers have overseen the transformation of a desert backwater into a modern state, all the time trying to prevent progress from undermining its Islamic roots. Much of the royal family's legitimacy rests on Islam. A few years ago, Fahd stressed this by declaring himself the guardian of Islam's holiest shrines at Mecca and Medina. Allowing American infidels in to protect the holy places has drawn resentment from Moslem quarters. Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi has for years berated the Saudis for befriending the United States and urged Moslems to stop making the annual pilgrimage to Mecca as long as ``it remains under American military occupation.'' Iran's Islamic revolutionaries have constantly reviled the Saudi leaders as ``American stooges'' and called for the downfall of the royal family. The Saudis have long discouraged outsiders peering into their world. The thousands of Westerners, Americans and others, who keep the oil flowing, live mostly in their own compounds. That too may be changing, with thousands of American GIs flooding into the once-veiled kingdom. American and other Western journalists have been allowed in and events in Saudi Arabia are now daily on prime-time television. Saudi newspapers, which until recently ignored controversial subjects, are now reporting the harsh realities facing the kingdom. Arab reporters, however, have been advised to refer to the U.S. presence as part of a multinational force comprising Egyptian, Moroccan and other Arab units as well.

DOC.HEAD: UN Charter Provides Joint Military Action to Enforce Embargoes
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Following are Articles 41, 42, 43 and 51 under Chapter 7 of the U.N. charter covering Security Council action in cases of threats to peace and acts of agggression:
DOC.HEAD: Article 41
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council may decide what measures not involving the use of armed force are to be employed to give effect to its decisions, and it may call upon the members of the United Nations to apply such measures. These may include complete or partial interruption of economic relations and of rail, sea, air, postal, telegraphic, radio and other means of communication, and the severance of diplomatic relations.
DOC.HEAD: Article 42
DOC.TEXT: Should the Security Council consider that measures provided for in Article 41 would be inadequate or have proved to be inadequate, it may take such action by air, sea or land forces as may be necessary to maintain or restore international peace and security. Such action may include demonstrations, blockade, and other operations by air, sea, or land forces of members of the United Nations.
DOC.HEAD: Article 43
DOC.TEXT: 1. All members of the United Nations, in order to contribute to the maintenance of international peace and security, undertake to make available to the Security Council, on its call and in accordance with special agreement or agreements, armed forces, assistance, and facilities, including rights of passage, necessary for the purpose of maintaining international peace and security. 2. Such agreement or agreements shall govern the numbers and types of forces, their degree of readiness and general location, and the nature of the facilities and assistance to be provided. 3. The agreement or agreements shall be negotiated as soon as possible on the initiative of the Security Council. they shall be concluded between the Security Council and members or between the Security Council and groups of members and shall be subject to ratification by the signatory states in accordance with their respective constitutional processes.
DOC.HEAD: Article 51
DOC.TEXT: Nothing in the present Charter shall impair the inherent right of individual or collective self-defense if an armed attack occurs against a member of the United Nations, until the Security Council has taken measures necessary to maintain international peace and security. Measures taken by members in the exercise of this right of self-defense shall be immediately reported to the Security Council and shall not in any way affect the authority and responsibility of the Security Council under the present Charter to take at any time such actgion as it deems necessary in order to maintain or restore international peace and security.''

DOC.HEAD: Sen. Simpson, Gov. Sullivan Coast to Primary Wins
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to update with more early returns. Pick up 7th graf, `The hunt...
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. Alan Simpson and Gov. Mike Sullivan handily won their primary races Tuesday, while GOP gubernatorial candidate Mary Mead took an early lead in an unusual two-woman race for her party's nomination. With 154 of the state's 471 precincts reporting, Mead had 69 percent of the vote to state Rep. Nyla Murphy's 31 percent. Simpson, the Senate minority whip, was easily winning his third Republican nomination with 83 percent of the early vote. It wasn't clear which of six little-known Democrats would win the right to challenge Simpson. Kathy Helling, a 32-year-old college student, and Al Hamburg, who was convicted last year of forging names on a campaign petition, were the top vote-getters in early returns. As it was four years ago, Sullivan walked away with the nomination Tuesday. He got 88 percent of the early vote in his primary contest with motorcycle mechanic Ron ``Suds'' Clingman. The governor said he would have preferred to face stiffer competition. ``I have to say that when you watch people debating the issues on the other side, you wish you had some primary opposition so you could talk about the issues,'' said Sullivan. The hunt for the GOP gubernatorial nomination pitted Mead, 55, the daughter of former Gov. and U.S. Sen. Cliff Hansen, against Murphy, a 59-year-old Casper woman who has served the past 12 years in the state House of Representatives. Mead's campaign stressed her skills as a rancher and businesswoman and attacked Sullivan's economic development efforts. Murphy, in turn, accused Mead of having a negative attitude toward Wyoming and of failing to propose solutions to the shortfalls she perceived. Sullivan largely ignored the primary campaign and stuck close to his gubernatorial duties. U.S. Rep. Craig Thomas was uncontested in the primary. Elected last year to fill Dick Cheney's unexpired term in office, Thomas is seeking his first full-term in the House this fall. Also unopposed was his Democratic challenger, Pete Maxfield, a University of Wyoming law professor.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgaria Imposes Travel Ban on Romanians Because of Cholera
DOC.TEXT: About 300 Romanians were pulled off a train by Bulgarian authorities after Bulgaria imposed travel restrictions because of a cholera outbreak in Romania. Dimitar Dimitrov, Bulgaria's consul in Bucharest, said Tuesday that the new restrictions were imposed to protect Bulgarians against the cholera epidemic, which broke out last month in Romania's Danube delta area. Seventy-four cases have been reported in the Danube region since mid-July. Thirty-one victims are still hospitalized. Dimitrov said the travel restrictions would allow individual Romanian travelers to transit through Bulgaria for no longer than 30 hours. They are also prohibited from bringing Romanian foodstuffs or beverages into the country. Those traveling in organized group tours, which typically provide room and board, will be able to stay in Bulgaria for longer periods, Dimitrov said. On Tuesday, a group of 300 Romanian tourists, most of them gypsies, were taken off a train by Bulgarian authorities at the Russe-Girgiu border crossing because of the new regulations, the Bulgarian state news agency BTA reported. Some scuffled with police who tried to put them onto a train back to Romania. The Romanians pulled the emergency brake on the return train and jumped off, scattering before police could stop them, BTA said. The news agency said the Romanians also were carrying large quantities of goods, apparently to be sold on the black market. East Germany and Czechoslovakia have both imposed travel restrictions on Romanians. Many Romanians travel abroad to buy or sell goods or to seek better living standards. Bulgaria is a major transit route for Romanians who travel to Turkey for purchasing goods _ some of which are sold on the Romanian black market. Under the Bulgarian government decree, Bulgarians are temporarily banned from private travel to Romania.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Deploys Missiles in Kuwait
With PM-Gulf Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The 800 missiles Iraq has moved into Kuwait are thought to be either Soviet Scud-B missiles or the Iraqi modification of the Scud-B, the Al Husayn. Here at a glance are the specificatons of both, according to Jane's Defence Weekly:
DOC.HEAD: SCUD-B
DOC.TEXT: TYPE: Short range, road mobile, liquid propellant, single warhead ballistic missile. DESCRIPTION AND SPECIFICATIONS: Propulsion is a single stage liquid rocket motor with inertial guidance. Range is approximately 185 miles. The Scud-B carries a single conventional high explosive blast-fragmentation or chemical warhead. The Scud-B is approximately 37 feet long, 3 feet in diameter and carries a payload of 2,172 pounds. The accuracy of the missile is within 1,476 feet.
DOC.HEAD: AL-HUSAYN
DOC.TEXT: TYPE: Short range, road mobile, liquid propellant, single warhead ballistic missile. DESCRIPTION AND SPECIFICATIONS: The Al Husayn missile is believed to be a modification of the Soviet Scud-B with decreased payload and increased propellant weight to give it increased range. Propulsion is a single stage liquid rocket motor with inertial guidance. Range is approximately 400 miles. The Al Husayn carries a single conventional high explosive blast-fragmentation or chemical warhead. The missile is approximately 40 feet long, 3 feet in diameter and carries a payload of 1,102 pounds. The accuracy of the missile is within 3,281 feet.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Forces Continue to Build in Gulf Region
With PM-Gulf-Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is look at the forces buildup in the Persian Gulf region. In line with Pentagon practice, no details have been provided on numbers of U.S. aircraft or troops arriving in the gulf, nor their exact locations.
DOC.HEAD: NAVAL FORCES
DOC.TEXT: _ At least 24 ships, 17,000 men, 200 aircraft and three aircraft carriers in the gulf, the nearby Arabian Sea and the Red Sea. Warplanes from the carrier Independence, just outside the gulf, fly nightly missions over that strategic sea. _ The U. S. Navy's hospital ships USNS Mercy and USNS Comfort have left the United States for the gulf. _ The Marines are sending in 45,000 of their finest and an armada of Marine Corps amphibious assault ships is heading for the gulf. The seaborne units, equipped with amphibious tracked vehicles that can travel on land at speeds up to 50 mph, are designed for offensive and defensive operations. They are supported by a variety of aircraft, including the F-A18 Hornet, a ground attack airplane also capable of air-to-air combat. _ Among other weaponry the Marines are taking to Saudi Arabia: more than 100 M1 battle tanks and 150 fixed-wing aircraft, including Harrier vertical takeoff planes used for light attack missions and close air support of ground troops, and A6-E Intruder bombers used in Libya in 1986. Other attack-oriented naval forces that are in the area aboard aircraft carriers include F-18s and EA-6B radar-jamming planes designed to foul enemy communications during combat.
DOC.HEAD: LAND FORCES
DOC.TEXT: _ Some elements of the 101st Airborne Division from Fort Campbell, Ky. The 101st has a total of 15,400 soldiers and includes two attack battalions, each armed with 18 AH-64 Apache helicopters and 18 AH-1 Cobra anti-tank helicopters. It also has two assault helicopter battalions, each with 45 Blackhawk copters. The division also has one medium-lift helicopter battalion equipped with 18 CH-47 Chinook helicopters, and one air cavalry squadron, which performs reconnaissance with 12 AH-1 Cobra helicopters and 12 OH-58 observation helicopters. _ Some elements of the 24th Infantry Division (Mechanized) from Fort Stewart, Ga., which have been deployed. The 24th has a total of 16,600 soldiers and includes three M-1 tank battalions, each with 58 tanks, and three FVS battalions, each with 54 Bradley Fighting Vehicles, plus reserve units. It also has two active artillery battalions equipped with 155mm self-propelled artillery, and one active battalion equipped with nine multiple-launch rocket systems. _ Some elements of the 82nd Airborne Division from Fort Bragg, N.C., which have been deployed. The 82nd, a paratroop division, has a total of 12,800 soldiers. Each of its nine battalions is equipped with 20 TOW anti-tank weapons. _ An Army source said troops from Fort Hood, Texas, also were to be deployed. News reports said 1,000 soldiers had been readied for deployment. Five batteries from the 11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade at Fort Bliss, Texas, have been ordered to prepare for departure to the gulf. The 229th Aviation Regiment, Fort Rucker, Ala., left Wednesday for the Gulf. A typical ``attack'' regiment has about 300 soldiers, 18 Apache helicopters, 13 UH-58 scout choppers, and three Black Hawk aircraft used to transport supplies and machinery. _ Elements from the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment at Fort Bliss are being deployed to the Middle East. The regiment has 4,200 soldiers and is among the Army's best desert-warfare units. A spokesman confirmed the deployment but refused to give any details. Elements of another Fort Bliss unit, the 11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade, were sent Sunday to Saudi Arabia.
DOC.HEAD: AIR FORCES
DOC.TEXT: _ 22 F-117A Stealth fighter-bombers _ At least 48 F-15 fighters were being sent from the 1st Tactical Fighter Wing at Langley Air Force Base, Va., and A-10 attack jets from the 354th Tactical Fighter Wing at Myrtle Beach Air Force Base, S.C. The A-10 is armed with a six-barrelled 30mm anti-tank cannon said to make it the best anti-tank weapon in the world. _ An unknown number of F-16 Fighting Falcon planes began arriving in Saudi Arabia on Friday, and the Pentagon announced Saturday that F-16s were continuing to arrive from Shaw Air Force Base, S.C. _ Fourteen F-111 bombers have been flown to Incirlik, Turkey, 425 miles from the Iraqi border. _ An unspecified number of KC-10 and KC-135 tanker aircraft and RC-135 reconnaissance aircraft, as well as Airborne Warning and Control System radar planes have arrived in Saudi Arabia. _ The Air Force says B-52 bombers also have been sent overseas since the gulf crisis started.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Hostage Worries 14 Others in Lebanon Will Be Forgotten
LaserPhoto BX2
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former hostage Frank Reed says his 14 Western comrades in Lebanon are forgotten, deprived, sick men whose plight is worsened by the new hostage crisis in the Persian Gulf. ``God forbid they come out in a box,'' he said. ``What's frightening is that they could be there for 10 years,'' he said in an interview Tuesday. ``They told me the day I was captured, `You're going to be here for 20 years.' I'm a very lucky man to be out.'' Reed said the 3,000 Americans held in Iraq and Kuwait will take priority over the six Americans and eight other Westerners held in Lebanon by the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, which is believed to be an umbrella group for Shiite Moslem terrorists. ``I think it it will have an overall effect of them being put further and further down in the agendas,'' said Reed. ``As far as I know, the American government is doing nothing.'' State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said he had no comment on Reed's remarks. Reed implored the American public to ``start writing people, the president, their senator, their representative, to make them aware of the humanity that supposedly exists in this country.'' ``For God's sake we're talking about almost six years that Terry Anderson and Tom Sutherland have been in captivity,'' he said. ``They should be freed. When I left them they were sick. This is very degenerating.'' Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest held of the hostages. He has been in captivity nearly 5{ years. Sutherland, 59, acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut, has been held for a little over five years. The other American hostages are: Joseph Cicippio, 59, acting comptroller at the American University in Beirut; Edward Tracy, 59, West Beirut resident; Alann Steen, 51, a communications instructor at Beirut University College, and Jesse Turner, 42, professor of mathematics and computer science at Beirut University College. Reed, 57, lives in suburban Malden. He was the founder and president of the Lebanese International School. He was freed in April after 3{ years in captivity. No American hostages have been released since then. Reed has criticized the Bush administration for its stand against negotiating with terrorists. The demands of the kidnappers in Lebanon include the release of prisoners held by Israel in southern Lebanon and terrorists jailed in Kuwait and Western capitals. There are conflicting reports on the fate of the prisoners in Kuwait. Some say they escaped after the Iraqi invasion. Others say they have been killed. Some suggest they have been moved to Baghdad, the Iraqi capital. If the prisoners in Kuwait got out, the Western nations now have less to offer to the kidnappers to free the hostages, Reed said. The conditions under which the Americans in Iraq and Kuwait are being held are not known. In Lebanon, the hostages have been blindfolded, chained and malnourished. Reed said he was badly beaten, apparently for trying to escape twice, and poisoned with arsenic. Reed said he was sympathetic to American families who have relatives among the hostages in Iraq and Kuwait. ``But I believe they're a hell of a lot safer in that situation than the people I left behind are,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis Heated Up throughout August
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here is a chronology of the Iraq-Kuwait crisis:
Aug. 1 _ Iraq pulls out of talks with Kuwait on Iraqi grievances over oil pricing, Kuwaiti war loans to Iraq, and Iraqi claims on Kuwaiti territory. Aug. 2 _ Iraq's powerful army overruns Kuwait before dawn, seizing the emir's palace and other government buildings. President Bush orders U.S. economic embargo against Iraq. Aug. 3 _ Shelling and gunfire echo through Kuwait City as Kuwaiti forces mount last-ditch resistance. Iraqi troops push to within few miles of Saudi Arabian border. State Department says American civilians are trapped in Kuwait. Aug. 4 _ Iraq announces new military government for Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. European Community imposes trade embargo on Iraq. Aug. 5 _ Kuwait's new Iraqi-installed government claims Iraqi troops begin pulling out of Kuwait, but United States skeptical. Japan suspends Iraqi oil imports. Aug. 6 _ U.N. Security Council orders worldwide embargo on trade with Iraq. In Saudi Arabia, U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney confers with Saudi leaders about defending the oil kingdom against any Iraqi attack. Aug. 7 _ Bush orders deployment of U.S. combat troops and warplanes to Saudi Arabia. A fresh U.S. Navy task force sets sail for region. Turkey cuts off exports from Iraqi oil pipeline through Turkish territory. Aug. 8 _ Iraq declares Kuwait has been annexed. Britain agrees to join multinational force in the gulf. Other oil-producing nations indicate they will step up production to make up for embargoed Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. Aug. 9 _ American troops take up position in Saudi Arabia's oil-producing province. Iraq says it has canceled its estimated $15 billion debt, incurred during the Iran-Iraq war, to Kuwait. Iraq closes its borders for foreigners, trapping thousands of Americans and other Westerners in Iraq and Kuwait. Aug. 10 _ Twelve of 20 Arab League states vote to send all-Arab military force to join Americans in defense of Saudi Arabia. First Egyptian contingent arrives in Saudi Arabia. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein urges Arabs to sweep ``emirs of oil'' from power in gulf states. Aug. 11 _ Saudi Arabian anti-aircraft batteries reportedly fire on Iraqi reconnaissance planes near Kuwaiti border. Thousands of Arabs demonstrate in Yemen and Jordan against United States. Bush suggests Saddam risks overthrow from within unless he ``changes his spots.'' Aug. 12 _ Saddam says he is ready to resolve the gulf crisis if Israel withdraws from territories it occupies. Secretary of State James A. Baker III says the U.S. Navy will interdict Iraqi oil shipments. Aug. 13 _ Iraqi troops in Kuwait round up American and British visitors from two hotels in Kuwait for transport to Iraq. King Hussein of Jordan secretly meets with Saddam in Baghdad. Aug. 14 _ King Hussein flies to Washington in effort to mediate U.S.-Iraq confrontation. Aug. 15 _ Saddam offers to withdraw from Iran territories and release prisoners of war in bid to with favor with Tehran against the United States. Aug. 16 _ Bush pressed King Hussein to close Iraq's access to the sea through Aqaba, Jordan, but Hussein indicated Bush made little headway. Aug. 17 _ Bush has decided to call up military reserves to meet shortages of doctors, cargo handlers and other specialists in the gulf crisis. Aug. 18 _ A U.S. frigate fired warning shots across the bow of an Iraqi oil tanker in the Gulf of Oman and U.S. forces briefly went to battle stations over the incident. Aug. 19 _ Saddam offers to free all foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait if the United States promises to withdraw its forces from Saudi Arabia and guarantee that an international embargo will be lifted. Aug. 20 _ Iraq announces it has carried out a plan to move Western hostages to vital military installations to use as human shields to deter any U.S. attack and warned its people not to try to hide any of the thousands of foreigners trapped in the country. Aug. 21 _ Arab and Western nations condemn Saddam's threats against hostages and continue adding armed forces to the region. Saddam defends the holding of foreigners and promises ``a major catastrophe'' if war breaks out.

DOC.HEAD: Bernard Wex, Designer of Longest Suspension Bridge Span, Dead at 68
DOC.TEXT: Bernard Wex, designer of the world's longest suspension bridge span, has died, according to a newspaper report today. He was 68. The London newspaper The Independent reported that Wex died on July 31. It stated no cause of death and gave no explanation for three-week delay in reporting it. Wex designed the Humber Estuary Bridge in northeast England, which was officially opened by Queen Elizabeth II in 1981. The Guinness Book of Records lists its main span, measuring 4,626 feet, as the world's longest suspension bridge span. As partner-in-charge with the firm of consulting engineers Freeman Fox and Partners, Wex both designed the bridge and directed its construction. Wex graduated with honors in civil engineering from London's prestigious Imperial College in 1951 and then joined Freeman Fox, working under the internationally renowned bridge designer Gilbert Roberts. Wex was involved in the design of several important bridges under the guidance of Roberts and later Oleg Kerensky. They included the Auckland Harbor Bridge in New Zealand and the Severn and Forth Road Suspension Bridges, both in Britain. He was honored by the queen for his services to engineering by being made an officer of the Order of the British Empire in 1982. He leaves a wife and two sons. The report did not mention funeral services.

DOC.HEAD: NJ Senator's Visit to Iowa Seen as Testing Presidential Waters
DOC.TEXT: New Jersey Sen. Bill Bradley knows about making the right moves when he sets foot on the farm soil of Iowa. Almost 40 years ago, as a Little Leaguer from Missouri playing baseball in a regional championship in Ottumwa, Iowa, he stepped off first base and was tagged out. The sting of being caught off guard has stayed with him. A more careful Bradley recalled the early misstep this week during his third trip to the state since 1988. Bradley's visit to the home of the nation's first Democratic presidential caucuses raised questions asked any time a politician of national repute steps into the Iowa limelight. ``I don't know that much about him,'' said Elaine Baxter, Iowa's secretary of state. ``I feel good about the things I've heard _ the respect of his colleagues, a very substantive person, able to reach out to those voters in the middle. I would need to see where he stands on women's issues, economic issues and foreign policy.'' Standing on a flatbed truck, a relaxed Bradley addressed a group of Democrats _ weaving tales about his pro basketball past with a campaign boost for Iowa Sen. Tom Harkin, a fellow Democrat. The crowd looking up from picnic tables applauded. They laughed at his jokes. And many walked away wanting to know more about the 6-foot-5 New Jersey senator. ``As a speaker, I thought he was really a surprise,'' said Gloria Sullivan of Des Moines, who anticipated a dry delivery. Bradley's appearances in Winterset, Des Moines and Cedar Rapids were read as testing the waters. But Arthur Davis, chairman of the Iowa Democratic Party from 1985 to 1987, said the real question is whether Bradley returns to Iowa after this fall's Nov. 6 election. ``If we see him after November, it will be because he's interested in exploration,'' Davis said. Bradley insists he wants to serve another six years in the Senate. ``To anyone who says anything about the presidency, I say, no, I'm not running for president,'' the two-term incumbent said. Given his insistence, Bonnie Campbell, the Democratic candidate for Iowa attorney general and past state Democratic chairman, said Bradley's appearance amounts to good strategy. ``If you even had anything on your mind down the road, what would make Democrats think more warmly toward you than helping one of the most popular senators in Iowa?'' she said. Davis cautioned that Iowa might have trouble with a Bradley candidacy. ``Are we going to go East again? Although Iowa did go for Governor Dukakis, does the salvation of the party lie in Eastern liberals?'' Bradley's Iowa visit was one of his few this election season on behalf of fellow Democrats. He spent Friday in Texas with Ann Richards, the Democratic gubernatorial nominee. He's also helping raise money for Dianne Feinstein, who is running for governor of California, and Harvey Gantt, who is running for the Senate from North Carolina. Bradley's opponent, Republican Christine Todd Whitman, has accused him of neglecting New Jersey interests while in Iowa. Bradley argued that he was there ``so I can collect my chits'' with Harkin, who as chairman of a Senate appropriations subcommittee holds the purse strings for several Bradley health and education bills.

DOC.HEAD: US Move to Bolster Saudi Weaponry Has Long-term Consequences
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's decision to add more F-15 fighters and heavy tanks to Saudi Arabia's defensive shield against Iraq has an additional benefit, officials say: drawing the once-resistant Arab nation closer to the West. International cooperation in the bid to reverse Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has opened doors long closed to Washington, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Tuesday as he returned from a four-day trip to the Persian Gulf. ``I think the degree of cooperation today _ in terms of U.S. military presence and a collective security effort _ obviously is far greater than it has ever been before,'' Cheney said. Because the threat from Iraq is so serious to the moderate Arab rulers in the gulf region, Cheney said, ``Nations that previously have had sort of an arms-length relationship with the U.S. military are eager to cooperate with and support our efforts in the region, and the efforts of the other nations involved.'' The secretary was scheduled to brief Bush on his trip today in Kennebunkport, Maine. Cheney's high-speed swing through the Persian Gulf was designed to gain support for the U.S.-led campaign against Iraq. He visited the Persian Gulf sheikdoms of Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Oman, Qatar and Saudi Arabia to garner support for Operation Desert Shield, and also stopped in Egypt. With Saudi Arabia's King Fahd and defense minister Prince Sultan, Cheney discussed the monarchy's hardware wish list to boost the kingdom's defenses against Iraq's buildup of about 160,000 troops in occupied Kuwait. A senior Pentagon official said the administration intends to move quickly to supply additional F-15 jet fighters and heavy tanks to the desert kingdom. The Saudis want more than the dozen F-15s that President Bush ordered for an emergency transfer during the early days of the Persian Gulf crisis. Cheney told reporters that no specific agreements on weapons sales were reached during talks in Jiddah. Although Cheney declined to say exactly what was being discussed, he stressed that the Saudis need to improve their defensive hardware quickly. The goal is to keep Saddam Hussein's army far away from the strategic Saudi oil fields. ``We are obviously looking at aircraft, we're looking at munitions to go with the aircraft, we're looking at things like protective (anti-chemical weapons) gear, anti-aircraft capabilities and armor munitions,'' Cheney said. ``They need tanks in order to be able to defend against Iraqi tanks, so we're improving their capabilities in that area.'' The Saudis have purchased U.S.-made F-15Cs and F-15Ds and own 58 of the jets, as well as 550 tanks. But across their northern border, Iraq's heavily mechanized forces possess 5,500 tanks and about 500 combat aircraft. The United States has rushed dozens of its most sophisticated F-15Es, F-16s and F-117A stealth fighter bombers for the operation, but the Saudis want to improve their own defensive position, the official said. And although the Saudis recently signed a deal to purchase about $3 billion worth of M1-A2 tanks, the vehicles won't be ready until the mid-1990s. That makes U.S. stocks of M1-A1 or M-60 tanks candidates for sale, given that many armored vehicles will be removed from Europe if a conventional arms accord is reached with the Warsaw Pact. Asked about a report that Cheney was negotiating a deal for a Saudi purchase of 24 F-15Es, the official said the talks involved the less sophisticated F-15Cs and F-15Ds, but he also declined to rule out such a sale. The F-15E has been updated to give it a much wider range of operation, and it is equipped with Sidewinder and Sparrow air-to-air missiles. Many in Congress would be sure to oppose any sale of the updated version, given concerns for Israel's security. The Reagan administration was rebuffed several years ago when it attempted to sell the Saudis the new model. But such sales could help boost a flagging U.S. defense industry, which is expected to suffer if some of the proposed Pentagon budget cuts go through. Prior to a stop in Cairo, Egypt, to confer with his counterpart there on Desert Shield, Cheney told reporters he was pleased with the support he had received during his tour. The United Arab Emirates announced it would become the second nation in the gulf region to host foreign troops. That decision will help the flow of food, ammunition and supplies to the U.S. armed forces on land and sea throughout the gulf region. ``Various nations are cooperating in various ways. Some are providing forces, some are providing bases for our forces, some will help with financial support,'' Cheney said.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Drivers, Though Despondent, Stick Out Strike
DOC.TEXT: As the Greyhound strike grinds well into its sixth month with no resolution in sight, drivers are using odd jobs, their savings or unemployment checks to scrape by. ``The old-timers ... some of them are having a hard time finding any other work,'' said Darrell Horn, president of a drivers union local in Portland, Ore. ``They're very despondent. But they're not going to go back to work under these conditions.'' The bus line's 6,000 drivers walked out March 2 over a dispute in wages and job security. Drivers contend they only wanted to regain ground they lost after taking pay cuts over the past decade that dropped their salaries from $31,000 to $24,000. Now, the bus line, currently under the protection of bankruptcy court, has told those drivers their jobs no longer exist because it has resumed ``business as usual'' with 3,000 strikebreakers it hired. ``We still consider Greyhound as our company, the one we built, the one we gave up our wages for and vacations for, just to keep the company afloat and give it a chance to breathe,'' Bob Beard, a Greyhound driver for 29 years, said from his home in suburban Washington. Greyhound contends the union created its own problems with excessive wage demands. It blames the company's financial trouble on security and legal costs stemming from initial strike violence it contends was orchestrated by union leaders. Drivers have found a variety of ways to make ends meet. Jim Gajdos has a job hawking $1 programs at a minor league ballpark in Boise, Idaho. For Jerry Reidell in Bellingham, Wash., the dispute has meant switching roles with his wife: He's now at home with their two children while she works at the Postal Service. Other striking drivers have taken temporary and part-time jobs with tour or charter bus companies. Some have been forced to use their savings or are trying to survive on unemployment and $50-a-week strike benefit checks. Most drivers enjoyed their jobs, despite the pay cuts, because of the independence and cross-country trips, strikers said. ``People don't really think of us as cowboys, but we're kind of the stagecoach drivers of the '90s,'' Gajdos said. ``There's a certain romance to the job.'' Gajdos and Reidell have both dipped into their savings to help in the pinch of lost paychecks. Gajdos said that because his Greyhound pay had dropped over the years, he's used to a life without the extras. ``I guess you could say we've been introduced to poverty on the installment plan,'' Gajdos said. Many local unions have food bank set up where grocers and charities donate canned goods and cereals for drivers. Horn said union drivers are pinning their hopes on some potential resolutions: _A bankruptcy judge might replace Greyhound Chairman Fred G. Currey with a trustee willing to resume negotiations with union drivers. _A New York investment banking firm, the Blackstone Group, could take over the company, a move it has been studying. Blackstone has said a takeover would include bringing union drivers back and possibly allowing employees to have part ownership. _A National Labor Relations Board administrative law judge in Milwaukee could agree with the board's general counsel and find that Greyhound engaged in unfair labor practices. That would mean the bus line would have to take back the union drivers and give them as much as $10 million a month in back pay. However, Greyhound has already said it would appeal such a decision, which could mean court battles for years. Greyhound contends its financial problems will be resolved with a reorganization plan that streamlines the company's operations. But that reorganization plan isn't due until October, and extensions on initial plan deadlines frequently are granted. Frank Motsay, president of Local 1610 in Washington, said the drivers' cause has been hurt by a lack of publicity in recent months, especially since Currey held a news conference May 7 and said the strike, in effect, was over because replacements had been hired. ``You can't unilaterally declare a strike over when you have unfair labor practices hanging over your head. Fred Currey is not going to end this strike by simply wishing it away,'' Motsay said. Labor leaders from other unions have privately said the drivers were ill-prepared for a walkout and should have tried other methods first to avoid a strike, but many of the striking drivers seem determined to continue the walkout.

DOC.HEAD: US Force in Saudi Desert Now Tops 35,000, General Says
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: At least 35,000 U.S. troops are now in Saudi Arabia or on their way _ and more will be going, says the Air Force general in charge of getting troops to the desert kingdom. The estimate Tuesday by Gen. Hansford T. Johnson, while not precise, was the clearest official indication of the size of the U.S. military buildup, which President Bush ordered in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait three weeks ago. Johnson, commander of the U.S. Transportation Command and Military Airlift Command, told reporters that the equivalent of 1 billion pounds of military equipment and soldiers had been shipped from U.S. shores to the Saudi desert. He said that was comparable to ferrying 400,000 U.S. automobiles over that distance. Johnson said military security rules prevented him from disclosing the exact number of soldiers or amount of equipment that have been sent to Saudi Arabia, but he said, ``We've moved in essence'' the equivalent of a town the size of Jefferson City, Mo. The population of Jefferson City is 35,408, according to the preliminary 1990 census. ``We've also moved all of their equipment, cars, trucks, foodstuffs, stocks, household goods and water supply,'' Johnson said. In addition to the U.S. ground forces in Saudi Arabia, an estimated 20,000 sailors are deployed on warships in the Persian Gulf, the Arabian Sea, the Red Sea and the Mediterranean as part of Operation Desert Shield to defend against a possible Iraqi attack. Johnson said he could not discuss planned additional deployments, but Pentagon sources have said contingency plans call for sending as many as 250,000 troops, depending on Iraqi military moves. An administration source gave a different figure Tuesday, saying Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, planned to tell Bush today that the United States was approaching a target figure of 100,000 military personnel in the region. The transportation strain has fallen most heavily on the Pentagon's airlift operation, Johnson said, because of the need in the earliest stage of Desert Shield to get as many light infantry on the ground in Saudi Arabia as possible. He described the air operation as ``the largest sustained airlift ever over a short period of time.'' Besides the workhorse C-141 and C-5 military transport planes used to ferry men and equipment, Johnson said the Pentagon has relied heavily on the commercial airline industry. Several airlines volunteered to provide charter passenger service, he said, but late last week the Pentagon decided to commandeer 38 civilian cargo and passenger jets because the volunteer pool was too small. Johnson said he didn't expect to force additional commercial planes into service. Johnson also acknowledged that the urgent nature of the deployments was forcing the Pentagon to put off certain safety inspections of the C-141 fleet, which has been plagued by structural cracks in some planes. ``We're taking some risk'' by pressing the full fleet into service before completing the safety review, he said. The general said the overall air and sea transportation effort had gone well, aided in part by more than 4,200 military reservists who had volunteered to come on active duty. Johnson told of one man who called to volunteer for duty aboard a merchant ship for the 10,000 mile trip to Saudi Arabia, but that he was a little concerned about his insurance ``and a few other little details.'' The man was 81 years old. ``We didn't call on him this time, but he was ready to go,'' Johnson said. The latest additions to the U.S. military operation in Saudi Arabia include: _An undetermined number of soldiers from the 24th Infantry Division, a mechanized unit based at Fort Stewart, Ga., left from Hunter Army Airfield near Savannah on Tuesday. _The tank landing ship USS Manitowac and the amphibious assault ship USS Iwo Jima left port at Norfolk, Va., to pick up Marines at Moorehead City, N.C., for the week-long voyage to the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Food Stamp Rise Shows Extent of Poverty, Congressman Says
DOC.TEXT: The sharp rise in food stamp recipients shows how prevalent poverty is in America, a congressional committee on hunger says. ``At some time everyone is going to have to come to grips with the fact that we have this many poor people,'' said Rep. Tony Hall, D-Ohio, in a statement released Tuesday by his House Select Committee on Hunger. The statement followed published reports about an Agriculture Department study that showed the number of people on food stamps rose 1 million between May 1989 and May 1990 to top 20 million for the first time in five years. The Agriculture Department report had been requested by the Senate Appropriations Committee, which is still considering how much to allow for the food stamp program next year. The House has approved $18.1 billion. Congress appropriated $16 billion for this year's program. ``What is remarkable about the recent growth in participation is that there is no consensus about its causes,'' said the Agriculture Department, which released a summary of the report this week. ``It occurred even though there were no major changes in the food stamp program or in the economy, at least as measured by the national unemployment rate.'' Hall said, however, that the findings in the report demonstrate how even a slight downturn in the economy can be too much for some people, throwing them onto public assistance rolls. The rise extended to 44 states and the District of Columbia, varying in size and timing from state to state. Nearly half the total increase was attributable to a rise in recipients in Texas, California and Florida, the report said. The Agriculture Department investigators said the increases are so recent that much of the data traditionally used to analyze food stamp trends are not available. However, the study offers several possible reasons for the increases: _Greater long-term unemployment that's not showing up in statistics. _More working poor. _Higher food prices. _Changes in the distribution of income. _More female heads of household. _Changes in the immigration laws giving thousands of aliens legal status and making them eligible for food stamps. _Improved accessibility and outreach. The 1990 farm bill approved by the House earlier this month would make even more people eligible than current law, with provisions designed to help children, the near-homeless and homeless, the elderly, disabled and rural Americans who traditionally have not had as much access to the food assistance program.

A prominent medical journal broke the rules of scientific impartiality by printing an article assuring the safety of a synthetic hormone that boosts cow milk production, says the head of a foundation that is critical of genetic engineering. Jeremy Rifkin, president of the Foundation on Economic Trends, says today's article in the Journal of the American Medical Association was written by two scientists who have worked for a leading maker of bovine growth hormone. ``The editors of JAMA are showing a flagrant disregard for scientific impartiality by publishing an article written by scientists who have been under contract to Monsanto,'' Rifkin said Tuesday. The General Accounting Office, Congress' investigative arm, and the inspector general's office of the Department of Health and Human Services are reviewing the Food and Drug Administration's handling of the hormone. The JAMA article says FDA ``uses a systematic, scientific process to ensure that all new products used by dairy farmers are safe'' and has answered all the concerns about the safety of milk from cows that have received the hormone. The authors, William Daughaday and David Barbano, noted that the FDA pronounced the hormone safe in 1985, and could approve its commercial use by next year. But Rifkin said: ``Protection of the public interests demands independent, long-term studies to determine the safety of milk from cows that have been injected.'' ``BGH has been overwhelmingly rejected by both farmers and consumers recent public opinion surveys,'' said Rifkin. ``The introduction of BDH would devastate the family farm, undermine the purity of dairy products, add billions of dollars to the cost of dairy support programs, hurt cows and pose potential health problems.'' Wisconsin and Minnesota have temporarily barred use of the hormone. However, an editorial in JAMA by an outside researcher concurred with Daughaday and Barbano, saying ``milk produced from cows treated with bovine somatotropin is no different from the milk of untreated cows.'' ``It is both inappropriate and wrong for special-interest groups to play on the health and safety fears of the public to further their own ends,'' said the editorial, by Charles H. Grossman, an immunologist at the Department of Veterans Affairs in Cincinnati.

DOC.HEAD: Rural America Needs Special Attention, AIDS Commission Says
DOC.TEXT: Health services and educational programs for rural Americans at high risk of getting AIDS must be expanded dramatically to stem the spread of the disease, the National Commission on AIDS says. ``AIDS education is virtually non-existent and desperately needed in rural communities,'' the commission said in a report to the White House and congressional leaders Tuesday. This absence of information about AIDS has fanned ``an epidemic of fear and bigotry'' in rural America, where people infected with the AIDS virus fear being ``found out'' nearly as much as they fear the disease itself, the panel said. Physicians and other health-care professionals across the country also must be educated about acquired immune deficiency syndrome because too many of them are refusing to treat AIDS patients, the commission's report said. Another area of concern to the commission was access to experimental drugs, which panel members said is extremely limited for minorities, women and children, even those who have no other hope. The 15-member commission that advises Congress and the White House urged swift action on its latest recommendations, as it did for its recommendations in two previous reports. ``We're very late in responding to a massive problem, but getting later makes no sense at all,'' said Dr. June Osborn, commission chairwoman and dean of the University of Michigan School of Public Health. The 13-page report drew from the commission's visits to Georgia and Texas. Panel members heard from people who had been rejected by their church, lost their jobs and were evicted from their apartments because they were infected with HIV, the human immunodeficiency virus that causes AIDS. ``Ignorance and misinformation are seriously hampering, if not crippling efforts to treat'' rural Americans with HIV infection and AIDS, the report said. AIDS is a more severe problem in the cities, but the epidemic is growing faster in rural areas. Cases of the disease rose 37 percent in rural areas compared with 5 percent in metropolitan areas with more than half a million people from 1988 to 1989, the report said. The commission recognized recent federal efforts to include more blacks and Hispanics in government-funded testing of experimental drugs, but said: ``We can and must do better.'' Blacks and Hispanics account for 43 percent of all AIDS cases, but they make up only 23 percent of clinical trial participants, the report said. Children and women of childbearing age usually have been excluded from clinical trials, but the panel said that must change. The report also said the National Institutes of Health had moved too slowly to find drugs to manage opportunistic infections, which are the cause of death for most AIDS patients. The panel said NIH should give that research a higher priority while continuing work on drugs that act on the AIDS virus. Turning to health-care personnel, the commission said it ``heard repeatedly about a serious shortage of dentists willing to treat people with HIV infection and AIDS.'' The report related the experiences of one witness who said the only two dentists in his community who would accept Medicaid declined to see him because he was infected with HIV. ``One dentist's excuse was that his office was carpeted and he would not be able to sterilize the room after the visit. The other dentist said she had plants and could not take the risk of him infecting her plants and her plants then infecting her other patients,'' the report said. The commission also recommended creation of ``a comprehensive community-based primary health care system, supported by adequate funding and reimbursement rates.'' Such a system ``is essential for the care and treatment of all people,'' not just those with AIDS, the panel said. However, the panel did not outline the specifics of such a system.

DOC.HEAD: Quickie Marriages, Anti-Saddam T-Shirts: America Prepares for War
DOC.TEXT: In Texas, near Fort Hood, the waiting period for marriage licenses is waived to accommodate soldiers shipping out to the Middle East. A Florida manufacturer of sunblock cream offers to make an unscented batch because, ``I'd hate to see 5,000 of our guys advancing across the desert toward the enemy smelling like a coconut.'' Perhaps influenced by the movie ``Dirty Dozen,'' 14 inmates at Cross City Correctional Institution in North Florida announce they want to fight in Saudi Arabia, redeem their honor, and gain their freedom. In thousands of ways, America prepares for war. ``We are not just seeking release from prison,'' the inmates said in a letter. ``We are willing to defend this country and in the process, restore some of the lost honor we have inflicted on ourselves and this country.'' The noble sentiments were lost on Bob Macmaster, a spokesman for the Florida Department of Correction. He suggested the prisoners have been watching too many movies. Around the country, the Middle East confrontation brings these changes: _New Mexico state police were urged by their chief, Neil Curran, to pump their own gas to save money and to shop for the lowest price. _Bookseller Diana King in Mountain Brook, Ala., found a run on atlases because ``people want to know where it all is.'' _In Texas, there were runaway sales of camouflage-colored muscle shirts. In Georgia, a business handed out little American flags to wave proudly from car antennas. _Sharon Wagner of El Paso, Texas, who owns a computer portrait business, told The Associated Press she wants to print Saddam Hussein's likeness on T-shirts with a bull's eye on his chest. Along Interstate 75, gray-green trucks took the 101st Airborne from Fort Campbell, Ky., to Florida ships bound for the Middle East. People stood on overpasses in north Georgia to cheer the troops on their way. One banner read: ``Get Their Gas and Kick Their Ass.'' Don Gage of Dalton, Ga., supplied a flag, 30 feet by 50 feet. ``Gosh,'' he said, ``we had to do something. We want them to know we care. And I'll tell you this: We can't wait to put it on the northbound side to welcome them back.'' In Johannesburg, Mich., Mary Wolf raised a flag outside her home and said, ``I'm hoping it spreads like wildfire across the United States ... Let the hostages know we're caring.'' Bell County, Texas, waived the 24-hour waiting period for marriages of Fort Hood soldiers and issued a record 160 licenses last week. A New York City comedy club featured seven comedians with the central theme ``Iraq-Nophobia.'' Everywhere that soldiers leave for the oven-baked Middle East, there is a rush to buy sunblock cream. Paul E. Burke Sr., president of Native Tan Inc., in Daytona Beach, Fla., offered to supply odorless sunblock at cost. Eileen Bronko of Naugatuck, Conn., sister of a Saudi-based soldier, led a contingent of 50 people to tie a ribbon around the town flag pole. She wants Americans to decorate trees with red-white-and-blue ribbons to show they care about the troops and not just about oil prices. Fabric stores in Enterprise, Ala., and Dothan, Ala., have given away thousands of yards of yellow ribbon since troops from nearby Fort Rucker shipped out last week. Dean Richards, program director for the nationwide Satellite Music Network, got a call from a frightened girl he estimated to be 8 to 10 years old. She asked that he play `Right Here Waiting for You' by Richard Marx. The youngster said ``her daddy was in the Marines and she was right here waiting for him to come back,'' said Richards. Richards devoted air time all last weekend to 500 messages to GIs along with playing musical requests. The network contacted the Armed Forces Radio network and arranged for a tape of the show to be replayed for troops in the Middle East. It will happen again next weekend. K-Mart manager Wesley Bennefield _ whose store in Hinesville, Ga., sold 24,000 items of bug spray, suntan lotion, skin lotion, lip balm and foot power to the Army at Fort Stewart last week _ said the service got a discount. ``You might say we're waving the flag,'' said Bennefield. ``I'm a patriotic guy.''

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Hits Poorer Nations Harder
DOC.TEXT: Nearly three weeks after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the first signs are showing of a gathering economic crisis in the developing world. In Nepal, there's a run on gasoline, and gas prices have increased 50 percent in Zambia. Sri Lanka is worried about access to the Persian Gulf states who are major purchases of tea, its principal foreign exchange earner. Scores of oil-poor and cash-strapped nations face inflation, slower growth and increased debt after Iraq invaded Kuwait, causing crude prices to rise from about $20 a barrel to more than $25. The worst hit are the smaller and poorer nations of the world, for whom increasing oil prices and U.N. sanctions on trade with Iraq and Kuwait will drastically disrupt their already tenuous balance of payments. Manpower-exporting countries ranging from the Philippines to Egypt risk suffering rising unemployment and declining foreign exchange _ gained by workers' sending part of their paychecks home _ if their citizens lose jobs in Iraq and Kuwait. ``We could have an economic crisis of calamitous proportions _ especially if a shooting war starts in the gulf,'' says I.Z. Bhatty, a member of an economic think tank in New Delhi. ``Oil is a product which has the most linkages with the rest of the economy.'' Many of these nations have little or no capacity for refining crude oil, so they were ready buyers of petroleum products from Kuwait, which had the most advanced refineries in the gulf. The pinch is also being felt in Eastern Europe, where several countries have given Iraq large export credits and have little hope of cashing in on the debt. Here are some of the countries affected and how they're trying to cope:

BANGLADESH _ The government has announced restrictions on fuel consumption and shops have been ordered to close by 8 p.m. to conserve electricity. Bangladesh receives at least $100 million annally from citizens working in Iraq and Kuwait, about 12 percent of its total remittances. The country would face enormous unemployment if these 110,000 people return home.

BULGARIA _ President Zhelyu Zhelev says Iraq owes his nation $1.2 billion that it was repaying in oil shipments. Also, Bulgaria will lose $160 million in incomplete exports to Iraq. Zhelev has declared a moratorium on Bulgaria's $10.3 billion debt.

EGYPT _ About 54,000 Egyptians working in Iraq and Kuwait have returned home. At least 1.2 million Egyptians were working in the two countries before the crisis began, and they contributed a large chunk of the $3.5 billion of foreign remittances every year. Trade with Iraq, which stood at $74 million last year, is frozen.

INDIA _ India was already affected by a resource crunch and depleted foreign exchange reserves when the gulf crisis hit. The government estimates its oil bill will rise by $850 million in 1990, and at least 170,000 of its citizens in Iraq and Kuwait will stop sending remittances home.

LEBANON _ Fuel prices have quadrupled and food prices have doubled since Iraq's invasion. The Lebanese pound has plummeted to an all-time low of 850 to the dollar. Kuwait was at the forefront of a $2 billion reconstruction plan in Lebanon, which has been devastated by 15 years of civil war.
PAKISTAN _ Remittances from 180,000 Pakistanis in Iraq and Kuwait have dried up.

PHILIPPINES _ Devastated by an earthquake last month, the Philippines faces the return of 93,000 of its citizens working in Iraq and Kuwait. The two countries also supplied 22.5 percent of the Philippines' fuel needs.
ROMANIA _ Iraq owes Romania $1.7 billion in export credit.

SRI LANKA _ The government has said it will not stop trade with Iraq. ``Sanctions can be imposed by rich countries. We cannot afford to stop selling our products,'' says Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne. Sri Lanka sells tea worth $100 million to Iraq every year and receives about $500,000 from its citizens working in the gulf, according to government figures. Gasoline and cooking prices have been raised.
YUGOSLAVIA _ Construction companies were involved in projects worth $1 billion in Iraq. Also, Baghdad owes Yugoslavia $1.1 billion and was repaying with supplies of crude oil.
ZAMBIA _ Zambia has announced a 50 percent increase in fuel and kerosene because of the gulf crisis.

ZIMBABWE _ Zimbabwe imported two-thirds of its fuel needs from Kuwait, about $120 million annually. The government says it has a two-month supply in reserve and that Saudi Arabia has promised to make up the shortfall.

Figures for July show the government heading toward a possible new record deficit. The $189.1 billion deficit so far during the first 10 months of fiscal 1990 already surpassed the entire $152.1 billion imbalance piled up during the previous year, the Treasury Department said Tuesday. And it has only $32 billion to go in the next two months to beat the $221.1 billion record set in 1986. It is already 52.9 percent above the $123.7 billion deficit compiled at the end of the first 10 months of 1989. The White House Office of Management and Budget in July forecast a $218.5 billion deficit when the current fiscal year ends Sept. 30. Louis Crandall, an economist with R.H. Wrightson & Associates in New York, said that ``much of the concern over the deficit trend this year has been because of weakness in receipts.'' However, he noted that revenues in July totaled $72.4 billion, up 9.3 percent from the comparable month last year and said, ``That doesn't seem to be getting worse.'' Nevertheless, while individual tax revenues rose, corporate tax revenues dropped, illustrating the weak economy. And the overall receipts were more than offset by spending which rose 16.4 percent to $98.3 billion. The outlays included $3.2 billion by the Resolution Trust Corp., the government agency charged with bailing out the savings and loan industry. The S&L bailout cost $15.8 billion in June and $35.2 billion so far this year. The government expects to regain much of the bailout cost by selling real estate, loans, securities and other assets from failed thrifts. That, the government says, will help reduce the deficit in future years. In addition to spending on the thrift bailout, economist Crandall noted other ``very strong spending in many categories, particularly Medicare and Medicaid.'' Spending by the Health Finance Administration, which administers both programs, was 25 percent higher in July than a year ago, Crandall said. Revenues for the first 10 months of fiscal 1990 totaled $850.1 billion, up 4.3 percent from the same period of 1989. But spending totaled $1.04 trillion, a 10.7 percent increase over the first 10 months of last year. The biggest spending categories, as usual, were the military, Social Security and other programs of the Department of Health and Human Services, and interest on the national debt. Military spending totaled $22 billion in July and $241.4 so far this year. It is projected to total $290.2 billion for the entire fiscal year. Social Security payments amounted to $19.6 billion for the month and $203.1 billion for the year so far. They are projected to total $244.9 billion for the year. Other HHS payments, including Medicare and Medicaid, totaled $17.3 billion during July and $161.4 billion thus far this year. They are projected to total $192.4 billion in fiscal 1990. Interest on the national debt amounted to $18.4 billion for the month and $228.6 billion so far this year. It is projected to total $261.1 billion for the entire year.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Tries to Visit Iraq as a Journalist
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson says he wants to go to Iraq as a journalist rather than diplomat but still thinks he can help ease tensions by interviewing officials and Americans held hostage in that country. ``It would not be appropriate to go there as a diplomat,'' the former Democratic presidential contender turned television-show host told reporters Tuesday. Assuming such a role ``would interfere with what is a growing crisis,'' he said. But Jackson, who traveled to Syria in 1984 to negotiate the release of a Navy pilot shot down over Syria, said journalistic communications could encourage a diplomatic solution to the Middle East crisis. ``We are not certain just yet as to what our government's plans are for that area,'' Jackson said. ``If on the one hand it is military deterrence and diplomatic initiatives, then communications could facilitate a level of dialogue that appears to be closing.'' ``The Jesse Jackson Show'' is scheduled to begin next month, syndicated by Time-Warner Inc., which Jackson said would help underwrite the trip. The staff of the new show is trying to make arrangements for the trip, he said. But he added in an interview later with WTTG-TV that ``pressure has been applied (by the administration to discourage the trip) and it's unfortunate and it is inconsistent.'' The White House and the State Department denied any effort to discourage Jackson from traveling.

DOC.HEAD: Census Figures Released for Eight States, Puerto Rico
DOC.TEXT: Iowa suffered a slight population loss between 1980 and 1990, according to Census figures that are subject to change. Seven other states and Puerto Rico gained population, according to the figures that were released Tuesday. The figures are released under the local review program, which allows local governments to question the results because of missed counts or overcounts. Final official state population figures are scheduled to be issued Dec. 31. The first such reports, for 18 states, were released Friday. The figures made available Tuesday, and comparable state populations from the 1980 census, are: Arkansas, 2,337,395, up from 2,286,000. Iowa, 2,766,658, down from 2,914,000. Minnesota, 4,358,864, up from 4,076,000. Missouri, 5,079,385, up from 4,917,000. New Jersey, 7,617,418, up from 7,365,000. New Mexico, 1,490,381, up from 1,303,000. Puerto Rico, 3,599,258, up from 3,197,000. Utah, 1,711,117, up from 1,461,000 Wisconsin, 4,869,640, up from 4,706,000.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Illusory Vacation Could Backfire
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is still in Maine at the midpoint of his 25-day holiday, mixing golf with the gulf in a vacation marred by the biggest U.S. military operation since the Vietnam war. ``What you don't want to do is appear to be held hostage in the White House to events,'' Bush told reporters as he headed off to his summer home 12 days ago. But it appears there's a price to be paid for not being a hostage, too. At a time when young soldiers are sweltering in newly dug foxholes in the Saudi desert, gas masks attached to their garrison belts, the president has been pictured almost daily out golfing at breakneck pace or chasing bluefish in the Atlantic in his beloved cigarette boat, Fidelity. Polls show the public overwhelmingly backs Bush's stand in defense of Saudi Arabia and, by lesser margins, the public supports his taking a vacation too. But Bush may be laying himself open to partisan attack at a later date with the maladroit way the White House has projected his image on several occasions in the past two weeks. As Democratic political consultant Bob Squier put it, ``If I ever need it, I now have a shot of Bush climbing into a hot boat and wasting gas on the day he sent American boys to risk their lives for more wasted gas.'' The crisis has clearly made heavy demands upon the president's time at Walker's Point, the scenic family refuge on Maine's rocky coast. Twice he has jetted back to Washington. He has delivered speeches at the Pentagon and before the Veterans of Foreign Wars. He opened his door to Jordan's King Hussein and Saudi Arabia's Prince Saud. And he has kept the phone lines ringing at other capitals. Republican pollster and White House adviser Robert Teeter said a poll that he and Democrat Peter Hart conducted for the Wall Street Journal and NBC found the public supporting Bush's decision to stay on vacation by a 53 percent to 39 percent margin. The same survey found overwhelming support for Bush's handling of the gulf crisis: 72 to 16 percent. Teeter, in an interview from Ann Arbor, Mich., called the questions raised about Bush's staying in Kennebunkport, ``purely a story created by the press.'' ``Ultimately, what counts is how he handles (the crisis) and what the results are. This we will all forget,'' said Teeter. Stephen Hess of the Brookings Institution says the media are giving a false impression of how the presidency works. ``It's a question of image versus reality,'' said Hess, a White House adviser in past administrations. ``The reality is the presidency goes where the president is. ... Logistically, they are perfectly supplied wherever they are. And Kennebunkport is not exactly Nome, Alaska.'' Norm Ornstein, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, said, ``I do not think it's a bad idea to send indirectly to Saddam Hussein the message that if we're in a long war of nerves, Bush is not panicking. He's going about business as usual.'' And Bush may be better off facing this crisis in the ``psychologically mellow'' surroundings of his summer home with wife and family rather than back in the white House ``grumbling and puttering around alone,'' Ornstein said. But Ornstein said he is puzzled by the ``political tone-deafness'' of Bush's sojourn in Kennebunkport. ``Every day there are pictures and sound bites of him responding to events in the gulf, all showing him on the golf course, getting out of the boat, jogging, and I don't think that's a particularly good image for him to be putting out,'' he said. It may not matter much at a time when Americans ``have rallied around our commander in chief and rallied around the flag,'' said Ornstein. ``But if something goes wrong ... his recreating is going to be a major piece of the attack against him.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Christopher Connell covers the White House for The Associated Press.
