DOC.HEAD: Indians Block Rail Line Despite Police Action
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Spelling of Stl'atl'imx cq. Dollar figures U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Police have arrested about 40 Indians blocking a rail line, but another group of natives set up another blockade within hours further down the tracks. The premier of this Canadian province, Bill Vander Zalm, condemned the second blockade Tuesday, called because of a dispute over land claims. ``I would suggest they are doing harm and they should cease, desist and avoid the sort of confrontational issues this could lead to,'' he said. Earlier Tuesday, police arrested about 40 Indians at Seton Portage for defying a provincial Supreme Court injunction ordering them to end their blockade of British Columbia Rail's main line. Those arrested included three chiefs _ Marvin Bob of the Pavilion band, Rod Louie of Seton Lake and Roger Adolph of the Fountain band _ all part of the Stl'atl'imx nation. The Stl'atl'imx, unhappy with British Columbia's response to their land claims proposals, had asked the police inspector to charge the provincial government with the theft of their land. Those arrested at Seton Portage were taken to Lillooet, about 100 miles northeast of Vancouver. They were to be released on their own recognizance after being charged with disobeying a court order, authorities said. When the first blockade was removed, two freight trains bound for Prince George continued a journey stalled since Friday, when the blockade began. But before a southbound train had gone far, Indians from the Lillooet People's Movement blocked the line on Indian land near Mount Currie, about 60 miles southwest of Seton Portage, said Ray Pierre, manager of the Mount Currie Indian band. Pierre said the line will be blocked for at least 24 hours. The BC Rail line runs between Vancouver and Prince George. The railroad said it was losing more than $635,000 a day because of the blockade. BC Rail obtained the Supreme Court injunction Saturday. The blockade also was in support Mohawks in Oka, Quebec, who have been in an armed standoff with police and the armed forces since July 11. The dispute arose over the Oka community's plans to expand a golf course onto what the Mohawks said was ancestral land. A police attempt to remove a Mohawk barricade led to the shooting death of an officer, but responsibility in the death remains to be established. Karistanoran, a Mohawk spokesman, said proposals now call for full sovereignty in all Mohawk communities in Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Sen. Simpson, Gov. Sullivan Coast to Primary Wins
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Mead winning GOP nomination; PICKS UP 9th graf pvs, `Mead's campaign ...'
DOC.TEXT: The rancher daughter of a former Wyoming governor won the GOP nomination for her father's old job Tuesday and will square off in November against Democratic Gov. Mike Sullivan, who coasted to victory. Republican Sen. Alan Simpson handily won his primary race for re-election. With 69 percent of the vote in, rancher Mary Mead had 67 percent of the vote to 33 percent for 12-year state Rep. Nyla Murphy. ``We're not celebrating yet, but we are looking foward to doing it,'' Mead said from her Jackson ranch. ``We have lots of friends here at my house. ... A friend sent a case of champaign and I hope to break it out and toast victory.'' Mead, 55, is seeking to give Wyoming its first father-daughter combination in the governor's mansion. Her father, Cliff Hansen, served one term as governor from 1963 to 1967 before moving on to the U.S. Senate. Sullivan walked away with the Democratic nomination, receiving 88 percent of the early vote against motorcycle mechanic Ron ``Suds'' Clingman, who had called for lowering the drinking age to 18 and decriminalizing drugs. Simpson, the Senate minority whip, headed easily to his third GOP nomination with 85 percent of the vote and will meet little-known Democrat Kathy Helling, a 32-year-old college student. With 69 percent of the vote in, she received 35 percent to 22 percent for Howard O'Connor, her closest rival in a six-way race. The first-term governor said he would have preferred to face stiffer competition. ``I have to say that when you watch people debating the issues on the other side, you wish you had some primary opposition so you could talk about the issues,'' said Sullivan. Mead's campaign stressed her skills as a rancher and businesswoman and attacked Sullivan's economic development efforts. Murphy, in turn, accused Mead of having a negative attitude toward Wyoming and of failing to propose solutions to the shortfalls she perceived. Sullivan largely ignored the primary campaign and stuck close to his gubernatorial duties. Rep. Craig Thomas had no opposition in the primary. Elected last year to fill Dick Cheney's unexpired term, Thomas is seeking his first full term in the House. Also unopposed was his Democratic challenger, Pete Maxfield, a University of Wyoming law professor.

DOC.HEAD: Founder of National Merit Program Dead at 87
DOC.TEXT: John M. Stalnaker, a psychologist who founded and was president of the National Merit Scholarship Corp., has died at age 87. Stalnaker, who died at his home Sunday of lymphatic cancer, taught psychology, developed tests and handled administrative duties at the Universities of Chicago and Minnesota and Purdue, Princeton and Stanford. At Princeton, Stalnaker originated and operated the National Pepsi-Cola Scholarship Program, forerunner of the National Merit Scholarship. He helped develop that project as a consultant to the Ford Foundation. Today, the non-profit organization channels scholarship money from 425 corporations and foundations and 200 colleges and universities to more than 30,000 students. Eight thousand high school students are selected each year for the program. After the Merit Program was established as an independent corporation in 1955, he was named its first president, a position he held until his retirement in 1969. He also was associate director of the College Entrance Examination Board from 1936 to 1945. During World War II, Stalnaker directed the Army-Navy College Qualifying Test and other examinations. President Lyndon Johnson appointed him to the Board of Foreign Scholarships, which he served as chairman from 1962 to 1965. In 1964, he became the first director of Presidential Scholarship Program. Survivors include his wife, Edna, a daughter, two sons and a sister. Funeral services will be private.

DOC.HEAD: McDonalds Damaged In String Of Bombings
DOC.TEXT: A bomb shattered windows at a McDonalds restaurant before dawn today, one of three bombings that rocked the capital, police said. No one was injured in the attacks authorities blamed on rightists. At around 1 a.m. a man hurled a plastic bag that exploded, destroying doors and windows of the McDonalds, another hamburger stand and a passing taxi, police said. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the latest attacks. Lt. Col. Pablo Bernabe, police chief of suburban Valenzuela, blamed rebel soldiers for the bombings. ``We are inclined to believe that this was the handiwork of ultrarightists who are sowing fear among our people to destabilize our democratic government,'' Bernabe said. The McDonalds bombing was the latest attack since dissident right-wing soldiers bombed buildings of the Department of Trade and Industry on Aug. 13, and the third since late Tuesday. A bomb shattered glass windows of a private investment building in the Binondo district Tuesday night. This was followed about three hours later by a blast near a fire station in Valenzuela that shattered windows of nearby houses and the fire station. No one was injured. Rumors of another coup attempt swept the capital following the bombings and the military has been place on full alert since Friday. President Corazon Aquino on Tuesday said ``enemies of democracy'' continue to plot against her government, which has survived six coup attempts by dissident troops since its formation in February 1985. ``These people will never succeed as long as we have trust in each other, especially if we have trust in God,'' she told 5,000 people who attended a Mass to commemorate the assassination of her husband, former Sen. Benigno Aquino, seven years ago. The bloodiest coup attempt occurred in December, in which at least 113 people died and 600 were wounded.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Lower in Japan
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 25,210.91, down 1,086.93 points, or 4.13 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Astronomers Help Keep Abe's Reputation Honest
DOC.TEXT: Two astronomers say they have discovered evidence that may keep Abraham Lincoln's reputation as ``Honest Abe'' intact. They say Lincoln, as a lawyer before he became president, played fair 133 years ago when he got a murder suspect off the hook by discrediting a witness who said he saw the crime by the light of a bright, three-quarters-full moon. Lincoln produced an almanac that indicated the moon was setting and near the horizon at 11 p.m. on Aug. 29, 1857, when Duff Armstrong supposedly bludgeoned a man to death after a religious camp meeting in Illinois. Armstrong was acquitted. But townspeople remembered there was indeed a full, bright moon at the camp meeting that night. Some suspected Lincoln of producing a phony almanac. Now it appears that both Lincoln and the townspeople's memories were correct, said astronomers Donald Olson and Russell Doescher of Southwest Texas State University in San Marcos. Using computers to recreate the sky above central Illinois on the night of the murder, the astronomers found that what occurred was an unusual lunar phenomenon that caused the moon to move quickly from its highest point in the sky to setting. The moon on that night was 74 percent full and near a position it reaches only once every 18.6 years, in which its arc is at its lowest in the sky as seen by people in the northern hemisphere. The astronomers' calculate that just before 8 p.m., during the camp meeting, the moon was due south and at its highest point for the night. But by 11 p.m., the moon was already dropping from view near the southwestern horizon. Coincidentally, there will be a somewhat similar event on this year's anniversary of the slaying. Olson said the moon will be about three-quarters full and low in the sky, although not in as extreme a southern declination as it was the last time the 18.6-year cycle came around, in early 1987. Olson said it took about six months of research and combing through libraries in five states to collect the data needed to re-create the sky. ``This is really fun to blend astronomy with something else,'' he said. ``We've made a small contribution to this episode. The books (on Lincoln) are a little bit confusing on this.'' He got the idea to investigate the ``almanac trial'' mystery when he saw a photograph last year of Norman Rockwell's painting of Lincoln in court. ``Being an astronomer this interested me,'' he said. ``I thought, what the heck is he doing with that almanac?''

DOC.HEAD: Peace Talks Sour As Fighting Picks Up In El Salvador
DOC.TEXT: A fourth round of talks to end El Salvador's bloody civil war has deadlocked with a new wave of leftist guerrilla attacks on government troops. Both sides said they were pessimistic about reaching any agreement before five days of talks were scheduled to wrap up today. The government rejects rebel demands to dismantle the army and punish officers for alleged human rights abuses during a 10-year-old war that has killed 73,000 people. ``Tomorrow, the meeting will end and there will be no agreement on the issue of the armed forces,'' rebel negotiator Salvador Samayoa told a news conference late Tuesday. Samayoa accused President Alfredo Cristiani's rightist government of failing ``to make any move whatever'' to get closer to the rebel position demanding that both the army and the guerrillas be dismantled. ``It could be said that we are stuck,'' Justice Minister Oscar Santamaria, who heads the U.S.-backed government's negotiating team, said even before Tuesday's session began. He criticized the rebels for the attacks Monday and Tuesday that killed 11 people and wounded 12. A San Salvador army barracks across the street from Cristiani's residence was among the targets. The State Department said rebel violence during the talks raised doubts about the rebels' willingness to negotiate. ``The guerrillas should immediately cease these attacks and negotiate seriously to end the war,'' said the department's deputy spokesman, Richard Boucher said Tuesday in Washington. Mediator Alvaro de Soto, a personal representative of U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, said it also was unlikely that agreement could be reached on a cease-fire Sept. 15, as originally planned. He said the negotiations will continue as scheduled every month, but added that ``given the dynamics of the ... process, it's impossible to arrive at a negotiated cease-fire agreement before Sept. 15.'' Representatives for the two sides had set the Sept. 15 deadline for a cease-fire at their first round of talks earlier this year, and both had expressed optimism this could be done when the round opened Friday. Cristiani has said the size of the army was open to discussion and talking about a purge of officers responsible for human rights abuses should come after a cease-fire. But he says abolishing the army was out of the question because it is unconstitutional. More than 73,000 people have been killed in the civil war, most of them civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Addresses Crowd of 100,000 on Invasion Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel, marking the first free commemoration of the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion, told 100,000 Czechoslovaks that they must finish toppling the ``burdensome heritage'' of Communist rule. The huge crowd on Tuesday overflowed Wenceslas Square in downtown Prague, the site of confrontations 22 years ago between Soviet tanks and weeping, angry Czechoslovaks who pelted them with rocks and garbage. The Aug. 21, 1968 military intervention crushed the Prague Spring reform movement that tried to introduce Communism with a human face. Havel, the dissident playwright catapulted to the presidency by November's peaceful democratic upheaval, cautioned the crowd that reform remains unfinished. ``It is the burdensome heritage of the totalitarian system that we haven't yet come to grips with,'' he said. ``In many communities huge bureaucratic monsters continue to rule.'' But Soviet tanks no longer back them, he said, adding: ``We will have only ourselves to blame if we allow them to overpower us. It is necessary for all the people to put their noses to the grindstone. We've lost 20 years, and we cannot afford to lose another single day.'' Havel's comments concentrated on the future, blasting what he called the Communist legacy: inefficiency, corruption and dilettantism that he said threatened Czechoslovakia's budding democracy. Tuesday's observances marked the first free commemoration of the invasion anniversary. Last year, before Czechoslovakia's hard-line Communist leaders were ousted, riot police waded into thousands of people who gathered in Wenceslas Square to remember the Soviet-led invasion and to demand reform. The official CTK news agency estimated the crowd filling Wenceslas Square on Tuesday at 100,000. It was believed to be the largest gathering there since November's revolution when hundreds of thousands of Czechoslovaks crowded the square repeatedly to press their demands for democratization. Those demonstrations culminated in the toppling of Communist rule and led to democratic elections in June in which Havel's Czech Civic Forum political movement and its Slovak counterpart, Public Against Violence, won a parliamentary majority. Alexander Dubcek, the reformist Communist Party leader who spearheaded the Prague Spring movement, also addressed the crowd. Dubcek, who emerged from years in oblivion to become speaker of the freely elected Parliament, was greeted with chants of ``Long Live Dubcek!'' as he spoke. Bulgaria's premier, Andrei Lukanov, told state TV: ``As a nation and as a party we must be ashamed of ourselves for taking part in the events in Czechoslovakia in 1968.'' The Soviet Union and Warsaw Pact allies who participated in the invasion now condemn it. Although a normal working day, much of Tuesday was given over to observing the invasion's 22nd anniversary. At daybreak, costumed members of the ``Jester Society'' student group swarmed through subway stations in a mock invasion of the city. Also Tuesday, Mayor Jaroslav Koran made seven Soviets honorary citizens of Prague. The seven were arrested after they staged a demonstration in Moscow protesting the invasion shortly after Warsaw Pact troops moved into Czechoslovakia. Koran also formally stripped the honorary citizenship of Soviet dictator Josef Stalin; Klement Gottwald, Czechoslovakia's first Communist president, and Gustav Husak, the Communist Party leader installed by Moscow after the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
NASA Loses Contact with Magellan Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES pvs urgent series, minor editing. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Engineers lost radio contact with the Magellan spacecraft Tuesday night for the second time in five days, NASA said. Scientists weren't immediately sure if the spacecraft's computer circuits would send out a radio beam in an attempt to re-establish communication with Earth, as the Venus-orbiting craft is supposed to do in an emergency, NASA said. Magellan's mission is to map up to 90 percent of Venus' surface using radar to peer through the planet's thick clouds, which prevent the use of optical cameras. The spacecraft went into orbit around Venus Aug. 10 after a roundabout, 948-million-mile trip. It was launched from the shuttle Atlantis 15 months ago. ``They lost it at 7:03 p.m. PDT'' while tracking the craft with a NASA antenna dish near Canberra, Australia, said Jim Doyle, spokesman for NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The mishap came only hours after NASA released the spacecraft's first pictures of Earth's closest planetary neighbor. They showed Venus has quake faults, lava flows like those in Hawaii and Idaho, and long, parallel valleys and ridges similar to those between the Sierra Nevada and the Rockies. The loss of Magellan, the centerpiece of a $744 million mission to explore Venus, would be a major blow to NASA, which grounded the shuttle fleet temporarily because of fuel leaks and found the Hubble Space Telescope had a flawed mirror. Doyle said that if the craft was beaming radio waves across the sky while spinning _ as it is supposed to do to in an emergency _ engineers could re-establish intermittent contact between 12:03 and 12:30 a.m. PDT Wednesday. Less than seven hours before contact broke off, project manager Tony Spear said that as far as engineers could tell, ``the spacecraft is healthy,'' despite a loss of contact for more than 14 hours starting last Thursday night. The spacecraft's automatic self-protection system made Magellan re-establish with NASA engineers last Friday morning. Then, they sent Magellan a command to make it stop spinning and stay in touch with Earth. Engineers said they still haven't figured out why they lost contact with Magellan last week. One leading theory is that a cosmic ray or a high-energy particle from the sun caused a blip in Magellan's computer memory, said spacecraft system engineer John Slonski. ``We're not ruling out a software flaw or some hardware problem'' or perhaps some unknown electrical fields surrounding Venus, Spear said. Cosmic ray ``hits'' on spacecraft electronics can be expected to interfere with Magellan about once each year, Spear said. Similar events occasionally have disrupted the Pioneer Venus Orbiter, launched in 1978, and the Tracking and Data Relay Satellites in Earth orbit, Slonski said. The pictures released Tuesday were taken during an Aug. 16 test when Magellan bounced its radar beam off Venus for the first time. As promised by NASA, the pictures are 10 times more detailed than the best radar images of Venus made by the Soviet Venera 15 and 16 spacecraft and by the radio telescope at Arecibo, Puerto Rico. They show details as small as 400 feet across, or a third bigger than the length of a football field. The large number of fractures and ``Venusquake'' faults seen in images from the spacecraft suggest the crustal movements that shaped the landscape are ``perhaps even more violent than I imagined before,'' said Steve Saunders, Magellan's chief scientist at Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``Overlapping lava flows of various ages'' and six to 10 miles wide appear as bright and dark splotches, he said. But Saunders said the pictures don't yet show any of Venus' major volcanoes, whether any of them are active or if the planet's crust is broken into the kind of drifting plates that carry whole continents across the face of the Earth. Previous spacecraft revealed numerous mountainous volcanoes. The lava flows are ``similar geologically to volcanic deposits seen on Earth at Hawaii and the Snake River Plains in Idaho,'' NASA said in a statement. The parallel sets of elongated valleys and ridges resemble those in the basin-and-range province of the intermountain region of Utah and Nevada, or at the Great Rift Valley in eastern Africa. They show that at least part of Venus' crust has been stretched apart, Saunders said.

DOC.HEAD: Nazi-Style Beer Hall To Get Facelift
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese brewer pressured by a petition drive says it will revamp a beer hall modeled after the stadium Hitler built to host the 1936 Olympics. Suntory Ltd. made the announcement Tuesday, four days after receiving a petition signed by more than 60 people objecting to the ``fascist motif'' of Malt's Stadium. The beer hall opened three months ago in the chic Aoyama district of Tokyo. It was modeled after the Berlin stadium that Adolf Hitler intended to be a showcase for what he considered German superiority during the 1936 summer games. Four imposing columns line the front of the restaurant. The entrance is flanked by two statues made of styrofoam, and the roof is decorated with a horse-drawn chariot. Statues of athletes dangle from the ceiling inside. There are no swastikas. Geraldine Harcourt, a translator from New Zealand, and American free-lance writer Leza Lowitz organized the petition, which received support from Japanese as well as foreigners. It demanded the immediate removal of decor that ``symbolizes the era of Nazism which brought about the death of over 6 million people.'' ``Suntory is very insensitive to use an image of the Berlin Olympics, which was the showcase of Hitler,'' Ms. Harcourt said. ``There are other possible designs (Suntory) could have copied.'' Ms. Harcourt had earlier complained about the restaurant's showing of a documentary on the 1936 Olympics that included shots of Hitler. Suntory stopped showing the film. Suntory clearly was taken aback by the criticism. ``We had never thought about the connection between the Berlin Olympics and the Nazis,'' said company spokesman Masashide Kanzaki. Hiroko Uchimi, a spokeswoman for the public relations firm representing the bar, said the ``idea was to introduce architecture with a masculine image, and to emphasize it with a sense of aggressiveness in sports.'' Sports is the theme of the restaurant. ``We never had any complaints from other customers here,'' she said. Suntory officials met with the two petitioners and agreed to change the exterior to remove the offending design, Kanzaki said. He said the company would publicly ``admit that we were ignorant of such historic issues and that we offended people.'' Ms. Harcourt said she was pleased by Suntory's response. The restaurant was packed Monday night and it appeared most of the customers were oblivious to the controversy. Haruhiko Sato, a 44-year-old interior designer drinking beer with a colleague, said he did not connect the entrance with Nazi Germany. ``We don't know much about Nazi history, but it has very little to do with us Japanese, especially today when we enjoy peace,'' he said. Takashi Saito, a professor of international politics at Tokyo's Gakushuin University who specializes in Nazi history, said Japanese generally are less sensitive about the horrors of Nazism than Westerners. ``The younger generation especially tends to be oblivious of the issue,'' he said. Japan is not the only Asian nation where the commercial use of Nazi imagery has stirred controversy. In May 1988, a ``Nazi Bar'' featuring caricatures of Hitler and photos of storm troopers opened in Bangkok, Thailand. Waiters wore swastika-emblazoned arm bands. The owner said he picked the Nazi theme because of its ``powerful, catchy and emotive appeal,'' but complaints prompted the bar to change its name after about a month. The decor also was changed. Nazi symbols also have been a hit in Japan. A Tokyo fad a few years ago was collecting items bearing the swastika and other Nazi symbols.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Challenges NRC Decision on Low-level Waste
DOC.TEXT: More than two dozen groups are challenging in court a Nuclear Regulatory Commission decision to ease controls on the disposal of low-level nuclear wastes. The lawsuit, filed in the U.S. Court of Appeals here Tuesday, says the new policy means unhealthy levels of radiation could be left in the soil and buildings at closed nuclear power plants and that radioactive contamination could drift into the ground water at garbage dumps. It also alleges the NRC did not provide for adequate public participation before issuing the new policy in June. ``The NRC's rule trades off people's lives in favor of the financial interests of the nuclear industry,'' said Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen, one of the groups that filed the lawsuit. The NRC said it would, on a case-by-case basis, deregulate the disposal of certain low-level atomic wastes from nuclear power plants, hospitals, laboratories and other facilities if the radioactive emissions are considered ``below regulatory concern.'' Other groups joining the lawsuit were the U.S. Public Interest Research Group, the Natural Resources Defense Council, the Nuclear Information and Resource Service and Physicians for Social Responsibility.
DOC.HEAD: Asian Organized Crime Groups Gaining Strength, Senator Warns
DOC.TEXT: Asian organized crime groups are spreading into this country soon could be bigger than the Cosa Nostra in its heyday, says Sen. Joseph R. Biden. ``Asian Triads will be the dominant organized crime force in this country by the middle of this decade,'' the Delaware Democrat said Tuesday. He said Triads _ highly secretive criminal societies born in China centuries ago _ could have 9,000 members in the United States in 10 years. That is double the Justice Department estimate of Cosa Nostra strength at its peak in the 1960s. FBI officials confirmed the problem is growing. ``It's coming at us and its coming at us real quick and we better be ready,'' said Robert M. Bryant, deputy assistant director in the FBI's criminal investigative division. Biden and Bryant both stressed that criminals represent only a tiny sliver of the Asian-American community. ``Most Asian-Americans are hard-working, law-abiding, patriotic citizens,'' Bryant said. Their comments came at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing. Biden is chairman of the committee.
DOC.HEAD: Report Shows Sharp Rise in Food Stamp Recipients
DOC.TEXT: A government report showing a sharp rise in the number of food stamp recipients demonstrates there are more poor people in the United States than many wish to admit, says Rep. Tony Hall, D-Ohio. ``It shows you to a certain extent the sleeping giant that is out there,'' Hall said Tuesday in a statement released in response to published reports of an Agriculture Department study on food stamps. He said the findings in the report demonstrate how even a slight downturn in the economy can be too much for some people, throwing them onto public assistance rolls. The report, a summary of which was furnished by the Agriculture Department on Tuesday, said the number of people using food stamps rose by more than 1 million between the second quarter of fiscal 1989 and the second quarter of this fiscal year. The rise extended to 44 states and the District of Columbia, varying in size and timing from state to state. Nearly half the total increase was attributable to a rise in recipients in Texas, California and Florida, the report said. The House earlier this month approved a farm bill that would expand access to the food assistance program. The House approved $18.1 billion for fiscal 1991. The Senate has yet to act. The Agriculture Department study was undertaken at the request of the Senate Appropriations Committee, which was concerned about the recent rise in recipients. The Bush administration, anticipating 18.1 million food stamp recipients this year, requested $13.3 billion for fiscal 1990. Congress approved $14.8 billion and later provided an additional $1.2 billion when the initial amount proved to be too low.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: ``Cosby Show'' actress Lisa Bonet wants a judge to order the National Enquirer to hand over a negative of her baby daughter. She alleges the negative showing her then month-old daughter, Zoe Kravitz, was stolen by a drug store clerk from the Reseda, Calif., pharmacy that developed her photographs. Her lawyers asked in papers filed in federal court Monday that ``the seedier elements of the paparazzi'' produce the negative. She has sued the American Drug Stores Inc. chain for unspecified compensatory damages and $5 million in punitive damages. Her lawyers say the negative will prove a clerk stole it to sell to the National Enquirer. She alleges a missing photo from the roll appeared in the supermarket tabloid on Jan. 10, 1989. American Drug Stores denies the allegations, said spokesman Carl Haupt. Attorneys for the magazine refused to comment.

Caesars Palace said it will present evidence that Rodney Dangerfield has ``severe problems with cocaine, marijuana and alcohol abuse'' if the comedian's lawsuit against the resort goes to trial. Dangerfield's attorney, Barry Langberg, called the allegations ``a joke.'' The 64-year-old comedian is seeking $225,000 in damages from Caesars. He claimed he suffered severe eye damage when he was scalded by a burst of steam when entering a steam room behind the hotel's showroom in 1988. The resort has filed a breach-of-contract countersuit against its former headliner for $100,000 plus punitive damages. In court papers filed Monday, the resort instead blamed Dangerfield's lifestyle and his use of a certain type of eyedrops for his eye problems. The document said a witness will testify that at a party after the alleged incident, Dangerfield was ``so intoxicated from drugs and alcohol that he literally passed out face first in a plate of food.'' Dangerfield claimed he had to cancel five performances at Caesars because of the injury, at $45,000 per show. The trial opens Monday in federal court.

An attorney for New Kids on the Block claimed USA Today and the tabloid Star magazine infringed on the pop group's copyright by setting up for-profit telephone lines about the band. Attorney Jim Warren said at a hearing Monday in federal court that the publications' use of 900 numbers to gauge the group's popularity is a way of making money and is thus covered by trademark laws. But lawyers for the Star and USA Today said the 900 lines, for which callers pay a fee, were used for news-gathering and were protected by the First Amendment. ``We're in the business of reporting that information,'' said Charles Diamond, a lawyer for Gannett Satellite Information Network Inc., which publishes USA Today. The judge did not immediately issue a ruling.

Imelda Marcos plans to return to Honolulu next month to mark her late husband's birthday with a graveside Mass. The former Philippines first lady is expected to arrive on Sept. 2, and hold a Mass on Sept. 9 at a cemetery outside Honolulu where Ferdinand Marcos is buried, her attorney, James Linn, said Tuesday. Mrs. Marcos has spent the past six months in New York, where she stood trial in federal court on fraud and racketeering charges. A jury acquitted her. Marcos died in exile Sept. 28 in Honolulu.

Film director Roman Polanski, a fugitive since 1977 for having sex with a 13-year-old girl, can send a lawyer to defend himself against a lawsuit filed by the victim, a state appeals court ruled. In a 2-1 ruling Monday, the court said Polanski did not forfeit the right to defend himself by his ``reprehensible, irresponsible and unlawful absence.'' A lawyer for the woman said the ruling will be appealed to the state Supreme Court. Polanski pleaded guilty in 1977 to unlawful sexual intercourse with a minor at the home of actor Jack Nicholson. He fled before being sentenced and now lives in Paris. The unidentified victim sued in 1988 for damages for physical and emotional distress. The woman asked for a default ruling against Polanski _ that is, a ruling declaring him the loser. She argued that a fugitive should not be allowed to use the courts to defend himself. Superior Court Judge George Dell refused to find Polanski in default, and the appeals court agreed.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall Sharply, Dollar Rises in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Concern over prospects in the Middle East and overnight declines on overseas stock markets sent share prices in Tokyo falling sharply Wednesday, traders said. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 1,086.93 points, or 4.13 percent, to close at 25,210.91. The index shed 192.63 points on Tuesday. The dollar closed at 146.92 yen, up 0.37 yen from Tuesday's close. After opening at 146.57 yen, the currency ranged between 146.50 yen and 146.95 yen. In bond dealings, the No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond was quoted at 83.03 points as of 3 p.m. (2 a.m. EDT), down from Tuesday's close of 83.22. The yield stood at 8.105 percent, up from 8.06 percent. Traders attributed the Nikkei's drop to declines on Wall Street and major European markets stemming from gloomy prospects for stability in the Persian Gulf crisis, declining domestic bond prices and rising oil prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 52.48 points to 2,063.96 amid concern about the Middle East. ``How the situation between Iraq and the United States will develop is everyone's concern, and there is hardly any reason to buy issues,'' said Makoto Suzuki, an analyst with Nomura Securities. North Sea Brent crude oil for October delivery was valued at $27.63 a barrel in Tokyo, up slightly from Tuesday's $27.38. Currency dealers said the dollar remained in a narrow range, carried over from overnight trading in New York, where the currency closed at 146.80 yen, up from 146.51 yen. Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co., said the Tokyo foreign exchange market's reaction to conditions in the Middle East has diminished mainly because the crisis had been factored into the market as a chronic problem. In times of international turmoil, the dollar usually is regarded as a safe-haven, although economic trouble in the United States has dimmed its attractiveness in recent trading.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Boys are Just as Likely as Girls to Have Reading Problems
DOC.TEXT: Boys are just as likely as girls to have reading disabilities but are more likely to be diagnosed by teachers as having the handicap because of their rambunctiousness, says a study published today. ``The very commonly held notion that there are more reading disabled boys than girls is really not an accurate one,'' said Dr. Sally E. Shaywitz, an associate professor of pediatrics at the Yale School of Medicine. More boys than girls wind up in special education classes, apparently because of the long-held and mistaken belief that overactivity and other behavior problems go hand in hand with the learning problem, the study said. The result has been that some boys _ who typically are more rambuctious than girls _ are wrongly being labeled reading disabled, Shaywitz said. At the same time, some girls _ and some boys _ are not receiving the help they need because they show no behavior problems, Shaywitz said. Shaywitz and her fellow researchers followed more than 400 children from 12 towns in Connecticut from kindergarten through the third grade. The findings were reported in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. Tests showed that roughly the same number of boys as girls had a reading disability, but two to four times as many boys were placed in special reading classes. Dr. James Kavanagh, deputy director for The Center for Research For Mothers and Children, in Bethesda, Md., welcomed the study but said more work is needed. ``It's done carefully, and it makes good sense,'' he said. ``Our conventional wisdom has always said that boys have more of these problems.'' About 2 million children in the United States are designated as learning disabled. Most are found to have a reading disability, defined as a reading problem that can't be explained by a student's intellectual ability, she said. Students with dyslexia, for example, often reverse their letters or have trouble with their memory or visual perception that makes reading difficult. Children with dyslexia can be taught to read when their disorder is recognized. The study found a possible explanation for the mislabeling in the way teachers view the behavior of boys and girls. Children who were identified by their schools as reading disabled but who did not meet the researchers' criteria were significantly more likely to show behavior problems. Conversely, children who needed special reading help but were well behaved tended to be overlooked by the system, the study found. The schools identified 27 of 198 second-grade boys and seven of 216 second-grade girls as reading disabled. By the third grade, 20 of 199 boys were labeled reading disabled by their schools, compared to nine of 215 girls. Meanwhile, the researchers found 13, or 45 percent, of the third-graders receiving special education didn't have a reading disability after all. ``By putting the wrong labels on the wrong individuals people are not getting quite the right services they need,'' Shaywitz said. Shaywitz said her study shows that doctors should not rely soley on schools to identify children with learning disabilities.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Invasion Maroons Kuwaitis In Europe
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Sharply dressed Kuwaiti protesters have protested Saddam Hussein's invasion of their oil-rich homeland, while their embassies across Europe are busy helping financially strapped countrymen wait out the crisis. ``Saddam, Saddam, you are Hitler!'' about 200 demonstrators chanted Tuesday outside the Kuwaiti Embassy at yet another morale-boosting rally against the Iraqi president. Most of the demonstrators were women, some dressed in Dior or St. Laurent, others in traditional Arab robes. Most of the men, they say, have gone to join the Kuwaiti resistance. Other European habitats of the rich also have been scenes of such demonstrations. Rolls-Royces bring their owners to anti-Iraq demonstrations in Geneva. Kuwaitis march in beachwear along the chic Promenade des Anglais in Nice in southern France. When Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, about 20,000 Kuwaitis were estimated in London, away from the Persian Gulf's searing heat. Kuwaiti embassies and consular offices are helping with the expenses of those left behind and providing any news of relatives. The embassy in London arranges for those without housing to return to Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates and other Gulf Cooperation Council states, which have offered their oil wealth to assist Kuwaitis. Kuwaiti honorary consul Boerge Hansen and Kuwaiti Airlines in Copenhagen had offered to pay hotel bills and arrange air tickets for those stranded in Denmark. In Rome, the Kuwaiti Embassy said it was paying rent and long-distance telephone bills for some of its citizens. The embassy in Bern, Switzerland, set up a fund for needy Kuwaitis, but found no takers. ``Almost all who are here are well-to-do,'' said Abdel Aziz Abouzeid, spokesman at Kuwait's U.N. mission in Geneva. ``Nearly all have Swiss accounts. They have money, so they are staying.'' However, five-star hoteliers on Lake Geneva and in Cairo say there are markedly fewer free-spending guests from Kuwait. ``We came here on holiday to go to the theater, the cinema and for the shopping,'' said a 21-year-old university student outside the embassy in London. ``Kuwaitis love shopping, but it has all been canceled,'' said the student, who said he feared reprisals against his family and identified himself only as Mohammed. News reports of a suicide car bombing that killed Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait City boosted exiles' morale, said Khaled Al-Hajen, 31, another demonstrator. ``The resistance is strong, but they do not have efficient guns. Some are using hunting guns,'' he said. The largest number of stranded Kuwaitis are in the gulf countries, where many young men say they are eager to join the resistance. ``We will fight, win or die,'' said Bandar al-Shallahi of the Kuwait News Agency in Bahrain. ``It's pointless to live without a country.''

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Votes To Remove Red Star and Other Communist Symbols
DOC.TEXT: Parliament has voted to remove the red star and other Communist symbols from buildings and the national flag after a protester threatened to set himself on fire if the decision were not taken. The state BTA news agency said Parliament adopted a decision Tuesday to remove ``all insignia of foreign countries.'' The red star and the hammer and sickle were adopted from the Soviet model by Communist leaderships in Bulgaria and other Eastern European countries. On Monday the governing Socialist Party, the former Communist Party, said it would remove the red star from the party headquarters building in downtown Sofia. Despite the decisions, an unspecified number of anti-Communist protesters surrounded the Socialist Party headquarters, chanting ``Down with the BCP!'' the abreviation of the Bulgarian Communist Party, BTA said. The Communist Party renamed itself the Socialist Party earlier this year. It won the majority in multiparty elections in June. Petar Dertliev, the popular leader of the opposition Social Democratic Party, assured the crowd that the symbols would be removed and that ousted long-time Communist leaders and other former functionaries would be held responsible for wrongdoings during the four decades of Communist rule. Plamen Stanchev, a 20-year-old worker, had threatened Monday to set himself on fire if the red star were not removed from the Socialist Party headquarters. BTA did not say when the symbols would be removed. But the Socialist Party said Monday the red star, which is perched on a pinnacle on top of the party headquarters shining over the city center, would be dismantled Friday or Saturday. The white, green and red Bulgarian flag has a red star above the coat-of-arms. BTA said the star would be removed from the flag as well.

DOC.HEAD: Death Row Inmate's Sentence Commuted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `The board ...' to DELETE missing first reference to victim.
DOC.TEXT: Georgia's parole board says it commuted a killer's sentence to life in prison one day before he was to be executed because he never was tried by a jury and because relatives of the victim had pleaded for mercy. William Neal Moore, 39, received the commuted sentence Tuesday hours after he had won a 30-day stay of execution from the U.S. Supreme Court. Moore, who had been scheduled to die today in the electric chair, will be eligible for parole in nine years _ after he has served 25 years. The board's unanimous decision stemmed largely from the fact that no jury ever weighed Moore's fate, said board chairman Wayne Snow Jr. But he said, ``We're not suggesting there would be any difference in what the jury would decide.'' Moore had pleaded guilty to murder in 1974. But a judge sentenced him to die anyway, a decision that would have rested with a jury had Moore gone to trial. The board also received messages on Moore's behalf from Mother Teresa and Jesse Jackson. Several nieces and cousins of the victim appeared at Tuesday's board meeting, testifying on behalf of the born-again Christian. A family spokesman said relatives of the victim were ``very positive'' and forgiving of Moore. ``To say the least, the board was much impressed by the fact that we did have family of the victim who asked for clemency. That's not something we often see,'' said Snow. He also said the board was impressed by Moore's good prison record but wasn't moved by his jailhouse conversion _ ``We hear that all the time.'' It was the third time the board has commuted the death sentence of a Georgia death-row inmate since capital punishment was reinstated in 1976. The other cases involved conspirators who had been sentenced to death when the actual killer got life in prison. Moore was convicted of killing Fredger Stapleton, 74, in 1974. A friend had told Moore, a depressed 23-year-old soldier from Fort Gordon, that Stapleton kept $20,000 in his home, according to testimony. Moore got drunk and Stapleton fired at him when he entered the home. Moore shot back, killing the man. The Columbus, Ohio, native said he joined the Army as a teen-ager, compiled a spotless record and was weighing a military career when his wife, his childhood sweetheart, soured on military life and left him, taking their 2-year-old son.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Preventing some foreigners from traveling is not an act of vengeance, but a force ... to deter a crime of aggression President Bush intends to commit against the people of Iraq.'' _ Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, on the foreigners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait by the Persian Gulf crisis.

``I think it will have an overall effect of them being put further and further down in the agendas. As far as I know, the American government is doing nothing.'' _ Former hostage Frank Reed, on the plight of his 14 Western comrades in Lebanon since the new Iraqi hostage crisis.

``It is the burdensome heritage of the totalitarian system that we haven't yet come to grips with. In many communities huge bureaucratic monsters continue to rule.'' _ President Vaclav Havel, cautioning 100,000 Czechoslovaks marking the first commemoration of the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion that reform remains unfinished.

DOC.HEAD: Senior Leader Deng Turns 86
DOC.TEXT: China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, turned 86 today, but there was no public observance of his birthday in the capital. Deng, who is reported to suffer from cancer, has retired from all his Communist Party and government posts but still has final say over policy and important decisions. Deng's last public appearance was July 3, when he toured the Asian Games village and visited Beijing's tallest skyscraper. Reports said he walked unaided up the 28 steps to a platform on a track and field course and declined a seat during the elevator ride up the skyscraper. He is believed to be vacationing at Beidaihe, the seaside resort to which he and other leaders retire every August. Last year, newspapers marked Deng's birthday by trumpeting the publication of a new collection of his speeches. That announcement followed months of publicity that seemed to signal an emerging personality cult after the June 1989 crackdown on pro-democracy protesters.

DOC.HEAD: Mackintosh: No `Miss Saigon' Without Casting Freedom
DOC.TEXT: An actors' union decision to let a white man play a Eurasian pimp in ``Miss Saigon'' wasn't enough for its producer, who says the hit London musical won't see Broadway unless he's free to cast other roles. Cameron Mackintosh's decision could cost him $600,000 already spent and $25 million in advance ticket sales, but he said Tuesday the principle comes first. ``I cannot in good conscience reschedule the production in the absence of a positive working environment and an understanding ... that artistic freedom of choice cannot be compromised,'' Mackintosh said in a statement. Mackintosh said he was willing to work out differences with the union, Actors' Equity, and had sent a letter spelling out his worries. Equity had no comment on Mackintosh's decision. The union Aug. 7 had barred Jonathan Pryce from re-creating his award-winning role when the show comes to Broadway in March. Mackintosh then canceled the show. Under pressure from its members, the union reversed itself Thursday. A rapproachment could bring ``Miss Saigon'' to Broadway in April. The show stands to become the most expensive Broadway production ever. The show has a cast of 50, including 34 roles for minorities. The Pryce role is the only one in the cast that has been announced. The musical is a love story about an American soldier in Vietnam during the final days of the war in 1975. Equity, representing 37,500 members, initially said it couldn't ``appear to condone the casting of a Caucasian in the role of a Eurasian.'' Mackintosh said Equity's reversal last week was insufficient evidence that the union had a change of heart. In explaining its reversal, the union said Pryce could come to Broadway because he was a ``star.'' Actors' Equity has veto power over foreign actors in the United States but usually does not interfere with those deemed ``stars.'' ``Their decision was made solely on the technical basis of Mr. Pryce's acknowledged star status,'' Mackintosh said. ``As I have repeatedly stated, it is also essential that the profoundly unpleasant atmosphere currently surrounding the production be dispelled.'' Pryce won a 1977 Tony for his work in ``Comedians'' and won the Olivier Award, the London equivalent of the Tony, for his portrayal of the brothel owner in ``Miss Saigon.'' Asian-American groups had urged Equity to stand firm against Pryce, citing the dearth of good roles for minority actors.

DOC.HEAD: Slum Dwellers Hurl Stones, Demand President Resign
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Hundreds of demonstrators shouting ``Down with Poverty!'' marched through the slums and some shattered car windows, demanding that President Ertha-Pascal Trouillot resign. Police dispersed the 300 demonstrators after about two hours and arrested three protesters, radio Haiti-Inter reported. Demonstrators shattered the windows of several cars parked outside the Legislative Palace, where the Council of State, which governs alongside the president, was meeting. Several demonstrators interviewed by the radio said the protest was organized by slum neighborhood committees. But they said the march was infiltrated by supporters of ousted dictator Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier, who was ousted in 1986. The president of the Council of State, Louis Roy, said anonymous callers had telephoned the Legislative Palace and threatened several council members with death. About 50 people unfurled the red-and-black Duvalierist flag in front of the Legislative Palace and several motorists followed the marchers giving protesters free bottles of rum. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, a former Supreme Court justice, was appointed president in March to head a civilian caretaker government after military leader Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril was deposed following mass protests. She is to govern until elections are held, which are tentatively scheduled for Nov. 4. But unhappiness over recent political murders and the return of several figures associated with the repressive Duvalier family regime that ruled Haiti for 29 years has cast doubts that free and fair elections can be held. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot has come under increasing pressure to resign from several political groups and some members of the Council of State, a quasi-legislative body that shares power with her caretaker government.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down Sharply, Dollar Up in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange tumbled sharply today in the ninth-largest daily plunge, nudging the dollar up against the yen in Tokyo. Traders said concern over prospects in the Middle East, overnight declines on overseas stock markets, slumping domestic bond market and rising interest rates all contributed to the slide. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 1,086.93 points, or 4.13 percent, to close at 25,210.91. It was the ninth-largest loss ever recorded by the index, which had shed 192.63 points Tuesday. Today's close was the lowest since Feb. 26, 1988, when the index closed at 25,165.18 points. A total of 360 million shares changed hands on the first section, up from Tuesday's 280 million shares. ``There were almost no buyers because of a wait-and-see mood prevailing in the market,'' said Kyuhei Sato, an equity analyst with Yamaichi Securities. ``Worries among investors over the stock market's future trend strengthened because of uncertainties over stability in the Middle East,'' he said. Following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, a multinational force led by U.S. troops has been pouring into the Middle East to stop further aggression. Sato said the market already has factored in the ``current stalemate'' between Iraq and the United States, but investors are worried about a deterioration of the sitution that an exchange of fire could bring. In the currency market, the dollar closed at 146.92 yen, up 0.37 yen from Tuesday's close. It opened at 146.57 and ranged between 146.50 and 146.95. ``Affected by the stock market's plunge, the dollar-yen trading was rather mixed today,'' said Yuichi Tsuchiko, a dealer with Fuji Bank. On the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 110 10-year Japanese government bond closed at 82.63 points, down from Tuesday's close of 83.22. The yield stood at 8.200 percent, up from 8.060 percent. Meanwhile, Persian Gulf oil prices moved slightly higher. Dubai Fateh crude for October delivery was valued at about $26.55-$26.65 a barrel, higher than the $25.90 late Tuesday in New York. The price for October delivery of North Sea Brent was $27.75 a barrel, up from the $27.75 quoted late Tuesday in New York.

DOC.HEAD: `60 Minutes' No. 1 For the First Time in Two Years
With PM-Nielsens-List
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: For the first time in two years, ``60 Minutes'' was the most-watched show on TV, its ratings apparently boosted by the Persian Gulf crisis. A week earlier, interest in the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait prompted more viewers to watch the network news than prime-time programs. The latest ratings released Tuesday by the A.C. Nielsen Co. showed entertainment shows back on top with an average rating of 27.8, compared with 27 for evening news shows. Each ratings point represents 921,000 households. CBS' ``60 Minutes,'' ordinarily one of the top 20 shows and often one of the top 10, was No. 1 with a rating of 15.8 on Sunday after giving coverage to the Gulf crisis. ``Cheers'' on NBC and ``Roseanne'' on ABC tied for second at 15.1. In the overall network ratings, NBC was No. 1 for the 14th consecutive week, with an average of 9.7. CBS busted out of its usual last-place standing to become the No. 2 network with a 9.2 average. ABC had an 8.9. In entertainment, Fox Broadcasting's ``The Simpsons'' and ``Married ... With Children'' were back in the top 10, landing in the No. 4 and No. 8 spots, respectively. The first of Maria Shriver's occasional specials for NBC tied with the powerhouse ``Cosby Show'' for 12th. The slickly produced installment of ``Cutting Edge with Maria Shriver'' contained interviews with football player Lyle Alzado, pop singer Sinead O'Connor and ``Cheers'' star Kirstie Alley. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 15.8; ``Cheers,'' NBC, and ``Roseanne,'' ABC, (tie) 15.1; ``The Simpsons,'' Fox, 13.7; ``Designing Women,'' CBS, 13.6; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 13.4; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 13; ``Coach,'' ABC, and ``Married ... With Children,'' Fox, (tie) 12.8; ``Murphy Brown,'' CBS, and ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC, (tie) 12.6.

DOC.HEAD: Mob Turncoat Nets 41 in Mob Crackdown
DOC.TEXT: A mob informant whose recordings led to charges against 41 people wore a ``wire'' to his own initiation into the Mafia, during which he took a blood oath to ``burn in hell if I betray my friends.'' State police Tuesday arrested 29 people, including John Riggi, reputed boss of the DeCavalcante crime family, and the son of jailed Philadelphia-New Jersey mob boss Nicodemo ``Little Nicky'' Scarfo. More arrests were expected today. The arrests _ on charges including racketeering, gambling, bribery and drug trafficking _ were based on information provided by George Fresolone, an informant in the Scarfo organization who is now in hiding, authorities said. During the year-long investigation of the Scarfo, Gambino, Colombo, Luchese, Genovese and DeCavalcante Mafia families, he recorded more than 400 conversations through this summer, when he was initiated into the Scarfo mob. It is only the second time in history that the secret initiation rite has ever been recorded, officials said. During the ceremony in the Bronx, Fresolone's trigger finger was pricked to draw blood, authorities said. The five initiates then recited an oath _ ``May I burn in hell if I betray my friends in the family'' _ while rubbing out a piece of paper set on fire in their palms. A gun and a knife present at the ceremony signified that members ``live by the gun and die by the gun, live by the knife and die by the knife,'' authorities said. The recordings detail how the Mafia families cooperated in setting up illegal activities and shared profits from bookmaking, loansharking, illegal video machines, drug distribution, municipal corruption, union control and violence, said Col. Justin Dintino, spokesman for the state police. Although Scarfo is serving a 69-year federal sentence in Illinois, authorities said their investigation showed he was channeling messages to his organization through his son, Nicodemo Scarfo Jr., 25, during prison visits. The younger Scarfo's arrest will likely deal the elder Scarfo a devastating blow, Dintino said. Scarfo's son was ``someone that he completely trusts'' and whom he had envisioned as the future boss of the crime family, Dintino said.

DOC.HEAD: Washers Didn't Hobble Hubble, NASA Says
DOC.TEXT: NASA says it has ruled out the possibility that household washers in a measuring device caused the Hubble Space Telescope's focusing flaw. ``Just when we thought we knew, we're back to square one,'' said Charles Pellerin, NASA director of astrophysics. ``It's frustrating.'' NASA investigators had suggested last week that improperly installed washers 1.3 millimeters thick might have caused the 1.3-millimeter flaw in the mirror, which is producing blurred images from the orbiting telescope. But Pellerin said Tuesday the investigators had only estimated the thickness of the washers last week. When the washers were measured, they turned out to be much thinner _ too thin to have caused the mirror flaw, he said. Now, he said it's increasingly possible that the cause of the mirror flaw was a mathematical error made in transposing the design of the measuring device, known as a reflective null corrector, from the drawing board to the assembly room. The $1.5 billion telescope was supposed to provide unprecedented views of outer space. Its 94-inch primary mirror was made from 1979 to 1982 by the Perkin-Elmer Corp., whose optical division in Danbury was bought last year by Hughes Danbury Optical Systems. The NASA team visited Hughes twice to review data and test results. Last Thursday, the investigators said there was an estimated 1.3 millimeter error between the mirror and the field lens of the reflective null corrector, which guides the grinding and polishing of a mirror. The board's strongest hypothesis was that three washers had mistakenly been inserted into a plate that held a lens in place in the null corrector. They weren't certain, though, that the washers were to blame at all. Charles Spoelhof, a member of the investigative team, said the board only estimated the washers' thickness because they were still mounted inside the reflective null corrector and weren't accessible. When the washers were measured a few days ago at Hughes, they were found to be just .75 millimeters thick _ by precision optical standards, a huge spacing difference from the estimated 1.3-millimeter thickness, Pellerin said.

DOC.HEAD: Storms Sweep South, Rain Drenches East
DOC.TEXT: A thunderstorm rumbled through Alabama today and rain drenched parts of the East and Northeast. Today's forecast called for storms along the Gulf Coast from Louisiana to Florida, rain from New Jersey down to the Carolinas and west to Ohio, Kentucky, Tennessee and Alabama, and showers over Washington, Idaho, Montana and Wyoming. Storms swept through the Carolinas and parts of Georgia, Tennessee and Kentucky and South Dakota on Tuesday night. A tornado touched down near Bushnell, Neb., on Tuesday, but there were no reports of injuries or major damage. Thunderstorm gusts reaching 75 mph damaged trees and power lines near Wrens, Ga. Large hail fell in the Carolinas, Alabama, Georgia, Arkansas and Tennessee. Rain was scattered over broad areas of the nation, from New York to Illinois, throughout the South, the Southwest, the Plains and the Pacific Northwest. Rain brought flooding to parts of Washington, Indiana and Illinois. More than 7 inches of rain have fallen already in the Chicago area this month, double the average for all of August, the National Weather Service said. Heavy rain flooded roads and homes in the city's western suburbs Tuesday. Daytona Beach, Fla., tied a record temperature of 94 degrees set for the date in 1988. Unseasonably high temperatures continued Tuesday over portions of the southern Plains and the Tennessee Valley. The high temperature for the nation Tuesday was 105 degrees at Lake Havasu City and Yuma, Ariz., and in Waco, Texas.
