Marie 53 fair; San Antonio 82 fair. _West: Albuquerque 69 fair; Anchorage 55 partly cloudy; Boise 63 cloudy; Casper 64 fair; Fairbanks 54 partly cloudy; Great Falls 58 fair; Honolulu 79 fair; Las Vegas 83 fair; Los Angeles 67 fair; Medford 67 partly cloudy; Pendleton 65 cloudy; Phoenix 88 fair; Portland, Ore. 65 cloudy; Reno 62 fair; Salt Lake City 60 fair; San Diego 68 fair; San Francisco 59 fair; Seattle 63 cloudy; Spokane 57 partly cloudy. _International: Calgary 57 fair; Montreal 59 fair; Ottawa 55 fair; Regina 66 partly cloudy; Toronto 64 partly cloudy; Winnipeg 66 fair; San Juan 79 partly cloudy.

DOC.HEAD: Felon Holds Up Judicial Appointment
DOC.TEXT: A felon serving on a once-obscure state board is holding up confirmation of a judicial nominee who once worked for the judge who sent him to prison for assault in 1971. Diane Kottmyer, a federal prosecutor nominated to the state Superior Court by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis five months ago, was a law student when Joseph ``Jo Jo'' Langone III was given a six-month sentence. She did not clerk for U.S. District Judge Andrew Caffrey until 1974 and had no involvement in the case. But Langone, for unexplained reasons, holds a grudge against her. ``I want to bury her,'' the 73-year-old undertaker said. ``It's a free funeral. She would go first class, with the motorcycle cops and everything.'' His opposition to Kottmyer, 44, who gained a reputation prosecuting mobsters and corrupt Boston police officers, has put the eight-member Massachusetts Governor's Council on the political map. The council, which is elected every four years, is a holdover from colonial days, originally intended to check the power of the royal governor. Today, it approves all state expenditures and confirms judicial appointees. Nearly all its actions are routine. Because Kottmyer lives in Langone's district outside Boston, Langone must nominate her before the council can decide whether to approve her for the judgeship. He has so far refused to do so. Langone, a member of the council since 1977, initially suspected Kottmyer had played a role in recommending that he be sent to prison for assaulting a drug investigator who had parked his car outside Langone's funeral parlor. The investigator had not been keeping surveillance on Langone. Though he later learned from news reports that Kottmyer had nothing to do with his conviction, Langone has still pledged to stop her nomination. Kottmyer has refused to comment. Kottmyer helped prosecute reputed Mafia figure Ilario Zannino, and Langone recently sent a letter to a judge asking that Zannino's 30-year prison sentence be reduced. But he denied his interest in the Zannino case had anything to do with his opposition to Kottmyer. Judicial officials have called on Langone to remove himself from the nomination process. Former U.S. Attorney William Weld, a gubernatorial candidate, has called for the council's abolition. ``Only in Massachusetts would a convicted felon be able to pass judgment on the qualifications of a person nominated to the bench,'' he said. Caffrey, who sentenced Langone in 1971, said Langone harbored ``a clearly articulated bias'' against Kottmyer and should step aside from the nominating process. Council members, who need only be a state resident for five years to be eligible, are up for re-election this year. Langone, a Democrat, will meet two challengers in the Sept. 18 primary; the general election is on Nov. 6. State law does not prohibit people convicted of a crime from holding public office unless they engaged in corruption to gain the job. Langone's district includes the predominantly Italian-American neighborhoods of East Boston and affluent suburbs such as Lexington and Reading.

DOC.HEAD: Siberian Prisoners Charged In Hijacking
DOC.TEXT: Pakistan today charged 11 Siberian labor camp prisoners with hijacking a Soviet jetliner and forcing it to land in the southern port city of Karachi, according to news reports today. The prisoners sought political asylum from Pakistan after the Aeroflot Tupolev 154 jetliner, with 20 passengers and nine crew members on board, landed Monday. A hijacking conviction carries the death penalty or life imprisonment. The 11 have also been charged with illegal possession of firearms, said the independent Dawn daily newspaper, published in Karachi. Four machine guns, three pistols and several rounds of ammunition were reportedly confiscated from the prisoners, the newspaper said. Pakistan has in the past refused to extradite hijackers, preferring to try them. Palestinian guerrillas involved in a 1986 Pan Am hijacking in Karachi were tried in Pakistan and sentenced to death. The sentence has not yet been carried out. The Soviet prisoners hijacked the jetliner Sunday after overpowering their guards at Neryungry, 3,100 miles east of Moscow. They were being transfered to a prison in the nearby city of Yakutsk in Eastern Siberia. After forcing the aircraft back to Neryangry, where six prisoners and 41 women and children left the plane, the aircraft flew west to Krasnoyarsk in Siberia. The aircraft refuelled and flew to Tashkent, where a new crew boarded and the hijackers demanded to leave the country. They originally wanted to go to New Delhi but landed in Karachi, complaining their fuel supply was dangerously low. There have been at least 13 hijackings or attempted hijackings of Soviet aircraft since late May.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest 48 People for Plotting Revolution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to ADD that maximum sentence is death, MOVES UP reference to acccusation North Korea involved in pvs. Pickup 3rd pvs, `Police said...'; DELETES redundant 12th graf, `Although the...' ADDS byline
DOC.TEXT: Police said today they have arrested 48 suspected radicals for plotting to overthrow President Roh Tae-woo's government. Police said the group included 10 soldiers. Police said all would be charged with violation of security laws and face a maximum penalty of death by hanging, a police announcement said. Although the police did not mention North Korea in announcing the arrests, the government has often accused the Communist country of instigating anti-government activity in South Korea. Police said 17 radicals and the 10 soldiers were arrested Tuesday. The other 21 people were arrested in separate operations since March, police said. All were involved in the formation of a group called the Revolutionary Workers Class Struggle Union, which sought to topple Roh's government through armed revolution, police said. Police said most of those arrested were former members of the now defunct underground student Constitutional Assembly, a radical group which played a major role in the formation of South Korea's radical student movement in the early 1980s. The group was outlawed in 1986 and many members were arrested at that time. Police said the group initially called ``Fiery Flower'' was reorganized and in 1989 became an underground organization. Police said the group had plans to attack a munitions area where weapons were kept for reserve army troops. The location of the munitions area was not disclosed and the unit the soldiers belonged to was not disclosed. Those under arrest tried to instigate anti-government struggle among workers and students on college campuses, police said. Police released several names of those arrested, but none were well-known radicals. Police said it was hoped other members of the organization would disband and no more arrests were expected. On Saturday, police said 19 students had been charged with violating the nation's national security law and another 56 were on the fugitive list. All were charged in connection with writing articles in praise of North Korea in campus newspapers and magazines.

DOC.HEAD: Sen. Simpson, Gov. Sullivan Coast to Primary Wins
DOC.TEXT: The rancher daughter of an ex-governor won the GOP nomination for her father's old job and will square off in November against Democratic Gov. Mike Sullivan, who coasted to victory against a motorcycle mechanic. In other primary races Tuesday, Republican Sen. Alan Simpson handily won nomination for a third term. With 96 percent of the vote in, rancher Mary Mead received 67 percent of the vote to 33 percent for 12-year state Rep. Nyla Murphy. Referring to 16 years of Democratic governors, she said, ``The people in Wyoming that I've talked to think it's time for a change.'' Mead, 55, had stressed her skills as a rancher and businesswoman and attacked the governor's economic development efforts. She stands to give Wyoming its first father-daughter combination in the governor's mansion. Her father, Cliff Hansen, served from 1963 to 1967 before moving on to the U.S. Senate. Sullivan easily won nomination for a second term, receiving 88 percent of the vote against mechanic Ron ``Suds'' Clingman. Clingman had called for lowering the drinking age to 18 and decriminalizing drugs. The governor said he would have preferred stiffer competition. During the primary campaign, he largely ignored the race. Simpson, the Senate minority whip, was nominated with 84 percent of the vote and will meet little-known Democrat Kathy Helling, a 32-year-old college student. Helling, who received 34 percent of the vote in a six-way Democratic race, said a strong grassroots campaign and her stand against abortion would make her a formidable opponent, despite Simpson's financial resources. ``It's very gratifying,'' Simpson said of his victory. ``But you work hard and the people watch you and they want to know how bad you want it. I hope I disclosed to them I am ready to work for it.'' Rep. Craig Thomas had no opposition in the primary. Elected last year to fill Dick Cheney's unexpired term, Thomas is seeking his first full term in the House. Also unopposed was his Democratic challenger, Pete Maxfield, a University of Wyoming law professor.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Firing 1,500 in Economy Drive
DOC.TEXT: About 1,500 USAir employees will be given pink slips today and into next week as company officials cancel a planned expansion. In making the announcement Tuesday, airline officials said only probationary employees would be released in response to a weakening economy and a lull in the airline business. Spokeswoman Susan Young said the employees were hired as part of the planned expansion. USAir flies about 3,000 domestic flights daily, supported by 55,200 employees. The cuts are ``across the board, in most departments and in most geographic areas of the country,'' Young said. She said specifics were not available but would include all types of employees anywhere from airport maintenance workers to secretaries. ``We deeply regret that this action is necessary, but these employees were hired in anticipation of an expansion program that has been reduced in light of current economic projections,'' said USAir president Seth E. Schofield. Young said travel has been flat, the nation's economy weakening, and the economic climate for the next 12 to 24 months does not look so good. The airline completed a $1.6 billion takeover of Piedmont in 1989 and a $385 million buyout of Pacific Southwest Airlines in 1987. Since then, USAir has grown rapidly under deregulation and still has plans to add new overseas routes. Last week USAir announced it would furlough 211 pilots effective Jan. 1.

DOC.HEAD: Two Germanys Pledge Continued Non-Nuclear Status After Unity
DOC.TEXT: East and West Germany pledged today not to build or acquire nuclear, biological and chemical weapons after merging into a single German state. West Germany's foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, said both states reaffirm previous undertakings ``not to manufacture, possess or have control over'' the three types of mass destruction weapons. He read a joint statement by both German governments saying, ``They declare that the united Germany, too, will abide by this obligation.'' Genscher spoke at a meeting of parties to the 140-nation Non-Proliferation Treaty, the world's main agreement to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons. The conference is reviewing implementation of the 1970 treaty. Genscher said the treaty, which both German states have joined, ''will continue to apply to the united Germany.'' A united Germany will seek an extension of the treaty when the issue comes up in 1995, he said. The treaty binds states that do not possess nuclear weapons not to make or acquire them.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Gains, Gold Retreats
DOC.TEXT: The dollar firmed in European trading this morning. Gold prices declined. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 146.92 yen, up 0.37 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar retreated to 146.40 yen. ``Affected by the stock market's plunge, the dollar-yen trading was rather mixed today,'' said Yuichi Tsuchiko, a dealer with Fuji Bank in Tokyo. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 1,086.93 points, or 4.13 percent, to close at 25,210.91. It was the ninth-largest loss ever recorded by the index, which had shed 192.63 points Tuesday. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.5580 West German marks, up from 1.5545 _1.2858 Swiss francs, up from 1.2855 _5.2435 French francs, up from 5.2325 _1.7590 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7530 _1,161.75 Italian lire, up from 1,155.75 _1.1373 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1437 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9195, compared with $1.9215 late Tuesday. ``The market has become so scared to do anything, there isn't much business in the dollar,'' said Jim O'Neil, international economist at Swiss Bank Corp. in London. He said this will probably prevent the dollar from penetrating the lows it reached last week at 1.5450 Deutsche marks and 127.70 Swiss francs even if it looks as if the Fed is easing rates. At the same time, he added, any knee-jerk rally triggered at the start of a Persian Gulf conflict will probably take the dollar only as high as 1.60 marks. ``The basic strategy is still sell the dollar on a rally,'' he said. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $410 a troy ounce Tuesday morning, down from $413.25 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $409.90, down from $414.75 late Tuesday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $1.24 an ounce today, to close at $408.69. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.14 a troy ounce, down from Tuesday's $5.20.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Warns Europe, Japan Against Backing U.S.
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A state newspaper today cautioned Europe and Japan against backing the United States in the Persian Gulf crisis, saying their regional interests would be harmed ``if they walk in the steps of Washington.'' Another newspaper warned that Iraq would take war ``into the cities of attacking nations'' and said the Soviet Union also should realize U.S. interests might harm those of Moscow. A third said the United States, which has condemned the holding of foreign ``hostages'' by Baghdad, is the last country that has a right to talk about human rights. The state-run Al-Gomhuriya warned France, Italy, West Germany and Japan not to participate in what it termed ``American occupation of the gulf oilfields.'' Those nations ``should know where there interests lie so that they don't blindly follow the American schemes designed to seize the Arab oil wells,'' the daily said in a front-page editorial. The daily accused the United States of ``imposing its hegemony'' on the European countries and Japan and trying to control their ecnomoies through dominating Arab oil resources. It said Europe and Japan risked losing long-term economic interests in the Arab world if they supported the United States. The newspaper said the Europeans and the Japanese should deal with ``the new and unified Iraq,'' which it described as a ``regional power of wealth and profound history.'' That was a reference to Iraq's annexation of Kuwait, which it invaded Aug. 2. The United States and several Arab nations have sent troops to Saudi Arabia to defend it against possible Iraqi attack, and several nations have joined the U.S. by sending warship to the region to help enforce a U.N. embargo on Iraqi goods. The Baghdad Observer warned that any flareup in the gulf will lead to all-out war. ``One should not expect the Iraqis to sit idle when their towns and population centers are being bombarded by the U.S. planes and shells. Iraqis will take the war into the cities of the attacking nations if it is attacked,'' the paper said. ``The U.S. wants to impose hegemony on the region and as they put it, `teach naughty Iraq a lesson.' Washington wants governments in this part of the region to be weak enough to give in to the expansionist demands of Israel. It said the United States appears to believe it can do anything it wants ``with no parties daring to challenge it.'' The paper said ``American military presence in the Middle East means a defensive line close to the Soviet Union, a line which would confront any future Soviet attempt to have an influence in this vitally strategic area.'' Al-Qadissisya, the Iraqi army newspaper, said, ``He who speaks about human rights must first have a record book free from crimes against humanity.'' It said Iraq's step to keep foreigners in strategic locations to ward off an attack ``is different from the reality of America's black history and its record, which is full of crimes against humanity and struggle of peoples whose territories were under occupation.''

DOC.HEAD: Professor Targeted by Dartmouth Review Resigns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `My effectiveness...' to CORRECT time element.
DOC.TEXT: A black music professor has resigned from Dartmouth College ``liberating'' himself from repeated attacks during the past seven years by a conservative, off-campus student weekly newspaper. ``I wish I were leaving under more favorable circumstances,'' William Cole said in a prepared statement. ``I know that many people will feel that the forces which are part of my leaving Dartmouth have won a major victory. However, this problem is no longer for me to wrestle with. It is a problem for Dartmouth to wrestle with.'' Faculty Dean James Wright said Cole ``never sought to be a public figure. He joined Dartmouth's faculty to teach, write and pursue his other professional interests. But some would not permit this to be.'' The Dartmouth Review targeted Cole in what it said was a crusade against the decline of higher education, once describing him as part of ``Dartmouth's Dynamic Duo of Mediocrity.'' The Review began attacking his teaching ability and personality in 1983. An article that year called one music course he taught ``the most outrageous gut course on campus.'' The newspaper also described him as a ``lean, scruffy fellow'' who ``looks like a used Brillo pad.'' Cole filed a $600,000 libel suit against the paper that was settled out of court two years later for no money. He also had a classroom confrontation with student staff members of the Review, who got a judge to rule they were unfairly suspended as a result. A federal court threw out the white students' discrimination claim. Cole said at the time he didn't think Dartmouth recognized the threat the attacks posed to the institution. ``It's causing people, irrespective of if they are black, white, male or female, to think about whether they want to teach here,'' he said in 1988. ``It's causing liberal-minded students to think about whether they want to come here.'' ``My effectiveness as a teacher and participant in the Dartmouth community was compromised,'' Cole said in his statement last week, by ``a series of events which began in 1983.'' ``There is a tendency to dwell upon and continue to analyze these issues,'' he said. ``For my part, the end of my association with Dartmouth is liberating.'' Cole said his departure frees him to concentrate on performing, promoting music of minority artists and participating in multidisciplinary artistic events. Cole came to Dartmouth in 1974 and taught courses in American jazz and the music of non-Western cultures. He has written books on jazz artists Miles Davis and John Coltrane. He also has performed in his own group, Wind and Thunder. He was awarded tenure in 1979 and was promoted to full professor in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Epidemic of Domestic Violence Largely Overlooked by Doctors
DOC.TEXT: Even though domestic violence causes more injuries to women than auto accidents, muggings and rapes combined, doctors largely ignore the problem, says a report in a medical journal. But a spokesman for emergency-room physicians says the report overstates the shortcomings of doctors and fails to show they are sometimes hampered by a lack of support services or by women's reluctance to implicate batterers. Twenty-two percent to 35 percent of women who visit emergency departments have symptoms linked to abuse, either physical or stress-related, said the report in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. ``Thirty-four percent of all female homicide victims older than 15 years are killed by their husbands or intimate partners,'' added the report by the journal's associate editor Teri Randall, who cited FBI data from 1976 to 1987. ``While most clinicians wouldn't consider discharging a patient with a life-threatening condition, data from emergency department records show that a majority of women who are victims of domestic abuse are discharged without any arrangements made for their safety, to return to the same abusive relationships that caused their injuries,'' the report said. ``The only physicians who ask about violence are psychiatrists, and they're only interested if it occurs in a dream. They rarely ask about the violent events that occur in real life,'' Dr. Mark Rosenberg, director of injury control for the national Centers for Disease Control, told the journal. But the report ``just might be overstated,'' said Dr. Jack Allison, vice president of the American College of Emergency Physicians. He said the report fails to convey that many communities lack shelters or other services for abused women, and many women cover up for the wrongdoings of batterers. In addition, ``there are still times, unfortunately, when women go back to those relationships _ they choose not to go to shelter, choose not to press charges, choose not to get out of the abusive situation. That's a real frustration for physicians,'' he said in a telephone interview Tuesday from Greenville, N.C. A 1987 study of one urban emergency department indicated physicians treating victims deliberately injured by other people rarely asked about the victim's past sexual or physical abuse, living arrangements or prospects for safety. By not asking these questions, the physician lost the opportunity to address the cause of the patient's medical condition and closed the door to preventive measures, the study concluded. Mildred Dailey Pagelow, a sociology professor at California State University, Fullerton, told the journal, ``Physicians will often say, `I'm not a law enforcement officer, and I'm not a social worker. I'm here to treat the body, and she needs to see a psychiatrist.'' Yet a growing number of physicians think the treatment of domestic violence is a medical matter, the report said. ``Quicker than you can put on a Band-Aid, you can acknowledge the violence, you can assert that this is illegal, not her fault, and that a lot of women are in this situation,'' said Dr. Anne Flitcraft, an assistant professor of medicine at the University of Connecticut, Farmington, and co-director of the New Haven-based Domestic Violence Training Project. ``You can educate her about the community-based resources available to help her, and ask her, `Are you safe?''' Ms. Flitcraft told the journal. Many hospitals have instituted procedures specifically designed to help abused patients, the report said. For example, specially designated nurses act as patient advocates, seeing that abused women receive help from a psychiatrist or social worker, if appropriate, and supplying a referral list to shelters, legal services and counseling services, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Research Scientists Indicted for Selling Stolen Trade Secrets
DOC.TEXT: Two research scientists have been indicted for allegedly conspiring to sell the trade secrets for two drugs that cost over $400 million to develop. Bernard Mayles, 52, and Mario Miscio, 63, were charged with conspiracy, wire fraud, mail fraud and interstate transmission of stolen property. They were indicted Tuesday in U.S. District Court in Newark. If convicted on all counts, each faces a maximum of 30 years in prison and millions of dollars in fines. The drugs involved were ivermectin, a leading anti-parasitic drug, and interferon, which has shown promise in treating cancer and hepatitis. The two were arrested in Atlanta on Aug. 10. An FBI undercover agent posing as an international broker with connections in Eastern Europe and the Third World paid $1.5 million in return for a sheaf of documents and two tests tubes stored in a cooler of dry ice, the indictment said. At the same meeting, the two agreed to sell the secrets and microorganisms necessary for the production of interferon for a sum between $6 million and $8 million, the indictment said. Ivermectin, which is patented by Merck for use in a number of drugs, is also used to treat thousands of people in West Africa and South America who suffer from river blindness. Mayles had worked for 11 years at Merck and Co., and 5 years as a researcher at Schering-Plough. Miscio is the director of Biopharm Research Inc. of Hazlet. Pharmaceutical companies spend an average of 12 years and $231 million on research and development to bring a single drug to market, according to Pamela Adkins, a spokeswoman for Merck. U.S. attorney Michael Chertoff said, ``This type of crime strikes at the heart of the research and development system, at the type of incentive necessary to develop drugs and bring them to the marketplace.''

DOC.HEAD: American Who Escaped Kuwait Arrives Home
DOC.TEXT: An expatriate American who slipped past Iraqi troops disguised as an Arab in a daring escape from Kuwait last week, arrived home to smiling and crying relatives. ``Hello America, I love you,'' Stephanie McGehee called out Tuesday on entering the terminal at San Diego's international airport. ``It's good to be home,'' said McGehee, a part-time photographer for The Associated Press who had lived in Lebanon and Kuwait for 13 years. McGehee, 37, of Leucadia, fled the Kuwaiti capital for Saudi Arabia last Friday in the lead car of a 13-vehicle caravan of Americans and other foreigners. Dressed in a floor-length black chador, she used her knowledge of Arabic dialects to slip past Iraqi troops that invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. But the group was forced back at the last checkpoint, and they had to drive into the desert and around Iraqi troop positions to reach Saudi Arabia. McGehee's father, Bill, said he was never doubted that his daughter would escape safely. ``I know Stephanie knows how to take care of herself. I know she has the ability of being able to do what she has to do.'' McGehee had been in hiding nine days when the Iraqi government announced it wanted all U.S. and British expatriates to gather at the International Hotel. McGehee said that's when she decided it was time to flee Kuwait. ``When I heard Saddam Hussein's speech and he said he would send Americans home in coffins, I said, `No way. Not me.'''

DOC.HEAD: Pope, Worried About War, Offers Prayer
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II, in his first public comment on the crisis caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, spoke today of the ``danger of war'' and offered a prayer for peace. During his weekly general audience the pope spoke about the threat to world peace, addressing a small group of Japanese pilgrims. ``Today we add to our prayers the danger of a war that threatens the desired peace in the world,'' the pope said, in Japanese. ``May the Lord, through the intercession of the Blessed Virgin Mary, answer our invocations. With this wish, I bless everyone from my heart.'' The Vatican press office released a translation of the pope's remarks. On Tuesday, the pope met with the papal envoy to both Iraq and Kuwait to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, which began Aug. 2 with the Iraqi invasion and prompted many nations to send troops to defend Saudi Arabia. On Monday, the Vatican newspaper underlined ``this grave hour in the history of humanity'' and reprinted messages of peace delivered decades ago at the United Nations by John Paul and a predecessor, Paul VI. A cautiously-worded editorial about the crisis that appeared Aug. 8 in the Vatican paper, L'Osservatore Romano. It urged nations to refrain from resorting to the ``law of the strong.'' The editorial implicitly criticized Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Parents of Quints Get Aid to Care for Nieces
DOC.TEXT: The parents of eight children who include the country's first test-tube quintuplets will receive about $1,000 a month to care for three nieces, ending a four-month application process. The state Department of Social Service on Tuesday licensed the home of Raymond and Michele L'Esperance for foster-care, making the Davisburg family eligible for more benefits to care for its children. The decision was announced in Oakland County Probate Court, where the couple had turned in hopes of getting their license application approved quickly. ``We are elated,'' said Raymond L'Esperance, who had been trying since April to get the license. The L'Esperances, parents of eight children from current and previous marriages, began caring for the 6-, 10- and 13-year-old nieces last year when the girls' parents sought drug and alcohol rehabilitation. The couple was receiving $295 monthly from Aid to Families with Dependent Children, but sought the foster-care license to qualify for more government aid. Oakland County Probate Judge Barry Grant had pushed the Department of Social Services to act quickly. ``It's disturbing to me what could've happened if these children were not fortunate enough to be wanted by their aunt and uncle,'' Grant said. ``The system, as it presently exists, is not addressing the needs of children.'' The L'Esperances had quintuplets in 1988, believed to be the first conceived in vitro and successfully carried in the United States. Michele L'Esperance works in a home for battered women. Her husband is a Macomb County corrections officer and holds a second job in a tool-and-die shop. Michele L'Esperance has said it costs more than $300 a week just to feed the family.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Wants Unification in Early October, Sources Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Social Democrats rejecting Oct. 6 unification date, background on parties' motivations. TRIMS. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl wants East Germany to dissolve and unite with his country on Oct. 6, one day before East Germany's founding as a sovereign nation, sources said today. The preference of Kohl, who has been able to dictate most of the pace of unification, throws yet another date into the politically charged debate over when East Germany should unify. West German government sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Kohl wants unity to take place one day before the 41st anniversary of East Germany's founding as a Communist state on Oct. 7. The date was proposed by Guenter Krause, Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere's top aide and the county's leading unification official. Kohl and de Maiziere are both Christian Democrats who have been battling with the left-leaning Social Democrats in both countries over the timing of unity. As late as Tuesday, de Maiziere favored that unity take place on Oct. 14, when elections are held to create the five states that East Germany will become in a united nation. However, East German Social Democrat spokesman Helga Wanke said today that her party rejected the Oct. 6 date. She said the party was standing firm on its insistence that unity take place on Sept. 15. East Germany will unite by approving a clause in the West Germany Constitution that allows former German lands to accede to the Western nation. The Social Democrats say they want unity to come in mid-September so that West Germany can more quickly assume direct responsibility for East Germany's failing economy. Joblessness has been climbing since East Germany converted to a free market on July 1. But the Social Demcrats also want quick unity so Kohl, they say, will be forced to admit the true costs of bailing out the East German economy. Both parties are in the midst of a political campaign to lead the united nation. Common German elections are tentatively set for Dec. 2. An apparent East German agreement to unite on Oct. 14 fell apart Tuesday amid name-calling and growing rancor. The Social Democrats, the nation's second-largest party, defied their leader and rejected unity on that date. Richard Schroeder, parliamentary leader of the Social Democrats, had agreed to the proposal. He quit his post after his party decided not to accept it. The conservative Christian Democrats hold the most votes in Parliament and are in the best position to set the date for the historic merger. De Maiziere's government has suffered a series of dismissals, resignations and charges of incompetence in the past week. On Sunday, the Social Democrats withdrew from de Maiziere's governing coalition in a dispute over unification. Six ministers have resigned or been ousted from the Cabinet in the past week. The chief of the agency set up to sell East Germany's ailing enterprises resigned amid criticism of his failure to unload the businesses. Kohl wants to keep unity and electons close together. He lost a bid to have them both held on the same day, Oct. 14, because that required rewriting West Germany's constitutional timetable to elections. The East German Parliament must approve unification by a two-thirds majority, but only a simple majority is needed to set a date. All the major parties are committed to unification, but the debate has been reduced to a political brawl over when it should take place. Many details remain to be worked out. Fighting between political parties in both Germanys, essentially in the throes of an election campaign, will likely resurface. How to distribute East German property has been a roadblock to a political treaty that is to mesh the two countries. Some of the property is claimed by West Germans who fled the region after the Soviet onrush late in World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Guards and Inmates Injured in Uprising at New York Jail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with authorities now saying four inmates taken to hospitals, de-emphazizing higher injury figure, which included those treated at scene for smoke inhalation, picks up 5th graf pvs: `The extent ...
DOC.TEXT: An inmate's stabbing touched off the second uprising in eight days at the city's Rikers Island jail and left about 25 guards and four prisoners injured, authorities said today. Eighteen inmates barricaded themselves in their cellblock and set fires Tuesday night after the prisoner was stabbed, said Correction Department spokeswoman Ruby Ryles. The assailant's identity was not known, she said. Forty guards ended the uprising within 30 minutes, Ryles said. It was not immediately known if force was used. Ryles had said Tuesday night that about 75 people were injured and that most of them were treated for smoke inhalation. None of the injuries was life-threatening, Ryles said. Twenty-five guards and four inmates were taken to local hospitals, Emergency Medical Services spokeswoman Gail Christianson said this morning. The extent of the damage to the jail was not immediately known. Last week, up to 1,000 guards blockaded the entrance to the island in the East River for 36 hours, protesting inmate violence against guards and demanding more authority to use force. The blockade left the jail short of staff and prevented inmates from receiving visitors. As the blockade was ending Aug. 14, hundreds of prisoners rioted in anger, and 162 guards and inmates were reported injured, most of them by tear gas. During the disturbance, officers were accused of lining up some inmates and beating them bloody with nightsticks. The city is investigating the accusations. The Rev. Irvine Bryer, a member of the Board of Correction, said guards told him they forced prisoners into a corridor and beat them while shouting, ``We control the jails, not you!'' The blockade ended after guards reached an agreement that allowed greater leeway in the use of force. But a federal judge barred the Correction Department from implementing the new rules and ordered a compromise be reached.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Activist Drowns Following Anti-Geothermal Protest
DOC.TEXT: KAILUA-KONA, Hawaii (AP) _ As environmental activist drowned in Keauhou Bay shortly after leading a flotilla of boats and surfboards in an anti-geothermal protest, police said. Dexter Cate, 47, was diving from a kayak Tuesday evening when he failed to surface, said police Lt. Errol Ishimine. Cate was arrested in Japan in 1980 for freeing 300 dolphins from nets. He was deported following a trial in which he was given a six-month suspended jail term. Cate said he freed the dolphins to call attention to their slaughter by Japanese fishermen who said the dolphins were competiting for the same fish and threatening their livelihood. Cate, a Hilo High School teacher, had been participating Tuesday in a demonstration aimed at state-backed plans for development of major geothermal energy plants in the Wao Kele O Puna rainforest. The protest was near a hotel where an international symposium on geothermal development was being held. When Cate failed to surface, his 11-year-old son flagged down a passing boat to get help, Ishimine said. His body was recovered from 80 feet of water and the death is classifed as a public accident, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Tanker, Shadowed by U.S. Warship, Reaches Aden
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to CLARIFY that ships anchored, sted docked, in Yemeni waters, background on Baba Gurgur. Pickup 8th, `The Baba...'
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi tanker that ignored warning shots from an American warship entered the waters off Yemen's port of Aden today and dropped anchor near two other Iraqi ships already anchored there. Shipping sources said a U.S. warship shadowed the tanker Baba Gurgur until it entered Yemeni waters. The tanker was one of two Iraqi tankers that refused to stop Saturday when U.S. Navy frigates fired warning shots across their bows. Yemen has told the U.N. Security Council that it would turn away the Baba Gurgur and adhere to the United Nations trade embargo imposed on Iraq after its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Yemeni officials would not comment on the tankers today. However, the official Yemeni news agency quoted an unidentified Foreign Ministry official on Tuesday as saying Yemen did not intend to ``intercept or obstruct'' any ships. The Red Sea country could still adhere to U.N. sanctions by simply ignoring the tankers and refusing them permission to load. Saudi Arabia used a similar ploy to turn away the two other Iraqi tankers now anchored at Aden. Those tankers, the Al-Fao and Al-Qadissiyah, left their anchorage in the Red Sea off Saudi Arabia last week when they were unable to load crude. Aden port control on Tuesday said the two tankers were anchored outside the oil terminal in Aden. A Western diplomat said the two empty tankers may have sailed to Yemen just to tie up in a safe port. The Baba Gurgur is a 36,397-ton Iraqi products carrier, a ship designed to pick up finished oil products from a refinery for delivery to distribution points elsewhere. Shipping sources said the refinery at Aden has not accepted a consignment of Iraqi crude in more than a month. Before the crisis, however, Iraq sent crude to that refinery. It said recently that the Baba Gurgur was en route to Aden to pick up fuel oil stored there. The Baba Gurgur ignored three warning shots fired across its bow Saturday by the frigate USS Bradley in the Persian Gulf and sailed to Yemen shadowed by an unidentified American warship. Another Iraqi tanker, the Khanaqin, ignored six warning shots from the frigate USS Reid in the Gulf of Oman. That ship reportedly was also sailing toward Yemen. A U.S. military spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said on Tuesday that the Khanaqin was still under surveillance. But he refused to disclose the location of the vessel. Shipping sources in Yemen confirmed that the Baba Gurgur was anchored off Aden but said they also did not know the location of the Khanaqin. The tankers' arrival in Yemen has focused unwanted attention on its government, which has generally avoided criticism of Iraq since it invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 and has opposed the multinational force defending Saudi Arabia. However, oil executives in the gulf say Yemen needs the revenues from its refinery at Aden and cannot afford to run the risk of drawing international sanctions for breaking the embargo aganist Iraq. Yemen has been gripped by pro-Iraqi and anti-U.S. demonstrations that included rock-throwing assaults on the American Embassy in the first days of the Persian Gulf crisis. Gen. Ali Abdullah Saleh, president since May in the merged state formed of North and South Yemen, went to Washington early this year to foster ties with the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-American Demonstration by Jordanian Women
With PM-Persian Gulf, Rdp
DOC.TEXT: About 200 Jordanian women carying banners and singing patriotic songs marced on the U.S. Embassy today, demanding the United States withdraw troops from Saudi Arabia and lift the economic embargo on Iraq. The women, who marched from downtown Amman in blazing heat, were stopped by police about 100 yards from the mission. For about an hour, they blocked traffic on a main avenue nearby, chanted slogans and sang songs. The women carried large cloth banners reading: ``Stop the American blockade,'' and ``Jordanian Women Protest American Intervention.'' Other placards said: ``Mr. Bush don't stick your nose in Arab affairs,'' and ``American mothers, why send your sons to die in the Arabian desert?'' Small children held up bunches of flowers and placards that read: ``Remember the flower children _ make love, not war.'' A statement delivered to the U.S. Embassy by a delegation of women demanded the U.S. troops withdraw from Saudi Arabia, where they are stationed to deter a possible Iraqi invasion of the kingdom. They also demanded an end to the economic embargo of Iraq. U.N.-imposed sanctions were imposed after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and subsequent annexation of the emirate. ``The United States is planning to plunge the region into World War III and complete annihiliation,'' the statement said. Riot police wearing helmets and carrying shields and truncheons remained seated in a truck opposite the embassy's main gate during the demonstration. Such protests, an almost daily occurrence in Jordan, reflect the predominantly pro-Iraqi feeling of Jordanians, half of whom are either of Palestinian origin or from the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. In part because of the popular sentiment in favor of Iraq, King Hussein has still not committed himself fully to upholding the U.N. sanctions. Another consideration is that Jordan exports about 40 percent of its goods to Iraq. Consequently, Iraqi goods continue to pass through Joran's Red Sea port of Aqaba, a hole in the international sanctions against Iraq. President Bush has said he might have U.S. warships block ships leaving and entering the port.

DOC.HEAD: Purdue Researchers Find Portion of Hormone Linked to Alcoholism
DOC.TEXT: Purdue University researchers believe they have unlocked a key in the battle against alcoholism. They have isolated a chunk of a hormone that makes the body feel good after drinking alcohol. Graduate student Suchitra A. Krishnan studied rats who were placed under stress and then allowed to drink alcohol. Under both conditions, they produced the adrenocorticotrophic hormone, or ACTH. ``We think a fragment of the hormone is responsible for making the rats want to drink alcohol after the stress is relieved, even if they were low- or non-drinkers before. Apparently they learn to drink to reproduce the good feeling,'' said Krishnan. Krishnan presented her findings Tuesday at the 21st Congress of the International Society of Psychoneuroendocrinology in Buffalo, N.Y. Krishnan and pharmacy professor Roger P. Maickel said that if a drug containing the same amino acids as the ``feel good'' section of ACTH were given to alcoholics, it might satisfy their desire to drink without alcohol's many bad side effects. In the study, Krishnan gauged the rats' alcohol consumption by letting them drink from either of two bottles of sweetened water, one containing 10 percent alcohol. Then the rats were divided into two groups made up of low, moderate and heavy alcohol consumers. Krishnan caused stress among one group by closely confining them for periods of time over several days. During the confinement the animals all drank less alcohol than each one had before being stressed. But after the stress ended they generally drank two to three times more alcohol than before. A second group of rats was not stressed but was injected with a piece of the ACTH molecule, called ACTH4-10, for several days. Most drank no alcohol during that time, but several days after the injections stopped they began drinking at twice to three times the rate they had before. ``The ACTH4-10 acts like a reward mechanism to the rats,'' Krishnan said. ``For the most part, they didn't want to drink alcohol at all during the injections because they were already getting a substantial dose of the fragment.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Loses Touch With Magellan Again; Venus Pictures Show Violent Geology
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 3rd graf, `So the...', to UPDATE with spacecraft not responding to commands. Picks up 4th graf, `Contact was...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA11 of Aug. 21
DOC.TEXT: NASA engineers today struggled to restore radio contact with Magellan after losing touch with the Venus-orbiting spacecraft for the second time in five days. Space agency engineers' failure this morning to hear from Magellan after the link broke indicated the craft's computerized emergency systems didn't immediately activate to help re-establish communication with Earth, NASA said. So the engineers at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory repeatedly sent new computer commands toward Magellan's presumed position around Venus in an attempt to tell it to radio Earth, said NASA spokesman Bob MacMillin. Nothing was heard hours after the commands should have elicited a response from Magellan. Engineers met to plan their next step. ``Bad news. Nothing. Not a peep out of it,'' MacMillin said. ``It's kind of a mystery.'' Contact was lost at 7:03 p.m. Tuesday while NASA was tracking Magellan with an antenna dish near Canberra, Australia, said laboratory spokesman Jim Doyle. The latest blow to Magellan's $744 million mission to map Venus came Tuesday night, less than eight hours after the space agency released the craft's first snapshots of Venus. The pictures revealed a remarkably violent landscape shaped by impact craters, quake faults, vast lava flows, and ridges and valleys like those in the western United States. The loss of Magellan would be another major blow to NASA, which grounded the space shuttle fleet temporarily because of fuel leaks and found the Hubble Space Telescope was impaired by a flawed mirror. The spacecraft's emergency systems allowed engineers to locate the spacecraft on Friday, more than 14 hours after they lost contact with it the first time. Eight hours later, they restored steady contact by sending Magellan a command to stop spinning and keep one of its antennas pointed at Earth. Magellan's mission is to map up to 90 percent of Venus' surface using radar to peer through the planet's thick clouds, which prevent the use of optical cameras. The spacecraft went into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10 after a roundabout, 948-million-mile trip. It was launched from the shuttle Atlantis 15 months ago. When Magellan's first Venus pictures were released Tuesday, Magellan project manager Tony Spear said that as far as engineers could tell, ``the spacecraft is healthy,'' despite last week's malfunction. He and other engineers said they still hadn't figured out the cause of the problem. But Spear had been optimistic enough to say he still planned to have Magellan start its Venus mapping mission the first week of September. Jet Propulsion Laboratory is known for its ability to overcome problems with wayward spacecraft. After the twin Voyager probes were launched in 1977, one lost contact with Earth for eight days. The radio link was restored and the probes went on to explore the outer planets. Spacecraft system engineer John Slonski said one leading theory to explain last week's loss of contact with Magellan was that a cosmic ray or a high-energy particle from the sun caused a blip in its computer memory. ``We're not ruling out a software flaw or some hardware problem'' or perhaps some unknown electrical fields surrounding Venus, Spear said. He also said cosmic ray ``hits'' on spacecraft electronics can be expected to interfere with Magellan about once each year. Magellan made its first pictures of Venus during a test conducted just before last week's malfunction. As promised by NASA, Magellan's first pictures are 10 times more detailed than the best radar images of Venus made by two Soviet probes and a giant radio telescope in Puerto Rico. They show details as small as 400 feet across. The pictures show ``Venus is intensely fractured and faulted,'' with at least part of its terrain shaped by geological forces ``even more violent than I imagined before,'' Magellan project scientist Steve Saunders said Tuesday. The pictures cover a small portion of the planet near Hawaii-like volcanic highlands. The pictures show plains covered by six- to 10-mile-wide lava flows that solidified and then were cracked by faults. Saunders said the flows resemble those in Hawaii or along the Columbia and Snake rivers in the Pacific Northwest. Also visible are a couple of volcanic cinder cones, a 20-mile-wide meteorite crater and long, parallel sets of two- to three-mile-wide valleys and ridges that look like the basins and ranges of Utah and Nevada, Saunders said.

DOC.HEAD: France Sending Ground Troops; Turkey May Join Multinational Force
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: France was said to be sending its first ground forces to the Persian Gulf today, and Iraq's neighbor Turkey said it was considering joining the multinational force deployed to deter further aggression by Baghdad. In Japan, debate was heating up over whether the country ought to break with its longtime ban on deploying of military forces overseas. On Tuesday Spain, Belgium, the Netherlands and Italy said they were sending warships to the Persian Gulf region, and the nine-member Western European Union, meeting in Paris, agreed to to coordinate military action. In Paris, military sources said a reconnaissance squadron, the first French ground forces being sent to the Persian Gulf, would likely leave today for the United Arab Emirates. The sources said the squadron is equipped with amphibious, anti-tank vehicles armed with cannons and machine guns. The announcement by President Francois Mitterrand the deployment of a squadron, about 180 men, signaled a toughening of the French posture. ``We are in a war mindset ... from which it will be difficult to emerge,'' Mitterrand told reporters Tuesday after a special Cabinet session. He also said that French warships in the region could open fire, with his approval, to enforce the U.N. embargo on Iraq. France has dispatched eight vessels to the region with 3,800 men. Meanwhile, Turkey's defense minister, Safa Giray, said Turkey might join the U.S.-led multinational force ``if our assessment shows this would be to the benefit of our country.'' Turkey has placed its air force in a state of readiness since the outbreak of the crisis caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2. But officials have denied reports of troop movements to Turkey's southern region and of deployment of U.S. F-117 stealth fighters in Turkish bases and partial mobilization. At the request of the United States, Ankara closed Iraqi oil pipelines through Turkey and severed trade ties with Iraq. In Japan, the largest opposition party today urged the government not to send personnel to the Middle East. In a meeting with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, Socialist Party Chairwoman Takako Doi said the government should honor a law allowing emergency personnel to be sent only to nations hit by natural disasters, party officials said. Japan has joined other countries in imposing economic sanctions against Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait, but has not contributed personnel or financial support to the multinational forces stationed in the region. In his meeting with Ms. Doi, Kaifu cited Japan's ``growing responsibility'' in international affairs, Kyodo News Service reported. Japan is more dependent on Middle East oil than any other industrialized country and obtained 11.2 percent of its oil from Iraq and Kuwait in the first quarter of the year. In Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, defense ministers from the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council met today to discuss defense strategy. Abdullah Bishara, the general secretary of the alliance, told Kuwaiti television before the meeting that the council has decided to muster the troops of the Penisula Shield rapid deployment force. The force of up to 10,000 troops has been based for the last two years at the northeastern Saudi base of Hafr Al-Baten. The bulk of the multinational military force has been deployed by the United States, which is leading a huge buildup of ground, air and sea forces in and around Saudi Arabia to defend it against possible Iraqi aggression. The Pentagon has refused to disclose the precise number of American troops in the region or on the way, but Gen. Hansford T. Johnson, the top official responsible for getting troops and supplies to Saudi Arabia, indicated it was 35,000. An additional 20,000 sailors are deployed on warships in the area. In addition to tens of thousands of American troops, there are smaller numbers of soldiers from Egypt, Syria and Morocco. The force also includes warships from the Western allies. Military officials have estimated that Iraq has up to 170,000 soldiers in Kuwait and hundreds of tanks and missiles. Meanwhile, Kuwait's ousted government pledged today to step up its armed struggle against Iraqi invaders through guerrilla attacks and conventional warfare. Crown Prince Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah told a news conference in Cairo that Kuwaiti attacks on Iraqi occupation forces would increase within days. Most of the world still considers the al-Sabah family, led by Emir Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the legitimate rulers of Kuwait. There have been reports of Kuwaiti guerrilla resistance since the invasion, but they have not been confirmed independently. The reports included accounts of attacks by suicide vehicle bombers and blowing up of Iraqi tanks and fuel trucks. In Iraq, the Baghdad Observer newspaper warned that any flareup in the gulf will lead to all-out war. ``One should not expect the Iraqis to sit idle when their towns and population centers are being bombarded by the U.S. planes and shells. ``Iraqis will take the war into the cities of the attacking nations if it is attacked,'' the state-controlled paper said.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam a `Destructive Loser,' Foreign Secretary Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UDPATE with Foreign Office comment on staff of Kuwait embassy being reduced, but embassy staying open. Pick up 8th graf pvs, ```You see...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is a ``destructive loser'' whose hostage-taking reflects his isolation in the region and the world, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said today. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said she was ``deeply upset'' by reports that Iraq soldiers continue to round up Britons at gunpoint in Kuwait. ``Our nationals should be looked after very well indeed. It's a scandal the way they are being treated,'' Mrs. Thatcher told reporters. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 trapped 4,500 Britons in Iraq and Kuwait. The Foreign Office said on Monday that 137 of the British citizens are known to have been rounded up in Kuwait and none in Iraq. The Foreign Office said today it has traced 97 of the Britons held in Kuwait and that 76 of them are at civilian installations. Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, said the indication was that the other 21 Britons were held at military installations. Foreign Office spokesmen were unavailable to immediately comment on the situation of the 21. Hurd expressed satisfaction with decisions Tuesday by Greece and Spain to join the international naval force in the Persian Gulf and by the Western European Union to coordinate military action. He said he was also pleased that the European Community refused to close embassies in Kuwait, as Iraq had ordered. Britain has rejected the order to close its embassy, although the Foreign Office said the staff would be reduced from the current 10 to a core group of three or four diplomats. ``You see the pressures which are building up at our instigation,'' Hurd said in an interview with BBC radio. ``I think this policy of Saddam Hussein's is a loser. It was designed to weaken particularly European opionion. What happened yesterday ... showed it has had the opposite effect. It's strengthening. ``It portrays him instead of being a warrior, as being a worried man sheltering behind women and children. And that I'm sure is bad news for him.'' Hurd said that Iraq's tactic of placing Western citizens in harm's way to deter military attacks was a strategy of desperation by a nation without any strong allies. ``This human shield policy is ... not going to work,'' Hurd said. If any of the hostages were harmed, he said, ``that of course would create a new situation. We have never ruled out further measures, neither we nor the Americans. The prime minister and I have all been very clear that we do not rule out further measures if the economic measures don't work.'' Defense Secretary Tom King, appearing on BBC-TV, said the hostages must not influence the policy of Britain and its allies. ``We have to take decisions in the interests of ending aggression. We can't take hostages into account in this situation or we run the risk that more hostages will be taken,'' he said. Hurd said he was encouraged the majority of Arab states have supported the sanctions against Iraq and that some have contributed military forces. ``The fact is that Saddam Hussein has kicked the Arabs in the teeth,'' Hurd said. ``Anyone interested in the Arab-Israel dispute, anyone interested in a settlement there, and a peace process there, that's been put way on the back burner. By whom? By Saddam Hussein. He's a loser, a destructive loser,'' Hurd said.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Bombs Jaffna Peninsula in New Offensive Against Rebels
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with defense ministry comment. Pickup pvs 5th graf, `The peninsula...'
DOC.TEXT: The air force bombed and strafed targets on the Jaffna Peninsula today in what military officials called a new offensive against the northern stronghold of the Tamil Tiger rebels. Planes dropped leaflets over the peninsula Tuesday announcing an indefinite curfew and warning more than 850,000 civilians to stay out of the line of fire, said the officials who spoke on condition of anonymity. The curfew took effect at 6 a.m. local time today, and the planes began bombing runs an hour later, the officials said. They said the aerial attacks were directed at ``identified terrorist targets.'' The military was accused earlier this year of indiscriminately bombing civilians in Jaffna. Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne was quoted in a government statement as telling foreign diplomats that the bombing was carried out ``after careful intelligence assessment to minimize any loss of civilian life.'' The peninsula, 185 miles northeast of Colombo, is the headquarters of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the main guerrilla organization seeking an independent Tamil state in the north and east of this Indian Ocean island. The Tigers broke a 13-month cease-fire on June 11 to re-open its 7-year-old campaign for independence from the Sinhalese-dominated government. The Tigers have beseiged about 250 policemen and soldiers inside Jaffna Fort since the fighting resumed in June. Three other camps, including an airstrip, also are cut off by the insurgents. Officials in Colombo, the capital, said one man in the fort was killed by sniper fire Tuesday. An offensive has been widely expected since July, when government troops seized positions in several villages south of Elephant Pass, which controls the causeway and the only road to the peninsula. But the government's attention has focused on the east coast, where the Tigers have been pushed out of the major towns. The east also has been the scene of communal violence among the Tamil, Sinhalese and Moslems in which hundreds of civilians have been killed. At least 14,000 people have died since the civil war began in 1983 over Tamil claims of discrimination by the Sinhalese majority. The mainly Buddhist Sinhalese, who make up 75 percent of the country's 16 million people, control the government and military. Tamils, who are mainly Hindu, comprise 18 percent, while Moslems account for 7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Robbery Involved in Slaying of Three Store Employees
DOC.TEXT: Robbery was the motive in the killings of three automotive parts store employees shot at point-blank range, investigators say. Police were looking today for the killer or killers who tied up the Super Shops employees when the store closed Sunday evening. Super Shops President Gregg Koechlein would not say Tuesday how much cash was stolen from the store. ``But it's so inconsequential an amount to think that three people were killed for this. It shocks the conscience,'' he said. Other company officials said the day's cash receipts probably did not exceed several thousand dollars. ``Even if you get a million dollars, is it worth executing three people? This is just a vicious, cold-blooded killing _ there's no other way to describe it,'' said city police Lt. Houston Williams. The victims were identified as assistant manager Darrell Esgar, 22, of Huntington Beach, and salesmen Chad Chadwick, 22, of Orange and Russell Williams, 21, of Seal Beach.

DOC.SECOND: PM-South Africa, 4th ld-Writethru, a0529, a0531, a0535,0726
DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Soars in Townships Despite Calls for Peace
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines urgent series; Edits to conform; No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JOH1
DOC.TEXT: Rival Xhosas and Zulus battled with guns, axes and spears today, killing at least 39 people despite peace calls to end violence that has claimed at least 478 lives in 10 days. Police and witnesses said gangs of Zulus and Xhosas clashed early today at a sprawling migrant workers hostel at Vosloorus, a township east of Johannesburg. Scores of armed Xhosas stormed the complex, grappling with Zulus in hand-to-hand fighting as the hostels were set on fire. ``It was awful. The bodies had been castrated. There were lots of burnt bodies,'' a local journalist said. ``Everyone was in shock.'' Police said at least 39 people were killed in Vosloorus. After dawn, police moved in and fired tear gas to break up the fighting. Bodies were put in small piles for collection. Witnesses said many of the bodies also had been ritually mutilated. They said police vehicles were attacked in Vosloorus. Overnight fighting in Kagiso township west of Johannesburg killed 20 people, police said. Xhosas fighting Zulus living in a migrant workers hostel set up burning barricades in streets to try to prevent attacks, witnesses said. Maxwell Mulovhedzi, a security guard, said fighting erupted in Kagiso when armed Zulus from the hostel attacked passersby. ``They attacked an old man with an axe and killed him,'' he said. ``After a while they attacked another two people, killing them both.'' In other township violence: _A 13-month baby was burned to death in a house that was firebombed Tuesday night in Kwathema, according to news reports. _A white security guard working for a private company was shot and killed in Soweto late Tuesday and his shotgun taken, police said. _A black police officer was killed and another officer critically injured today when two black men hurled a Soviet-made grenade into their vehicle in Soweto, according to South African Press Association. _Armed blacks also hurled firebombs at police armored vehicles and shots were fired at police patrols in Kagiso, police said. ``Blacks threw stones and petrol bombs at police. In two cases they fired shots at police, who fired tear gas and then birdshot in retaliation,'' said a police spokesman, Lt. Ida van Zweel. Today's violence raised the death toll for the last 10 days to at least 478, with hundreds injured, police said. More bodies were found in other black townships, they said, and the toll was expected to increase. The fighting erupted Aug. 12 between Zulus of the conservative Inkatha movement and Xhosas, tied to the African National Congress. The latest clashes came after government and black leaders Tuesday called for peace and an end to the fighting. Government officials also said they hoped the ANC, which did not take part in the talks, would now join peace efforts. But senior ANC leaders declined to comment. ANC leader Nelson Mandela has refused to meet with Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi. In talks Tuesday in Pretoria, President F.W. de Klerk conferred in Pretoria separately with Buthelezi and Gen. Bantu Holomisa, head of the Xhosa homeland of Transkei, to try to end the bloodshed. ``Not only must the bloodshed cease, the war of words must cease,'' the government and black leaders said in a joint statement later. ``This has often been interpreted at grassroots level as license for violence.'' The South African Youth Congress today accused police of aiding Inkatha fighters in the township clashes. The congress is an ANC-affiliated youth organization that is generally more militant than the parent group. Holomisa made a similar charge on Tuesday after meeting with de Klerk and other government leaders. Police and government leaders have repeatedly denied such charges. Holomisa leads a nominally independent homeland in the southeast part of the country far away from the fighting. He is an ally of the ANC, the largest black opposition movement, but he has no real influence outside his region. Buthelezi's supporters have been locked in a struggle with the ANC in Natal Province for the past five year in a contest that has claimed some 5,000 lives.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Killed in Two-Car Crash
DOC.TEXT: Two cars collided at a rural intersection, killing eight people and injuring a 5-year-old girl, officials said today. The driver of one car ran a stop sign and struck the second auto, said Gratiot County Deputy Rebecca Cook. The injured girl was taken to Sparrow Hospital in Lansing. Cook said no condition report was available. The accident occurred Tuesday night in Elba Township in central lower Michigan. Cook said the dead ranged in age from 3 to 28 years. Their identities were being withheld while relatives are notified. Five people were riding in one car, four were in the other.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Nations Consider Holding Informal Weekend Talks
DOC.TEXT: Six OPEC nations are considering holding an informal meeting this weekend to discuss the turmoil in the oil markets caused by the Persian Gulf crisis, sources close to the cartel said today. Oil prices edged higher in London on crisis jitters today. North Sea Brent crude oil for October delivery was valued at $27.90 a barrel at midday, up from Tuesday's $27.10. In late-morning trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the October contract for West Texas Intermediate _ the benchmark grade of U.S. crude _ was up 64 cents to $29.35 a 42-gallon barrel. The September contract for unleaded gasoline gained 1.74 cents to $1.03 a gallon, while home heating oil shot up 3.79 cents to 87.50 cents a gallon. Meanwhile, some tankers were being reflagged to avoid economic sanctions against Iraq. The Spanish oil company Compania Espanola de Petroleo SA said it planned to transfer 126,000 tons of Nigerian crude oil from a barred Iraqi-flagged tanker to another ship to allow the oil to be imported to a Canary Island refinery. The Spanish merchant marine had barred the Iraqi-flagged Almuntanabbi from Spanish ports Monday, but a merchant marine spokesman said today the deparment agreed to the transfer of the Nigerian crude to a ``neutral'' ship. The Kuwaiti-flagged Triden Arrow, blocked Saturday by Spain from unloading 1,000 tons of Brazilian cotton in Barcelona, switched to the Liberian flag Tuesday and was permitted to unload. Regarding OPEC plans, Indonesia has suggested that six of the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries gather in Vienna on Sunday to examine the situation, according to the sources, who demanded anonymity. The sources stressed that no final decision has yet been made on whether to meet. ``It may or may not be held,'' said one source. ``If it is, it will be very, very informal.'' No decisions could be made at the gathering, he said. The idea of the consultations is apparently an attempt at a compromise between those countries which want an emergency meeting of all the cartel's members and those which do not. On Monday, OPEC announced that there was no majority support for a Saudi Arabian request to call an urgent meeting. The kingdom's oil minister, Hisham Nazer, said last Saturday that his country intended to increase oil production by 2 million barrels a day with or without OPEC's approval. Higher Saudi pumping would make up about half of the loss of some 4 million barrels a day caused by the international embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil that followed Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Nazer had urged the cartel to hold an emergency session to discuss the situation. The United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Venezuela and Ecuador were said to support his plea. Iran's oil minister, Gholamreza Aqazadeh, said he opposed an emergency meeting because there was enough crude in storage to make up for the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude. Under the Indonesia proposal, the sources said Iran, Saudi Arabia, Nigeria, Algeria, Indonesia and Venezuela would gather for the informal talks. Those nations represent two committees recently set up by the cartel to monitor oil production and include Algeria, which holds the cartel's presidency, and Indonesia, which is the alternate president. In its statement on Monday, OPEC said Algerian Mining Minister Sadek Boussena, the cartel's president, would hold consultations with some ministers before the end of the month. It did not elaborate. Saudi Arabia, which pumps about a quarter of the cartel's oil, has an OPEC-set production quota of just under 5.4 million barrels a day. At their summer conference last month, OPEC ministers agreed to limit their output to 22.5 million barrels a day in the last half of the year to try to push crude prices up to $21 a barrel. With the gulf crisis, the average price of a basket of crudes monitored by the group surged last week to $25.29 a barrel. The next formal meeting of the organization is not scheduled until mid-December.

DOC.HEAD: Former Thornburgh Aide Pleads Innocent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT Barr age to 47 sted 37; SUBS last graf to fix typo in `questions.'
DOC.TEXT: A former top aide to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh pleaded innocent today to drug-related charges. Henry Barr, 47, a former Justice Department lawyer, was indicted earlier this month by a federal grand jury in Harrisburg. He is charged with two counts of lying to federal officials about drug use, and one count each of cocaine possession and conspiracy. Barr, who lives in suburban Harrisburg, first worked with Thornburgh during the 1970s when Thornburgh was a federal prosecutor in Pittsburgh. He followed Thornburgh to the Justice Department in 1988 and left in May 1989. The indictment accuses Barr of using cocaine at a suburban Harrisburg home on April 8, 1989. It also alleges he lied about drug use on a federal form the FBI uses to check the background of people in sensitive jobs and repeated the lie in an interview with federal agents. If convicted on all counts, he could face up to 12 years in a jail and fines of $510,000. Barr would not answer reporters' questions before or after his brief appearance today in U.S. District Court. His indictment stems from an investigation that has resulted in guilty pleas from two former deputy state prosectors.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Gulf-Americans
DOC.TEXT: Here is the statement issued today by State Department spokesman Richard Boucher on the situation in Kuwait: Consistent with United Nations Security Council Resolution 662, the government of the United States, along with most other nations represented in Kuwait, has rejected the Iraqi demand for the closure of diplomatic missions in Kuwait and will be retaining a diplomatic presence in that country. Ambassador Howell will remain in charge. This is consistent not only with Security Council resolutions, but also with our obligations to the American private community who, along with other foreign nationals, have been deprived of the freedom to leave and return to their home countries. We will continue to insist that the Iraqi occupation authorities accept responsibility for the protection of American citizens and accord them their basic rights. We will also insist that American diplomats in Kuwait continue to receive the full protection which their status accords them under international law. American citizens should be assured that we plan to have sufficient diplomatic staff at the embassy in Kuwait to look after their safety and welfare, which remains our highest priority. They will serve our community to the best of their ability. Citizens should also know that the United States government will continue to work with others to insist on the full implementation of U.N. Security Council Resolution 664, which demands that Iraq permit and facilitate the departure of all foreigners from Kuwait and Iraq, as well as immediate and continuing consular access to foreign nationals.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-Americans
DOC.TEXT: Here is the full text of the State Department message for U.S. citizens in Kuwait that was broadcast today over the Voice of America and the British Broadcasting Corp.: The U.S. State Department, like most other embassies in Kuwait, today announced that it would not close its embassy in Kuwait as demanded by the Iraqi government. All essential embassy personnel will remain in Kuwait for the express purpose of serving American citizens detained in Kuwait. The Iraqi government has from the beginning of this situation stated that diplomats are free to leave Kuwait. We are taking them at their word and have ordered the departure of all dependents and staff that do not have a mission in Kuwait at this time. The United States government wants American citizens to be assured that your welfare is foremost in our thoughts. We are determined to continue working for your release from Kuwait and your safe return to your families. We advise you to stay in close contact with the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, to stay in your homes and to keep a low profile. Anyone thinking about an overland journey out of Kuwait should plan their route carefully and be aware that Iraqi forces are under orders to stop and take into custody anyone identified as an American citizen. We advise Americans who are considering crossing the desert there is a confirmed report that at least one person has died attempting to cross. There are also unconfirmed rumors that others may have died attempting this route. While there have been individuals who have been able to cross the border without incident in recent days, there can be no guarantee for the safety of those attempting to cross.

DOC.HEAD: PUSH Fails To Win Support from Portland Black Groups
DOC.TEXT: Operation PUSH has failed to win support from black leaders in Portland, Ore., after two days of protests and meetings on its boycott of Oregon-based Nike Inc. ``PUSH wasn't happy it could not rally local support,'' Robert Phillips, president of the Portland NAACP, said Tuesday. Leaders of the Portland branches of the NAACP, the Black United Front, the Urban League and the Coalition of Black Men met Monday with PUSH Executive Director Tyrone Crider. Joining Crider were Chicago Alderman Dorothy Tillman and other activists who flew to Oregon to garner support for the boycott. About 150 people attended a rally Monday night. About 40 of them were PUSH supporters from Chicago, and several Portland residents said they had come more out of curiosity than sympathy with the boycott. Black community leaders in the Portland area said the boycott is ill-conceived and lacks leadership. They expressed anger that Chicago-based PUSH ignored them before forging ahead with its war against Nike, the nation's largest athletic shoe maker. PUSH called for the boycott two weeks ago, saying Nike denies blacks adequate employment and business opportunities. Nike, based in suburban Beaverton, says its policies and programs for minorities could be models for the industry. PUSH, which originally stood for People United to Save Humanity, was founded by Jesse Jackson. He gave up direct leadership of the organization to run for president in 1984 and more recently has left its board.

DOC.HEAD: Blockade Resolution and Soviet Objections Discussed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to UPDATE with five Security Council members meeting to discuss blockade resolution. Pickup 13th, `Kuwait's foreign...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
The five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council met today to try to draft a resolution calling for a military blockade to enforce international economic sanctions against Iraq. The Soviet Union has slowed U.S. efforts to get U.N. approval for a military blockade, Western diplomats say, and the private meeting today was expected to discuss Soviet concerns. The diplomats said Tuesday that Moscow has sought clear and demonstrable failure of the U.N. embargo before approving any U.N. military force. China had dragged its feet for the same reason, but a Kuwaiti official in Beijing said today the Chinese government promised not to block such a move. The meeting was held at the French Mission and involved representatives from the United States, Soviet Union, China, Britain and France. On his way into the meeting, U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering said, ``We'll be continuing our consultations in the day, pushing toward hopefully trying to do something today, if its at all possible.'' Asked if the Soviets were blocking progress, Pickering replied: ``Well, I don't put my finger on anybody, we'll wait and see.'' Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said in an interview published Tuesday that some elements of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's proposal to end the Middle East crisis ``merit serious attention.''
