Saddam offered on Sunday to free thousands of foreign hostages in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait if the U.S.-led multinational force protecting Saudi Arabia from Iraqi aggression withdraws and the United States guarantees the U.N. embargo on Iraq will be lifted. ``I think that there are elements which attract attention,'' Shevardnadze was quoted as telling the Soviet newspaper Pravda. ``We are studying all the details, all the blocks of the speech of the president of Iraq.'' The Western diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Soviet and Chinese objections have slowed the momentum for tougher measures following the near-unanimity of the Security Council in four previous votes against Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The permanent Security Council members deliberated a precedent-setting proposal Tuesday that would authorize foreign naval vessels to use minimum force in policing the U.N. embargo. No final action was taken. Any of the five permanent council members can kill council resolutions with a veto. The Soviets in the past week have wanted to revive the Military Staff Committee before imposing a blockade. The committee consists of military officers of the five permanent officers to coordinate U.N. enforcement actions, but it has never had an active role, even during the 1950-53 Korean War. Soviet Ambassador Valentin Lozinsky last week told Security Council that the Soviets would participate in a blockade only under a U.N. flag. For the second day in a row, Shevardnadze met in Moscow Tuesday with Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister Saadoun Hammadi, but the Soviet news agency Tass gave few details of their talks. Hammadi also spoke with Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, who urged Iraq to allow foreigners to leave its territory.
Kuwait's foreign minister, Sheik Sabah Al-Ahmed, said in Beijing today that China has promised not to veto military enforcement of the U.N. embargo. He met this morning with Premier Li Peng and Foreign Minister Wu Xueqian, but the Kuwaiti official did not say from whom he extracted the promise. Chinese Ambassador Li Daoyu, in the first public statement about the Beijing government's stand, said Tuesday that Security Council decisions ``thus far imply no permission for military involvement by big powers and their naval blockade. ``Under the present circumstances,'' he told the Xinhua news agency, ``resort to military actions will lead to further aggravation of the situation and escalation of the armed conflict, which does not help solving the problem.'' He urged that efforts be channeled through the Security Council's sanctions committee before military action was authorized. Li did not say how China would vote on military involvement, but diplomats said China was likely to abstain and not cast a lone veto. All five permanent council members have veto power and can kill any resolution. The United States, Britain and France were supportive of a unique resolution which would provide a U.N. umbrella, but not a U.N. flag and command, for international warships enforcing the embargo. Britain's U.N. ambassador argued that such a possible ``momentous step'' requires that all nations move ``extremely carefully.'' In a display of unprecedented cooperation, the 15-member Security Council has adopted four mandatory resolutions in the past three weeks: Condemning Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait; calling for sweeping economic sanctions against Iraq; rejecting Iraq's ``annexation'' of Kuwait and demanding freedom for thousands of foreigners held against their will in Iraq and Kuwait. Under Article 42 of the U.N. Charter, the Security Council may call for a blockade and enforcement of its embargo through military force, if its earlier sanctions have been violated. Article 42 never has been invoked for a U.N. enforcement action.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Soviet Military Experts Continue to Aid Iraq
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Military experts sent to Iraq before its invasion of Kuwait continue working for the Iraqi government, despite a Kremlin order to sever all trade and financial ties with Baghdad, a Soviet colonel said today. The 193 Soviet experts have been training Iraqi soldiers to use Soviet-built weapons, repairing and maintaining those weapons, and building test ranges, Col. Valentin Ogurtsov told a news briefing. ``They are fulfilling their contractual duties,'' he said. Soviet experts are not involved in military operations and did not provide advice for Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, he said. Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov issued an order to all Soviet agencies earlier today to cut business ties with Iraq to comply with U.N. sanctions, the Tass news agency reported. The Soviet Union had been Iraq's main arms supplier, providing most of its modern tanks, missiles and jet fighters. But the day after the Iraqi invasion, the Soviet Union cut arms supplies to Baghdad, and Ogurtsov said one weapons shipment was stopped in transit. Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III signed a joint statement condemning Iraq's attack on its oil-rich neighbor. But the Soviet Union, together with China, has slowed U.S. efforts at the United Nations for military action to back up the economic embargo of Iraq, Western diplomats say. Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh rejected repeated questions about whether the continuing work by the military experts violated the U.N. emgargo and the Soviet government order. He said nationals from other countries continued to work in Iraq, although he did not identify the nations or jobs their nationals were performing. Iraq has made hostages out of thousands of foreigners who were trapped in Iraq and Kuwait by the invasion. Iraq has also moved some foreigners to Iraqi military installations to prevent an attack by a U.S.-led multinational force being deployed in Saudi Arabia to protect it against Iraqi aggression. ``This is not a simple solution,'' Gremitskikh said. ``Don't single out the Soviet Union. ... I don't think this presence runs counter to the United Nations position.'' Ogurtsov said that when the Soviet government contracted to sell weapons to Iraq, it also agreed to provide technical experts to show Iraq how to use them. Gremitskikh said when the contracts expire, the experts will leave and will not be replaced. The contracts range from 10 days to one year, Ogurtsov said. ``At the present time, they work not only in training centers but on test ranges. Suppose we supplied a new type of tank. It has new unknown capabilities to the local personnel so we build a kind of test range to test it. ... This is the kind of activity they are involved in,'' Ogurtsov said. ``We are trying to make the period of stay shorter and shorter but we are going to phase out the work eventually,'' Ogurtsov said. The military experts were among 7,791 Soviets stranded in Iraq after its attack on Kuwait. Gremitskikh said Soviet women and children would begin to be evacuated from Iraq on Sunday. He indicated that Iraq would then allow Soviet men to be evacuated. Also today, a special envoy from Saudi Arabia arrived in Moscow. The Soviet Union has no diplomatic relations with the kingdom, Gremitskikh said. Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister Saadoun Hammadi met with Shevardnadze Monday and Tuesday. Saudi Arabia and Moscow had full diplomatic relations until 1938, when dictator Josef Stalin closed his embassy in Jiddah to cut costs. Several attempts to re-establish ties during the 1980s faltered over what Saudia Arabia called the Soviet Union's ``belligerent attitude'' toward its 50 million Moslems.

DOC.HEAD: Atlanta's New Chief Bell Faces Unresolved Ethics Charges
DOC.TEXT: The city's new police chief has two unresolved departmental charges against him, according to a Georgia Bureau of Investigation report. Atlanta Police Department records on Eldrin A. Bell show the department's internal affairs unit recommended charges against him in 1989 for allegedly operating a security business in the city _ a conflict of interest _ and doing it without departmental permission. The records were contained in the GBI report given to Mayor Maynard Jackson prior to Bell's nomination for police chief, which the Atlanta City Council approved Monday. Bell refused to speak with reporters Tuesday and denied there were open charges against him. He also has maintained he no longer has an interest in a security business. The mayor, who said Monday the GBI report contained nothing new, first said Tuesday there were no open charges, but later criticized former Chief Morris G. Redding for not resolving the open charges before retiring last month. ``The first time I found out the former chief did not do his duty was over the past few days,'' said Jackson, who has asked acting City Attorney Joe Harris to look into the matter. The charges allege Bell, who will oversee a force of 1,590 officers, operated a security business based in the zone he commanded in 1988 and that he hired off-duty zone officers to work for his firm, Taking Care of Business Inc. The allegations against Bell were made by the International Brotherhood of Police Officers union. Deputy Chief W.J. Taylor, who was acting chief and a finalist for the job, said he was aware of the unresolved charges against Bell, but did not act. ``I thought it inappropriate to adjudicate disciplinary action against another candidate,'' he said. He said the file was still sitting on the desk where Redding left it when he retired. ``I didn't read the file,'' he said. ``I had decided not to make a decision until the new chief is appointed. I wanted to remain neutral,'' Redding said in a July GBI interview. He added that if the charges were upheld, Bell could have faced a maximum one- or two-day suspension.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Calls Up Reserves, Crisis Causes U.S.-Soviet Disagreement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Bush calling out reserves, Soviet military advisers still working for Iraqi government, U.N. Security Council `big five' meeting under way, other details. Edits to trim. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WX6, NK1, NY4,7,25, XJAK2, LON5, CS1, NA1,3
DOC.TEXT: The United States pledged today to defy Iraqi orders to close down its embassy in conquered Kuwait, and cracks appeared in what had been unprecedented U.S.-Soviet unity in the 3-week-old Persian Gulf crisis. In the gulf, the military buildup intensified. President Bush today ordered military reserves to active duty, and the U.S. aircraft carrier Saratoga today steamed through Egypt's Suez Canal toward the Red Sea to join a growing American flotilla, a canal spokesman said. In Moscow, a Soviet official disclosed today that military experts sent to Iraq before its invasion of Kuwait continue to work for the Iraqi government despite a Kremlin pledge to go along with sanctions aimed at isolating Iraq. Col. Valentin Ogurtsov said the 193 Soviet experts have been training Iraqi soldiers to use Soviet-built weapons, repairing and maintaining those weapons, and building test ranges. But he said the advisers were not involved in military operations and did not provide advice on the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The Soviets were also slowing U.S. efforts to get U.N. approval for a military blockade, Western diplomats said. The diplomats said Tuesday that Moscow has sought clear and demonstrable failure of the U.N. embargo before approving any U.N. military force. The five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council met today to discuss a proposal to enforce the embargo. U.S. and other warships already have been shadowing Iraqi vessels. U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering, on his way into the meeting in New York, declined to specifically blame the Soviets for foot-dragging, but said he hoped for action on the matter today. Western nations today renewed angry protests over the roundup of foreigners trapped in the wake of the invasion. Denmark warned Iraq could be trying to split the West by selective hostage-holding. In Washington, the State Department today announced the U.S. intention to defy Saddam's demand to close the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait by Friday, but said it would reduce the staff. Other nations, including Britain, have announced plans to do the same. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the decision was consistent with ``our obligations to the American private community'' of about 2,500 people in Kuwait. An estimated 500 Americans are trapped in Iraq. Pope John Paul II, in his first public comment on the crisis, today pointed to the ``the danger of war'' and offered a prayer for peace. A day earlier, the pontiff met with the Vatican envoy to both Iraq and Kuwait to discuss the situation, and papal spokesman Joaquin Navarro said the diplomat is ready to pursue any humanitarian initiatives if asked. Meanwhile, an Iraqi tanker that had defied warning shots from an American warship, reached Yemen's port of Aden today and dropped anchor near two other Iraqi ships already docked there. Yemen had told the U.N. Security Council that it would adhere to the sanctions against Iraq. Yemeni officials would not comment on the tanker's presence today. But the official Yemeni news agency quoted an unidentified Foreign Ministry official on Tuesday as saying Yemen did not intend to ``intercept or obstruct'' any ships. With no sign of letup in the crisis, the Tokyo stock market tumbled today. Oil prices edged higher in London on crisis jitters today, and were also up in late-morning trade on the New York Mercantile Exchange. In diplomatic activity on the crisis, Saudi Prince Bandar bin Sultan arrived in the Soviet Union, the official Soviet news agency Tass said. Also, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak conferred today with Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama on the gulf crisis, Egypt's Middle East News Agency said. Also today, defense ministers from the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council met today in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, to discuss a unified defense strategy to complement the U.S.-led military buildup in Saudi Arabia. Abdullah Bishara, the general secretary of the gulf alliance, told Kuwaiti television before the meeting that the council has decided to muster the troops of the Penisula Shield rapid deployment force. The force of up to 10,000 troops from six gulf nations has been based for the last two years at the northeastern Saudi base of Hafr Al-Baten. Arab League foreign ministers were to meet in emergency session on Monday, but an Egyptian Foreign Ministry official said the gathering had been rescheduled for Aug. 30. He did not say how many nations had agreed to attend. Baghdad has expressed willingness to negotiate with the United States, but White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater dismissed the offer Tuesday as the ``same old litany from Iraq.'' He said no talks are possible until Iraq withdraws its tens of thousands of troops from Kuwait. In a speech directed at Bush, Saddam defended detaining foreigners and promised ``a major catastrophe'' if fighting breaks out. Of the 3,000 Americans trapped in Iraq and Kuwait by the invasion, 54 are believed to have been seized by Iraqi authorities, the State Department said Tuesday. Iraq says it is using some as human shields at military installations. The British Foreign Office said today that 21 Britons are known to be held at Iraqi military installations. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd denounced Saddam today as a ``destructive loser'' whose hostage-taking reflects his isolation in the region and the world. Iraq's reported willingness to release European Community citizens from Kuwait could be an attempt to split the Western countries, Danish Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen cautioned today. That was underscored by an Iraqi newspaper's warning today to Europe and Japan, telling them their own interests would be harmed if they ``walk in the steps of Washington.'' The state-run Al-Gomhuriya warned France, Italy, West Germany and Japan not to participate in what it termed ``American occupation of the gulf oilfields.'' U.S. forces in the gulf, meanwhile, continued to grow. The U.S. aircraft carrier Saratoga and the guided missile cruisers Biddle and Philippine Sea sailed through Egypt's Suez Canal today en route from the Mediterranean to the gulf region, said canal officials. The Saratoga joins the carriers Eisenhower in the Red Sea and the Independence, stationed in the Arabian Sea just outside the Persian Gulf. A fourth aircraft carrier, the Kennedy, is enroute to the Mediterranean. More than 25 U.S. warships are in the region. Britain, France and the Soviet Union also have warships in the area. Belgium and Australia have vessels on the way. French military sources said today a reconnaissance squadron, the first French ground forces being sent to the area, would likely leave today for the United Arab Emirates. U.S. Air Force Gen. Hansford T. Johnson estimated Tuesday that at least 35,000 American military personnel are either in or en route to the kingdom. In addition 20,000 sailors are aboard U.S. ships deployed in the region. Iraq, meanwhile, has moved surface-to-surface Scud missiles into occupied Kuwait, increasing the threat of a chemical weapons attack, Brig. Gen. Turki Bin Nassar, a Saudi base commander, told reporters in the kingdom on Tuesday. But he said that U.S. and Saudi forces have defenses against the Scuds, including U.S. Patriot anti-ballistic missiles in place in Saudi Arabia. Also, Tass quoted Kuwaiti officials as saying Iraq has mined all important government installations in Kuwait, including oil refineries, power plants, sea ports and water distilleries. However, British intelligence sources in Saudi Arabia said Iraqi forces must steal water, food and fuel to survive. They also said the Iraqi threat of chemical warfare is not as great as first feared.

DOC.HEAD: King Hussein Says Processing Of Refugees May Be Slowed By Heavy Exodus
DOC.TEXT: King Hussein said today his country is heavily burdened by thousands of refugees fleeing Kuwait and may have to ``slow down the process'' of receiving them. ``On the human level we have some serious problems,'' he told reporters at a nationally televised news conference. ``We have received within Jordan since the beginning of this crisis an approximate number of 185,000 people of different nationalities.'' Of the nearly 120,000 refugees who remain in Jordan, he said: ``We are finding enormous difficulty in meeting the needs of these people or in arranging adequate modes of transport for them to leave Jordan.'' Many Egyptians, Palestinians and other mostly Arab refugees fleeing Kuwait since the Aug. 2 invasion by Iraq have entered Jordan. Only a few of the thousands of Westerners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, including about 3,000 Americans, have been able to flee to safety. The rest are being held as hostages by Iraq. ``We may have to slow down the process of receiving more people unless we can speed up the movement of people to their respective destinations,'' Hussein said. ``We are trying our very best to provide food and shelter and medical facitilities.'' Hussein also said he would continue efforts to help bring a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis, saying any escalation ``would have a devastating effect on this region and the world.'' ``I am in touch with leaders throughout the world, and we will continue to do our utmost to contribute to the solution of the crisis to the best of our ability,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Orders Military Reserves to Active Duty
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout with Pentagon statement, explanation of reservist call-up; raises Bush quote; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today ordered military reserves to active duty, signing an executive order that calls an unspecified number of reservists to bolster the U.S. military effort in the Persian Gulf. The order did not give a number of reservists involved in the call-up, but Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We do not anticipate approaching the full 200,000 authority provided by law.'' ``I hereby determine that it is necessary to augment the active armed forces of the United States for the effective conduct of operational missions in and around the Arabian Peninsula,'' Bush's executive order said. Bush sent letters to the speaker of the House and the president of the Senate to inform them of the action, telling them his order empowers Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney to designate the reservists to perform missions he ``may determine necessary.'' An administration official said the Pentagon expects to call up 40,000 reservists ``between now and the end of August.'' The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, was asked if more could be ordered to duty later. ``We'll have to see,'' the official said. ``Forty thousand is initially what we're looking at.'' The call-up will focus on personnel who can fill the jobs of active duty forces on duty in the Gulf in such areas as cargo handling, airlift, food and water handling, surface transportation, medical services, construction and intelligence, Fitzwater said in a statement. While taking reservists from their normal jobs may be disruptive, the Pentagon told reporters, ``What must be emphasized is that those who have been ordered to active duty are vital to our national commitment in this operation.'' Announcement of the call-up came shortly before Bush met here with Cheney, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcraft and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. It was the first time the president has activated the reserves since March 1970, when the reserves were called up during a postal strike. Presidents have called up the reserves 10 times since World War II. The 26,273 reservists called up by President Nixon in 1970 helped deliver the mail during the postal strike. The last mobilization of reserves for a hostile action occurred from January 1968 to December 1969 when President Johnson called up more than 35,000 reservists to help with the Vietnam War. White House Chief of Staff John Sununu said this would be a ``very surgical, specialized call-up'' of personnel in specific jobs, rather than a broad call-up. Meanwhile, the administration decided today to reduce the staff of the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait but to keep it open despite a demand by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. The State Department announced the U.S. intention to defy Saddam's demand to close the embassy by Friday. Spokesman Richard Boucher said the decision was consistent with U.N. Security Council resolutions and ``also with our obligations to the American private community.'' Bush summoned his top defense advisers to Kennebunkport to get an update on the gulf situation. Cheney and Powell were expected to report that the United States is approaching a target of 100,000 military personnel in the region, said one source, speaking on condition of anonymity. Officials have declined to give specific figures. But the Air Force general in charge of transporting troops to Saudi Arabia, Gen. Hansford T. Johnson, indicated Tuesday that at least 35,000 U.S. troops are there or en route. Another estimated 20,000 U.S. troops are at sea in the area. The Pentagon has said that reservists subject to the call-up will serve with their units, but once they report for duty, some could be transferred to other locations. The rationale for the call-up, the Pentagon said last week, was that ``the airlift, sealift, and support requirements for this operation are enormous.'' ``All-volunteer reservists are well aware of their missions and train intensively, often with the active force, to be ready,'' according to the Pentagon. Cheney arrived in Washington late Tuesday after a four-day tour of five Persian Gulf states. He met Tuesday with Saudi officials to share military intelligence and discuss the possible sale of additional F-15 fighters and heavy tanks to bolster the kingdom's defenses. The Saudis are hosting the massive buildup of U.S. forces and equipment as Iraq moves missiles into Kuwait within target range of many Saudi cities. Officials claim a successful trip for Cheney, whose meetings with the leaders of Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Oman and Qatar were intended to seek support for the U.S.-led military operation. The defense secretary said the Bush administration also favors increasing aid to Egypt. Fitzwater told reporters Tuesday ``the world is united'' in demanding unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's army from Kuwait. Speaking at a Falmouth, Maine, golf tournament where Bush was playing, Fitzwater shot down Iraq's televised offer Tuesday to conduct talks, saying the administration considered it ``the same rhetoric that we've heard before.'' Western nations are willing to talk to Iraqi officials about the welfare of their citizens held in Iraq and Kuwait, he said, ``but that's not the same as negotiations over a (United Nations) demand to get out.'' In addition to freedom for the Westerners, ``We demand complete and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. That is the position of the United Nations and that's the position of all nations,'' Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Italy Deputy, Porn Star Offers Sex for Hostage Swap
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Italian politician and porn star Illona Staller, better known as La Cicciolina, has offered to have sex with Saddam Hussein if he agrees to free foreigners he is holding in Iraq. ``I am willing to go to bed with Hussein if in exchange he sets free the hostages, because this way it would be making love, not war,'' Ms. Staller said Tuesday night. ``I am willing to let him have his way with me if in exchange he frees the hostages.'' Ms. Staller, 35, who represents the Radical Party in the Italian parliament, arrived in this South American capital Monday for a series of TV and nightclub appearances. During an appearance on Channel 9, Ms. Staller attributed the Middle East conflict to ``the selfishness of the great powers and the booty they all want to split after the conflict.'' ``This is taking place because of oil, and that's why I support the development of solar energy,'' she said. ``The sun can't be divided between the United States and the East. The sun shines on everyone equally.''
Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad.

Aug. 20 Arizona Daily Star, Tucson, Ariz., on the Persian Gulf: If the United States expects to hold the respect of its fellow members in the United Nations, it ought to abide by embargo rules against Iraq and Kuwait. And if Uncle Sam wants broad cooperation in the U.N. sanctions, he will accept the U.N. Security Council's guidance and restrain himself from military action on his own. The Bush administration thinks it has the authority to maneuver mighty U.S. naval ships into the way of food and commodity ships bound for Iraq, and oil ships on their way out. It doesn't. ... Nothing is gained for the Bush administration to step outside the bounds of the body it's trying to rally into joint action against Iraq. Sanctions against Iraq and tiny Kuwait, which Iraq forcibly seized, could become particularly potent if they're given time to work. ... The sanctions are vital and eventually should coerce Iraq into negotiating, but sanctions compliance can't involve warships and gunfire unless the Security Council decides the boycott isn't being honored. Let's stick to the rules.

Aug. 15 Houston Chronicle on the Persian Gulf: If George Bush and Saddam Hussein were eyeball to eyeball, Saddam blinked sometime on Aug. 7. Former Secretary of State Dean Rusk's classic characterization of a confrontation seems only too appropriate to the touch-and-go moment when Saddam first started backing down. Other Arabs, true to Middle East tradition, seemed the first to sense it. Saddam blinked when he failed to move against Saudi Arabia in that short period when he knew American forces were coming but hadn't gotten there yet. It was the time when he could have had his maximum leverage, taking the ground and forcing the Americans to fight their way in _ if they wanted to in those dramatically changed circumstances. It is no coincidence that most of the other Arab states not directly involved moved against Saddam as soon as they saw he didn't strike at Saudi Arabia during the moment of opportunity. They sensed right. The Iraqi dictator has been steadily backing away since, in one form or another. The danger is by no means over. There is still plenty of opportunity for explosion. But Saddam shifted from power to propaganda at the moment he chose not to fight. He is trying to change the subject from the invasion and annexation of Kuwait to an overall anti-Israeli, anti-colonial, pan-Arabic struggle. The challenge to everyone else is now to be as smart and cooperative in rejecting this ploy as they were in facing Saddam down militarily.

Aug. 16 The Indianapolis News on reporting the Persian Gulf crisis: The Pentagon has developed a bad habit of keeping the news media from doing their job. Beginning with the invasion of Grenada, the Pentagon has fallen into a pattern of keeping the press from covering the activities of the U.S. military. This is a grave mistake. After Grenada, it happened again in Panama, and it has happened again in Saudi Arabia. The American public should protest loudly. Not until ... seven days after the United States sent troops to Saudi Arabia did the Pentagon allow U.S. journalists to travel along with American troops and cover the story. They also waited a week to grant reporters access to the ships that guard the Gulf of Oman and the Persian Gulf. ... When the United States moves troops, it can and should send journalists along with them. ... The American people have a right to know what is happening to their sons and daughters. They have a right to know what really is happening in the Persian Gulf. And they have the obligation to see that the Pentagon begins to act responsibly in its dealings with the press.

Aug. 18 The Oregonian, Portland, Ore., on U.S. military bases in Philippines: Negotiations are scheduled to begin later this month over the future of U.S. military bases in the Philippines. The treaty governing the bases expires next year. The outcome is uncertain, and the political situation in the Philippines is unstable. That's why the United States must continue to pursue alternatives to Philippine bases. Negotiations with Singapore, for example, should continue even as Manila talks begin. Nevertheless, the Philippine bases are important, and for the talks to have any chance of success, certain steps are needed. ... The United States must ... respond to the challenge of the Philippine Senate's nationalist bloc, the main group opposed to the bases. The opinion of nationalist senators has to be considered because the senate must ratify any new bases treaty. They charge the bases are a remnant of U.S. colonial rule and benefit only the United States. The bases do serve U.S. security interests, but they also contribute substantially to the Philippine economy and security against outside aggression. The United States might win points by offering to link a new treaty more securely to the welfare of more Filipinos. For example, a new treaty could award more ship repair contracts to Filipino companies but only if they meet U.S. standards of competence and have a track record of honest business dealings. Finally, U.S. representatives must enter the negotiations with a clear idea of what the United States can afford.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Twenty-Nine Injured in Head-On Rail Collision
DOC.TEXT: Two British Rail trains collided head-on outside a station Wednesday, and the ambulance service said 29 injured people were injured. Two people apparently suffered broken limbs, the ambulance service said. The accident occurred 200 yards north of Hyde North station in Manchester, about 185 miles northwest of London. There was no indication of the cause of the accident. On Aug. 1, 29 people were injured when two rush-hour passenger trains collided at Reading station, 36 miles west of London. That incident is still under investigation. Faulty wiring in a signal was blamed for a three-train crash at Clapham Junction in south London on Dec. 12, 1988, in which 35 people died and more than 100 people were injured.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Forces Find Biggest Challenge is Carrying Water
With AM-Gulf Rd, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. soldiers deployed to defend Saudi Arabia are finding the biggest challenge of desert operations is carrying enough water. To prevent dehydration, the Americans have been told to drink about five gallons of water a day. That means when soldiers go out on desert patrols, they're loaded up with an extra 10-15 pounds in backpacks that already weigh about 30 pounds. Because of the extra weight, they have to stop every 15 or 20 minutes for a break. ``I usually carry four canteens with me,'' said Lt. James Mead, a Marine who trained in desert warfare at Twentynine Palms, Calif., in the Mojave Desert. The Marines and Army are assigned to the eastern province of Saudi Arabia, but U.S. Defense Department rules prevent identifying their exact location. The names of enlisted men interviewed cannot be reported. The logistics of hauling enough water for the thousands of Americans in Saudi Arabia is just one of the hurdles facing troops as they settle into position. Everywhere soldiers go in the desert, they drag a 5,000-gallon water tank in a trailer behind their truck. Although most of the men have desert experience _ some in Egypt, Somalia and Jordan _ the reality of a possible long-term assignment in the broiling sands of the Arabian Peninsula came as a shock. ``They said it would be hot, but not this hot,'' said a Marine as he relaxed in his shorts during a break. The United States has not fought a desert war since 1943 when it joined with Britain to defeat Germany in North Africa. Remembering that conflict not so far away, a member of the 82nd Airborne carried a copy of the book ``Rommel's Desert War'' in his pack. The temperature rises to above 120 degrees here, creating furnace-like conditions particularly for airmen in flight suits. ``These don't breathe real well,'' said Doug, a Marine Cobra pilot, pointing to his full body suit made of Nomex, a fire retardant material. The Cobra, an attack helicopter, is air-conditioned, but other helicopters like the Huey and the CH-53, both used to transport troops, are not. In the sun, the men must stay covered from head to toe, even wrapping a cloth around the neck to prevent sunburn. All wear hats, sunglasses and sunscreen. Chapped lips have becomed such a problem the Marines have ordered extra balm, said Maj. Mark Hughes. The vastness and unique conditions of the Arabian desert have posed problems. Ground troops often spend twice as long digging a foxhole because the sand is so fine it collapses on itself. Pilots have had trouble reading their navigational maps in a terrain altered by constantly shifting sands. The intense heat affects nagivational equipment, causing slight variations in the readings. In addition, there are the standard problems faced in any desert. The sand clogs machinery, forcing added maintenance and extra spare parts. Concealment becomes paramount as the men try to hide their position in an exposed area. They use camoflauged netting to cover the tents. ``We move at night so people won't see us,'' said Chris, a Marine platoon commander. Delivering supplies is difficult because helicopters and vehicles leave tell-tale dust clouds and tracks that are easily spotted by the enemy.

DOC.HEAD: Government Destroys Base of Group Opposing Airport Expansion
DOC.TEXT: Bulldozers guarded by thousands of riot police Wednesday began demolishing the headquarters of a radical group that has been fighting expansion of Tokyo's international airport. Four members of the group were arrested after they threw bottles and cement at radicals, the officials said. Government officials said the action was part of efforts to complete a long-delayed expansion of the airport at Narita, 40 miles northeast of Tokyo. The airport has only one runway. Guarded by 6,500 riot police, bulldozers began demolishing iron fences surrounding Sanrizuka Struggle Hall, a two-story prefabricated headquarters built by local farmers and the extremist group Chukakuha, or Middle Core Faction. The group opposes the airport expansion as part of its anti-government campaign. Four radicals occupying the headquarters defied a government order to leave the building, which is less than a mile from a 4,400-yard runway under construction. The radicals threw bottles and chunks of cement at officials and reporters before police arrested them. In a statement, airport authority president Kauharu Matsui said the demolition of the headquarters ``is very significant for our smooth negotiations in the future to obtain the land still necessary to resume the expansion of the airport, as well for the airport security.'' The government plans to build a new terminal and two additional runways by the end of March 1991 to cope with overcrowding at the 12-year-old airport. Of the 2,630 acres of land sought for the expansion project, the government still needs to acquire 52.6 additional acres, including 40 acres held by eight farmers who refuse to move, said Kaoru Shirohata, spokesman for the New International Airport Authority. The Airport Authority says the airport is handling more than 19 million passengers a year, 6 million more than its official capacity.

DOC.HEAD: Skippers of Submarine, Fishing Boat Charged Over Collision
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors have filed criminal charges against the skippers of a Japanese submarine and a fishing boat involved in a collision two years ago that left 30 people dead, officials said Wednesday. Officials said the case is the first time a Japanese military officer would face criminal charges in an accident involving a military vessel. The incident occurred July 23, 1988, between the 154-ton sports fishing boat and the 2,200-ton submarine Nadashio, which was traveling on the surface near the mouth of Tokyo Bay. Keisuke Yamashita, who was captain of the submarine, and Manji Kondon, skipper of the fishing boat, were charged Tuesday with interference of sea traffic and professional negligence resulting in injury and death, according to the Yokohama District Public Prosecutor's Office. The maximum penalty for the charges is five years in prison or a fine of $1,360.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: can afford.
DOC.TEXT: August 17 News-Republic, Baraboo, Wis., on Marion Barry: Washington, D.C., residents have been cheering (the) virtual acquittal of Mayor Marion Barry on drug charges. It's a strange situation, considering what should have been destructive testimony that Barry has been a drug user. While the mayor was found guilty of one misdemeanor drug possession charge, a mistrial was declared on 12 other charges, including felonies. Barry could still be re-tried on the charges, and attorneys are considering such a move. But, in the meantime, Barry has received what amounts to a hero's welcome from many residents of Washington. That's a sad commentary on conditions in the nation's capital. During Barry's trial, his defense counsel admitted that Barry has used cocaine _ a very dangerous drug. That means that Barry lied to the nation and to his constituents when he earlier denied involvement with drugs. Further, he used his office to perpetrate and advance that lie. All the while, he was factitiously engaged in a war against drugs. Barry's supporters have said that the trial's outcome was vindication from a persecution by federal officials. They have labeled it a battle between the white establishment and disenfranchised blacks. In their current support of Barry, what they are really saying is that it's OK to use drugs if you're black, and that legal action against black users is racial persecution. They have put a man above the law in a system where the rule of law is paramount. Barry should be ashamed and step down from public office. He has violated the public trust. Yet, his fans cheered the outcome of the trial, and Barry plans to run for a spot on the city's council.

Aug. 21 Albuquerque (N.M.) Journal on the need for students to speak English: Few should argue with Secretary of Education Lauro Cavazos' insistence that children in the United States are not ready to learn if they cannot speak English on their first day of school. The position particularly angers Hispanics and educators. For many non-English-speaking students, the burden of learning both a new language and simultaneously studying other subjects can be a heavy one. That child often starts dropping behind classmates almost immediately. Many never catch up, an observation supported by high dropout statistics among the children of many minority groups. Criticism of the Cavazos position is ethnocentric and ignores the fact that most of the nation's commerce, government, education and communication is conducted exclusively in English. Those with a poor command of the language are at an immediate disadvantage in the community. Cavazos is of a generation of Hispanics that recalls with some bitterness punishment meted out in both private and public schools to those who spoke Spanish in the classroom. Practices have changed, but the need for children to speak and understand English very early in their school years has not.

Aug. 17 The Columbus (Ohio) Dispatch on genetic engineering: More than 100 genetically engineered drugs, vaccines and other substances have been approved by the Food and Drug Administration. These have been used against diabetes and hemophilia, among other things, in recent years. The good they have done is incalculable. But there is a downside, too, particularly when a genetically engineered substance is not considered a drug, and therefore does not come under close FDA scrutiny. And that is what happened with tainted L-tryptophan that last year killed 27 and injured 1,500 Americans. The genetically engineered bacterium, developed by a Janapese drug company, Showa Denko K.K., was widely used as a nutritional supplement and sleep aid. In the genetic engineering process, it's believed a byproduct called Peak E was produced, which may cause EMS, a rare and sometimes fatal blood disease. Although bacteria have been used for years in the manufacture of biologically active substances, only since 1975 have there been man-made alterations in the genetic structures of common bacteria. This may be the first known example of biotechnology gone awry, but even so it raises serious questions about the nation's growing biotechnology industry. Should there be more supervision? If so, should the government do it? ... FDA officials have said the growing use of genetic engineering in the manufacture of drugs and dietary products is something the agency plans to look at in the future. Let's hope the agency does this before another accident produces deadly results.

Aug. 17 New Haven (Conn.) Register on margarine: Add another memo to your ``everything in moderation'' file: Gorging on margarine, instead of butter, is not the way to stave off heart disease. A Dutch study, published in ... The New England Journal of Medicine, found that margarine contains fatty acids that actually increase coronary risk by raising blood levels of a harmful form of cholesterol and lowering the levels of a form that protects against heart disease. Doctors are quick to caution people not to switch back to gorging on butter. Butter still has a more damaging effect on cholesterol than margarine. Doctors wisely advise people, instead, to use margarine, in fact all fats, in moderation. Doctors would probably also be the first to agree that you don't have to spend a decade in medical school to develop a recipe for a healthful life and lifestyle. If we all adhered to the common sense rule of ``everything in moderation'' _ food, exercise, work, television, even anger _ we'd all probably be healthier and happier. It's excess that ruins us, not moderation.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Reservists, Guardsmen in Congress Must Resign to Go On Active Duty
With AM-Gulf Reserves, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: At least 13 Congressmen belong to National Guard or military reserve units, but they can't be called to active duty unless they first give up their seats. Any time there is a mobilization of Guard and reserve units, the Pentagon automatically puts members of Congress and other top government officials who are reservists or Guardsmen on standby. ``Their name is in a computer; that's about all it amounts to,'' said a congressional staffer who didn't want his name used. To see active military duty, whether combat or a war of nerves with Iraq's Saddam Hussein, members of Congress would have to first surrender their seats. Rep. Dave McCurdy, D-Okla., a captain and member of the judge advocate's corps in the Air Force Reserve, said lawmakers weren't likely to resign for a limited call-up. ``If there is an acknowledged war and the entire nation is mobilized,'' McCurdy said, ``I think we'll all go.'' Seven of McCurdy's colleagues are in the reserves and five more are active in their state National Guard units. All fall under federal guidelines that require officials in line of succession to the presidency, members of Congress and other key officials to transfer from ready to standby reserve status. They may participate in drills and training exercises, and collect points for retirement pensions. But they cannot be paid or activated. Rep. Thomas Carper, D-Del., a Navy Reserve commander and decorated flight officer in the Vietnam War, said he had to get a waiver from the chief of naval operations to keep flying and maintain his status as a qualified mission commander aboard a P3 surveillance plane, the type of aircraft now tracking merchant shipping to and from Iraq. ``When I was elected in 1982, I learned I could no longer hold a mobilization billet even though I'm a member of a combat-ready patrol squadron,'' Carper said. Former Rep. John O. Marsh Jr., a Virginia Democrat and later secretary of the Army, was the last lawmaker to go to war while still holding a seat in Congress. He was a major in the Virginia National Guard when he volunteered to spend a 30-day active-duty tour in Vietnam during a 1966 congressional Christmas recess. ``I got on a regular lift just like any other replacement troops going over,'' he said. ``Only a few people there knew I was a member of Congress. The agreement I had with the chief of staff of the Army was there would be no publicity.'' Since the Civil War, presidents and members of Congress alike have recognized an inherent conflict in having lawmakers who exercise civilian control and oversight of the military simultaneously serve under military commanders. President Lincoln prohibited his generals from allowing lawmakers to join them in combat after his close friend, Sen. Edward Baker, R-Ore., crossed the Potomac to take part in the Battle of Balls Bluff and was killed. Denied a leave of absence for a second tour of duty in World War II, Republican Henry Cabot Lodge of Massachusetts gave up his seat in Congress in 1944 to join the fighting in Europe. He had been granted one Senate leave, to serve in 1942 with American tank crews in Libya. But after other lawmakers _ including a then-junior House Democrat from Texas, Lyndon Johnson _ demanded ``cameo appearance'' tours, the War Department in 1943 stopped activating sitting members of Congress. ``It's a pretty basic conflict of interest,'' said Senate Historian Richard A. Baker. ``It was inconveniencing a lot of people and there was a big concern that a lot of it was being done for political considerations.'' There was also the concern that services would use reserve promotions to reward legislators for shepherding projects or weapons systems through the complex authorization and appropriations webs of Congress. ``I don't think in this day and age that you can serve two masters,'' said Rep. Bill McCollum, R-Fla., also a Navy Reserve commander.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Nationals' Fate Increasingly Uncertain
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Baghdad saying some French, Japanese nationals would be freed; King Hussein suggesting flow of refugees to Jordan may be reduced; U.S. says Kuwait embassy will stay open. TRIMS. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq, in its latest use of trapped foreigners to pressure the international community, said today it would allow some French and Japanese nationals stranded in Iraq and occupied Kuwait to leave as a ``goodwill gesture.'' Earlier today, Iraqi newspapers had warned Japan and Europe not to ``walk in the steps of Washington'' by helping the multinational force deployed to protect Iraq's neighbor, Saudi Arabia. About 731 Japanese and 560 French citizens were trapped in Iraq and Kuwait when Iraq invaded the emirate on Aug.2. Meanwhile, there were signs today that an escape route for thousands of foreigners _ mainly Arab nationals _ might be restricted. Jordan's King Hussein said his country is heavily burdened by refugees fleeing Kuwait and may have to ``slow down the process'' of receiving them. ``We have received within Jordan since the beginning of this crisis an approximate number of 185,000 people of different nationalities,'' he told a news conference in Amman today. ``We are finding enormous difficulty in meeting the needs of these people or in arranging adequate modes of transport for them to leave Jordan.'' Baghdad's latest announcement, carried by the official Iraqi News Agency, quoted Sadi Mehdi Saleh, the speaker of the Iraqi Parliament, as saying lawmakers ``decided to make yet another goodwill gesture and allow some French and Japanese nationals to travel out of Iraq.'' He did not say how many people the decision involved, nor elaborate on when exactly they would be allowed to leave. The move came as Western governments renewed their protests over Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's vow to use trapped foreigners as human shields for vital installations in the event of an attack. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain today denounced Saddam as a ``destructive loser'' whose hostage-taking reflects his isolation. The British Foreign Office said 21 Britons are known to be held at Iraqi military installations. ``This human shield policy is ... not going to work,'' Hurd said. President Francois Mitterrand of France said the National Assembly would hold an special session on Monday to discuss the crisis. He alco called the trapped Westerners ``hostages.'' ``When you are told that they may be freed in exchange for a political or military benefit, they are hostages,'' he said. ``There is no need to hide behind semantics.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said 18 Americans got out of Kuwait Tuesday but ``there are still 54 Americans missing'' _ 13 in Kuwait and 41 in Iraq. More than 3,000 Americans are among the thousands of foreigners who were trapped in Iraq and Kuwait by the Iraqi invasion of its oil-rich neighbor. President Bush has described the Americans as hostages and said he would hold Iraq responsible for their safety. On Tuesday, Iraqi authorities told Western ambassadors that citizens of seven European Community nations who are in occupied Kuwait would be allowed to leave, an Italian Foreign Ministry official said. The action would affect citizens of Italy, Belgium, Spain, Denmark, the Netherlands, Ireland and Greece, the official said. But the Dutch ambassador to Iraq denied reports that Dutch nationals are allowed to leave Kuwait. The Dutch Foreign Ministry said 147 nationals are in Iraq and 83 in Kuwait. Danish Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen warned that Iraq's reported willingness to release some European Community citizens from Kuwait could be an attempt to divide Western countries who support sanctions against Iraq and have deployed forces to the region. There are 83 Danes stranded in Kuwait and 17 in Iraq. Irish officials said today they were trying to confirm reports that the 50 Irish citizens in Kuwait would be allowed to leave. Also today, Iraqis detained about 130 Swedes, Finns and Austrians at the Turkish border after an 800-mile trek across the desert from Kuwait. The Iraqis said their documents were not in order, Swedish officials said. The convoy of buses and cars arrived at the border this morning after 30 hours of driving across Iraq, and were still waiting three hours later to cross into Turkey, Swedish radio reports said. The convoy was held up on the Iraqi side of the border because local officials had not been told that it had permission to leave Kuwait, said Lars-Olaf Lundberg, a spokesman for the Swedish Foreign Ministry. Swedish officials had said Tuesday that 250 Swedes, Finns, Swiss and other foreign citizens had been given permission to drive out of Kuwait. The status of foreign missions in Kuwait, too, was unclear. Saddam on Monday demanded the closing of embassies in Kuwait City by Friday, and a Foreign Ministry spokesman said diplomatic personnel who stayed ``will be treated ... as ordinary foreign nationals.'' Washington was making contingency plans to reduce the number of U.S. diplomats in Kuwait, but U.S. officials said today they would not close the embassy. ``Obviously, we need to maintain an essential presence to take care of American citizens,'' a U.S. official told The Associated Press late Tuesday. There are about 120 U.S. diplomats in Kuwait. They are concerned mainly with keeping track of the 2,500 or so Americans trapped in the emirate since Iraq's invasion three weeks ago. Britain and the Soviet Union already have decided to scale down their diplomatic presence in Kuwait without ceasing operations. Nine West European nations, meeting Tuesday in Paris, rejected the ultimatum and asserted their intention to remain open.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Epilepsy Drug Prevents Seizures After Head Injuries
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: A widely used epilepsy drug reduces the risk of seizures by 73 percent during the first week after a serious head injury but is ineffective after that, a study concludes. Seizures are a hazard of serious head trauma, and doctors routinely prescribe the drug Dilantin for up to three years after the injuries. However, some researchers in recent years have questioned whether this treatment works. To help resolve these doubts, the latest study tested Dilantin, known generically as phenytoin, for one year. The study ``provides convincing evidence of the effectiveness of phenytoin in preventing seizures during the first week after serious head injury,'' the researchers wrote. An estimated 500,000 Americans suffer head trauma that result in brain injury each year. About 2 percent suffer recurring seizures as a result. The study, directed by Dr. Nancy R. Temkin at the University of Washington in Seattle, was published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. It was financed in part by Warner-Lambert-Park-Davis, which makes Dilantin. In the research, people with serious head injuries were randomly assigned to take Dilantin or placebos. During the first week, 4 percent of those getting Dilantin suffered seizures, compared with 14 percent in the placebo group. However, over the next two years, there was no significant difference. In an accompanying editorial in the journal, Dr. W. Allen Hauser of Columbia University said the study ``provides answers to important questions.''

DOC.HEAD: Third Defendant Sentenced to up to 8 Years
DOC.TEXT: A young man convicted of unlawful imprisonment in the killing of a black man by a gang of whites in the Bensonhurst neighborhood was sentenced today to two and two-thirds to eight years in prison. State Supreme Court Justice Thaddeus Owens sentenced John Vento to the maximum one and one-third to four years on each count, with the sentences to run consecutively. Vento also was sentenced to 90 days on each of four menacing counts. Those terms are to run concurrently with the longer terms. ``I'm very sorry about what happened,'' Vento said before he was sentenced. ``When somebody talks about sleepless nights _ I have many.'' After nine days of often bitter deliberations following a weeklong trial, a jury acquitted Vento on July 3 of the most serious charge _ intentional murder _ but deadlocked over a second murder count and a riot charge. Owens ordered a new trial on the unresolved charges for Sept. 17. Vento is to be tried with a co-defendant, Charles Stressler. Four other defendants are to be tried later. The defendants, all young white residents of Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, are charged in the Aug. 23 fatal shooting of Yusuf Hawkins after Hawkins and three friends, all black teen-agers, went to Bensonhurst to look at a used car. Soon after the killing, Vento contacted prosecutors. He agreed to cooperate in the investigation and voluntarily appeared before a grand jury. But around the first of the year, Vento fled the city and reneged on his deal. In May, Joseph Fama was convicted of murdering Hawkins. Keith Mondello, the ringleader of the young whites, was acquitted of murder and manslaughter charges, but convicted of riot, unlawful imprisonment and other crimes. Owens gave each the maximum sentence _ 32 and two-thirds years to life for Fama and five and one-third years to 16 years for Mondello.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Royalty Hold Open Audiences
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This story was based on a pool report
DOC.TEXT: First came several Kuwaiti refugees, expressing their gratitude for the hospitality of the Saudi government. Next came a man involved in a land dispute. A short time later there was a man seeking help finding medical treatment. Another came to offer a poem. Prince Muhammad bin Fahd bin Abdul Aziz, the son of King Fahd and governor of Arabia's oil-rich Eastern Province, had time for each of them. Muhammad was holding open court Wednesday in his ornate palace, continuing a tribal tradition of being host to a daily Majlis, complete with a Bedouin royal guard. In Saudi Arabia, even the king is obliged to hold Majlis and anyone is welcome. Some of those who brought problems or praise to Muhammad on Wednesday wore gold-braided abayas over their ankle-length thobes, the traditional white shirtdresses worn by Saudi men. Other wore dingy thobes and tattered sandals. All got a few minutes of the prince's time, and his promise to look into their concerns. Watching was a horde of reporters from the United States, Europe and Japan, who listened intently to discussions of local land disputes before seeking Muhammad's view on the larger dispute that had brought them there _ the Iraqi invasion of neighboring Kuwait. The Kuwaitis, he said, are welcome in Saudi Arabia and will be housed for free, offered medical care and even pocket money if necessary. ``The Kuwaitis are like brothers,'' he said. ``Any number are welcome in this country.'' It is Muhammad's province, which makes up 30 percent of Saudi Arabia and borders Kuwait and Iraq, that will bear the brunt of the Kuwaiti influx and the thousands of American and other troops flooding into the kingdom to defend it and its oil fields. The Eastern Province would be the major prize for any invader: It has the richest oil fields in the world, the country's petrochemical and other industries and is home of a sprawling, ultramodern Persian Gulf port. Muhammad hopes aloud that economic and political sanctions will force Iraq's Saddam Hussein to pull his troops from Kuwait. But, if necessary, he says Saudis are ready to die for their country. ``Saudi Arabia will never start war,'' he said. ``We are only defending our country.'' Muhammad said the American and other foreign troops were welcome, but that he hoped they, like the Kuwaitis, soon would be able to head home. ``These friendly forces are here for a purpose and when their purpose is finished and there is no reason for them to be here they will go home,'' Muhammad said. The opening of the Majlis to foreign reporters was the latest in a series of events this past week that have given the West an unprecedented look at the Saudi government and society. The Majlis dates to the country's nomadic, tribal days and the guidance of the Koran that Moslems confer among themselves to settle disputes and make policy. There were about 100 people waiting in chairs arranged around the huge hall. After Muhammad entered, everyone shook his hand and offered greetings. Those with problems formed a line, carrying a written explanation of their problem. Muhammad tells the man seeking medical help he will have aides look into the matter. Several men with land disputes, including one who said he faces fines for building a store without government permission, get the same response. With the crowd of journalists circled around him, Muhammad tells the man offering a poem, ``We have no time now.'' After the meeting, he would rather talk about the local government and its traditions than the Iraqi forces fewer than 200 miles to the north and their impact on life in Saudi Arabia. When a reporter asks if Saudi Arabia is likely to move toward a democracy, Muhammad looks around at the local people and says: ``This is democracy. ... Saudi Arabia is improving every year. I don't think we need to change except for the better.''

DOC.HEAD: Study: House-Dust Mites Cause Childhood Asthma
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Exposure to house-dust mites during infancy appears to be an important cause of childhood asthma in places where the climate is humid year-round, a study concludes. The study, conducted in England's soggy south, found that babies who lived in homes with high levels of dust mites had an especially high risk of suffering asthma as they grew older. The work supports the growing belief that a variety of proteins from common household creatures, especially cats and cockroaches, can trigger this frequent childhood illness. It also suggests that modern home construction, including insulation and central heating, is raising the risk of asthma. ``Has the modern world gone wrong about house design somewhere so we are doing something to make houses more of a risk to children?'' asked Dr. Thomas A.E. Platts-Mills. Platts-Mills, a researcher at the University of Virginia, is a co-author of the study published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. He said that between 4 percent and 8 percent of U.S. youngsters have asthma. The problem tends to go away as people get older, but it can remain a lifelong problem. His study was based on a survey of 67 children in Poole, England. Researchers check for house-dust mites by testing samples of dust from their homes. By age 11, 17 children had asthma. All but one had been exposed to high levels of house-dust mites at age 1. The tiny mites are an unseen but common inhabitant of houses everywhere. They are especially common in places with humid year-round climates. Platts-Mills said that places in the United States where they are likely to be a problem include Florida, Seattle and Galveston, Texas. In the study, children had an elevated risk if the house dust in their homes contained 500 or more mites per gram. However, houses can have high levels of mites and still look perfectly clean. Children whose asthma is triggered by house-dust mites are allergic to a form of cysteine proteinase, a protein found in the mites' gastrointestinal tracts and droppings. In house construction, Platts-Mills said, ``the critical offenses are carpets, central heating and tight housing. If you put these three together, you raise the temperature. And if you increase the tightness of the house without dehumidification, you raise humidity and create ideal conditions for microbes.'' Wall-to-wall carpeting is an especially cozy breeding ground for mites, he said. Vacuuming fails to pick up the bugs and their droppings. Shampooing the rugs aggravates the problem by increasing dampness. He offered these tips for holding down levels of the creatures: _ Wash blankets and pillows every 10 days. _ Use hot water in washing. Avoid cold-water detergents, which fail to kill the mites. _ Use air conditioning and dehumidifiers to keep humidity below 50 percent. _ Don't vacuum rugs when children are in the room, because this stirs up the mites.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-FBI Agent Beginning Third Espionage Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with trial beginning. Picks up 3rd graf pvs: At Tuesday's ... SUBS 10th graf pvs, `But under...' to conform.
DOC.TEXT: The third espionage trial of former FBI Agent Richard W. Miller began today, as the prosecution outlined its case against the former hapless agent and his involvement with a married Soviet emigre. Assistant U.S. Attorney Adam Schiff told the judge in the non-jury trial that Miller passed a secret document to a woman who later pleaded guilty to being a Soviet spy. Miller, wearing a tan suit over his large frame, took notes while Schiff delivered his opening statement. Miller's two sons, wearing gray business suits, sat among the spectators behind him in the courtroom. A federal judge ruled Tuesday that Miller's statement to his boss that he had traded a secret U.S. document for sex and money will be allowed into evidence. At Tuesday's pretrial hearing Miller, the first FBI agent convicted of spying, said his 1984 confession was false and that he simply said what he thought his interrogators wanted to hear. ``I wanted to be honest and I wanted to be so honest that the statements I made were to the benefit of the FBI. I wanted no stone unturned,'' Miller said. But later, ``I came to the conclusion that I did not give anybody any document,'' he said. In a defense motion, Millier claimed as he had before his first trial, that religion unduly influenced his Oct. 2, 1984, meeting with his boss, Richard Bretzing, and fellow agent Phillip Christensen. Bretzing, who was then in charge of the Los Angeles office, was a bishop in the Mormon church. Christensen also is a Mormon. At the time, Miller had been excommunicated from the church. According to testimony, Miller asked the agents for their ``blessing'' during a break in his interrogation. ``I looked to Mr. Christensen and Mr. Bretzing as spiritual advisers. I looked to them for strength and clarity of all the confusion that was in my mind,'' Miller said. But under grilling from Schiff, Miller appeared to contradict the defense's contention of undue religious influence. ``When you made those statements that you gave documents to (a Soviet spy), those admissions had nothing to do with religion, did they?'' Schiff asked. After a long pause, Miller answered, ``No.'' U.S. District Judge Robert Takasugi refused to suppress the admission on Tuesday, saying he would take into account the question of religious influence when he weighs the admission as evidence. Takasugi is hearing the case without a jury. In two earlier trials Miller, a 20-year veteran of the agency, was portrayed as a fat bumbler who had an affair with a married Soviet emigre. Prosecutors said Miller, now a private investigator's assistant, became bitter and vengeful after repeated FBI reprimands over his ballooning weight and inept performance. They said he was easily recruited as a spy who passed secrets to Svetlana Ogorodnikov in exchange for sex and $65,000 in cash and gold. But his lawyers said Miller actually wanted to save his career by trying to infiltrate the KGB. Miller admits he had an affair with Ms. Ogorodnikov, but denies ever passing her government secrets. Ms. Ogorodnikov and her husband, Nikolay Ogorodnikov, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit espionage and were sentenced to prison. Miller was imprisoned for five years before being granted bail in October 1989 by the appellate court. He was released from prison in November 1989 after posting $337,000 bail. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said the jury in the second trial wrongly heard about Miller's lie detector tests.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Convicted in Obstruction-of-Justice Trial
DOC.TEXT: U.S. District Judge Robert Aguilar was convicted today of illegally disclosing a wiretap to its target and lying to the FBI with the intent to obstruct a grand jury investigation. Aguilar was acquitted of three other charges. He could be sentenced to five years in prison for each of his convictions and faces likely impeachment and removal from office by Congress if either count is upheld on appeal. A U.S. District Court jury returned the verdict after deliberating a little more than four days in Aguilar's second trial. Another jury acquitted him of one charge at his first trial in March and deadlocked on seven others. After the first trial, the prosecution dropped two counts, including an unprecedented charge that Aguilar used his federal judgeship as a ``racketeering enterprise'' to obstruct justice. Aguilar, 59, of San Jose, was appointed to the bench in 1980 by President Carter. His lawyers and supporters have accused the Justice Department of targeting him as a liberal judge who has ruled against the government in important cases, an accusation the department has denied. He was convicted of: _Disclosing to Abe Chapman, an elderly ex-mobster and a former relative of Aguilar by marriage, in February 1988 that Chapman was the s close down its embassy in conquered Kuwait, and cracks appeared in what had been unprecedented U.S.-Soviet unity in the 3-week-old Persian Gulf crisis. In the gulf, the military buildup intensified. President Bush today ordered military reserves to active duty, and the U.S. aircraft carrier Saratoga today steamed through Egypt's Suez Canal toward the Red Sea to join a growing American flotilla, a canal spokesman said. Iraq offered today to free some French and Japanese nationals trapped in Iraq and Kuwait in what it called a ``goodwill gesture.'' The move came as Iraqi newspapers urged Europe and Japan to stop supporting U.S.-led military and economic offensives against Iraq. The Iraqi statement, carried by the official news agency, did not say how many of the 731 Japanese and 560 French citizens trapped in the two countries would be freed, or when they would be allowed to go. Western nations have protested the detention of foreigners trapped in the wake of the invasion and their use as human shields against possible attack. In Moscow, a Soviet official disclosed today that military experts sent to Iraq before its invasion of Kuwait continue to work for the Iraqi government despite a Kremlin pledge to go along with sanctions aimed at isolating Iraq. Col. Valentin Ogurtsov said the 193 Soviet experts have been training Iraqi soldiers to use Soviet-built weapons, repairing and maintaining those weapons, and building test ranges. But he said the advisers were not involved in military operations and did not give advice on the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The Soviets were also slowing U.S. efforts to get U.N. approval for a military blockade, Western diplomats said. The diplomats said Tuesday that Moscow has sought clear and demonstrable failure of the U.N. embargo before approving any U.N. military force. The five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council met today to discuss a proposal to enforce the embargo. U.S. and other warships already have been shadowing Iraqi vessels. U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering, on his way into the meeting in New York, declined to specifically blame the Soviets for foot-dragging, but said he hoped for action on the matter today. One weak spot in the enforcement of sanctions has been Jordan, which has allowed shipments to and from Iraq to pass. Jordan's King Hussein said at a news conference in Amman today his country was overburdened by thousands of refugees _ mostly Arabs _ fleeing Iraq and Kuwait via Jordan. He linked the refugee problem to the sanctions. Asked when Jordan would fully enforce the sanctions, he said, ``When...we can slow traffic through the border. Thousands are crossing daily and we are trying to slow this down.'' In Washington, the State Department today announced the U.S. intention to defy Saddam's demand to close the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait by Friday, but indicated it would reduce the staff. Other nations, including Britain, have announced plans to do the same. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the decision was consistent with ``our obligations to the American private community'' of about 2,500 people in Kuwait. An estimated 500 Americans are trapped in Iraq. Pope John Paul II, in his first public comment on the crisis, today pointed to the ``the danger of war'' and offered a prayer for peace. A day earlier, the pontiff met with the Vatican envoy to both Iraq and Kuwait to discuss the situation, and papal spokesman Joaquin Navarro said the diplomat is ready to pursue any humanitarian initiatives if asked. Meanwhile, an Iraqi tanker that had defied warning shots from an American warship, reached Yemen's port of Aden today and dropped anchor near two other Iraqi ships already there. Yemen had told the U.N. Security Council that it would adhere to the sanctions against Iraq. Yemeni officials would not comment on the tanker's presence today. But the official Yemeni news agency quoted an unidentified Foreign Ministry official on Tuesday as saying Yemen did not intend to ``intercept or obstruct'' any ships. With no sign of letup in the crisis, the Tokyo stock market tumbled today. Oil prices edged higher in London on crisis jitters today, and were also up in late-morning trade on the New York Mercantile Exchange. In diplomatic activity on the crisis, Saudi Prince Bandar bin Sultan arrived in the Soviet Union, the official Soviet news agency Tass said. Also, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak conferred today with Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama on the gulf crisis, Egypt's Middle East News Agency said. Also today, defense ministers from the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council met today in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, to discuss a unified defense strategy to complement the U.S.-led military buildup in Saudi Arabia. Baghdad has expressed willingness to negotiate with the United States, but White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater dismissed the offer Tuesday as the ``same old litany from Iraq.'' He said no talks are possible until Iraq withdraws its tens of thousands of troops from Kuwait. In a speech directed at Bush, Saddam defended detaining foreigners and promised ``a major catastrophe'' if fighting breaks out. Of the 3,000 Americans trapped in Iraq and Kuwait by the invasion, 54 are believed to have been seized by Iraqi authorities, the State Department said Tuesday. Iraq says it is using some as human shields at military installations. The British Foreign Office said today that 21 Britons are known to be held at Iraqi military installations. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd denounced Saddam today as a ``destructive loser'' whose hostage-taking reflects his isolation in the region and the world. Iraq's reported willingness to selectively release foreigners from Kuwait could be an attempt to split the Western countries, Danish Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen cautioned today. That was underscored by an Iraqi newspaper's warning today to Europe and Japan, telling them their own interests would be harmed if they ``walk in the steps of Washington.'' The state-run Al-Gomhuriya warned France, Italy, West Germany and Japan not to participate in what it termed ``American occupation of the gulf oilfields.'' U.S. forces in the gulf, meanwhile, continued to grow. The U.S. aircraft carrier Saratoga and the guided missile cruisers Biddle and Philippine Sea sailed through Egypt's Suez Canal today en route from the Mediterranean to the gulf region, said canal officials. The Saratoga joins the carriers Eisenhower in the Red Sea and the Independence, stationed in the Arabian Sea just outside the Persian Gulf. A fourth aircraft carrier, the Kennedy, is enroute to the Mediterranean. More than 25 U.S. warships are in the region. U.S. Air Force Gen. Hansford T. Johnson estimated Tuesday that at least 35,000 American military personnel are either in or en route to the kingdom. In addition 20,000 sailors are aboard U.S. ships deployed in the region.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Crashes Into Singer's Gate
DOC.TEXT: A woman driving a pickup truck crashed through the gate at the home of Grand Ole Opry star Porter Wagoner and then fled, police said. Officers obtained warrants charging Glenda Kniphfer with trespassing and vandalism, both misdemeanors, after the incident late Tuesday. She was being sought Wednesday. Police said she had been ordered off the property before. ``It was an old acquaintance that he knew from the past,'' Lt. Glenn Yates said. ``She'd been drinking and ran her car into a fence and fled before we got there.'' ``It's no big deal,'' Wagoner said outside Night Court, which issued the warrants. ``If it was, I would tell you.'' Wagoner, known for sequined stage outfits, was Dolly Parton's duet partner in the late 1960s and early 1970s. He has performed on the Grand Ole Opry since 1957.

DOC.HEAD: Falls Daredevil Arrested Again
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian has been arrested for the second time this month on charges of attempting to perform a stunt at Niagara Falls. Peter E. DeBernardi, 43, was arrested Tuesday near the base of the Horseshoe Falls and charged with criminal trespass and attempting to perform a stunt on parks property, said a Niagara Parks Police spokesman. Police would not elaborate on DeBernardi's planned stunt. The Buffalo News, quoting unidentified sources, said DeBernardi had a length of rope with him and speculated that he might have planned to try repeating a 1988 stunt in which he rappelled into the gorge at the base of the falls. DeBernardi and two other men were arrested last week in Niagara Falls, N.Y., while on their way to attempt a trip over the American Falls in a plastic-foam ball. Last September, DeBernardi was part of a two-man team that went over the Horseshoe Falls in a barrel.

DOC.HEAD: Spike Lee Decries What He Says is Double Standard
DOC.TEXT: Spike Lee has denied allegations of anti-Semitism over his film ``Mo' Better Blues.'' He accused those making the charges of applying a double standard to his work. ``I challenge anyone to tell me why I can't portray two club owners who happen to be Jewish and who exploit the black musicians who work for them,'' Lee wrote Wednesday in The New York Times' Op-Ed page. ``All Jewish club owners are not like this, that's true, but these two are.'' The characters, Moe and Josh Flatbush, are a pair of penny-pinching entrepreneurs who take advantage of black musicians. Some Jewish organizations criticized Lee for using stereotypes, but the director advised his critics to examine Hollywood history if they want to see real stereotyping. ``Not every black person is a pimp, murderer, prostitute, convict, rapist or drug addict, but that hasn't stopped Hollywood from writing these roles for African-Americans,'' Lee wrote. The criticism will not change the content of his movies, Lee promised. ``If critics tell me that to avoid charges of anti-Semitism, all Jewish characters I write have to be model citizens, and not one can be a villain, cheat or a crook, and that no Jewish people have ever exploited black artists in the history of the entertainment industry, that's unrealistic and unfair,'' Lee concluded.

DOC.HEAD: Geraldine Ferraro's Son Seeks Remainder of Probation Dismissed
DOC.TEXT: John Zaccaro Jr. has been a model probationer and should be released early from probation on a cocaine-selling conviction, his lawyer argued today.
