The son of 1984 vice presidential candidate Geraldine Ferraro was convicted two years ago of selling one-quarter gram of cocaine for $25 to an undercover officer while a student at Middlebury College in Vermont in 1986. Zaccaro's attorney, Charles Tetzlaff argued that Zaccaro should be released from probation early because he is beginning his first semester as a law student at Catholic University in Washington, D.C., and would have to return monthly to New York state, which is supervising his probation. The District of Columbia won't accept any probation cases unless there is less than a year in the term. Zaccaro has been serving a sentence of one to five years on probation. But Tetzlaff said that under New York state regulations, Zaccaro would be eligible for release from probation in December. Addison County States Attorney John Quinn argued that Zaccaro should be supervised for at least another semester because he was arrested while in a college atmosphere and now he is back in that atmosphere. Vermont District Judge Francis McCaffery made no immediate decision on the request to dismiss Zaccaro from probation. Zaccaro served three months of his sentence under house arrest at a Burlington luxury apartment whose amenities were ridiculed by some who argued the former congresswoman's son received special treatment from the courts.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Up, Financial Markets Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to UPDATE with West Texas Intermediate hitting $30 a barrel, financial markets losing ground. A version moved on financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Tensions in the Middle East pushed up wholesale energy prices today beyond the $30-a-barrel level for crude oil and depressed prices of stocks, bonds and the dollar. In mid-afternoon trading today on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the October contract for West Texas Intermediate _ the benchmark grade of U.S. crude _ was up $1.30 to $30.01 a 42-gallon barrel. The September contract for unleaded gasoline gained 2.44 cents to $1.035 a gallon, while home heating oil shot up 5.79 cents to 89.50 cents a gallon. Analysts blamed the jump in oil on tensions resulting from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait earlier this month. On Wall Street, stock prices lost more ground today after an early attempt to rally fizzled out. Analysts said investors were concerned about the effect of sharply higher oil prices on the economy. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up about 15 points in early trading, was down 21.04 at 2,582.92 by 1 p.m. EDT. Declining stocks outpaced gainers by more than 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange. On Tuesday the Dow had closed down 52.48 points at 2,603.96. The downturn on Wall Street also he fighting. Bodies were put in small piles for collection. Witnesses said many of the bodies also had been ritually mutilated. They said police vehicles were attacked in Vosloorus. Overnight fighting in Kagiso township west of Johannesburg killed 20 people, police said. Xhosas fighting Zulus living in a migrant workers hostel set up burning barricades in streets to try to prevent attacks, witnesses said. Maxwell Mulovhedzi, a security guard, said fighting erupted in Kagiso when armed Zulus from the hostel attacked passersby. ``They attacked an old man with an axe and killed him,'' he said. ``After a while they attacked another two people, killing them both.'' In other township violence: _A 13-month baby was burned to death in a house that was firebombed Tuesday night in Kwathema, according to news reports. _A white security guard working for a private company was shot and killed in Soweto late Tuesday and his shotgun taken, police said. _A black police officer was killed and another officer critically injured today when two black men hurled a Soviet-made grenade into their vehicle in Soweto, according to South African Press Association. _Armed blacks also hurled firebombs at police armored vehicles and shots were fired at police patrols in Kagiso, police said. ``Blacks threw stones and petrol bombs at police. In two cases they fired shots at police, who fired tear gas and then birdshot in retaliation,'' said a police spokesman, Lt. Ida van Zweel. The latest violence raised the death toll for the last 10 days to at least 502, with hundreds injured, police said. More bodies were found in other black townships, they said, and the toll was expected to increase. The fighting erupted Aug. 12 between Zulus of the conservative Inkatha movement and Xhosas, tied to the African National Congress. The latest clashes came after government and black leaders Tuesday called for peace and an end to the fighting. Government officials also said they hoped the ANC, which did not take part in the talks, would now join peace efforts. But senior ANC leaders declined to comment. ANC leader Nelson Mandela has refused to meet with Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi. In talks Tuesday in Pretoria, President F.W. de Klerk conferred in Pretoria separately with Buthelezi and Gen. Bantu Holomisa, head of the Xhosa homeland of Transkei, to try to end the bloodshed. ``Not only must the bloodshed cease, the war of words must cease,'' the government and black leaders said in a joint statement later. ``This has often been interpreted at grassroots level as license for violence.'' The South African Youth Congress today accused police of aiding Inkatha fighters in the township clashes. The congress is an ANC-affiliated youth organization that is generally more militant than the parent group. Holomisa made a similar charge on Tuesday after meeting with de Klerk and other government leaders. Police and government leaders have repeatedly denied such charges. Holomisa leads a nominally independent homeland in the southeast part of the country far away from the fighting. He is an ally of the ANC, the largest black opposition movement, but he has no real influence outside his region. Buthelezi's supporters have been locked in a struggle with the ANC in Natal Province for the past five year in a contest that has claimed some 5,000 lives.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Says: Washington, and the Living is Easy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-7, `Top of...' with 4 grafs to CLARIFY that population given for Bremerton was metropolitan area, UPDATE with further comment. Picks up 8th graf, `Why Bremerton...'
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Best Cities-List
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Forget the 48 other states. If you're looking for good living, go Pacific Northwest, young man, and bring your friends and family with you. Four of the nation's top eight places to live are in Washington state, while a fifth is next door in Oregon, according to the fourth annual Money magazine study of The Best Places to Live. This year's poll _ done with help from a Portland, Ore., consulting firm _ _indicates West is best: the farthest east the top 10 goes is Columbia, Mo. It's not until Wheeling, W.Va., at No. 12 that the survey gets anywhere near the Atlantic. The Northeast does dominate the bottom of the list. The final five were Waterbury, Conn., Pawtucket, R.I., New Britain, Conn., Fall River, Mass., and _ at No. 300 _ Allentown-Bethlehem, Pa. Top of the list, A-No. 1, king of the hill, was Bremerton, Wash., a town of 38,000 in a metropolitan area of 180,900. ``Is that right? A year ago they didn't know we existed. What a difference a year makes,'' said Bremerton Mayor Louis Mentor, a native of the area across the Puget Sound from Seattle. Mentor's not quite right; last year, Bremerton was ranked 179th out of the top 300. But the mayor has a ready, tongue-in-cheek explanation for the sudden surge: ``They elected me mayor in November. Re-election's looking good.'' Betti Holden, executive director of the Bremerton-Area Chamber of Commerce, compared the listing to a two-edged sword. ``We're already anticipating growth in the next decade. What is this national recognition going to do to the Bremerton area?'' she asked. Why Bremerton, you ask? ``A pristine environment, plentiful jobs, low taxes, housing appreciation, arts and leisure activities galore _ plus lower house prices and reduced workday stress,'' answers Money. Bremerton's Washington neighbors fared pretty well in the poll. At No. 2 was last year's winner, Seattle, while Tacoma pulled in at No. 4 and Olympia hit No. 8. All this was _ as you might imagine _ quite pleasing to Washington Gov. Booth Gardner. ``It's not surprising that these cities are rated so high considering the degree of care their residents have for their neighborhoods and communities,'' he said. Need further proof that things are relaxed in the Northwest? Get put on hold for the governor's office, and soothing music _ like James Taylor's ``You've Got a Friend'' _ plays on the other end. The top 10, in order, were: Bremerton; Seattle; San Francisco; Tacoma; Columbia, Mo.; Eugene-Springfield, Ore.; Minneapolis-St. Paul; Olympia; Sacramento, Calif., and Los Angeles-Long Beach. Two past winners, Nashua, N.H., and Danbury, Conn., were victims of ``the bursting of the Northeast's economic balloon.'' Nashua, No. 1 in 1987, fell from 5 last year to 133; Danbury went from No. 2 last year to 66. Biggest gainer on the list: the Monterey Bay, Calif., area, which jumped from 259 to No. 50. The nation's largest city, New York, made a comeback of sorts, moving up from No. 50 to No. 28. The magazine's methodology remained the same. A sample of 252 Money magazine readers rated the importance of 44 regional characteristics on a scale of 1 to 10. The most important things to the readers were clean water, low crime, clean air, number of doctors and availability of hospitals. Fast Forward of Portland, Ore., assisted the magazine editors in assigning points to each area based on those characteristics. Mentor said his city's best characteristic is its laidback lifestyle. ``It's an easy place. I know it sounds hokey, but we're a little behind out here,'' said Mentor. ``We may be 10 years behind in the latests styles. But we're also 10 years behind in crime, in prices, in housing cost. That's something.''

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Thornburgh Aide Pleads Innocent in Drug Case
DOC.TEXT: A former top aide to U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh pleaded innocent Wednesday to drug-related charges that resulted from a federal investigation of alleged drug use by public officials. Henry Barr, who worked for Thornburgh at the Justice Department and in Harrisburg when Thornburgh was Pennsylvania's governor, is apparently the highest-ranking present or former federal official to face drug charges, said Gordon Zubrod, the prosecutor in charge of the case. Barr pleaded innocent to four counts during a brief hearing before U.S. District Judge Edwin Kosik. Barr, 47, of suburban Harrisburg, is charged with one count of cocaine possession, two counts of lying to federal officials about drug use and one count of conspiracy. He was indicted earlier this month in an investigation that has resulted in guilty pleas from two former deputy state prosecutors. After the hearing, Zubrod said he expects Barr's lawyer to try to have the indictment thrown out. If that bid is rejected, Zubrod said, the case could be heard in October. Zubrod said that while no additional indictments are pending, the investigation into alleged drug use by other public officials remains active. Last week, he gave the impression that the case against other officials was closed. Barr and his lawyer, Charles Scarlata, refused to comment on the case after the hearing. The indictment accused Barr of using cocaine at a suburban Harrisburg home on April 8, 1989, when he was a special assistant to the U.S. attorney general. It also alleges he lied about drug use on a federal form the FBI uses to check the backgrounds of people in sensitive jobs and repeated the lie in an interview with federal agents. If convicted on all counts, Barr could face up to 12 years in prison and fines of $510,000. Court documents filed in connection with the investigation show that Barr was implicated by former state Deputy Attorney General Richard Guida, who pleaded guilty last week to one count of cocaine distribution. In a brief filed earlier this summer, Guida's lawyer, Paul Killion, noted that his client ``informed the FBI he had used cocaine with Henry Barr, the target of this investigation, on New Year's Eve of 1984,'' and on other occasions in 1985 and in 1987 or early 1988. The documents also identify several other people who allegedly saw Barr use cocaine. Barr's ties to Thornburgh extend two decades, when Barr was a federal prosecutor in Pittsburgh and Thornburgh was the U.S. attorney there. After a stint with the state attorney general, in which Barr successfully prosecuted defendants in a lottery-fix case, Barr served as a top legal aide to then-Gov. Thornburgh from 1982 to 1986. He followed Thornburgh to Washington in September 1988, serving as the Justice Department's liaison to the Drug Enforcement Administration and other agencies. Barr left the department in May 1989, two days after Guida learned he was a target of the federal investigation, and is now a lawyer in private practice. Thornburgh removed himself from the investigation earlier this year when he learned that Barr was a target.

DOC.HEAD: Ken in Barbie's Clothing Was Prank, Not Packaging Mistake
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to CORRECT `are' to `and'
DOC.TEXT: A Ken doll dressed in Barbie's clothing wasn't a manufacturing mistake after all. It was a stock clerk's prank. A clerk at a Toys R Us store acknowledged Tuesday he redressed the doll one night while goofing off. The store fired him when he confessed. ``We always did crazy things like that,'' Ron Zero said of the antics of the store's late-night stockers. ``We'd hang dolls in the aisle or put Ken and Barbie in the Barbie house with Barbie spanking Ken.'' Carina Guillot bought the Ken doll in the Tampa store last month while visiting from New Jersey. It was dressed in a purple tank top and a lace-covered purple and turquoise skirt. The doll quickly became a national spectacle _ spoofed by Arsenio Hall, featured on ``The Joan Rivers Show'' and in Newsweek and Fortune magazines. ``Oh well, it generated a lot of excitement for a while,'' Mrs. Guillot said. The director of the store said he was embarrassed and Mattel, the doll's maker, said it was vindicated. The store clerk said he dressed not one but three Ken dolls in women's clothes. He resealed the boxes with clear glue. He said he doesn't know what happened to the first one, and store managers have the third one. Store managers say that's not true. Zero said he laughed when he saw news stories about the doll. ``It was a kid clowning around,'' said store director Greg Warren. ``We had one fellow with quite a sense of humor.'' Warren said Zero was fired for tampering with the Ken dolls and several other toys.

DOC.HEAD: Loud Music Drives Loiterers From Store Parking Lot
DOC.TEXT: It brings back memories of the invasion of Panama, when American soldiers blared rock music at the Vatican Embassy to drive Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to surrender. But this time American GIs are the target of musical mayhem as a convenience store, Hoagy's Corner in Tillicum, 45 miles south of Seattle, plays loud country-western music to keep them from loitering in its parking lot. The 24-hour store, a subsidiary of Southland Corp., which also owns 7-Eleven stores, rigged up speakers and last Thursday began playing a country-western radio station around the clock. Rocky Ford, general manager at the Tillicum Hoagy's Corner store, says the music does a good job of keeping GI's from nearby Camp Murray and Madigan Army Hospital from buying beer and food and settling down in the parking lot with their car stereos on high. ``Sometimes 100 or 150 people are there with their radios blaring rap music,'' says Ford. ``We've never had a problem with them in the store. It's when they get their food to go outside.'' With just one weekend under his belt, Ford says the music deterrent has worked. Some customers complained about the music as they entered the store, but once they're inside they listen to milder music. The idea of playing awful music _ defined as anything that people who hang out can't stand _ came from employees at Southland's British Columbia division in 1985. Now, 10 7-Eleven stores in the Vancouver area pipe Muzak mood music outside because young people go elsewhere rather than listen to such all-time favorites as Petula Clark or Perry Como, said Len McGeouch, the division's loss prevention manager. ``It's not the style the younger generation likes,'' McGeouch said. ``It's not Bon Jovi.'' ``It's a backwards way of keeping people away, but you could turn it around and say it's for the kind of people you want to attract,'' said Leslie Ritter, marketing manager for Muzak, the Seattle-based company that provides the tapes. But the Tillicum store isn't that subtle. Store managers decided to tune in to a country-western station because at the volume they wanted the mood music got distorted. Other merchants and even nearby residents don't seem to mind, or at least they haven't called to complain. ``They play it loud enough so you can hear it all the time,'' said Susan Pidarson, assistant manager of a 7-Eleven store just down the highway. ``It's really good music.''

DOC.HEAD: Jews Say Responsibility for Nazi Past Must be in Unity Treaty
With AM-Germany-Unification, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jewish leaders said Wednesday a German unification treaty must contain a clear statement of responsibility for the victims of Nazi tyranny. In recent years, Jews have warned that younger Germans may begin to shirk the legacy of Nazi Germany, where 6 million Jews were murdered. As the two German nations come closer together, Jewish leaders want the past clearly spelled out in the preamble to the treaty linking both states. ``We are insisting that becomes part of the unification treaty,'' said Heinz Galinksi, chairman of the Central Council of Jews in Germany. ``That is our demand.'' Galinski, in a statement distributed by his West Berlin office, recalled that he had given a draft paragraph to West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl on July 18. In the draft, the 77-year-old survivor of the Auschwitz concentration camp specified German responsibility for the Nazi era. Galinski told The Associated Press he was ``very disappointed'' when West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble responded by suggesting that the treaty contain general wording about democracy, peace and human rights. There was no specific reference to the 12-years of Nazi rule, Galinski said. The Nazis came to power in 1933. Schaeuble is leading the West German team negotiating the treaty with officials from East Berlin. Jewish leaders insist the passage should specify the ``singularity'' of the Nazi era and acknowledge Germans' ``responsibility to all the victims'' of Hitler's tyranny. In addition to the Jews who died, the Nazis killed hundreds of thousands of gypsies, homosexuals and others deemed undesirable by the regime. The treaty is considered of enormous importance to the approximately 36,000 Jews in West Germany and the almost 400 practicing Jews in East Germany. With the date of unity racing closer, possible East German reparations to Holocaust victims have been the subject of separate talks with Jewish leaders. For four decades, East Germany's Communists refused to pay compensation to Jews, saying that as an anti-fascist state they were not liable for Hitler's crimes. After the fall of the communists last year, the democratically elected government in East Berlin offered to pay compensation. But Frankfurt Jewish community spokesman Michel Friedman said he was pessimistic on the subject of reparations and said he fears the matter may be left unresolved until after formal unification.

DOC.HEAD: Seabrook Shuts Down Three Days Into Regular Operation
DOC.TEXT: Three days after the Seabrook nuclear plant launched into regular operation, the reactor on Wednesday had its eighth unplanned shutdown since connecting to the regional power grid May 29. The $6.6 billion reactor was running at 100 percent power when the turbine generator prompted an automatic shutdown, said plant spokesman Ron Sher. Seabrook began supplying enough electricity for 1 million homes Sunday after a five-month testing program. All seven shutdowns since the reactor was connected to the New England power grid were turbine-related and the plant was shut down for about a month in April for turbine modifications. ``Today's shutdown occurred during scheduled maintenance activities that were taking place on a turbine control system, not the turbine itself,'' Sher said. Seabrook opponents see the shutdowns as confirmation of their long-held predictions. ``We've been talking about construction problems, bad quality control, for years,'' said Sam Miller of the Clamshell Alliance. The plant took 10 years to complete _ 1976-1986 _ and its operating license was delayed until last spring by people protesting emergency evacuation plans near the plant.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf of 3rd item to CORRECT by including the words `a month'
DOC.TEXT: Raymond and Michele L'Esperance, parents of the nation's first test-tube quintuplets and three other children, have gotten financial help from the state to care for three nieces. ``We are elated,'' Raymond L'Esperance said Tuesday after it was announced in court that his home had been approved for a foster-care license. The announcement makes L'Esperance and his wife, Michele, eligible for about $1,000 a month to care for the three extra children. They had gone to Oakland County Probate Court hoping to speed up the licensing process, which began in April. The L'Esperances began caring for the 6-, 10- and 13-year-old nieces last year when the girls' parents sought drug and alcohol rehabilitation. The L'Esperances had quintuplets in 1988, believed to be the first conceived in vitro and successfully carried in the United States. Michele L'Esperance, who works in a home for battered women, said it costs more than $300 a week just to feed the family. Her husband is a Macomb County corrections officer and holds a second job in a tool-and-die shop.

DOC.HEAD: Sri Lankan Troops Advance on Besieged Fort
DOC.TEXT: Sri Lankan troops landed on rebel-held Jaffna Peninsula by ship Wednesday and began advancing on a government fort that has been besieged by rebels for the past 10 weeks, officials said. A Western diplomat said it was the first movement by government troops in six weeks on the peninsula, a key stronghold of the rebel Tamil Tigers militia. The diplomat called the move a ``significant offensive'' but said government forces were in no position to unleash a knock-out blow against the rebels. The diplomat spoke on condition of anonymity. Authorities said ships ferried 750 to 1,000 troops to a naval base in the north. The troops then launched an offensive to relieve the garrison trapped in Jaffna Fort. The naval base is about 12 miles from the 200-year-old fort. Jaffna, 186 miles northeast of the capital of Colombo, is the headquarters of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the major rebel group fighting for Tamil independence from the ethnic Sinhalese-dominated government. Government planes Tuesday dropped leaflets on Jaffna announcing an indefinite curfew and warning the 850,000 civilians there that the government would mount air strikes against rebel positions. Most civilians on the peninsula are Tamils. The curfew took effect at 6:00 a.m. Wednesday, and warplanes began bombing runs one hour later, said the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The bombing apparently was a diversionary tactic while the naval vessels landed the troops ashore, the officials said. Army commander Lt. Gen. Hamilton Wanasinghe flew to Jaffna to supervise the operation, the military said. In a statement released by his office, Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne assured diplomats there would be no indiscriminate bombing of civilians and that ``any action would be taken only after careful intelligence assessment to minimize any loss of civilian life.'' But a Western diplomat said Sri Lanka's small, ill-equipped air force ``has nothing that is able to pound Tiger positions with any degree of precision.'' At least 14,000 people have died since the rebels took up arms against the government. The Tigers, who have accused the government of discrimination against ethnic Tamils, are demanding an independent state in the north and east where Tamils are most numerous. Tamils, who are mostly Hindus, constitute 18 percent of the population of this Indian Ocean island, while Sinhalese, who are mostly Buddhist, make up 85 percent of the population and dominate the military and government. Jaffna Fort was surrounded June 11 when the Tigers broke a 13-month cease-fire and resumed their seven-year-old civil war against the government. About 250 Sri Lankan police and soldiers are in the garrison, which has survived on supplies dropped from high-flying aircraft. It was unclear whether the forces would try to lift the siege or whether the fort would be evacuated. Officials said one man in the fort was killed by rebel fire Tuesday, raising the garrison's casualties to nine in the past month. Wijeratne, briefing Colombo-based diplomats Wednesday, said he proposed evacuating the fort and handing it over to the International Committee of the Red Cross. He said the Red Cross agreed to the plan, and was waiting for authorization from the government to discuss it with the rebels.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Again Occupy University Square
DOC.TEXT: University Square, the site of a 53-day anti-government demonstration that sparked a bloody crackdown in June, was again occupied by demonstrators Wednesday. About 700 protesters cut off traffic in the square, the capital's central intersection, and pledged not to leave until their demands were met. The new protest began when a government-sanctioned rally held by the Democratic Christian Revolutionary Party in nearby Union square turned into an anti-government demonstration. University Square was blocked for 53 days by anti-government protesters until mid-June, when the police moved to clear the square. In the violence that followed, thousands of miners, responding to a call for help from the government, beat protesters and passers-by and terrorized the capital for two days. The violence left six people dead, according to an official count. Demonstrators have since held anti-government protests in the capital, but until now they were careful not to disrupt traffic in the square. State-run television reported that Bucharest Student League President Marian Munteanu, an organizer of the previous rally, told authorities that students were not involved in the current protest. In June, Munteanu was beaten by miners and hospitalized, then kept in ``preventative detention'' for six weeks. On Wednesday, the demonstrators in the square shouted slogans equating President Ion Iliescu with former Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was deposed and executed in last December's revolution. Wednesday marked eight months to the day that Ceausescu fled Bucharest's Communist Party headquarters by helicopter with his wife, Elena. The couple was captured and executed after a summary trial on Christmas Day. Also Wednesday, the trial of Nicu Ceausescu, the late leader's youngest son, adjourned after the court was presented with medical evidence that he cannot endure prison conditions. The court was expected to decide Thursday whether to free the younger Ceausescu because of his failing health. Nicu Ceausescu is formally charged with ``complicity to genocide,'' but the prosecution has largely failed to provide concrete evidence that he issued orders to fire at demonstrators during the December revolution.

DOC.HEAD: Arab-Americans Concerned About Backlash From Mideast Crisis
With AM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Arab-Americans say they've been subjected to isolated cases of violence since the Middle East crisis began and they worry that the anti-Arab mood could become far worse. ``Saddam Hussein is an international renegade. It's unfair to stereotype all Arabs,'' said Jawad F. George, executive director of the National Association of Arab Americans. ``Arabs are replacing the Soviet Union as the enemy of the United States.'' In San Francisco, a professor received a death threat after telling a newspaper he favored a negotiated settlement to the crisis. An Arab-American newspaper editor in Detroit was told in a phone call he would be killed if any Americans were hurt in Kuwait. Cleveland police shouted ethnic slurs at an Egyptian grocer and jailed him for a night after a minor dispute with youngsters in his neighborhood. A young Palestinian walking in a Chicago supermarket with his mother was hit and told to go back to Iraq. The Los Angeles office of the Arab-American Anti-Discrimination Committee received obscene phone calls. ``Whenever there is a crisis in the Middle East, the Arab-American becomes a scapegoat,'' said Albert Mokhiber, the committee's director of legal services. Mokhiber said the 1985 terrorist attack on the cruise ship Achille Lauro that led to the death of an American passenger was followed by the letter-bomb murder of prominent Arab-American Alex Odeh. Mosques were attacked after the 1985 hijacking of a TWA aircraft to Beirut. Bricks were thrown through the windows of Iranian-Americans during the hostage siege in Tehran. ``The potential (for trouble) may be far worse in this case than anything we've ever seen,'' Mokhiber said. ``The entire Arab community is going to be vilified.'' He and other Arab-American leaders said America's 2.5 million people of Arab descent already are being negatively linked to Iraq. Only 150,000 Arab-Americans are of Iraqi origins, and many of those are refugees from persecution in their homeland. ``There's obviously a potential for tarring all Arabs with one brush,'' said Ann Joyce of the American-Arab Affairs Council. ``Anyone in the field sees this as a disaster.'' Arab-Americans say TV comedians, radio talk shows and political cartoonists are creating an anti-Arab hysteria by depicting ``Ay-rabs'' as ugly, hook-nosed, burnoose-draped sheiks or terrorists. They are referred to as ``camel jockeys'' or ``sandblowers.'' One Georgia radio station sponsored a ``towel head'' contest. Other stations are promoting songs with anti-Arab lyrics. Jim Zogby, president of the Arab-American Institute, said Arabs have always been depicted in movies as sinister and lacking in humanity. ``People don't know who we are,'' he said. ``It's terribly troubling to our community.'' Khalil Barhoum of the San Francisco chapter of the Anti-Discrimination Committee said threatening phone calls received by Bay area Arab-Americans ``made them realize there's a lot of bigotry. We're all Americans and we should have a right to voice our opinions.'' But many Arab-Americans are apparently choosing to muffle even moderate opinions until the crisis subsides. ``There's a feeling of vulnerability, a dread fear that if shooting begins what is sitting under the surface will rear its head rather vehemently,'' Zogby said. Detroit, home to America's largest Arab-American community of 250,000, has escaped major confrontations thus far. ``But there's tension and paranoia and fear,'' said Sam Baraka, a Palestinian doctor and official of Detroit's Arab Chaldean Council. ``It's very inflammable here and people don't want to speak,'' he said. ``Enough is enough, we are American citizens,'' said one Washington, D.C., Arab-American woman who declined to give her name. ``We don't need to be maligned. People say `go back where you came from,' but we came from here.''

DOC.HEAD: Marriage Registrar Takes Walk Down the Aisle
DOC.TEXT: Pat Bryden has performed thousands of marriages, but Wednesday's ceremony was different. It was her own. Ms. Bryden, 58, is the marriage registrar at Gretna, the Scottish village known worldwide as the place where eloping couples crossed the English border to tie the knot. For her marriage to ex-policeman Archie Smith, however, she chose to walk down the aisle in nearby St. Andrew's Church. ``Although I've married thousands of couples over the years, I never thought it would happen to me. I'm very, very happy,'' said the bride, who wore a blue suit with a pleated skirt and a pink hat. About 100 well-wishers greeted the couple outside the church, which was filled with 200 guests. ``I was hoping for a quiet wedding, but it wasn't to be. Pat is too well-known,'' said Smith, 59. Smith's wife, Rita, died in 1988, and a few weeks later his home in the Scottish town of Lockerbie burned down in the wreckage of Pan Am Flight 103, which was blown up in flight by a terrorist bomb. Ms. Bryden, a long-time family friend, went to console him and his two children, and love blossomed. ``He needed a lot of support at that time,'' she said. ``I was there with him.'' Changing laws and social mores have made it much easier to marry in Britain, and young lovers no longer arrive breathless with angry parents in hot pursuit. The romantic allure lingers, however, and Gretna still attracts some 1,400 couples a year _ making Ms. Bryden one of the world's busiest marriage registrars. Ms. Bryden, who had never married, has worked in the Gretna registry service for about 40 years. Twenty years ago she was authorized to perform marriages, and has officiated at about 10,000. Her office is in a small building which also houses a dentist's office, and couples sometimes recite their vows to the whine of a dentist's drill. ``From a legal point of view, there's nothing special about Gretna. Couples could wed just as easily anywhere else in Scotland. But they come here for the romance,'' Ms. Bryden said. ``The village's associations with love and marriage ensure their wedding will be something different... Something to remember all their lives,'' she said. Gretna's romantic associations date back to 1754 when an act of Parliament outlawed ``irregular'' marriages in England. No longer could couples simply declare themselves married in front of witnesses. They had to publish banns _ a delcaration of the intended marriage _ and those under 21 needed parental consent. The law did not apply in Scotland, so eloping couples headed up the main road from Carlisle to Glasgow, crossing the River Sark which marks the boundary of England and Scotland. Irregular marriages were banned in Scotland in 1940 but the marriage industry flourished as a registry office was opened in Gretna. Until the 1970s, when England reduced the marriage age from 21 to 18, thousands of runaways came to Scotland. There is usually a waiting list for wedding dates at the registry office, but work has started on a new office that will more than double the capacity to 3,000 weddings a year. The registrar intends to stay at her post. ``Gretna will always be a place of romance,'' Ms. Bryden said, adding: ``I think more and more people will come here to wed in the future.'' She receives letters and cards from ``satisfied customers'' all over the world. Now that she too is taking the plunge, she joked: ``I now understand why brides get nervous as their big day approaches.''

DOC.HEAD: Italian Cardinal Luigi Dadaglio Dies at Age 75
DOC.TEXT: Italian Cardinal Luigi Dadaglio, who held several Vatican diplomatic posts in North and South America, died Wednesday at the age of 75. The Vatican said Dadaglio had been hospitalized at Rome's Policlinico Gemelli hospital for several days with a heart ailment. Born in northern Italy's Piedmont region, Dadaglio was ordained a priest in 1937 and joined the Vatican Secretariat of State five years later. He went on to serve in Vatican diplomatic missions in Haiti, Dominican Republic, the United States, Canada, Australia, Colombia, Venezuela and Spain. In the United States, he served in Washington from 1950-53. While Dadaglio was posted in Madrid, the Vatican and the Spanish government signed five accords in 1979 regulating church-state relations. Elevated to cardinal by Pope John Paul II in 1985, he helped organize activities marking the church's Marian Year in 1987-88. In a message of condolence, the pope praised Dadaglio for his ``long and generous service in multiple posts carried out with competence and dedication on behalf of the church and the Holy See.'' Dadaglio's death brings the number of members of the College of Cardinals to 145. Of those, 109 are under the age of 80 and thus eligible to take part in a conclave to elect a new pope.

DOC.HEAD: Boris Yeltsin Visits Disputed Kuril Islands
DOC.TEXT: Russian federation president Boris Yeltsin on Wednesday became the first high-ranking Soviet official to tour the chain of islands the Soviet Union seized from Japan after World War II. Yeltsin visited Kunashir Island, in the south of the chain known to the Soviets as the Kurils and to the Japanese as the northern territories. He stressed the islands should remain under Soviet control but said they should be demilitarized. ``This is a place that doesn't deserve to be given up,'' Yeltsin said, according to an account by the independent news service Interfax. The official Soviet news agency Tass said it was the first time in postwar years that a leader of such high rank had visited the islands. His visit was cut short because of an approaching storm. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev refused to open a dialogue on the disputed islands during a meeting last month in Moscow with the speaker of Japan's parliament. The small group of islands, stretching north from the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido, were seized by Soviet troops in the last days of World War II, and the dispute has kept Japan and the Soviet Union from signing a peace treaty to formally end the war.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Sailor Second to Die in Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `The Antietam ...' to include that ship's home port is Long Beach, Calif., and restore dropped words
DOC.TEXT: A 19-year-old sailor was killed in an electrical accident aboard the USS Antietam, making him the second serviceman to die as a result of the Persian Gulf crisis, a Navy spokesman said Wednesday. Petty Officer Third Class Daniel M. Jones, an electrician's mate aboard the vessel, was electrocuted, said Navy Lt. Victor Beck, a spokesman in Boston. The accident occurred Tuesday during maintenance of the ship's ventilation system, Beck said. Efforts to resuscitate Jones were made within three minutes of the accident but he failed to respond. The Antietam was deployed to the Persian Gulf as part of Operation Desert Shield, Beck said. The ship, whose home port is Long Beach, Calif., is part of the Middle East Force, a group of warships that normally operates in the gulf. The spokesman said he did not know if it had reached the gulf when the accident occurred. Jones was a resident of Wakefield, 10 miles northwest of Boston, and graduated from Wakefield High School in 1988. ``He was just a very happy kid,'' Patricia Hallinan, a school administrator, said in a telephone interview. ``He was looking forward to life. I think the service offered him an opportunity.'' The Jones family had an unlisted number and could not be reached immediately. The first servicemen to die in the Persian Gulf troop buildup was Air Force Staff Sgt. John Campisi. The 30-year-old Californian died Aug. 12 when he was hit by a military truck on a darkened runway in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting to fix category code
DOC.TEXT: Here is a transcript of President Bush's news conference Wednesday: President Bush: Let me make a brief opening statement, and then I'll be glad to take any questions. First, Secretary Cheney and General Powell have just given me a very full and, I would say, encouraging briefing on the status of our deployment to the Persian Gulf. This has been a very complicated mission, calling for precision, calling for maximum coordination with Saudi Arabia and the other nations providing forces. The process has gone smoothly, and we've now moved what amounts to a medium-sized American city, completely capable of sustaining itself, all the way over to the Middle East. And the Secretary reports that the men and women in the armed forces have performed with extraordinary ability. Their morale is high and they've accepted the challenge of their mission with extraordinary dedication to duty. And I'm very proud of each and every single one of them. And I want them to know that the American people are behind them 100 percent, supporting them strongly. And it's also crucial that everyone understand we are not in this alone. We stand shoulder to shoulder right there in the Middle East with the armed forces of 22 other nations, from the Middle East, from Europe and around the world. Secretary Dick Cheney reports an impressive alliance of multinational forces that stands behind the United Nations resolve that Iraq completely and unconditionally withdraw from Kuwait, with the restoration of the legitimate government in that country. The United Nations has provided enormous leadership to the whole world community in pursuing this objective and voting the sanctions necessary to carrying it out. And let's be clear, as the deployment of the forces of the many nations shows, and as the votes in the United Nations show, this is not a matter between Iraq and the United States of America. It is between Iraq and the entire world community _ Arab and non-Arab alike, all the nations of the world lined up that oppose aggression. And as our forces continue to arrive they can look forward to the support of the finest reserve components in the world. We are activating those special categories of reservists that are essential to completing our mission. The United States considers its reserve forces to be an integral part of the total military command. These essential personnel will soon be joining the cohesive organization required to support the military operations in and around the Arabia Peninsula and I have the highest confidence in their ability to augment the active forces in this operation. We continue to pursue our objectives with absolute determination. I might add that I talked to the four leaders of Congress today and I am very pleased that they are giving us the strong support they have been _ Speaker Foley, Sen. Mitchell, Sen. Dole, Congressman Michel. And the world simply cannot waver in its opposition to the threat that Iraq has placed on the doorstep of all nations who cherish freedom and the rule of law. Now what I plan to do is take some questions. And then I know you'll have more questions for Secretary Cheney and General Powell. And then the discussions that we've had with these two gentlemen and with Secretary Eagleburger and Gen. Scowcroft, our chief of staff and Bob Gates, will continue for a little while this afternoon before they return to Washington. But, Dick, I am very grateful to you for your mission _ successful mission. And both to you and Colin, my sincere thanks for the superb leadership you are giving the United States military, the superb leadership you are showing in working with other countries as we pursue these high moral objectives. Q: Mr. President, the Soviets have voted with us in the Security Council for the economic sanctions, but we learned today that they have 193 military advisors still advising the Iraqi army on how to use Soviet-built weapons against the allied forces. Do you call upon them to pull those people out? A: Well, I think that frankly, I'd like to see Iraq do what is civilized and permit foreigners who want to leave leave. But I'm not going to comment on that, because I don't have this information that you're telling me about. Maybe Dick Cheney can comment on it later. Q: Sir? May I just follow, sir? A: Yeah. Q: You've talked to a least a dozen world leaders right from here in the past week and a half. Have you called President Gorbachev, and will you call President Gorbachev for his help in the crisis? A: Secretary Baker talked to Foreign Minister Shevardnadze less than two hours ago, and we are in close touch with the Soviets. At this point, I can say we are getting superb cooperation from the Soviets. There may be some differences. In fact, I think it's fair to say we've been discussing some of them regarding the timing of certain further U.N. action. But I have no argument with the way in which they have cooperated, and I would expect that Secretary Cheney would agree on that point. MORE

DOC.HEAD: KENNEBUNKPORT: that point.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Could I follow on that, sir? A: Yes. Yes. Q: Talking about the U.N. _ the action that you would hope to have, the U.S. forces fired across the bow of a ship that then was allowed to continue on and is now in Yemen. Why did they not pursue that farther? Do you want to wait until you now have that U.N. authority? A: Well, you know, we feel we have all the authority we need, and the world leaders I've talked to, particularly Francois Mitterrand and Margaret Thatcher, agree that we have all the authority we need. We have been trying, and I think prudently so, to work with other countries around the world. And the more unanimity we get out of the United Nations, for example, the better. So we are prepared to intercept shipping, but where I stand now is I'm talking to my top advisors here and have been on the phone to Secretary Baker a couple of times in the last two hours talking about should the United Nations _ should we give the United Nations more time to take more productive action? And it has taken productive action, obviously. The Chapter 7 was a significant step. So I think we've made clear to the shipping that they can be stopped, and that we have the forces to stop them right now. And I believe that Gen. Powell would back me up on what I've just said. So my question is, how much more United Nations action is required? And so I'm going to continue the discussion asking for the advice of my officials here. But at this juncture, I'm not prepared to say whether we're going to insist on U.N. action before we go further. But I think the record _ the signal must go out to the world that many countries are prepared to fully enforce these sanctions, and if there's some U.N. action that will help, so much the better. Q: How long will you wait for that U.N. action? A: We haven't made a determination. I think the signal is out there as we pursue certain vessels and clearly have superior _ have the demonstrated ability to board these vessels, that we can do it. So now the question is, how much more U.N. action is beneficiary, benefits this idea of the world staying more closely together? And I might be prepared to give a little time _ speaking just for the U.S., we're only one country there, important one though it may be _ in order to get more collective action. But, on the other hand, I need more advice in terms of the logistics, where these ships are, what the signal would be if we go ahead and take action to stop them, which we could confidently do. Q: Mr. President, despite demands from the Iraqis that the U.S. and other countries close their embassies in Kuwait and remove all their diplomatic personnel, the State Department announced today that the U.S. would not do that. Why have you decided to take that course of action, and how can you possibly enforce that? A: Because the occupation of Iraq is illegal under international law, and other countries agree totally that we must not take the position that this illegal regime can shut down legitimate embassies as a result of their aggression, that's why. Q: But with Iraq in military control of Kuwait, how can you possibly hope to enforce that? A: Well, my view is let's wait and see what happens. I don't go into these hypothetical questions. I'd like to explain this because I know there's a lot of them out there, as to what I might not or might do under certain circumstances. But here _ I think most countries that I'm aware of _ and I'd defer to Secretary Eagleburger _ would agree that they will not go along with agreeing to this kind of affirmation of Iraq aggression, aggression that has been thoroughly condemned by the United Nations. Q: I'd like to ask, please, about your hostage policy. You were very firm the other day in warning Saddam not to harm the Americans, but I wonder, as Commander in Chief, sir, do you consider the U.S. has been provoked right now? A: Consider what? Q: Has it been provoked? Has the United States been provoked now? A: I don't think it's a question of the United States, I think it's a question of the whole world is being provoked by this illegal action, outrageous action. Q: Do you have a plan for getting ... A: I don't discuss hypothetical contingencies. But I would reiterate, it is of grave concern to all the countries whose leaders I've talked to. Q: Mr. President? A: Yeah. Q: Will the United States give safe haven to our citizens in Kuwait and Iraq if, in the embassies if ... A: If citizens came to the embassy seeking support and help, clearly we would do that.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: KENNEBUNKPORT: do that.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Do you have plans to draw down the number of Americans in our embassy in Kuwait? A: I'd like to defer that question to Secretary Eagleburger when I continue this. There has been talk of it. Indeed, I think we're talking about taking down some personnel, but I'd like to ask him to be a little more definitive. Q: Mr. President, how constrained do you feel by the Americans trapped in Kuwait as you make your decisions? A: How? Q: How constrained do you feel as you make your decisions by the plight of the Americans in Iraq and ... A: I think any decision-maker in the United States or in any of these countries is concerned about the lives of innocent civilians, innocent people. And so you weigh that very thoroughly against your actions. Having said that, international law, in this case the Chapter 7 sanctions, must be enforced. Q: Mr. President, you said last Wednesday at the Pentagon that part of what we're fighting for, standing for in the desert is our way of life. Part of our way of life is heavy usage of energy, much more so than any other industrialized country. We haven't really heard you call upon Americans to conserve as part of this crisis ... A: I call upon Americans to conserve. Q: Do you want to elaborate? A: No, I think we ought to conserve in times like this. On the other hand, we're doing everything we can to guarantee that we don't panic Americans and that there will be an adequate supply of hydrocarbons. But I think it is a good time to conserve, so I'm glad you reminded me of that and I would call upon Americans to conserve. And I think that doesn't mean that life screeches to a halt, and therefore I would say that. But I also think that we're going to be able to guarantee an adequate supply of petroleum. Q: Mr. President, how many reserves are going to be called up as a first step? A: I will defer that question to Secretary Cheney. Q: Mr. President, do you sense any frustration or even desperation in the recent statements we've been hearing out of Iraq? A: I certainly sense a sense of isolation. I think the urgency in these statements and the high immoderate tone is due to worldwide isolation. And I think that's very clear and I think he's trying to whip up support and make this Iraq versus the United States. Indeed, it is Iraq versus the rest of the world. And I talked to leader after leader after leader; talked at length to Helmut Kohl today, and he's been making just that point and will continue to make that point. But yes, I think there is some of that feeling, that as they become isolated from their Arab brothers _ and they are _ and as they become isolated from traditional trading partners _ and they are _ there is a sense of irrational urgency there. Q: How seriously do you take his public threats? A: The United States won't be threatened. Q: Mr. President, the other day you called on Americans for personal sacrifice, but you didn't really elaborate. Were you talking about economic deprivation or were you ... A: No, I was not particularly talking about economic deprivation. I'm think of families whose plans have been severely altered by this. I'm thinking of more of that kind of thing when I made the statement. Q: Are you preparing Americans for the possibility of war and American deaths? A: I think any time you move American forces and any time you are up against what most of the world now considers to be an outrageous violator of international law, that the best thing is to be prepared. Q: Mr. President, King Hussein today in Jordan suggested that perhaps you moved too precipitously, in his words, that if there had not been this buildup that we might not be in the situation we're in and that Saddam Hussein might have withdrawn. Was there ever any signals, anything that suggested that that might have been in the case? A: No. And the king, regrettably, did not have much support in the Arab world for that position. You recall the vote at the Arab summit. He certainly had no support for that position in the United Nations and as the United Nations moved toward Chapter 7. And I would simply remind people who hear that allegation that it isn't just the United States, it's the rest of the world. But when we are invited by a friend to help defend it against aggression that has recently taken place and that threatens to take place again, we're going to respond, and that's a good signal to send to friends around the world. And I might say, the request for support was not taken without reason. The Saudis were very much concerned _ and let me just recite the history for the American people here. He had said, Saddam Hussein had said, ``We're withdrawing.'' I believe it was on a Sunday. And they had a picture of one truck, people frantically waving goodbye to the beloved brothers in Kuwait as they went north. And at the same time, there was truckload after truckload of armor and mechanized equipment moving south. Now, we're not dumb when we see that, nor are the Saudis, nor are the other countries that are rejoicing, as Dick Cheney will tell you, in the fact that we moved. But I think it's important to keep reminding people of why the Saudis felt threatened and probably today still feel threatened.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Iraq Says Two Planes Violated its Airspace
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS three grafs on uncertainty whether reported incursion was in occupied Kuwait or in Iraq, and whether planes turned away voluntarily or were chased away, background. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Iraq claimed two unidentified aircraft crossed from Saudi Arabia into Iraqi territory on Wednesday and violated its airspace. Iraq's official news agency quoted an unidentified military spokesman as saying, ``Two aircraft, coming from Saudi Arabia, penetrated the southern Iraqi border, and ranged some five kilometers (three miles) in Iraqi airspace.'' The spokesman did not identify the planes, nor say whether they were military aircraft. But Iraq's military spokesmen normally report only on military activities. U.S. military forces, including aircraft and thousands of personnel, have been in Saudi Arabia since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The Iraqi spokesman said the overflight was reported at 11.04 a.m. Wednesday. He said the planes flew at an altitude of 36,000 feet, with their speed reported at 435 mph. In his short statement to the agency, monitored in Nicosia, the spokesman did not say if the aircraft turned away voluntarily, or were chased away by Iraq's air defenses or air force jets. It also could not be determined if the spokesman was referring to a penetration of Iraq's own southern border with Saudi Arabia or that of Kuwait. Iraq says Kuwait is now part of Iraq after its invasion and subsequent annexation. No other details were immediately available. Last week, Iraq protested to the Ankara government the alleged violation of Iraq's northern airspace by two Turkish planes.

DOC.HEAD: New Park Sues Designer of Faulty Jaws, Earthquake Rides
DOC.TEXT: Universal Studios Florida contends two rides _ Jaws and Earthquake _ haven't worked properly since the park opened in June and it's suing the company that designed them. Universal alleges that Ride & Show Engineering Inc. of San Dimas, Calif., used poor workmanship and design on the highly touted attractions. Both have worked only sporadically since the park opened June 7. Their fitful operation and problems with a third ride, Kongfrontation, have forced the movie-theme park to offer a free admission ticket for each one sold. Ride & Show did not work on the King Kong ride, which has computer glitches. Joseph B. McHugh, vice president of marketing and administration at Ride & Show Engineering, said his company will fight the lawsuit. ``We strongly disagree with Universal's claims,'' McHugh said Tuesday. ``Except for the expense of litigation, we welcome the chance to vindicate our company.'' He said the company was considering a counterclaim against the theme park. Ride & Show handled the design and manufacture of Jaws, including the design of its seven computer-operated sharks. It also was responsible for key elements of Earthquake, including the main subway train that gets trapped in a modernized version of the 1906 San Francisco earthquake. Universal spokesman Doug Binder would not comment on the lawsuit filed in Tuesday in Orange County Circuit Court in Orlando. He said Jaws, Earthquake and Kongfrontation are currently in technical rehearsal, meaning that they are sometimes in operation and open to visitors. Signs at Universal's entrance tell visitors the three rides may be closed down at certain times. For their inconvenience, visitors can take advantage of the two-for-one ticket policy that has been in effect since June 8.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Reserves
Reserves Called to Active Duty 10 Times Since World War II
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with breakdown between National Guard and Reserve forces
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of the 10 previous times U.S. military reserves have been called to active duty since World War II: _July 1950 to July 1953, President Harry Truman called up 938,379 during the Korean war. Of the total, 139,000 were from the Army National Guard, 46,413 from the Air National Guard and the rest from other reserve components. _September 1957 to May 1958, President Dwight D. Eisenhower activated 8,873 members of the Arkansas Army and Air National Guard to Little Rock, Ark., during school integration disturbances. _October 1961 to August 1963, President John F. Kennedy called up 155,800 after the erection of the Berlin Wall. They included 67,424 Army guardsmen and 23,388 Air guardsmen. _September 1962 to October 1962, Kennedy called up 10,927 Mississippi Army and Air guardsmen to Oxford, Miss., to escort James H. Meredith during his registration as the first black student at the University of Mississippi. _October 1962 to November 1962, Kennedy called up 14,200 members of the Air Force Reserve during the Cuban missile crisis. _June 1963 to July 1963, Kennedy called up 16,463 Alabama Army and Air guardsmen to Tuscaloosa, Ala., during civil rights disturbances. _Sept. 10-14, 1963, Kennedy called up Alabama Army and Air guardsmen during Alabama public school integration disturbances. All were kept in their armories throughout the four days. _March 20-29, 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson called up 4,000 Alabama Army and Air guardsmen to Selma, Ala., during arrests of Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and other blacks protesting voter-registration rules. _January 1968 to December 1969, Johnson called up 35,280 reservists following the Tet offensive in Vietnam and the North Korean seizure of the U.S. surveillance ship Pueblo. They included 12,234 Army guardsmen and 10,673 Air guardsmen. _March 1970 to April 1970, President Richard M. Nixon called up 26,273 during the postal strike. Among them were 10,845 from the Army National Guard and 1,876 from the Air National Guard.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Newsman Ward Sims Dead at 65
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf pvs, `In 1968...,' to ADD detail on Sims' career.
DOC.TEXT: Ward Sims, a veteran Associated Press writer whose career included stints as correspondent in Juneau and Fairbanks and bureau chief in Anchorage, died Wednesday in Seattle. He was 65. Sims, who retired in 1984 after more than three decades with the news agency, had been flown to Seattle's Providence Medical Center on Aug. 15 after suffering a heart attack at his home in Sitka. ``He had been doing very well,'' said his wife, Virginia. ``Suddenly things began to go downhill. He died peacefully and quickly.'' He spent his entire professional career with The Associated Press, joining the agency in San Francisco in 1950 following his graduation from Montana State University. Sims was born in Tacoma, Wash., and served in the Army in Europe during World War II. Sims became correspondent in Tacoma in 1951 and later that year transferred to Seattle. In 1960, he was assigned Alaska statehouse correspondent in Juneau, assisted by his wife. In 1968, he transferred to the Philadelphia bureau and a year later became a general desk editor in New York. He returned to Alaska to open a Fairbanks bureau in 1977 and a year later became chief of bureau in Anchorage. One of the biggest stories he covered was the 1964 earthquake that devastated Anchorage, Valdez and other parts of south-central Alaska. Sims was the AP's first reporter on the scene and he spent weeks covering the disaster. His last byline for the news service was on a retrospective article about the disaster which was published last year on the earthquake's 25th anniversary. After his retirement Sims moved to Sitka, where he enjoyed fishing and hunting and was active in the Rotary Club. He also was a writing coach at the Juneau Empire. ``He's probably forgotten more than any of us will ever know about AP style and reporting in general,'' said Carl Sampson, managing editor of the Juneau Empire. ``But it went beyond that. We used Ward as a resource when we had a difficult story. We'd call for ideas and suggestions. We called him our Dutch uncle. Every newspaper needs someone like him.'' ``He was a super writer and a wonderful reporter,'' said Bill Tobin, Sims' predecessor in Juneau and now editorial page editor of The Anchorage Times. ``He was highly respected by everyone he dealt with.'' In addition to his wife, Sims is survived by a son, Dixon, of Fairbanks.

DOC.HEAD: Vacations Disrupted as Fires Sweep Southern France, 1 Dead
DOC.TEXT: Wind-driven fires that gutted at least 22 homes and forced thousands of Riviera vacationers to flee continued to burn out of control Wednesday in southern France. In the Alpes-Maritime region that includes Nice, a 42-year-old volunteer firefighter died when heat caused the tires of his firetruck to explode, and the vehicle rolled over. Two others firefighters were injured. Further east in the Var, 1,200 firefighters and 300 soldiers battled flames that have destroyed at least 10 homes and consumed more than 20,000 acres of dense brush native to the region the last two days. The firefighters brought 150 trucks and seven aerial tankers to battle the blaze, which broke out Tuesday near Collobrieres. A nearby hamlet was evacuated for safety reasons. But the flames were still advancing on a front several miles long Wednesday, pushed by high winds. Reinforcements arrived Wednesday from all over France and more were expected Thursday as regional authorities declared a state of emergency. The situation was equally bad in the Bouches-du-Rhone region around this Mediterranean port. Two days of fires blackened 12,500 acres and destroyed 12 homes. One of the fires on the outskirts of Marseille on Tuesday forced 1,300 people to evacuate their homes. Another in the scenic port of Cassis, a popular tourist spot like all the Riviera during August, destroyed 36 docked boats and caused about 1,000 vacationers to seek refuge elsewhere. Firefighters brought the blazes near Cassis and Marseille under control Wednesday. But others broke out near Nimes, Gemenos and Saint-Jean-de-Gargulier to consume thousands more acres of brush.

DOC.HEAD: One Defendant Gets Maximum Sentence in Bensonhurst Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A young man was sentenced Wednesday to the maximum two and two-thirds to eight years in prison for his role in the racially motivated slaying of a black teen-ager by a mob of young whites. John Vento, 21, who was supposed to be the prosecution's star witness until he backed out of a deal to cooperate, was convicted July 3 on two counts of unlawful imprisonment and four counts of menacing. He's been in jail since March, when he surrendered to FBI agents in Ohio. After nine days of bitter deliberations that followed a weeklong trial, a jury acquitted Vento of the most serious charge _ intentional murder _ but deadlocked over a second murder count and a riot charge. Following the trial, Vento also was charged with second-degree manslaughter. Justice Thaddeus Owens set a Sept. 17 trial date on the unresolved charges. Vento is to be tried with a co-defendant, Charles Stressler, who's also charged with second-degree murder. Four other whites are to be tried later in connection with the killing of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins. The defendants are all young residents of the Bensonhurst section, a mainly white and Italian neighborhood in Brooklyn. Hawkins was murdered after he and three friends, all black teen-agers, crossed paths with a white mob when they went to Bensonhurst to look at a used car for sale. ``I want to say I'm very sorry for what happened,'' Vento told the judge Wednesday, a day before the first anniversary of the attack. ``When someone says something about sleepless nights, I have many.'' Outside the courtroom Hawkins' father, Moses Stewart, said: ``I don't accept his apology. ... Apologies don't mean anything for me. He doesn't walk into Yusuf's room and see his clothes. He doesn't have to look into Yusuf's mother's face and see the pain.'' Owens sentenced Vento to one and one-third to four years on each of the unlawful imprisonment counts and 90 days on each menacing charge. He ruled the two imprisonment counts would run consecutively with the penalties for menacing concurrently. Assistant District Attorney Pamela Hayes asked for the maximum sentence, characterizing Vento as a troublemaker ``who has a problem in following the laws of society.'' The unprovoked attack that Vento helped organize traumatized not only the victims and their families, but the entire city, Ms. Hayes said. Shortly after the murder, Vento telephoned the district attorney, said he was in the gang, saw what happened and agreed to cooperate with the investigation in exchange for immunity from prosecution. He voluntarily testified before a grand jury in September, but around Christmas he fled New York. When he surfaced in Dayton, Ohio, several months later Vento announced he was backing out of his deal and would face prosecution. Vento was acquitted of intentionally murdering Hawkins, discrimination and criminal possession of a weapon. The jurors were unable to reach a verdict on riot and a second murder count, which charged Vento acted with ``depraved indifference'' to human life. In May, Joseph Fama was convicted of murdering Hawkins. Keith Mondello, the ringleader of the young whites, was acquitted of murder and manslaughter charges, but convicted of riot, unlawful imprisonment and other crimes. Owens sentenced both to the maximum of 32 and two-thirds to life for Fama and five and one-third years to 16 years for Mondello.

DOC.HEAD: Experts: Stealth Could Face Toughest Challenge Yet
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's radar systems, described by one expert as a sophisticated ``mish-mash from all over,'' could pose the first serious challenge to U.S. stealth aircraft, military analysts said Wednesday. The U.S. Air Force sent 22 F-117A stealth fighters to the Middle East Monday and experts said that even with the highly sophisticated air armada assembling in the gulf, they could play an important role. ``(Stealth) is a new system and it would be folly not to take the opportunity to use it under operational conditions,'' said Don Kerr, an aviation analyst with the International Institute for Strategic Studies. The ungainly matte black jets, designed to penetrate radar without detection, have seen combat only once _ during the U.S. invasion of Panama in December 1989. Les Aspin, chairman of the House of Representatives Armed Services Committee, dismissed the use of the high-tech fighter-bomber in Panama as a Pentagon ploy to win support for the expensive aircraft in Congress. One stealth plane in Panama dropped its bombs on a hill instead of its intended target, but a Defense Department investigation concluded the accident was caused by human error. Air Force Col. Anthony Tolin, until recently a stealth wing commander, said this week that the presence of the F-117A stealth planes in the gulf could be an important psychological weapon. Tolin is now assistant deputy chief of staff of the Tactical Air Command at Langley Air Force Base in Virginia. But stealth would face an Iraqi air defense system that military analysts in London described as costly and up-to-date. ``Iraq's radar equipment is a mish-mash from all over, mostly from the Soviet Union, but some from France and China,'' said Henry Dodds, an aviation specialist with Jane's Defense Weekly. Dodds, who endorsed the U.S. decision to deploy stealth, said Iraqi radar and air defense systems worked well during the eight-year war with Iran. But, he said, the Iranian air force is small, poorly trained and inexperienced. ``The Americans are a very different matter. I suspect the Iraqis have never come up against electronic warfare before,'' said Kerr. He said, however, Western forces should not be overconfident. ``It's not a question of sophistication. What you have to remember in military matters is that the enemy only has to get lucky once,'' Kerr said. The F-117A stealth fighters were built by Lockheed Co. at a secret plant in Burbank, Ca. At $42.6 million per plane, not including research and development costs, the fighters are one of the world's most expensive. The U.S. Air Force says it has 56 of them. The stealth will operate alongside an impressive array of fighter aircraft carrying some of the world's most sophisticated electronic warfare equipment. The U.S. military buildup in the Middle East includes 48 F-15 fighters, an unspecified number of B-52 bombers, Airborne Warning and Control System radar planes, F-16 fighters, A-10 attack jets, and reconnaissance aircraft. Carrier-based air power totals at least 100 planes, while the marines are taking 150 aircraft, including Harrier vertical takeoff fighters and A6-E intruder bombers of the type used to attack Libya in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Language Detective Finds Clues to Who We Are by the Words We Use
DOC.TEXT: Some people sit on a ``sofa.'' Others may call the same piece of furniture a ``davenport,'' a ``chesterfield'' or a ``settee.'' Your word choice says something distinctive about your identity. ``The words we use and how we pronounce them make us special and identifiable as part of a group,'' said William A. Kretzschmar, an associate professor in the University of Georgia's English department who has devoted his career to chronicling the distinguishing features of the spoken word. ``Language marks us,'' he said. ``It gives us a sense of community and culture.'' Kretzschmar is editor-in-chief of two linguistic atlases that will contain the results of 60 years of research on how Americans talk in two regions of the country. The Linguistic Atlas of the Middle and South Atlantic States plots the use of language in 11 states stretching from New York to northern Florida. The Linguistic Atlas of the North-Central States covers six states from Michigan to Kentucky and parts of Ontario, Canada. The first of the two volumes is expected to published within two years, Kretzchmar said Wednesday. The atlases are part of a project to survey all of the United States and Canada to document distinct areas of dialect. The project is an extension of research performed in the 1930s and 1940s, when specially trained interviewers documented the differences in speech among people in different parts of the country. More than 1,200 people in 500 communities in the Southeast were interviewed and recorded during that period. Depending upon where you live, you mmight call a mosquito-eating insect commonly found in wet areas a ``skeeter hawk,'' ``snake doctor'' or ``dragonfly.'' And a device for carrying water might be a ``pail,'' ``bucket'' or ``piggin.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Orders First Reserve Call-Up Since Vietnam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with congressional support, inserting 2 grafs after 6th graf pvs, In a
DOC.TEXT: President Bush ordered the first mobilization of reservists since the Vietnam War on Wednesday, declaring the part-time soldiers ``essential to completing our mission'' of opposing Iraq's Saddam Hussein in the Middle East. Officials said as many as 40,000 ``weekend warriors'' could be in uniform by the end of the month. ``We continue to pursue our objectives with absolute determination,'' Bush said of the Persian Gulf buildup.'' He spoke at a news conference at his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine, after signing the order for the Pentagon to call up reservists. Officials declined to identify units that would be activated, or to say when they would be called. But Army sources said some could be called up within 24 hours of Bush's order. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, appearing alongside Bush after returning from a six-country trip to the Persian Gulf, said he would decide exactly how many reserves to call up after he meets with the military service chiefs Thursday. In a further sign of the scope of the U.S. military buildup, Bush also authorized Cheney to extend enlistment terms of servicemen. The Pentagon said it had no immediate comment on how or when it might use that authority. The call-up won quick support from the chairmen of the armed services committees in both the House and Senate. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., called it an ``appropriate and essential act,'' and Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., said the action would give military planners greater confidence in the availability of reserves in future contingencies. The last time reserves were activated for military purposes was 1968 when 35,280 were called up by President Johnson following the Tet offensive in Vietnam and the North Korean seizure of the U.S. surveillance ship Pueblo. In 1970 President Nixon ordered a call-up during a mail strike. Bush, meeting with Cheney and Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, at Kennebunkport, signed an executive order that stated: ``I hereby determine that it is necessary to augment the active armed forces of the United States for the effective conduct of operational missions in and around the Arabian Peninsula.'' Cheney and Powell had been expected to report to him that the United States was approaching a target of 100,000 military personnel in the region, said one source, speaking on condition of anonymity. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said in a statement that ``the actual number of reserve personnel to be called to active duty will depend upon the operational needs of the armed forces'' in the gulf area. While not saying which reserve skills Bush wanted to tap, Fitzwater noted that the reserves are an integral part of military airlift, food and water handling, surface transportation, cargo handling, medical services, construction and intelligence. A Pentagon statement said some reserves called to active duty would be shipped to Saudi Arabia while others would remain on U.S. shores replacing troops already dispatched to the Mideast. ``These reservists will support Operation Desert Shield by joining active duty units deployed in and around the Arabian Peninsula or by filling critical military support vacancies in the United States or elsewhere,'' the statement said. An administration official said the Pentagon expected to call up 40,000 reservists ``between now and the end of August.'' Short of declaring a national emergency, the president can mobilize up to 200,000 of the nation's 1.2 million reservists for as long as 180 days. It is up to the Pentagon to determine how the total is divided among services. ``At this time we do not anticipate approaching the full 200,000 authority provided by law,'' Fitzwater said. While taking reservists from their normal jobs may be disruptive, the Pentagon statement said, ``What must be emphasized is that those who have been ordered to active duty are vital to our national commitment in this operation.'' The call to arms for America's civilian militia is the first real test of the Pentagon's ability to field an effective fighting force since it began shifting more wartime responsibility to the reserves 17 years ago. After the draft was abolished in 1973, the Pentagon adopted a ``total force'' concept that moved many key tasks, such as supply transport, medical services, and communications, away from the professional soldiers to part-time civilian reservists. The change was designed to ensure that no sustained conflict would be fought without the use of reserves. The idea was that following the publicly unpopular Vietnam war, the White House would be forced to measure national resolve early in any future military crisis by bringing civilians into the fighting force. Reserves also are cheaper than active duty forces. With the money-saving element in mind, many in Congress have urged that even more war-fighting responsibility be shifted to the reserves as the United States shrinks and restructures its armed forces in response to the end of the Cold War. Reserves are now integral to any large-scale military operation. For example, more than half of the Army's combat forces and two-thirds of its combat support and service support manpower are in the Army National Guard and Army Reserve. The Navy Reserve maintains 93 percent of naval cargo handling battalions, and the Air Force relies on reserves to man 92 percent of strategic interceptor aircraft in the continental United States and two-thirds of its medical evacuation crews.

DOC.HEAD: Dragnet Out in NYC for 4th Try to Snag Zodiac
DOC.TEXT: For the fourth time, a citywide police dragnet was being deployed in hopes of snaring the so-called Zodiac gunman. Three previous dragnets failed to catch the gunman who killed one man and wounded three others in pre-dawn attacks between March 8 and June 21. ``I don't know whether we scared him off,'' Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli said during a briefing Tuesday at police headquarters. ``He's not a fool,'' the chief said of the gunman. ``He has to assume that we have taken certain extraordinary measures in certain particular areas. He didn't want to get caught so he went someplace else.'' The fourth dragnet was in anticipation of a possible attack Thursday. The gunman, in the past, has attacked on Thursdays at intervals of 21 or 63 days. The elusive gunman had vowed in rambling letters to police and the media to shoot eight others, claiming a victim for each of the 12 astrological signs. So far, his victims have been a Scorpio, a Taurus, a Gemini and a Cancer. Thursday was considered a key night by a task force of 50 detectives, because it was 63 days from the gunman's last attack, June 21. It also could be significant because the astrological sign of Virgo begins Thursday. Detectives on the Zodiac task force have followed up on nearly 2,000 leads, and eliminated about a dozen suspects.
