Each of the three dragnets has cost the city $25,000 in overtime. Investigators have even checked fingerprints from the city morgue against two partial prints found on the gunman's letters, in an effort to determine whether the gunman had died. If the gunman eludes the dragnet again, the task force may be reduced, Borrelli said. The gunman claims to be the same Zodiac who terrorized San Francisco during the late 1960s and the early '70s, killing six people. Police doubt that, but think he may be getting his ideas from a book about the San Francisco attacks.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Jordan Closes Its Border With Iraq Despite Refugee Flood
DOC.TEXT: Jordan, strained by the daily influx of thousands of refugees fleeing from Iraq and occupied Kuwait, announced Wednesday the closure of its northeastern border. The announcement of the midnight closure (5 p.m. EDT) of Jordan's border with Iraq came shortly after King Hussein said 42,000 foreigners escaping Iraq and Kuwait crossed into Jordan during the day. That is the largest number since the Persian Gulf crisis began Aug. 2 with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The announcement from Interior Minister Salem Msadeh said the border was being closed because of ``concern for the health situation of the arrivals and to ensure suitable arrangements for their stay in Jordan. ``Until we provide them with suitable shelter, we find ourselves obliged to close the Jordanian border for the foreign arrivals from Iraq as of midnight Wednesday.'' Transportation here is limited, and people jam air terminals, the port and highways. Mosques, hospitals, schools and other public buildings have been pressed into makeshift accomodations for the masses, many of whom were left penniless when Kuwaiti banks suddenly closed after the takeover. Jordan's Hussein said earlier Wednesday that his country may have to ``slow down the process'' of receiving them because of the strain the influx is causing. Hussein said during a news conference that about 185,000 people of various nationalities have flooded the kingdom the last three weeks. A senior security official said Jordan has asked Iraq to decrease the flow of people. The official said most of the refugees had entered Jordan through the Ruweishid border post 210 miles northeast of the capital, Amman. Many are driven across Jordan in bus and truck convoys escorted by police to the Syrian or Saudi border the same day of their arrival. Others leave through charter flights from Amman's two airports. Egyptians are the largest single group of foreigners fleeing Kuwait and Iraq. Though 54,000 Egyptians have already passed through Jordan, more than 25,000 have been stuck in the bottleneck of their only exit point, Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba.

DOC.HEAD: Markets Can't Shake Off Shock From Middle East
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `From that...,' to UPDATE with Wednesday's closing stock price. SUBS 10th graf, `Among all...,' to UPDATE with oil price passing $31 a barrel. Also moved on business wire.
DOC.TEXT: Unlike many other events that have briefly depressed Wall Street's markets in recent years, the showdown in the Persian Gulf keeps driving down stock prices weeks after it first hit the headlines. One reason for this persistence, analysts say, is its timing. When Iraq invaded Kuwait, the news intensified recession worries that were already mounting fast in the financial world. A second, more emotional, factor has been the unhappy memories the crisis has evoked of the dreary investment climate that prevailed for so long in the 1970s when trouble erupted in the Middle East. As measured by the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, the stock market topped out at a record closing high of 2,999.75 in mid-July, more than two weeks before Iraq pulled off its surprise attack Aug. 2. From that peak through Wednesday's close, the average fell 439.60 points, or 14.6 percent, to its lowest level in more than six months. Through late July the market dropped as economists debated whether a much-heralded ``soft landing'' in business activity was turning into something more disruptive. When the hostilities flared in Kuwait, sending oil prices soaring, a good many analysts who had taken the ``no-recession'' view began to switch sides. ``Iraq caught both us and the world totally off guard in its Kuwaiti invasion,'' observes Edward Nicoski at the Minneapolis investment firm of Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. ``Yet the storm clouds were hovering weeks earlier over Wall Street. ``It is interesting how the market can foreshadow real-life events.'' Among all the numbers that dictate the moods of Wall Street, the most dramatic change has been in the price of oil _ from around $16 a barrel at the beginning of the summer to more than $31 as of Wednesday. This surge dashed investors' hopes that the Federal Reserve would see enough encouraging evidence on inflation to justify adopting a stimulative monetary policy that would foster lower interest rates. It also conjured up visions of ``stagflation'' _ a term coined in the 1970s to describe a combination of high inflation and stagnant economic activity. In some schools of economic thought, these two problems were once considered almost mutually exclusive. But they came together in the oil shocks of both 1973 and 1979. Those conditions, in turn, bore a large share of the blame for a generally poor performance by the stock market throughout the '70s. The market's woes grew especially acute in the fall of 1973, when members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries declared an embargo on oil shipments to the United States. Over a span of less than two months, from Oct. 12 through Dec. 5 of that year, the Dow Jones industrial average fell from 978.63 to 788.31, or 19.5 percent. Further sharp declines followed in a bear market that lasted for another year. Many economists have hastened to declare that today's situation differs greatly from the setting in which those events unfolded. For one thing, they say, industrial countries have markedly reduced their relative reliance on oil to fuel their economies. For another, world politics have changed dramatically, so that a nation such as Iraq in a militant position cannot readily play communist and capitalist powers off against each other the way it once might have done. Nevertheless, say some analysts, the stock market cares most about economics, and it is now groping for a new level that reflects a gloomier outlook for investors, consumers, workers and business planners. ``The economy continues to limp along the edges of recession,'' said David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International in New York. ``The Mideast crisis and all its ramifications reinforced the emerging consensus that things are more likely to get worse before they get better.''
EDITOR's NOTE: Chet Currier has covered the stock market for the AP since 1974.

DOC.HEAD: Hussein Warns of Escalation in Conflict, Announces New Mission
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New thruout to recast lead, UPDATES with Jordan announcing closing of border because of flood of foreigners. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: King Hussein warned Wednesday that any escalation of Persian Gulf conflict could have a ``devastating effect'' and said he will embark on a new round of talks with Arab leaders to defuse it. ``I still believe there is a chance to resolve the problem,'' Hussein said at a news conference. The king also told reporters the flood of refugees entering Kuwait from Iraq and Kuwait had severely strained Jordan's resources. Hours later, Jordan announced that because of the influx, it was closing its northeastern border with Iraq, shutting one of the few escape routes left for foreigners fleeing that country. The closure took effect at midnight (5 p.m. EDT), according to a government announcement. Hussein hinted at the closure during his news conference, saying the influx of refugees since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait was so great Jordan may have to ``slow the process.'' Speaking in the palace to a room crowded with journalists, Hussein said he believed ``we are almost facing a crisis of the world gone mad.'' He declined to say where he would go or with whom he would meet when he begins his new peace mission. Published reports say the king's position revolves around three principles _Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, restoration of the Kuwaiti ruling family to power, and negotiations in an ``Arab context'' to resolve the Iraq-Kuwait dispute. About 200 Jordanian women carrying banners and singing patriotic songs marched on the U.S. Embassy on Wednesday, demanding the United States withdraw its troops from Saudi Arabia and lift the economic embargo on Iraq. Such protests, an almost daily occurrence in Jordan, reflect the predominantly pro-Iraqi feeling of Jordanians, half of whom are either of Palestinian origin or from the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. In part because of popular sentiment in favor of Iraq, King Hussein has still not committed himself fully to upholding U.N. sanctions against Iraq. Another consideration is that Jordan depends heavily on trade with its neighbor through the Red Sea port at Aqaba. Sanctions would add to the kingdom's economic woes. Asked whether he was siding with his close ally, Iraq, or with the United States in the conflict, he said: ``My country is not siding with anyone but itself and with the Arab people and its hopes and aspirations.'' Any escalation of the conflict ``would have a devastating effect on this region and the world,'' he said. The king added that he did not believe Iraq planned further expansion. ``I believe that as far as you can tell, Iraq is holding a fully defensive posture and I have the impression that the Arab forces arrayed against Iraq in the area are in a defensive posture,'' Hussein said. Hussein said his country was seeking to clarify with the United Nations what trade with Iraq is barred by the U.N. resolution ordering sanctions against Iraq. ``There is an area of ambiguity that we have been trying to clarify with the U.N. as to what an embargo means, what is permitted to flow and what is not permitted to flow. And hopefully this will be clarified,'' he said. Pressed by reporters about what trade might be conducted under the sanctions, he replied: ``I don't know ... medicines, foodstuffs, these details are not clear.''

DOC.HEAD: Peace Talks Deadlock, Salvadoran Rebels Warn of Violence
DOC.TEXT: Salvadoran government and guerrilla negotiators ended six days of U.N.-mediated peace talks on Wednesday deadlocked in what one participant called ``a dialogue of the deaf'' over the future of the military. Each side accused the other of intransigence. Rebel chiefs said the stalemate made escalation of the war imminent. Another round was set for Sept. 13 in San Jose. The two sides agreed this year to pursue accords permitting a mid-September cease-fire. U.N. mediator Alvaro DeSoto acknowledged, as delegation members did earlier, that absence of agreement here made that virtually impossible. Rebel delegate Salvador Samayoa said, ``Escalation of military action is almost inevitable as a result of the government's intransigence and the absence of progress. ``We're speaking two different languages. It is a dialogue of the deaf.'' Francisco Mena, a senior guerrilla field commander, said, ``The picture is this: we're getting nowhere in negotiations, so let's have at it with the irons.'' The Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, the insurgent army known as the FMLN, submitted an 18-point document. The first demand is for ``total demilitarization of society, by means of disappearance of the two armies.'' The conservative administration of President Alfredo Cristiani, backed by the United States, says it is willing to ``restructure,'' reform and reduce the armed forces, but not to abolish them. Justice Minister Oscar Santamaria, the chief government delegate, characterized the rebel position expressed in San Jose as ``a setback'' from the position advanced last month. Army Col. Mauricio Vargas, also a government negotiator, termed the new document ``a low blow.'' The nearly 11-year-old civil war has killed an estimated 72,000 people, most of them civilians. The FMLN insists that military impunity for widespread violation of human rights end. International rights organizations have blamed the military and military-linked death squads in the deaths of up to 30,000 suspected opponents in the past 10 years. But not one officer has been tried for such a crime. The rebels demand a purge of the high command to ensure subordination to civilian authority and guard against abuses by a reformed security force. The FMLN proposes that a civilian-led police force be created to take the place of the army, following the lead of Costa Rica. Costa Rica abolished its army in 1949. It is the only Central American land that has enjoyed peace, relative prosperity and democracy in recent decades. In previous talks, the rebels demanded trial and punishment of officers implicated in four notorious human rights cases, including the 1980 assassination of Archbishop Oscar Romero and last November's massacre by soldiers of six Jesuit priest-educators, their housekeeper and her daughter. The new document adds demands for punishment of those responsible for two other cases, and for ``murders, massacres and bombardments of civilians that have occurred during the negotiation.'' It seeks investigations to determine responsibility for 20 other specific crimes in addition to ``all the crimes, murders, disappearances and massacres committed since 1979.'' ``Our position may appear to be maximalist. But this is what is needed to create a new society,'' said Mena, a former army captain who switched sides in 1981. The rebels last November launched the war's biggest offensive and say they are prepared to make another major military push. Rebel sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, say they are now better prepared to counter government air power because they have acquired dozens of anti-aircraft missiles. The insurgents say they bought the missiles on the black market. Army and Western intelligence sources suspect at least some of the missiles were provided by Sandinista military commanders in Nicaragua, or donated by Cuba. This was the fourth round of talks that began in Venezuela in May. Negotiations to date produced one accord _ on human rights _ signed last month.

DOC.HEAD: No Joke _ Bart Simpson Seeking Office
DOC.TEXT: It's no joke: Texas voters may get a chance to put Bart Simpson in the Legislature. It isn't Bart Simpson, the underachieving cartoon character. It's Bart Simpson the 24-year-old businessman. Businessman Bart told Bexar County Republican Party officials this week he'd like to run for the District 115 House seat. Nobody entered the GOP primary last spring for the seat, long held by Democrats. Party officials are checking to see if they can nominate a candidate for the general election. Bart, the would-be politician, quips his campaign might get a boost from Bart, the star of TV's ``The Simpsons.'' ``I do have a name that people would recognize,'' said Simpson, who works for a company that makes construction loans. But he hastened to add: ``I've wanted to be a state representative since I was in high school.'' Simpson said he's unsure how he'd list his name on the ballot. ``I've gone by Bart my entire life,'' he said, but added that he might adopt his full name, Barton, to head off cowabunga gibes. Steven Heinrich, executive director of the Bexar County Republican Party, said Simpson almost got laughed off the line when he called party officials Monday to say he was interested in running. ``Everyone thought it was a joke,'' Heinrich said. But the party is taking Simpson seriously, at least some of the time. ``If the Democrats can put up Gene Kelly, we can run Bart Simpson,'' said Heinrich. The Gene Kelley who isn't a dancer is a San Antonio lawyer _ and the surprise winner of the Democratic primary for a Texas Supreme Court nomination.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Military Experts Still Working In Iraq
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Soviet military experts continue to train Iraqi soldiers to use their Soviet-built weapons three weeks after Moscow cut weapons supplies to protest the invasion of Kuwait, officials said Wednesday. The revelation appeared to open cracks in what had been unprecedented U.S-Soviet unity in the 3-week-old Persian Gulf crisis. Col. Valentin Ogurtsov said 193 unarmed military experts were finishing their ``contractual obligations'' to show Iraqis how to use state-of-the art tanks, jet fighters and missiles, and to maintain and repair the hardware. Ogurtsov and Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh insisted the experts were not advising President Saddam Hussein's government and were not involved in military operations. Since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Gremitskikh has maintained he did not know what the military experts were doing in the Arab nation. Confirmation they were still working came only hours after Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov ordered all Soviet agencies to sever commercial ties with Iraq to comply with U.N. sanctions. The Soviet Union sold more than half the weapons Baghdad bought between 1982 and 1989. The day after the invasion of Kuwait, the Soviet Union halted arms supplies to Iraq, its long-time ally, and Ogurtsov said Wednesday one shipment was stopped in transit. On the same day, Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and Secretary of State James A. Baker III signed a rare joint statement condemning Iraq's attack on its oil-rich neighbor. But the revelations Wednesday, and reports from the United Nations that the Soviets were slowing efforts to get U.N. approval for military force to enforce economic sanctions, appeared to undercut the initial appearance of unity. At a news conference in Kennebunkport, Maine, President Bush said he was not familiar with the report on the Soviet military advisers. He said he had no argument with the Soviet response to the Persian Gulf crisis. ``At this point, I would say we are getting superb cooperation from the Soviets,'' Bush said. In Moscow, meanwhile, Gremitskikh and Ogurtsov fended off questions for more than an hour about whether the military experts' continuing work violated the U.N. economic embargo or the Soviet order. ``Don't single out the Soviet Union,'' Gremitskikh said. ``I don't think this presence of a very small number of military and technical experts ... runs counter to the United Nations' position.'' He said nationals from other countries continued to work in Iraq but did not identify their professions or their countries. Gremitskikh said that when the contracts expire, the military experts will leave and will not be replaced. Ogurtsov said the contracts ranged from 10 days to one year. The colonel said that when the Soviet government contracted to sell weapons to Iraq, it also agreed ``we would send technical experts to help the Iraqi military to learn how to use the arms supplied.'' ``We supply the new type of weapons, and if the local personnel is not acquainted with such a weapon, our expert goes there and teaches the method of using that type of weapon,'' he said. ``At the present time, they work not only in training centers, but on test ranges. Suppose we supplied a new type of tank. It has new, unknown capabilities to the local personnel, so we build a kind of test range to test it. ... This is the kind of activity they are involved in.'' Ogurtsov, asked why military experts were not recalled as part of the Soviet arms embargo, said: ``It's not for me to say. ... The decisions are taken not by us, but at the political level.'' The military experts were among 7,791 Soviets stranded in Iraq, which closed its borders after the invasion. In all, 21,000 foreigners were caught in Iraq and Kuwait, including 3,000 Americans, who have not been allowed to leave. Gremitskikh said Soviet women and children would begin to be evacuated on Sunday, after the last of the 882 Soviets caught in Kuwait had left. He suggested Iraq would then allow Soviet men to leave. The Soviets have not said how many of the 7,791 are men. Ogurtsov said many of the civilians were involved in oil drilling, research and other aspects of the oil industry. The Foreign Ministry has said the figure includes workers in energy and other industries, businessmen, diplomats and their dependents. It has denied reports that the Soviet Union has thousands of military advisers in Iraq. Also Wednesday, a special envoy from Saudi Arabia arrived in Moscow, carrying a letter for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The two countries do not have diplomatic relations. Prince Bandar bin Sultan, the Saudi ambassador to Washington, was instrumental in establishing diplomatic relations between Saudi Arabia and China. His arrival follows the visit of Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister Saadoun Hammadi, who met with Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze on Monday and Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: More Heavy Rain In Eastern Half Of Nation
DOC.TEXT: A slow-moving weather system continued to drop rain into already sodden ground from the Ohio Valley into the middle Atlantic states Wednesday. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered from the southern Ohio Valley to northern Florida and the central Gulf Coast Wednesday afternoon, while showers extended across the middle Atlantic Coast states. Up to 2 inches of rain fell Wednesday in parts of West Virginia, forcing some evacuations in Wayne County. Minor flooding also occurred in parts of Lincoln and Wood counties. Floods were possible in southeastern Ohio, and the mountains and northern foothills of North Carolina. In western North Carolina, Asheville was soaked with 4.55 inches of rain during the 24 hours up to 8 a.m. EDT Wednesday, and Piketon, Ohio reported 2.47 inches. Showers and thunderstorms formed during the afternoon over the southern Rockies and the central High Plains region. A few showers and thunderstorms were over the western Gulf Coast region, southern Arkansas and southeast Oklahoma, and western Iowa. Mostly sunny skies allowed temperatures to soar into the 90s Wednesday afternoon in the southern Plains and the lower Mississippi Valley, while showers kept readings in the 60s along middle Atlantic Coast. Mild weather prevailed across the Northwest with temperatures mostly in the 60s and 70s at midday. Readings soared into the 90s and above 100 degrees in the desert Southwest, and sunny skies allowed temperatures to warm very rapidly in the Great Basin. Ely, Nev., which tied Truckee, Calif., as cold spot in the Lower 48 states with a morning low of 34 degrees, was up to 70 by midday. Temperatures dipped into the 50s from the upper Mississippi Valley to New England, with morning lows in the 40s in northern Michigan and northern New England. Temperatures also dipped into the 40s and 50s in the Rocky Mountain and Colorado Plateau region, with readings in the 30s reported at some locations.

DOC.HEAD: Gingrich, Abandoning Bush, Calls for Tax Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Newt Gingrich, the No. 2 House Republican, parted with the Bush administration Wednesday in saying he will propose a tax-cut package when budget talks resume next month. Gingrich renewed his criticism of the idea of raising some taxes to fight the federal deficit, a concept President Bush accepted last June in a reversal of his oft-repeated opposition to new taxes. Gingrich, R-Ga., said that with a weakening U.S. economy threatened even further by the Persian Gulf crisis, the priority for budget bargainers should be to adopt policies that would help the country avoid a recession. ``I'd find it very hard to understand an argument for a tax increase in the face of a weak economy,'' Gingrich told reporters. He said that tax cuts stimulating the economy must be part of any deficit-reduction package. Gingrich, one of the budget negotiators, also criticized Democrats in general and Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, in particular in connection with the budget talks. He cited Democratic failure to propose a deficit-reduction plan at this year's budget negotiations and the opposition of many Democratic lawmakers to Bush's effort to cut the capital gains tax rate. ``They're following a strategy of taking the risk that Americans will be put out of work for the political advantage of the Democratic Party,'' Gingrich said. He said there is now a danger of a recession, ``which frankly I believe Senator Mitchell has frankly been planning for and which I think his behavior has clearly helped lead to.'' A spokeswoman for Mitchell declined to comment on Gingrich's remarks. White House officials and congressional leaders have been trying to hammer out a package of $50 billion in tax increases and spending cuts for next year and $500 billion over five years. Their negotiations, which started in May, have produced no agreements. The bargainers plan to resume their efforts as Congress returns from recess next month. Gingrich said he was considering a package of tax cuts worth perhaps $10 billion to $15 billion that he will propose when budget talks resume next month. ``It will be clearly, dramatically less expensive than a recession,'' Gingrich said of the tax-cut package. He said the proposal may include reducing the capital gains tax rate, providing tax breaks for first-time home buyers, and dramatically boosting the personal exemption allowed on income tax. He is also considering proposing cutting the Social Security payroll tax, setting up new IRAs, and providing more tax breaks for manufacturers, he said. The lawmaker said he was discussing his plan with other Republicans and with the White House.

DOC.HEAD: Four US Minesweepers Heading for Middle East
DOC.TEXT: Four U.S. Navy minesweepers are being sent to the Middle East as part of the military operation to defend Saudi Arabia, the Pentagon said Wednesday. USS Adroit, USS Leader, USS Avenger and USS Impervious will be taken to the Persian Gulf area aboard the commercial ship Super Servant Three. The Pentagon also said elements of Headquarters 3rd U.S. Army at Fort McPherson, Ga., have begun deploying to the Middle East. The 3rd Army is responsible for contingency planning as well as command and control of all Army units in the Middle East. No other details were provided.

DOC.HEAD: Lingerie-Clad Marchers Protest Repression
DOC.TEXT: Marchers clad in skimpy lingerie marched through the capital Wednesday, demanding the city be declared an ``erotic play zone'' free of ``repressive'' laws requiring clothing. Carrying with banners bearing slogans such as ``Lace Makes Men Sexy,'' the 12 men and three women marchers shouted ``bodies are beautiful'' and ``look who's wearing costumes here.'' Parade organizer Fred Wagforth _ dressed in white panties, a garter and fishnet stockings _ urged the 400 spectators to ``take off their clothes'' and ``be all genders now.'' ``Society creates authoritarian dualism between males and females. We want to experiment with gender roles and open up new terrain for ourselves,'' Wagforth said. A ``lingerie liberator'' clad in a women's slip and lace jacket challenged men in the audience to prove they weren't wearing men's underwear by taking off their pants. A spectator, moved by Wagforth's statement, stripped to his underwear and joined the throng, saying marching would allow him to ``get a better tan.'' ``I think it's a fun idea. I think people are afraid of their bodies,'' Don Peterson said. Besides the demand for an erotic zone, Wagforth told city officials that police should carry sexual accessories rather than weapons. ``People need to stop the repressive institution of democracy in America,'' Wagforth said. Two men, one dressed in a women's bra and panties and another in a lace outfit led the march, carrying a sign that said ``March for erotic action. Take your desires for reality.'' About 20 police officers monitored the event, directing traffic and following the group as they marched on the sidewalks and shouted to observers to take off their clothes and join them. A few people snapped pictures as the group passed. Duane Tessmer, who watched from the sidelines, said he thought the group had a statement to make, but were ``going about it the wrong way.'' ``They're screwed up. They're doing this for their own greed of walking around in clothes like that,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman's Husband, Sons in Gulf Conflict
DOC.TEXT: Donnita Cole knows how to wait. She has acquired the art of patience through three decades of fearing for her husband, an overseas oil worker familiar with quamires like the one that has trapped him in the Middle East. Since the 1960s, John Cole of Odessa, Texas, has endured a coup in Libya, an attempted coup in Indonesia, two Nigerian revolutions and one in Iran. Now the 50-year-old employee of Houston-based OGE Drilling Co. is among about 3,000 U.S. citizens detained three weeks after Iraq's Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The Persian Gulf crisis is for the Cole family yet another in a string of crises. ``He's not an adventurer. He's just trying to make the best living he knows how to for me and the kids,'' Mrs. Cole, 48, said in a telephone interview Wednesday from Odessa. And there's more. While Mrs. Cole is wearing a yellow ribbon for her missing husband, she is also flying an American flag in front of her home as a reminder of family members on military standby. Her 22-year-old twin sons, both Army combat specialists, and a son-in-law with the Air Force are waiting to find out whether they'll be sent to the gulf. One of the sons, whose names Mrs. Cole won't reveal, was sent with the U.S. troops to Panama in December. ``We've never really thought about it, but we have not led a dull life,'' Mrs. Cole said. ``But as far as going out and looking for excitement, we haven't. It's just that it's happened to us.'' During the Iranian revolution, Cole escaped from an offshore rig by boat and ended up in Bahrain. Mrs. Cole, who was living in Malta, spent nine days without word from her husband, listening to tales of atrocities from fleeing refugees. That decade-old experience helped prepare her for this one, she said. ``It hasn't made it easier, but it's helping me handle it better. It is never easy to handle anything like this,'' she said. ``You learn how to wait. And I am not a patient person _ not at all.'' Mrs. Cole was planning to join her husband in Kuwait Aug. 15. Instead, she is waiting for news from her husband. A network of families with relatives either deployed or held in the Middle East are helping her sort through fears, both as a hostage's wife and as a military mother. ``I think two different sets of thoughts. Sometimes they fit together, and sometimes they don't,'' she said. But for now, she said, the whole family is focusing on seeing John Cole come home. She said even one of her two daughters, whose husband is on standby in the Air Force, is preoccupied first with her father's welfare. ``Right now she's just worried about her daddy. We're just taking it one step at a time,'' Mrs. Cole said. ``Of course she's worried about her husband and her brothers. But right now, they're not there yet. We don't mean to be unfeeling, but we've got to have our worry priorities in order.''

DOC.HEAD: Jordan Closes Border With Iraq to Curb Refugee Flow
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Jordan closing border with Iraq, record number of refugees arriving Wednesday, ADDS quotes from King Hussein, details. Edits to trim. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jordan closed its border with Iraq at midnight Wednesday as the country found itself unable to handle the flood of tens of thousands of refugees fleeing Iraq and Kuwait. The announcement of the border closure came just hours after King Hussein told a nationally televised news conference that 42,000 foreigners had entered Jordan on Wednesday _ the largest number of arrivals in a single day since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Interior Minister Salem Masdeh said Jordan's northeast border with Iraq would close at midnight Wednesday (5 p.m. EDT). Msadeh said the border was being closed because of ``concern for the health situation of the arrivals and to ensure suitable arrangements for their stay in Jordan.'' ``Until we provide them with suitable shelter, we find ourselves obliged to close the Jordanian border for the foreign arrivals from Iraq as of midnight Wednesday,'' he said. At his nationally televised news conference, King Hussein said his country is heavily burdened by the flood of refugees. ``On the human level we have some serious problems,'' the Jordanian monarch said. ``We may have to slow down the process of receiving more people unless we can speed up the movement of people to their respective destinations,'' Hussein said. ``We are trying our very best to provide food and shelter and medical facilities.'' The number of arrivals Wednesday easily exceeded the huge influx of 30,000 foreigners who entered Jordan on Friday. A Jordanian security official said most of the refugees had arrived in the last 10 days. Hussein said about 185,000 refugees have crossed into Jordan since Aug. 2, and only 67,000 of them have moved on to other destinations. The overwhelming majority of arrivals have been Arab and Asian nationals, about 40 percent of them Egyptians. Of the nearly 120,000 refugees who remain in Jordan, he said: ``We are finding enormous difficulty in meeting the needs of these people or in arranging adequate modes of transport for them to leave Jordan.'' Transportation is limited in this poor country, and people jam air terminals, the port of Aqaba and highways. Mosques, hospitals, schools and other public buildings have been pressed into makeshift accommodations. Hussein said six refugees have died in Jordan _ two adults and four children _ but he did not say how they died. Security officials earlier had said a number of people died of heat exhaustion or sunstroke after the arduous overland journey through the desert from Kuwait and Iraq. A senior security official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Jordan has asked Iraq to decrease the flow of people. The official said most of the refugees had entered Jordan through the Ruweishid border post 210 miles northeast of Amman. Many of the refugees were left penniless when Kuwaiti banks suddenly closed after the Aug. 2 takeover. ``I have spent 12 years of my life working in Kuwait and saving my money for the future, and I ended up losing all of it,'' said Ahmad Mohammad Saleh, a laborer from Yemen who was staying at a mosque. ``All my efforts and hard work were wasted,'' he said in tears. Many are driven across Jordan in bus and truck convoys escorted by police to the Syrian or Saudi border the same day of their arrival. Others leave through charter flights from Amman's two airports. Egyptians are the largest single group of foreigners fleeing Kuwait and Iraq. Though 54,000 Egyptians have already passed through Jordan, more than 25,000 have been stuck in the bottleneck of their only exit point, Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba. They are waiting in cars and buses or under the blazing desert sun for space on the Egyptian ferries that can handle only about 3,000 people daily. Egyptian Ambassador Mahab Muqbel said Wednesday his government had begun an airlift to relieve the congestion and would increase the number of ferries. Israel offered to allow Egyptians overland passage from Aqaba through a 10-mile strip of Israeli territory. The strip forms a wedge at the top of the gulf of Aqaba between Jordanian and Egyptian land. Egypt rejected the offer. The congestion at Aqaba is duplicated on a smaller scale in some parts of the capital. Hotels in Amman are full, the airport is jammed and the embassies of most Asian and African countries are besieged. The minister of religious affairs, Ali Faqir, ordered all mosques in the country to provide shelter and food for the foreigners. Jordanian charitable organizations are distributing thousands of free meals. The security official said in an interview that government records showed that 193 American citizens as well as 38 Britons had crossed at Ruweishid since Aug. 7. He said almost all were Arabs with dual nationality. The Iraqi government is preventing the departure of an estimated 20,000 Westerners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait and intends to use them to deter possible attacks on strategic points such as military installations.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Calls Moscow On Gulf Situation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate grag, bgng: The Soviets xxx to CORRECT spelling of Hammadi.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: From his vacation retreat in Wyoming, Secretary of State James A. Baker III sought the help of the Soviet Union Wednesday in enforcing a worldwide economic blockade of Iraq. The response he got from Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on the telephone was a request for a slowdown at the United Nations, U.S. officials told The Associated Press. But, they said, Shevardnadze did not threaten a Soviet veto or any other means to stop the United States from seeking approval of a military blockade. In fact, the officials said, the Soviets are using their close ties to Iraq to urge the release of Westerners, including Americans, trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. In any event, the Bush administration asserts it already has legal authority to enforce the embargo _ with or without a new U.N. resolution. The Security Council, by a vote of 13-0, approved the embargo Aug. 6 and by unanimous vote on Aug. 9 declared Iraq's annexation of Kuwait ``void.'' Baker went to Wyoming on vacation last week, leaving Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger in charge at the State Department. The veteran U.S. diplomat was at the White House Sunday night advising President Bush on the Gulf crisis and again was at his side Wednesday in Kennebunkport, Maine. At the same time, Baker has kept a hand in. He talks frequently to Bush by telephone as well as to other senior officials, including Brent Scowcroft, the president's national security adviser. The Soviets supported Bush from the outset on economic sanctions as a way of trying to compel Iraq to reverse its occupation of Kuwait. Bush on Wednesday described Soviet cooperation as ``superb.'' State Department spokesman Richard Boucher on Tuesday called it ``excellent.'' Soviet support is critical. As a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council the Soviets could block any resolution with a veto. And Moscow has had a long and warm relationship with Iraq. Even though the Soviets ordered a cutoff in weapons shipments, Soviet military experts continue to train Iraqi soldiers in using Soviet-manufactured weapons. U.S. officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Moscow had given Washington assurances no advisers had assisted the Iraqis in their assault on Kuwait. And yet, the officials said, the Soviets gave the same assurances about Iraq's eight-year war with Iran and still were detected within range of the fighting. The topic did not come up in Baker's conversation with Shevardnadze, they said. Instead, they talked mostly about the situation at the United Nations. The Soviets want to let a certain period of time to pass before adopting a resolution calling for a military blockade, the officials said. One reason is the presence in Moscow of a senior Iraqi diplomat, Deputy Prime Minister Sadun Hammadi. He has met with Shevardnadze, Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov and Igor Belonsov, who is overseeing the evacuation of Soviet citizens from the Gulf. The Soviets would like to wait at least until Hammadi concludes his visit before approving a military blockade, the officials said. ``I don't think we are in serious disagreement,'' a U.S. official said. ``But the Soviets are hesitant to move as quickly as we'd like to in enforcing the sanctions. They are not working against us, but we are looking for their support, not just their acquiescence.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says US Could Stop Iraqi Shipping
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday the United States could stop Iraqi shipping in the Persian Gulf ``right now'' but was weighing how much time to give the United Nations to take further action backing up economic sanctions against Iraq. Bush, flanked by top military and national security advisers, answered questions on the Mideast crisis at his vacation home after signing an order calling up U.S. reserves for military duty for the first time since the Tet offensive in the Vietnam War. The president praised his military chiefs for the smoothness of the massive U.S. military buildup in the Saudi Arabian desert and the gulf waters, saying the Pentagon had deployed the equivalent of ``a medium-sized American city.'' He then went back inside for more consultations with his national security team, including discussion of whether to give ``the United Nations more time to take more productive action.'' Asked about Iraqi tankers that failed to stop despite U.S. warships' warning shots, Bush said, ``I think we've made clear to shipping that they can be stopped and we have the forces to stop them right now.'' At the United Nations, the five permanent Security Council members considered a resolution authorizing military force to back up sanctions against Iraq but reached no agreement on the precedent-setting proposal. In Washington, U.S. officials speaking on condition of anonymity said Secretary of State James A. Baker III had sought the help of the Soviet Union in enforcing a worldwide economic blockade of Iraq. But Baker, who telephoned Shevardnadze from Wyoming where the secretary was vacationing, was asked in turn by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to slow down U.S. efforts at the U.N., the officials said. Bush made clear that international backing was important, saying repeatedly that the United States was not standing alone against Iraq. ``This is not a matter between Iraq and the United States of America; it is between Iraq and the entire world community, Arab and non-Arab alike,'' he said. ``We are not in this alone; we stand shoulder to shoulder right there in the Middle East with the armed forces of 22 other nations.'' Asked if his recent comments and actions were meant to prepare people for the possibility of war and the loss of American lives, Bush said: ``I think any time you move American forces and any time you are up against what most of the world now considers to be an outrageous violator of international law, that the best thing is to be prepared.'' On other Mideast subjects: _ Bush was asked how constrained he felt by the 3,000 Americans trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, including some taken by the Iraqi army to vital military sites. He said, ``Any decision-maker in the United States or in any of these countries is concerned about the lives of innocent civilians, innocent people. You weigh that very thoroughly against your actions.'' But he added that the U.N. sanctions ``must be enforced.'' _ He declined to answer when asked about a report that the Soviet Union still had 193 military advisers in Iraq despite the United Nations embargo Moscow has supported. ``At this point, I would say we are getting superb cooperation from the Soviets,'' he said, noting that Baker had talked earlier in the day with Shevardnadze. _ Bush said the United States would not comply with Iraq's order to shut down the American Embassy in Kuwait City by Friday, and he doubted other nations would, either. The State Department announced earlier it would draw down all but essential diplomatic staff. He said the occupation of Kuwait ``is illegal under international law and other countries agree totally that we must not take the position that this illegal regime can shut down legitimate embassies as a result of their aggression.'' He said the U.S. embassies in Iraq and Kuwait would provide safe haven to Americans who managed to reach them. _ Bush said increasingly hostile statements from Baghdad about the United States betrayed ``a sense of irrational urgency there.'' Saddam, he said, is ``trying to whip up support and make this Iraq versus the United States. Indeed, it is Iraq versus the rest of the world.'' Bush said he had conferred at length by telephone Wednesday with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. He also spoke with Greek Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis, continuing his daily round of conversations with global leaders on the gulf crisis. The president, midway through a 25-day vacation in Maine that has repeatedly been interrupted by crisis planning, urged Americans to conserve energy, but said supplies for now are adequate. And he disdained a suggestion that he might want to keep his two-mile-per-gallon speedboat Fidelity docked. ``I'm going to keep using my boat. And I hope the rest of America will prudently recreate. I don't think we've reached the point where I want to call on everybody in the recreation industry to shut it down, or everybody that's taking a vacation in America to shut it down,'' Bush said. ``We are doing everything we can to guarantee that we don't panic Americans and that there will be an adequate supply of hydrocarbons. But I think it is a good time to conserve ... I would call upon Americans to conserve.'' Reporters asked Bush to prod the Saudis not to restrict the American news media from covering Operation Desert Shield. Bush gave an equivocal reply, saying, ``We are the guests of Saudi Arabia in their country. ... The more coverage the better as far as we're concerned.'' He also said, referring to reporters who manage to reach Iraq, that they should ask tough questions and be ``totally objective'' in their coverage. Asked about the Saudi foreign minister's statement Tuesday that Iraq was willing to put ``all the cards on the table'' and negotiate, Bush said, ``If they're willing to put all their cards on the table, that's good .... including complying with international law, that would be good.'' Bush, in his executive order, said the call-up of reserves was ``necessary ... for the effective conduct of operational missions in and around the Arabian Peninsula.'' The president sent letters to Congress, informing leaders there of his action that empowers Cheney to designate the reservists to perform missions he ``may determine necessary.'' It was the first time the president has activated the reserves since March 1970, when the reserves were called up during a postal strike. The last time reservists were called up for military duty was in January 1968, when the Vietcong's Tet offensive led President Lyndon B. Johnson to call up more than 35,000.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting a0710 to make keyword conform with digest
Bush Calls for Conservation, But Expects No Oil Shortage
With AM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday called on Americans to conserve energy, but said he has no intentions of giving up vacation jaunts on his power boat. Bush said during a news conference at his vacation home that there is no reason to expect an oil shortage, despite a reduction in world oil supplies cause by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and a subsequent international embargo on Iraqi trade. ``I'm going to keep using my boat, and I hope the rest of America will prudently recreate,'' said Bush, who has taken excursions on his boat fidelity during his vacation. ``I don't think we've reached the point where I want to call on everybody in the recreation industry to shut it down or everybody that's taking a vacation in America to shut it down,'' the president said. Persian Gulf tensions have meant a 4.2 million-barrel daily reduction in oil on the world market. But there had been a supply glut, and other oil producing nations are expected to make up much of the shortfall. Before Iraq invaded Kuwait, the United States was importing between 600,000 and 700,000 barrels per day from the two nations, about 4 percent of total U.S. oil consumption. There are 42 gallons of oil in a barrel. Bush declined to say what conservation measures he favors. Last week Energy Secretary James D. Watkins proposed boosting U.S. oil production, while asking drivers to trim their gasoline use by keeping tires properly inflated and obeying speed limits. ``We're doing everything we can to guarantee that we don't panic Americans and that there will be an adequate supply of hydrocarbons,'' the president said. ``I think it is a good time to conserve, so I'm glad you reminded me of that and I would call upon Americans to conserve,'' Bush said in response to a question. ``That doesn't mean that life screeches to a halt.''

DOC.HEAD: Retransmits a0705 to make keyword conform with digest
Bush, Cheney Back Freer Media Access in Saudia Arabia
With AM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Wednesday they would welcome freer media access to U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia, but it's up to the Saudis to allow it. ``We are the guests of Saudi Arabia in their country,'' Bush said during a news conference at his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine. ``And the more coverage the better, as far as we're concerned.'' Asked by a reporter if he meant ``we're at the total mercy of Saudi Arabia, that there's nothing we can do,'' Bush said he wasn't saying that and handed off the question to Cheney. Cheney said U.S. officials would try to secure freer access for journalists, but acknowledged that, ultimately, the Saudis are in charge. ``I do not have the final authority over what kind of access the government of Saudi Arabia grants to our press,'' he said. ``We'll work with the government of Saudi Arabia to provide as much access as we can. ``In the final analysis,'' he said, ``they'll make the decision, but obviously, we will be advocates for the concept that there should be significant coverage of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia available to the American people.'' The questions to Bush and Cheney were prompted by reports that the Saudis are beginning to restrict media coverage and may order most foreign journalists out of the country, possibly by week's end. Bush, after saying he supported freer coverage, raised the subject of the work of journalists who went to Iraq and talked to officials there. ``When people travel to countries like Iraq and countries of that nature, I hope the press ... coverage will be totally objective,'' he said. ``I hope the same tough questions are asked in every country as they are in this country, and I'm speaking of Iraq, particularly.'' Asked by a network reporter if he were criticizing coverage, Bush replied; ``I'm not criticizing. Don't be so sensitive about it.'' Cheney, commenting on the prospects for freer access in Saudi Arabia, said the Saudis may not see eye-to-eye with the U.S. media on what constitutes ``free and unrestricted'' coverage. ``They're very private in their personal lives and I think we have to respect their culture just as they respect ours,'' Cheney said. ``By the same token, I think it is important that we have an adequate flow of information to the American people about what our young men and women are doing in Saudi Arabia and I'm hopeful that we'll be able to arrange that,'' he said. Cheney said coverage had been ``pretty good'' so far under difficult circumstances. ``There are a lot of stories being filed out of Saudi Arabia,'' he said. However, 11 major news organizations expressed concern about current and prospective restrictions in Saudi Arabia in a letter Wednesday to Bush. The media said ``minimum access'' has been available through the Defense Department pool and extremely limited unilateral representation, with more severe limitations in the offing. ``We respectfully request that the administration do everything in its power to gain full media access to Saudi Arabia and to the American presence there,'' the groups said. ``Perhaps accreditation through the American military would be the correct solution.'' The letter was signed by officials in the Washington bureaus of ABC, CBS, NBC and CNN; The Associated Press; Time and Newsweek magazines; and the Washington Post, Wall Street Journal, New York Times and Los Angeles Times.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir: Iraq Will Pay `Fearsome Price' If It Involves Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Shamir comments on TV. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir warned Iraq on Wednesday that it will pay a ``terrible and fearsome price'' if it tries to drag Israel into the Persian Gulf conflict. Shamir said President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is trying to involve Israel ``so he can present this war as an Arab-Israeli war, and then the whole Arab world would have to back him.'' He denied Iraqi claims that Israeli soldiers were taking part in the U.S. military buildup in Saudi Arabia and that disguised Israeli pilots and warplanes took part in the American effort. ``Israel had no involvement whatsoever in this storm from the beginning. . . . Nobody can blame Israel that it played some role here,'' Shamir said on Israel Television in his first major interview since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``Those elements who wish to drag us into this whirlpool and maybe plan to attack Israel know perfectly well that if they try to do it, they will pay a terrible and fearsome price. People of Israel are not ready to play with their fate.'' Shamir acknowledged anxiety existed among the Israeli public and that the government was worried over this ``hour of emergency.'' But he refused to calm Israelis by divulging details about Iraqi military capabilities. Saddam has said he will retaliate by attacking Israel with chemical weapons in event of a U.S. military strike. Israeli military experts conflict on whether Iraqi missiles can carry chemical warheads. Israel has said it will retaliate if Iraq attacks and launch a military strike if Iraqi troops enter Jordan, which is between Iraq and Israel. Shamir assured Jordan's King Hussein that Israel will not attack his country first and was only interested in the stability of Hussein's throne. Banging his fist on the table, he then assured Israel the army was ready for battle and ``will know how to defend Israel at the hour of emergency.'' Shamir's comments came after a senior government official said war between the United States and Iraq seemed inevitable, and military analysts estimated that Israel would probably be dragged into such a conflict. ``The bottom line is that the United States and Iraq are on a collision course,'' said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The Americans are continuing to amass troops, and you don't do that unless you have the intention of using them. At the same time, you don't see the Iraqis offering anything that can provide a reasonable basis for negotiations.'' Shamir declined comment when asked about this scenario, saying his job was to consider Israeli response to any eventuality. But military analysts _ several of whom regularly get leaks from senior army officials _ agreed with the assessment. ``Most Israeli observers believe that it's likely the situation will escalate into fighting between the United States and Iraq,'' said Joseph Alpher, deputy head of Tel Aviv University's Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies. ``If and when fighting between the United States and Iraq breaks out, then Iraq most likely will try to drag Israel into it in order to rally Arab support.'' The escalation in the gulf poses a dilemma for Israel. While Israel sees itself as America's chief ally in the region, its role has been to keep a low profile so as not to break up the alliance against Iraq U.S. officials have tried to build with other Arab nations. Differences over how low Israel's profile should be were evident in arguments among Cabinet ministers over whether the government should distribute gas masks to the public to protect against a possible Iraqi attack. Some officials called for immediate distribution. Defense authorities maintain this could panic the public or sent a wrong signal to Iraq. Government leaders met on Wednesday to consider the question but delayed a decision by creating a special ministerial committee.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Bolsters Forces in Persian Gulf; Jordan Closes Border With Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tightens first three grafs, ADDS new 6th graf with Baker asking Shevardnadze for more cooperation in isolating Iraq; ADDS second U.S. fatality in accident. Splits into two takes. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The United States bolstered its forces in the Persian Gulf on Wednesday with a call-up of reserves, and Jordan closed its border with Iraq because of the strain of thousands of evacuees fleeing Iraq and occupied Kuwait. Baghdad, meanwhile, claimed that two aircraft flying in from Saudi Arabia penetrated three miles into its airspace. An unidentified military spokesman quoted by the official Iraqi news agency did not identify the planes or say whether they turned back voluntarily or were chased by Iraqi planes. It also was not clear if the spokesman was referring to a penetration of Iraq's own southern border with Saudi Arabia or that of Kuwait, which Baghdad now considers part of Iraq. On the diplomatic front, cracks appeared in what had been unprecedented U.S.-Soviet unity in the face of Iraqi aggression. Reports from the United Nations said Moscow was slowing efforts to win U.N. approval of a resolution allowing warships to enforce sanctions against Iraq. In Moscow, officials disclosed that Soviet military experts continue to train Iraqi soldiers in the use of their Soviet-built weapons, three weeks after Moscow cut arms supplies to protest the invasion of Kuwait. Secretary of State James A. Baker III telephoned Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze to urge Moscow to cooperate more fully in isolating Iraq, a State Department official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The State Department announced it would defy Saddam Hussein's demand to close the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait by Friday but said it would reduce the staff. Other nations, including Britain, have announced plans to do the same. Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the decision was consistent with ``our obligations to the American private community.'' About 2,500 Americans have been trapped in Kuwait and an estimated 500 in Iraq since Iraqi forces invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. There are about 120 U.S. diplomats in Kuwait. Iraqi took over its neighbor and drove out the ruling family after accusing Kuwait of stealing oil from a field that includes land both sides claim. Iraq also blamed Kuwait for a loss in vital oil revenue, saying it drove down world oil prices by cheating on its oil production quota. Jordan's announcement that it was closing its border came shortly after King Hussein told a news conference a total of 42,000 foreigners had crossed into Jordan during the day, the largest number since the crisis erupted. Interior Minister Salem Msadeh said the border was being closed because of ``concern for the health situation of the arrivals and to ensure suitable arrangements for their stay in Jordan.'' Hussein also said he would embark on a new round of talks with Arab leaders in hopes of defusing the crisis. He declined to say where he would go or with whom he would meet. Speaking in his palace to a room crowded with journalists, Hussein said he believed ``We are almost facing a crisis of the world gone mad.'' Many Egyptians, Palestinians and other mostly Arab refugees fleeing Kuwait have entered Jordan. Only a few Westerners have been able to flee to safety. Iraq is holding the rest in a bid to force the withdrawal of the U.S.-led multinational force defending Saudi Arabia from Iraqi aggression. President Bush ordered the Pentagon to call up reserves for active duty in the gulf. He did not say how many units were called up, but sources said as many as 40,000 may join Operation Desert Shield by the end of the month. It was the first activation of military reserves in 20 years. At the same time, the United States intensified the military buildup in the Persian Gulf. The aircraft carrier Saratoga steamed through Egypt's Suez Canal toward the Red Sea to join a growing American flotilla, a canal spokesman said. U.S. and other warships have been shadowing Iraqi vessels in the gulf to enforce the U.N. embargo. One of those vessels, an Iraqi tanker that defied warning shots from an American warship, reached Yemen's port of Aden Wednesday and dropped anchor near two other Iraqi ships in the harbor. Yemen had told the U.N. Security Council it would turn away the tanker and adhere to U.N. sanctions. The five permanent members of the Security Council met Wednesday to discuss a possible military blockade to enforce the sanctions. But Moscow was holding back, Western diplomats said, saying the Soviets want proof of the embargo's failure before approving military force. China had dragged its feet for the same reason, but a Kuwaiti official in Beijing said Wednesday the Chinese government promised not to block such a resolution. U.S. Ambassador Thomas Pickering said the five permanent council members _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, China and France _ were ``making progress'' drafting a resolution.

DOC.HEAD: Bush OKs License For U.S. Firm To Join Australian Space Project
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday opened the way for a U.S. company to help build a space port in Australia for a commercial firm that eventually hopes to launch American-made satellites with Soviet rockets. Bush authorized the State Department to grant a license to USBI Co. of Huntsville, Ala., a subsidiary of United Technologies, for the company to participate in the project at Cape York, Australia. The launch site would be operated in conjunction with the Cape York Space Agency. Bush's approval was needed because of security restrictions on sharing of technology with foreign countries. It allows planning for the project to proceed, but does not give a final sign off. Whether American-made satellites will ever be launched from Cape York is only a hypothetical question at this time, said a source on the president's National Space Council who asked not to be named. ``No U.S. satellite manufacturer, vendor or user has said he wants to launch on a Soviet rocket,'' the source said. ``USBI has been invited by the Aussies to help design and run the facility. They need their expertise; that's what the license is all about.'' USBI would provide program management, engineering and development for the launching facility and the Soviet Union would provide the boosters. The United States government has no involvement except to approve the license, said White House spokesman Steve Hart. The final license for the project could only be granted upon completion of agreements among the Soviets, Australia and USBI, he said. The agreements must provide that the Soviets provide boosters only for the single launch site and that U.S. regulations on technology transfers to the Soviet Union will be observed, the White House said. Those agreements are expected to be worked out in the near future. Hart said the government's intent is to ensure fair competition in international commercial space ventures. USBI executive Vice President Al Reeser said in a statement that the licensing ``will enable us to be a major participant in international launch services.'' ``We are pleased USBI is able to support the Cape York space agency. It is a big step for us.'' The Cape York Space Agency is a private international consortium that hopes to provide launch services needed to support commercial space ventures. The consortium was started by more than 60 firms from several nations.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: a resolution.
DOC.TEXT: Saddam's vow to place foreigners at military installations for use as human shields against attack drew more angry protests Wednesday. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd called the Iraqi president a ``destructive loser'' whose tactics reflect his isolation. Denmark suggested Saddam may be seeking to divide the allies by freeing some foreigners but holding others. The State Department says 54 Americans are believed to have been seized by Iraqi authorities, and Britain says 21 of its citizens are being held at Iraqi installations. Iraq said Wednesday it would allow some French and Japanese nationals to leave as a ``goodwill gesture.'' About 731 Japanese and 560 French citizens are trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. Before the announcement, an Iraqi state newspaper warned Europe and Japan of danger ``if they walk in the steps of Washington.'' Another said Iraq would take war ``into the cities of attacking nations.'' Pope John Paul II made his first public comment on the crisis Wednesday, pointing to ``the danger of war'' and offering a prayer for peace. Also Wednesday, France said it was sending its first forces, a reconnaissance squadron of 180 soldiers, to the Persian Gulf. And Turkey, Iraq's neighbor, said it was considering joining the multinational force. On Tuesday, Spain, Belgium, the Netherlands and Italy said they were sending warships to the gulf, and the nine-member Western European Union, meeting in Paris, agreed to to coordinate military action. At a news conference in Kennebunkport, Maine, Bush said he was not familiar with the report that Soviet military advisers remained in Iraq and said he had no argument with the Soviet response to the Persian Gulf crisis. ``At this point, I would say we are getting superb cooperation from the Soviets,'' Bush said. Col. Valentin Ogurtsov told a news conference in Moscow that 193 unarmed military experts are finishing their ``contractual obligations'' to show Iraqis how to use state-of-the art tanks, jet fighters and missiles, and to maintain and repair the hardware. Saudi Prince Bandar bin Sultan arrived in the Soviet Union Wednesday for talks, the official Soviet news agency Tass said. In other diplomatic activity, two top U.N. officials held talks in Baghdad with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz on the fate of the trapped foreigners. Also, defense ministers from the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council met in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, to discuss a unified defense strategy to complement the U.S.-led military buildup in Saudi Arabia. Tensions in the Middle East pushed up wholesale energy prices Wednesday beyond the $30-a-barrel level for crude oil and depressed prices of stocks, bonds and the dollar. Also Wednesday, a 19-year-old sailor was killed in an electrical accident aboard the USS Antietam, a Navy spokesman said. Petty Officer Third Class Daniel M. Jones, an electrician's mate, was the second serviceman to die as a result of the Persian Gulf crisis. Air Force Staff Sgt. John Campisi, 30, died Aug. 12 when he was hit by a military truck.

DOC.HEAD: ICRC Seen Walking Tightrope in Gulf Crisis
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The International Committee of the Red Cross is treading gingerly in the gulf crisis, fearing to anger Iraq by concentrating on the fate of Western hostages. Highlighting its precarious position was Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's accusation that the ICRC had failed to act to protect the thousands of trapped foreigners. There was no direct comment from the all-Swiss agency, traditionally pledged to confidentiality in its role as impartial monitor of the Geneva Conventions. A spokesman merely noted that the ICRC has been in touch with all states concerned since early August to ensure protection of the civilian population in both Iraq and Kuwait. The head of the agency's Middle East section flew to Baghdad Monday with a personal message from ICRC President Cornelio Sommaruga dealing with all issues of ``humanitarian concern.'' Sources familiar with committee thinking said its first aim is to continue practical work to help all people requiring assistance. Focusing on the trapped Westerners would raise doubts about its neutral stand, the sources added. The ICRC has been seeking authority to visit Kuwait to find out about the medical, food and other needs of the population. It has also been seeking to gain access to foreign nationals, but without success. The text of the 1949 Geneva Convention on the protection of civilians suggests that Iraq is clearly in violation of its provisions. Iraq joined the convention in 1956. But so far, the ICRC has stopped short of saying so publicly. By the announced transfer of foreigners to strategic locations, Baghdad violated article 28 stipulating that ``the presence of a protected person may not be used to render certain points or areas immune from military operations.'' A 1977 additional protocol elaborates on that, but neither Iraq nor the United States has ratified it. The text says the presence or movement of civilians ``shall not be used ... in attempts to shield military objectives from attacks or to shield, favor, or impede military operations.'' The 1949 convention says ``the taking of hostages is prohibited'' and that all aliens must be free to leave the territory of a party to a conflict ``unless their departure is contrary to the national interests of the State.'' Internees must not be held in ``areas particularly exposed to the dangers of war'' and they have the right to be visited by ICRC delegates. A special section dealing with occupied territories includes a prohibition of ``individual or mass transfers'' of persons from there to the territory of the occupying power. Kuwait is an occupied territory according to a U.N. Security Council resolution, but so far Iraq has not allowed ICRC delegates to visit there. The section on occupied territories has been cited by the ICRC on repeated occasions in denouncing Israel's policies in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. But the organization's position in Israel is relatively strong because the Jewish state cannot afford the bad publicity of barring the 42 ICRC delegates working there. In contrast, any public stand by the ICRC against Iraq might spell an end to its humanitarian mission in the Gulf crisis. Sources familiar with ICRC concepts said the agency has to be pragmatic and, that it must not risk blocking its work for a question of principle. Its Baghdad delegation includes 37 members. The sources, who declined to be identified further, said the ICRC had to maintain credible neutrality in this confrontation and to stress that it is not an instrument of Western or any other governments. The Geneva Conventions say it is up to signatory governments to make sure they are respected. The decision by neutral Switzerland, a non-U.N. member, to join the U.N. sanctions against Iraq has increased difficulties for the ICRC. The agency is known to have had serious misgivings when the Bern government proposed joining the world body, a proposal that was overwhelmingly defeated in a 1986 referendum.

DOC.HEAD: Military Man Named Interim Head of Panama's Civilian Police Force
DOC.TEXT: President Guillermo Endara announced Wednesday that a military officer has been named the interim chief of the country's newly created national police force. Endara told a news conference that he had appointed Lt. Col. Fernando Quezada to the post of director of the National Police after four civilians turned down the job offer for ``personal or professional reasons.'' Quezada will replace on an interim basis Col. Eduardo Herrera, who retired after holding the position since December's U.S. invasion that ousted Gen. Manuel Noriega. Endara refused to say whether the permanent head of the National Police will be a civilian. Panama created the National Police after the invasion as a civilian-run security force. It replaced the Panamanian Defense Forces, which for more than two decades filled both military and police functions. U.S. police and Army Reservists have trained the new force, but many of its 13,000 members served in the Defense Forces, which was led by Noriega. Quezada was among a group of Defense Forces officers who unsuccessfully tried to overthrow Noriega in March 1988. He was imprisoned until the December invasion. Endara said he had instructed Quezada to ``deploy all available national police to protect, prevent and put down any criminal activity.'' Panama has suffered a recent rash of robberies at banks, airports and businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Czech Minister Dies During Official Trip to Brazil
DOC.TEXT: The Czech minister of foreign trade, Slavomir Stracar, died in this capital from complications resulting from a heart attack, officials said Wednesday. Foreign Ministry spokesman Jose Vicente Pimentel said Stracar, who had been interned at the Armed Forces Hospital, died Tuesday night, a day after he fell ill at a luncheon held in his honor. Stracar, who headed an official delegation, was rushed to the hospital during the lunch, which occurred hours after he arrived in Brazil. The Czech embassy released a statement saying Stracar's body was being embalmed and would be transported to Prague.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Accuses Iraq of Blocking Its Entry, But CNN to Enter Country
DOC.TEXT: NBC, the only one of the three major U.S. networks not yet allowed into Iraq since the Persian Gulf crisis, accused Iraq on Wednesday of denying it entry because of seven highly critical NBC reports since 1988. It said it was being ``censored'' by that nation because of NBC reports that include ones on Iraq's use of poison gas on its Kurdish minority, Iraq's efforts to obtain triggers for nuclear weapons, and the country's biological weapons development program. NBC's rivals also have reported on those stories. NBC's unusual statement came as Cable News Network said that Iraq had granted it entry visas for Washington columnist Rowland Evans, who does two CNN weekend shows, and a CNN crew. The visas are good for Thursday and Friday. ``We expect to have them in there tomorrow,'' said CNN spokesman John Bianchi. Despite repeated and ``aggressive'' efforts by NBC to get similar visas, ``NBC News has still been denied access'' to Iraq, NBC News' executive vice president, Don Browne, said in a statement. ``We can only conclude that we are being censored by the Iraq government _ singled out because of a series of exclusive reports on `NBC Nightly News,' '' he said, referring to a list of seven NBC reports on the program. CBS and ABC crews, led by anchorman Dan Rather and Ted Koppel, respectively, were allowed into Baghdad last week, with Koppel the first U.S. network journalist permitted in since Iraq's Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait. Iraq officials have since ordered all of them out. The last network contingent to leave was from CBS. It left Baghdad on Tuesday. CNN's Evans, who writes the syndicated ``Evans and Novak'' column with Robert Novak, is being sent to Baghdad instead of a regular CNN correspondent because of his long expertise in Middle East affairs, said Bianchi. It isn't yet known if Evans will be able to arrange an interview with Iraq leader Saddam Hussein, Bianchi said. ``We don't know what they'll get or what they'll be allowed to get.''

DOC.HEAD: FBI Names Only Black Field Agent To Investigate Discrimination Claims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3, 4 and 11 pvs to CORRECT spelling of field agent's name to Philip sted Phillip. Pickup 12th graf pvs, bgng `Fernandez said it.'
DOC.TEXT: Two weeks after the FBI settled a racial harassment case brought by black agent Donald Rochon, the agency named its top-ranking black field agent to investigate allegations brought by Rochon, the FBI said Wednesday. As part of the settlement of the Rochon case, the agency agreed to conduct a full investigation of Rochon's claims and make the findings public by next April, said Rochon's attorney, David Kairys of Philadelphia. ``We are confirming that Paul Philip will be heading an investigation looking into the allegations made by Mr. Rochon,'' FBI spokesman Carlos Fernandez said Wednesday. Philip, 43, currently heads the field office in San Juan, Puerto Rico. He is the only black agent in charge of a bureau field office. The appointment by FBI Director William S. Sessions was made ``very, very recently,'' Fernandez said, but it had not been announced because, ``We have investigations all the time being headed by special agents. We don't make announcements about that.'' The New York Times reported Wednesday on the appointment. Rochon had charged in civil lawsuits that he was racially harassed by white agents when he worked in the FBI's Chicago office. Among other things, he claimed his family received threatening telephone calls and letters, including one that contained a photograph of the dismembered body of a black man. Another contained a bull's eye superimposed with a picture of a black man. Attorneys for the 40-year-old Rochon and the FBI signed an agreement the week of Aug. 5 that settled the 3-year-old legal battle. The settlement brought Rochon full pay and pension benefits, possibly worth a total of more than $1 million, Kairys said. Several members of Congress accused Sessions in April of tolerating discrimination, allegations denied by Sessions. A federal judge ruled in September 1988 that the FBI had engaged in widespread discrimination against its Hispanic employees. Officials acknowledged earlier this year that the FBI had settled three other racial discrimination suits, including one involving 30 employees of the fingerprint identification section. Philip has a ``tough assignment,'' said one congressional source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. But the source added: ``We think it's significant that he reports directly to the director and he has a team of eight agents working for him. He certainly has the manpower to do the job.'' Fernandez said it was not clear where Philip will be based as he conducts the investigation. ``He's not going to be in any one particular place,'' Fernandez said. ``He'll go wherever the investigation takes him.'' Rochon has been on disability leave since April because of emotional stress, and the settlement keeps him on disability leave until he is eligible to retire in 11 years, Kairys said. In addition, the FBI agreed to award Rochon some back pay for a promotion the agent claimed he was unfairly denied, and will pay Rochon's former wife, Susan, an undisclosed sum of money as compensation.

DOC.HEAD: War Clause Saves National Guard Group Hotel Charges
DOC.TEXT: A contract clause citing war as a valid excuse for canceling hotel reservations helped save a National Guard group about $10,000 Wednesday. Because of the crisis in the Persian Gulf, there are about 600 fewer National Guard members than expected at the 19th Annual Conference of The Enlisted Association of the National Guard of the United States, said Master Sgt. Tony Nathe. He is president of the private lobbying group, which has about 60,000 National Guard members. The conference opened Tuesday at the Hyatt Regency Hotel, where the group had expected about 1,500 members to attend meetings over four days, Nathe said. Attendance suffered because a large percentage of the group normally flies to the event in National Guard transport planes as part of training for National Guard pilots, he said. Most of those planes were unavailable because of the conflict, Nathe said. Because the group filled less than 80 percent of its reserved block of rooms at the Hyatt, it faced a charge of about $10,000 for use of meeting rooms that otherwise would have been free, he said. ``They (hotel managers) were saying, `Come on, you're not going to meet your block,' '' Nathe said. ``I told them to look at the war clause.'' A clause in the hotel contract said the agreement was subject to ``acts of God, war, government regulations, disaster, strikes, civil disorder, curtailment of transportation facilities or other emergency.'' ``Actually, there's been no war declared, but officially there's been no declaration of war since World War II and you know we've been in combat since then,'' said Sgt.
