Robert Metcalf, a conference organizer. ``It was pretty hard to hold them to the contract because of that clause,'' said Bill Gannage, the hotel's executive assistant manager of food and beverage. ``It's necessary to be as flexible as possible based on the circumstances in the Middle East.'' The group had made 400 room reservations at the Hyatt and needed to occupy 320 of the rooms to have free use of the meeting rooms, said Mike Pileggi, a conference organizer. The group only filled 193 of the rooms, Pileggi said. Softening the blow, the Guard group agreed to have a banquet at the Hyatt on Friday. The banquet had been scheduled for another site in Minneapolis, but was switched because fewer people than expected had signed up, Metcalf said.

DOC.HEAD: Parrot Pecks Housewife and Constable _ Polly Wanna Lawyer?
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Carolyne cq in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Polly needa lawyer. Police here placed a parrot in custody Wednesday after the bird attacked a housewife and then repeatedly bit the arresting officer while attempting a breakout. Constable Mark Levitt of the Wiltshire Constabulary nabbed the green parrot at the home of Carolyne Samuel in Hullavington. The housewife had called police after the bird flew into her home and attacked her. ``The parrot was very aggressive so, using police issue protective gloves, I picked it up and put it in a cardboard box and carried it to my police car,'' said Levitt, a crime intelligence officer at divisional headquarters in Chippenham, 90 miles west of London. The bird then made its bid for freedom by biting a hole in the side of the box, Levitt said. ``Moments later it was free and was flying around the police car,'' Levitt said. ``He was extremely annoyed and bit me eight times on the arm, drawing blood. I managed to grab him again and shoved him in the dashboard glove box where he couldn't create any more havoc.'' Levitt detained the bird in a cage at his home and then went to Chippenham District Hospital for treatment. On Wednesday night, the policeman said the parrot was safely under lock and key. ``I've got my revenge,'' Levitt said. ``I keep parrots of my own and the bird is now being kept in line by my African Grey, who is a bit of a yob (hooligan).'' Police said they were attempting to trace the parrot's owner.

DOC.HEAD: Company Recalls Faulty AIDS Test Kits
DOC.TEXT: A company that makes a five-minute AIDS test said Wednesday it has recalled a batch of 11,000 because of weak readings for the presence of antibodies against the deadly virus. ``Our quality control department found that the performance in this particular lot no longer meets our quality control release standards,'' said Christina Pappas, a spokeswoman for Worcester-based Cambridge BioScience. Pappas said the 11,000 tests _ packed in 140 kits _ represent only a fraction of the company's sales for the test. The tests are designed for use by physicians in clinics. The BioScience test is the only five-minute AIDS test that has received approval from the Food and Drug Administration, according to an FDA spokesman. Other tests must be sent out to testing laboratories for results. Pappas said that as far as the company knows, there have been no reports of false test results, either positive or negative. The company has notified all its customers and is replacing kits that are in the defective group.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Has Highest Per Capita Income Growth
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 16th graf, Connecticut had ..., to CORRECT last three digits of Massachusetts income. ^With BC-State Incomes-List
DOC.TEXT: The cost of cleaning up the Exxon Valdez oil spill off the coast of Alaska helped give the state the fastest growing per capita income in the nation last year, the government said Wednesday. Alaskans' per capita 1989 income totaled $21,656 for each man, woman and child, up 12.6 percent from the year earlier, according to revised estimates by the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis. That was nearly double the national average growth rate of 6.6 percent. The average per capita income was $17,596. Per capita income is the annual total personal income of residents, divided by the state's population. Personal income is income received from all sources, less personal contributions for social insurance. Three other Western states _ Hawaii, Nevada and Washington _ and farm states North Dakota, Montana, South Dakota, Idaho and Iowa were among the 10 states with the fastest growing per capita incomes. Maine, which had strong growth in both farm and non-farm income, was the only state east of the Mississippi River to make the top 10. ``The four Western states ... had fast non-farm income growth, mainly in manufacturing, construction and private service-type industries,'' the report said. ``The five farm states ... had fast growth in farm income, mainly reflecting a rebound from the 1988 drought,'' it said. Much of Alaska's earnings came from the lumber, food processing and oil and gas industries, the report said. But it added: ``A strong gain in transportation earnings reflected expenditures for clean-up operations associated with the oil spill in March 1989. Hotel services and retail trade also showed strength in Alaska; these industries supplied shelter and food for workers involved in the clean up.'' Hundreds of miles of Alaska shoreline were fouled when the tanker Exxon Valdez slammed into a charted reef March 24, 1989, releasing nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil into the water. It was the nation's biggest oil spill, coating hundreds of miles of shoreline and killing hundreds of otters and thousands of birds and other animals. Last summer's $2 billion clean-up program involved more than 10,000 workers and 1,000 boats. North Dakota had the second fastest per capita growth rate, up 9.9 percent. It was followed by Hawaii, 9.7 percent; Montana, 9.4 percent; South Dakota, 8.6 percent; Idaho, 8.3 percent; Iowa, 8.2 percent; Maine and Nevada, 8 percent each; and Washington state, 7.8 percent. States with the slowest growth were New Hampshire, 4.4 percent; Georgia, 5.1 percent; Kansas, 5.2 percent; and Arizona and California, 5.4 percent each. Connecticut had the highest per capita income, $24,683, followed by New Jersey, $23,778; Massachusetts, $22,174; Alaska, $21,656; New York, $21,073; Maryland, $21,013; New Hampshire, $20,267; California, $19,929, Nevada, $19,269; and Virginia, $18,927. The District of Columbia was not ranked as a state, but posted a per capita income of $23,491. At the bottom of the list were: Mississippi, $11,724; West Virginia, $12,345; Arkansas, $12,901; Louisiana, $12,921; Utah, $13,079; New Mexico, $13,140; North Dakota, $13,563; Alabama, $13,625; South Carolina, $13,634; and South Dakota, $13,685.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Killer-Forger Hospitalized After Overdose
DOC.TEXT: Convicted killer Mark Hofmann, the forger of Mormon historical documents who used bombs to cover his tracks, was in critical but stable condition Wednesday following a drug overdose, officials said. Hofmann, 35, serving a life sentence, was found unconscious at Utah State Prison shortly after noon and was taken to the University of Utah Health Sciences Center, said hospital spokeswoman Anne Brillinger. Brillinger confirmed that, for the second time in less than two years, Hofmann was being treated for an overdose of antidepressant drugs. She said he was conscious but still listed as critical. Hofmann pleaded guilty in January 1987 to second-degree murder in the Oct. 15, 1985, pipe-bomb slayings of Steven F. Christensen, 30, and Kathleen Webb Sheets, 50. He also pleaded guilty to theft by deception in his fraudulent document dealings, which netted him hundreds of thousands of dollars. Hofmann has said he killed Christensen to prevent him exposing his trafficking in fraudulent Mormon historical documents, and left the second bomb outside the Sheets home as a diversion. Hofmann became the chief suspect in the two bombings a day after the explosions when a third pipe bomb blew him from his parked car in downtown Salt Lake City. Hofmann claimed he meant to kill himself, but police scoffed at that notion, saying he was seeking another victim. Hofmann was hospitalized after a guard was unable to awaken him for his noon meal, said Dave Franchina, a state Department of Corrections spokesman. Hofmann was being housed in a maximum-security unit with a convicted killer who was taking a routine cold medication, Franchina said. Hofmann wasn't taking any prescription medication, he said. Hofmann didn't have access to the infirmary, but could mingle with other inmates for four hours a day, Franchina said. Investigators found nothing during an initial search of the cell. On Sept. 15, 1988, Hofmann was rushed from the prison to the same hospital in critical condition after taking an overdose of antidepressants in quantities sufficient, barring medical aid, to have caused his death.

DOC.HEAD: British Files New Charge in Iraqi `Super Gun' Project
DOC.TEXT: An additional charge of arms dealing was lodged on Wednesday against a scientist accused of involvement in the Iraqi ``super gun'' project. Metallurgist Christopher Cowley, 51, was accused of dealing with components and forgings for large caliber armaments and projectors between April 1, 1988, and June 30, 1989, when such equipment was banned from export. Cowley was formerly associated with Space Research Corp. of Brussels, Belgium, founded by Gerald Bull, a Canadian-born U.S. citizen. Bull, credited with being the world's leading designer of long-range guns, was was mysteriously murdered outside an apartment in a Brussels suburb on March 22 and his heirs said later the company had been dissolved. Bull worked on advanced howitzer systems for the U.S. Army, and his technology was used by Israel, South Africa and both sides in the Iran-Iraq conflict. Bull was said to be working for Iraqi President Saddam Hussein on a satellite to be launched from a rocket-propelled shell fired from a huge cannon at the time of his death. Cowley, who was charged previously in other dealings, was released on bond of $48,000 until Oct. 10 by magistrates in Sheffield, northern England. British customs officers in April seized large tubes that they said could be used to construct a giant gun barrel. Trucks heading for Iraq with steel forgings made in Britain were stopped in Turkey and Greece. Iraq said the pipes were part of an oil pipeline project. The Sheffield magistrates also allowed another defendant in the case, business executive Peter V. Mitchell, 42, to remain free until Nov. 15, on bond of $48,000. He is accused of exporting prohibited goods. Both men first appeared in court on May 3. Meanwhile in Geneva, Britain on Wednesday voiced ``deep concern'' about activities of some states that have ratified the treaty to halt the spread of atomic weapons. It cited the recent seizure of an Iraq-bound shipment of what it suspected to be nuclear triggers. Foreign Office minister William Waldegrave addressed a 140-nation conference reviewing implementation of the 1970 treaty. He did not specifically name any countries in referring to ``the question of clandestine procurement'' of nuclear technology. But he recalled the ``publicity surrounding recent action'' by British authorities ``to prevent export of sensitive items.'' It was an evident reference to the seizure at Heathrow airport of a shipment of what investigators said were nuclear triggers bound for Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: `Light Up the Sky' Revived
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: Moss Hart's 1948 Broadway comedy, ``Light Up the Sky,'' set on opening night of a play's out-of-town tryouts, is being given a full-throttle revival at off-Broadway's Roundabout Theater. It opened Tuesday night. The stage, the star actress' livingroom in a Boston hotel suite, is full of flowers and actors playing a lot of very dramatic theatrical people. The laugh lines and pace aren't a mile a minute, and if Hart was satirizing people he knew, we don't know them now. But this is a comedy of delicious characters and situations. And the actors on the Roundabout stage don't stint on showing full measures of humor and ridiculousness. Charles Keating is perfection as Carleton Fitzgerald, a ``sensitive'' director whose head-thrown-back poses and preciousness are summed up in his frequent exclamations, ``I could cry.'' Peggy Cass never overplays the star's mother, who specializes in zingers. Linda Carlson does overplay, on purpose, conveying a temperamental star who's not a great actress. Bruce Weitz and Betsy Joslyn have ``Guys and Dolls'' accents and bright, applaudable moves as the play's producer and his wife. Bill McCutcheon, as always, makes his part a gem. Near the end, he comes in blinking, as a bewildered, rich, elderly, lovable theater buff. The three acts are divided by time: toasting success before the play, vituperation after the play was laughed at, rejoicing when the play gets rave reviews. John Bolger plays the naive playwright, a rather colorless character but the only one who changes. He's delighted, then disillusioned. Whether he'll pull himself together in Act 3, enough to do some rewrites _ of course he will _ is the only suspense. ``Light Up the Sky'' isn't about suspense. It's about the funny side of the mercurial characters and the pothole-filled road to getting a show on Broadway. Larry Carpenter directed. Andrew Jackness designed the set and Martin Pakledinaz the costumes. The play will run at the Roundabout through Sept. 16. It will be followed by Hal Holbrook in ``King Lear'' from Oct. 17 to Dec. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Third Espionage Trial Begins for Former FBI Agent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 9th, `The latest ...' to inlcude reason for non-jury trial; Ogorodinkov is standard usage; Russian feminine form `Ogorodinkova' in quote in 19th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Richard W. Miller turned to espionage out of frustration with his life and career and his infatuation with a Soviet spy, a prosecutor alleged Wednesday as the former FBI agent's third trial began. ``His brand of espionage was a crime of dollars and cents. It was a crime of lust. It was a crime of dissatisfaction. For him, it was even a crime of boredom,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Adam Schiff said in opening statement. Most of all, the prosecutor added, it was crime of ``pure selfishness and self-interest.'' Miller's defense attorney, Joel Levine, denied the agent had traded secrets for sex and money, and contended he actually started his relationship with a Soviet spy to infiltrate the KGB so he could score points with the FBI. Miller was ``trying to resurrect his career and, to coin a phrase, snatch victory from the jaws of defeat,'' Levine said in his opening statement. Miller, wearing a tan suit over his large frame, took notes during opening statements. Two of Miller's sons sat among the spectators behind him in the courtroom. The court session Wednesday marked the beginning of the third trial for Miller, the first FBI agent ever accused and convicted of espionage. His first trial ended in a hung jury and the second resulted in a conviction later overturned by an appeals court because of trial errors. The latest trial is being held without a jury before U.S. District Court Judge Robert Takasugi, who took over for Judge David Kenyon. After presiding over the first two trials, Kenyon disqualified himself from further action. The defense had requested Takasugi decide the case to avoid another hung jury that could prompt yet another trial. Miller, arrested in 1984, was imprisoned for five years before being granted bail in October 1989 by the appellate court. He was released from prison in November 1989 after posting $337,000 bail. As in the previous trials, attorneys on both sides portrayed Miller as an overweight bumbler of an FBI agent, so absent-minded he once left his keys in front door of an FBI field office when he left for the night. Once again, the prosecution sought to link Miller's problems at work to his relationship with Soviet spy Svetlana Ogorodnikov, whom he met in 1984. Schiff said that in 1984 Miller's career was down in the dumps: he was spending 40 hours a week listening to wiretaps and had been given a two-week suspension for failing to meet an FBI weight standard. Miller's marriage was crumbling, and his financial problems were so bad he was taking out cash advances on his credit card and holding an outside job selling advertising for shopping carts to make ends meet. ``Richard W. Miller was ready for a private rebellion,'' said Schiff. ``The evidence will show that Richard W. Miller did not start his FBI career intending to be a spy, but a spy he became.'' For Miller, Ms. Ogorodinkov offered a solution to all his problems, the prosecutor said. The two began a sexual relationship, and Miller accepted $65,000 in cash and gold for giving her an FBI document outlining U.S. intelligence goals, Schiff said. ``Miller was infatuated with Svetlana Ogorodnikova. He enjoyed spending time with her, enjoyed sex with her,'' said Schiff. ``...He then saw her as a terrific opportunity to make a quick buck and a very big buck.'' The prosecutor said that when Miller discovered the FBI was on his trail, he admitted several times to passing the document to her, and at one point even referred to ``documents in the plural.'' The validity of the admissions are central to Miller's defense. Takasugi denied a defense pretrial request to exclude the statements from the trial. His attorneys contend Miller tried to tell the truth, but that FBI agents, with the preconceived notion he was lying, grilled him until he told them what they wanted to hear. The defense also pointed to religious admonitions Miller got from his boss, Richard Bretzing, a bishop in the Mormon church. Those admonitions, and other conversations, pressured Miller into an admission, Levine said. ``Mr. Miller became very emotional from (those) admonitions, and, in fact, cried on both occasions,'' said Levine. Levine noted the FBI had tried in 1982 to use Ms. Ogordnidov to get into the KGB with no success, and details of the investigation were in a file Miller had reviewed. The defense attorney acknowledged Miller was ``a bad agent in many respects,'' but Levine contended it was Miller's shortcomings that prompted him to try to infiltrate the KGB without authorization.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. to Reduce Diplomatic Corps in Kuwait But Keep Embassy Open
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 8th graf bgng: Mohamed Sadiq xxx to UPDATE with ambassador's reaction.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration decided Wednesday to reduce the staff of the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait but defied Iraqi President Saddam Hussein by refusing to shut down. Saddam has set Friday as the deadline for the U.S. and other foreign embassies to close and shift operations to Baghdad, the Iraqi capital. Asked what would happen next, President Bush said: ``We'll wait and see.'' There are about 60 American diplomats and about 60 dependents in Kuwait City. The State Department ordered all the dependents, including nearly 30 children, to leave. A number of U.S. diplomats also were ordered to leave. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said those officials no longer were needed because their jobs involved dealing with the overthrown Kuwaiti government. He declined to say how many were involved. About 2,500 Americans are trapped in the Persian Gulf country. Some may have been rounded up with other Westerners and sent to oil refineries and other industrial sites as a deterrent to U.S. military attack. On Monday, Bush described the Americans in Kuwait and about 530 in Iraq as hostages. He has insisted _ unsuccessfully so far _ that they be permitted to leave. Mohamed Sadiq al-Mashat, the Iraqi ambassador to Washington, was summoned to the State Department on Wednesday to receive a special appeal for the release of 12 Americans with what Boucher described as ``urgent medical problems.'' He gave a non-committal reply and was expected to convey the request to Baghdad, a U.S. official said afterward. Boucher said the U.S. intention to keep the embassy open was consistent with U.N. Security Council resolutions and ``with our obligations to the American private community.'' The reduction in embassy staff was announced in a separate message for broadcast to Americans in Kuwait by the Voice of America and the British Broadcasting Co. ``The Iraqi government has from the beginning of this situation stated that diplomats are free to leave Kuwait,'' the message said. ``We are taking them at their word and have ordered the departure of all dependents and staff that do not have a mission in Kuwait at this time.'' The first group of U.S. diplomats and dependents designated to leave Kuwait will depart in the next day or so, Boucher said. Another eight Americans who worked for United Nations agencies in Kuwait and their families may have reached Jordan Tuesday night, he said. Britain, the Soviet Union and several other nations already had decided to reduce their diplomatic staffs in Kuwait but to keep their embassies open despite Saddam's order. ``American citizens should be assured that we plan to have sufficient diplomatic staff at the embassy in Kuwait to look after their safety and welfare, which remains our highest priority,'' Boucher said. The announcement made no reference to a staff reduction. It stressed that Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and other American diplomats in Kuwait ``will serve our community to the best of their ability.'' ``We are determined to continue working for your release from Kuwait and your safe return to your families,'' it said. The broadcast advised Americans thinking of leaving Kuwait to ``plan their route carefully.'' It said Iraqi forces were under orders to stop and detain anyone identified as a U.S. citizen. A British citizen trying to leave the country was shot and killed, the broadcast said. Until now, the State Department and the embassy had advised Americans not to try to leave Kuwait without permission. About 500 Americans ignored the advice and got out. Asked why the message had been changed, Boucher said: ``The situation for Americans has changed. ... We try to provide our best advice.'' One problem confronting administration decision-makers is whether the American diplomats will be able to leave easily or safely. Boucher said Iraq had given assurances they would not need exit permits. Last week, when Iraq demanded that Americans and Britons in Kuwait gather at hotels, the embassy conveyed the order but gave no specific advice. A handful of Americans went to the hotel, found no Iraqi authorities there and left the next day. Saddam on Monday warned diplomats in Kuwait to close their embassies by Friday and transfer their missions to Baghdad. Otherwise, a foreign ministry spokesman said, they ``will be treated ... as ordinary foreign nationals.'' Nine Western European nations, meeting Tuesday in Paris, rejected the ultimatum.

DOC.HEAD: Coup Attempt Thwarted in Comoro Islands, Government Says
DOC.TEXT: Security forces in the Comoro Islands have thwarted a coup attempt by European mercenaries against the new government of the Indian Ocean republic, the Comoran Foreign Ministry announced. In a communique received Tuesday by Paris-based news organizations, the ministry said the attempt to topple President Said Mohamed Djohar took place Saturday night. No details were provided. Voters in the Comoros chose Djohar on March 11 to succeed Ahmed Abdallah Abderrahmane, widely believed to have been assassinated by the French mercenary Bob Denard. The Comoran Foreign Ministry said security forces thwarted the coup by arresting an unnamed European and two native supporters of Mohamed Taki, Djohar's main opponent in last spring's disputed elections. They carried documents outlining a commando strike against a military camp, the official Radio Comoro broadcasting station and the French Embassy in the capital of Moroni, the ministry said. ``The operation was intended to destabilize President Said Mohamed Djohar and the young Comoran democracy,'' the statement said. It added that Djohar appealed on the radio for ``all Comorans to mobilize and stand up to the mercenaries.'' The plotters hoped to drive out French paratroopers who arrived last December to guarantee security after Denard and about 30 mercenaries finally agreed to leave, the statement said. Two of the soldiers-of-fortune have recently been seen in the islands, the ministry said. Abdallah died Nov. 26 from a gunshot during a dispute with Denard at the presidential palace. Denard admits being in the same room but denies he was responsible. Denard, 61, deposed Abdallah in 1975 and returned him to power three years later. He effectively ran the republic through a 300-man presidential guard led by Europeans. After three weeks of disturbances following Abdallah's death, French paratroops landed in the Comoros and effected a transfer of power from Denard's mercenaries. Most of them returned to Europe. Denard remains in South Africa, which granted him a temporary visa. The mercenary cannot return to France, where he is wanted on criminal charges for a failed 1977 coup in the West African country of Benin. The three-island Comoran Republic _ with a population of about 425,000 _ is between Madagascar and Mozambique. A fourth island in the chain, Mayotte, remains French.

DOC.HEAD: Glass Beads Likely Cause of Columbia's Leak
DOC.TEXT: Glass beads found in hydrogen lines from the space shuttle Columbia contributed to its fuel leaks, NASA said Wednesday. The shuttle has been outfitted with new fuel plumbing and is scheduled to lift off Sept. 1 carrying the Astro observatory. ``We've looked for contamination. We don't see any,'' said William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program. Workers on Wednesday replaced part of a valve on one of Columbia's three main engines that wasn't working properly. ``We're comfortable with the hardware we have on the pad,'' Lenoir said. NASA scrubbed its attempt to launch Columbia on May 30 when hydrogen leaks were detected during fueling. Atlantis also was found to have a hydrogen leak, but in a different spot. Columbia's hydrogen lines were removed for inspection, and seals on a 17-inch-diameter valve were found to leak, Lenoir said. The valve is in a pipe that carries liquid hydrogen from the shuttle's external fuel tank to the main rocket engines. About 100 to 200 tiny glass beads were found when the seals were disassembled, along with some metal chips, Lenoir said. NASA officials don't know how the debris got there. Parker Hannifin Corp., which makes these parts, called fuel umbilicals, at one point was using the beads for other projects in the building where it made the shuttle parts, Lenoir said. NASA doesn't plan to take action against the California company, he said. ``We've no evidence at all that says that something wrong has been done here, that anybody's quality has escaped from us,'' Lenoir said. NASA plans to improve its test procedures for the disposable external tanks to prevent similar problems in the future, Lenoir said. ``Inherently, that makes it more expensive, which is why we didn't in the first place,'' he said. ``We've no reason to believe that our acceptance test procedure was at fault or caused any problems. We're just trying to buy some more margin.'' The space agency is designing a more efficient valve that should be ready in about two years, Lenoir said. If larger-than-allowable leaks are detected during fueling for the Sept. 1 launch, the mission will be called off again, Lenoir said.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian Police Break Up Student Demonstrations, Eight Injured
DOC.TEXT: Riot police fired teargas and shotguns Wednesday to break up student demonstrations that snarled traffic in Panama City for several hours. Eight students were reported injured by gunfire. Students from all over the capital took to the streets to protest a Supreme Court ruling upholding a decision by the National Institute to expel five of them for rowdy behavior. The Institute, a high school, dropped the students for taking part in a street demonstration two months ago that turned into a riot and featured the vandalism of local stores. As a result of Wednesday's demonstrations, Education Minister Ada Gordon announced she had ordered the Institute closed ``until security conditions are restored.'' Students at the Institute told reporters at least 55 people were hurt during clashes with police. But an official at the Social Security emergency room, who identified himself only as Dr. Soto, said in a telephone interview he knew of only eight who were injured, none seriously. Soto said the eight were treated for superficial shotgun-pellet wounds and allowed to leave. For hours, the demonstrators tied up traffic along Fourth of July Avenue, bordering the Panama Canal, and other main thoroughfares. Students from the Institute, the University of Panama, the School of Arts, and at least a dozen other high schools threw rocks at police trying to redirect traffic until the riot squads appeared and dispersed the protesters. President Guillermo Endara, a usually easygoing politician who took office eight months ago, said he was getting fed-up with student disturbances. Endara's predecessor, dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega, was removed by a U.S. military invasion in December and was flown to Miami for on trial for drug trafficking and money laundering. ``The government has been patient and has been acting with a very soft hand. But it must also protect citizens' rights to be on the streets,'' he told reporters. ``A few youths just cannot curb their right to transit, or cause damage to property and society. I am soft handed and I am glad that I'm soft-handed, but the time comes when one must act,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Steady Radio Contact is Restored with Spacecraft
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with steady contact restored, details. Pick up 16th graf pvs: `Venus and...
DOC.TEXT: Trouble-plagued NASA restored steady radio contact with Magellan on Wednesday after losing touch with the malfunctioning spacecraft for the second time since it started orbiting Venus. Engineers received radio signals from Magellan at about 4:33 p.m. PDT showing that its secondary antenna obeyed computer orders and was firmly pointed at Earth, allowing them to maintain a continuous link with the wayward spaceship, said Tommy Thompson, Magellan science manager at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``It took a ton off our shoulders,'' he said. ``We're going home with smiles on our faces.'' Intermittent contact had been restored at 12:32 p.m. PDT when a brief ``blip'' of a radio signal was received by NASA's Deep Space Network tracking station in Goldstone, Calif. That was about 17{ hours after contact was lost Tuesday night, laboratory spokesman Bob MacMillin said. ``You could hear cheers and clapping when we reacquired the signal,'' Thompson said. In an attempt to prevent further communications breakdowns, engineers were sending additional computer commands to Magellan to disable some of its safety systems, said Thompson. Those systems cut off communications with Earth on Aug. 16 and again Tuesday night when they detected some unknown problem aboard Magellan. The spacecraft's $744 million mission to make the best pictures of Venus yet had been scheduled to start the first week of September, but likely will be delayed until the problem is diagnosed and fixed, Thompson said. ``The patient is resting comfortably and is strong and healthy, but needs an operation _ and we don't know which operation right now,'' he said of Magellan. The spaceship's first radio blip to Earth on Wednesday afternoon indicated the spaceship finally had accepted repeated computer commands to start spinning and send radio signals into space so that some of those signals reached Earth, he added. Engineers received more intermittent signals before sending Magellan orders to stop spinning and keep an antenna aimed at Earth. Those orders restored steady radio communications. Earlier, National Aeronautics and Space Administration officials expressed optimism they would overcome the problem. ``I wouldn't say people are thrilled, but nobody's panicking. We're very optimistic we'll be able to regain contact with the spacecraft, figure out what's wrong and continue the mission,'' Ellen Stofan, assistant to Magellan's chief scientist, had said. The successful conclusion of Magellan's latest crisis averted, at least temporarily, another severe setback for NASA. The agency temporarily grounded its shuttle fleet this summer due to hydrogen fuel leaks, and also discovered the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope's performance was badly impaired by a flawed mirror. Planetary scientist Steve Wall said Magellan's radio signal fluttered in and out of contact before fading away Tuesday night, indicating an unknown problem made the spacecraft turn so the antenna it was using at the time no longer pointed at Earth. ``We do not believe anything like a massive failure occurred,'' he said. Venus and Magellan were almost 149 million miles from Earth on Wednesday, Wall said. Venus is Earth's nearest neighbor, and is the second planet from the sun. Magellan was designed to use radar to peer through Venus' thick clouds to make the most detailed pictures and maps yet of the rugged landscape, where temperatures reach 900 degrees Fahrenheit due to an out-of-control ``greenhouse effect.'' The spacecraft was launched from the shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989, then looped around the sun 1{ times, traveling 948 million miles before it slid into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10. Magellan first lost contact with Earth for more than 14 hours starting the night of Aug. 16. Then its automatic safety systems made the spacecraft spin slowly while beaming radio signals across the skies until some reached Earth. That resulted in eight hours of intermittent communications. Then engineers sent commands that restored a steady radio link. The safety systems didn't automatically make Magellan start spinning when its radio link failed for the second time starting at 7 p.m. Tuesday. Wall said the signal fluttered for 13 minutes before fading out. That happened less than eight hours after NASA released Magellan's first test pictures of Venus. The pictures showed that at least a small part of the planet's surface has been violently shaped by quake faults and vast volcanic lava flows. Stofan said prime suspects as the cause of Magellan's communications problem are defects in its computer programs or its hardware. Engineers had said Tuesday the leading theory to explain last week's outage was that Magellan's electronics were briefly disrupted by a cosmic ray or a high-energy particle from the sun. Jet Propulsion Laboratory is known for designing spacecraft to fix their own malfunctions. Voyager 2's main receiving antenna failed after its launch in 1977, leaving it deaf for about a week until the probe automatically switched to a working backup receiver, laboratory spokesman Jim Wilson said. The probe successfully completed a 12-year exploration of Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune last year.

DOC.HEAD: Reservists: Nervous But Ready
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with comment with Marine Reservist who was a hostage in Iran. Pick up 13th graf pvs, `Iowa National...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Reserves Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Military reservists got the call they had been waiting for Wednesday, only to find out they'll have to wait even longer to see if they'll be tapped. ``If the call comes, we'll go,'' said Jeffrey Smith, a New York City accountant and Army reservist. ``Right now I'm a little nervous. But I stand ready to go as everyone else does.'' ``If you sign on the dotted line, you have to expect to pay the piper,'' said Joseph Bellavia, a 43-year-old pharmaceutical salesman from Reading, Mass. He said he's ready to go, but his family, including eight children, doesn't want him to go. President Bush ordered the Pentagon on Wednesday to call military reserves to active duty for the first time in 20 years. The callup includes National Guard units and Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Reserves. Guard troops sent previously to the Middle East were responding to calls for volunteers rather than a federal callup. Officials didn't identify the units that would be activated, or say when they would be called. But a spokesman for North Carolina's National Guard said some of its units had been called into duty. ``We are aware of units that have been called. We are going through verification rosters,'' said Lt. Col. Baron Hignite, A Pentagon statement said some reserves called to active duty would be shipped to Saudi Arabia while others would remain in the United States replacing troops dispatched to the Mideast. ``We're at the highest stage of combat readiness in our history,'' Lt. Gen. John B. Conaway, chief of the National Guard Bureau in Washington, told the 19th annual conference of The Enlisted Association of the National Guard of the United States, meeting in Minneapolis. Smith, the New York accountant, was waiting along with thousands of other reservists to see if his unit would be called. Smith, 29, joined the Army in April 1979 and did three years active duty. He's been a reservist every since. ``Anybody who says they're not scared, they're lying,'' said Smith. On the other hand, Angela Adinolfi, 22, a reservist who works at Hanscom Air Force Base, Mass., said she ``wouldn't mind'' moving to active duty. ``That's what we're here for,'' she said. Former Iranian hostage Kevin Hermening of Mosinee, Wis., a sergeant in the Marine Reserve, is ready to go back to the Middle East. ``Like other Marine reservists, my bags have been packed for the last two weeks in preparation in case my president calls me,'' he said. Hermening, the youngest of the Americans held hostage in the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, was 20 when he was freed. Since his return, has has had frequent speaking engagements and has run unsuccessuflly for Congress. Iowa National Guard officials expected Iowa units would be called up but said it would likely involve only a few troops. ``I am not anticipating that we get word this afternoon and we leave tonight,'' said Warren Lawson, Iowa National Guard adjutant general, who said officials generally provide for an orderly deployment. ``This is what we're all about. It's like being a volunteer fireman, you hope there's never a fire, but if there is one, you know you're ready to deal with it,'' said Ray Martyniuk, a spokesman for New Jersey's Department of Military and Veterans' Affairs, which oversees the Army and Air National Guard. ``We're not doing anything special right now except for our normal business, But our mission is to train for something like this,'' said Col. Alex Garcia, deputy commander of the 111th Air Defense Brigade in New Mexico, which includes the 744th Medical Detachment. Some employers were taking stock of their personnel to determine the effect a call-up might have on their workforces. FHP Health Care of Utah reported that as many as 45 of its employees could be called to active duty. ``Every department is looking at how this may affect them so they can be prepared. We will strongly support our employees while they are there. There is strong (company) support for the American and United Nations' positions,'' said company spokesman James W. McPherson III. Master Sgt. Mary Lou Bornmann, a spokeswoman at New York City's Fort Totten, said many reservists have contacted their commanders volunteering for active duty. Fort Totten is headquarters of the 77th Army Reserve Command. ``We've had more people volunteering than we know what to do with,'' she said. ``I don't think anybody expected this now. But we're prepared.'' Some units of the 77th are likely to get called _ the command, the nation's largest, has 14,000 reservists, 6,000 of whom are in medical companies. But some reservists were apprehensive about being called up. In Georgia, Al Beverly was wondering how he would run a congressional campaign from the deserts of Saudi Arabia, if he's activated. ``I'm not going to resign my candidacy,'' said Beverly, 36, of Marietta, Ga., an Army reserve captain and Republican challenger to U.S. Rep. George ``Buddy'' Darden, D-Ga. ``I have to figure where to draw the line between being a captain and being a candidate.'' Others were concerned about jobs and paying bills. ``What's going to happen to my paycheck? How am I supposed to pay my car note?'' asked Yolanda Preston, 25, a teacher in Atlanta and Air Force reservist. ``I can't ask them to be patient for I-don't-know-how-many months.'' Jonathan Waldron, a Marietta, Ga., dentist and commander of the 4th Marine Air Wing Medical Unit, said if he is summoned, he would have to find some contingency plan for his 1,300-patient practice. ``I would prefer not to be called up, but I'm ready if I'm needed,'' said Waldron, 46, a reservist for 20 years. ``The concern I have is not for my well-being, but I've got four employees counting on a paycheck.''

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop Said to Stop Payments to Woman
DOC.TEXT: Former Archbishop Eugene Marino has stopped giving money to a woman with whom he had an intimate relationship that cost him his job, a church spokesman said Wednesday. The woman, Vicki Long, has received $14,000 in money orders since May from the New York town where Marino is in seclusion, according to news reports. Marino resigned in July, citing health problems, and the church has since acknowledged it was because of his affair with Ms. Long, 27. On Wednesday the Rev. Peter Dora, a spokesman for the Atlanta Roman Catholic Archdiocese, said Marino has stopped making payments. ``It is my understanding that he has not sent her any money after the end of July and he does not intend to send her any of his own money in the future,'' Dora said. The name signed on one money order to Ms. Long was ``Eugene Bradford,'' the name of the archbishop's dead grandfather, The Atlanta Constitution reported Wednesday. The newspaper quoted an unnamed person close to Ms. Long who is familiar with the money orders. Others were signed by two employees of the Larchmont, N.Y., Catholic retreat house where Marino went in May after church officials learned of his two-year relationship with Ms. Long, a former lay minister. On Aug. 9, Marino checked into St. Vincent's Hospital, a psychiatric center in Harrison, N.Y., near the church retreat house in Larchmont where he had been since resigning. Atlanta station WAGA-TV, quoting unidentified sources, reported Tuesday that Ms. Long had received money orders from May 22 through July 30. And WSB-TV in Atlanta reported an unidentified source as saying the Ms. Long had received $1,500 in money orders from Marino in July. Dora said that as archbishop, Marino's salary was $1,500 a month and Marino is presently receiving the same amount from a pension fund. He emphasized that the money sent to Ms. Long was Marino's personal money. ``There are no diocese funds going to her a this time, there will be no money in the future and there will be no settlement on any claims she might make against the archdiocese in this regard,'' Dora said. Marino, 56, was the nation's highest-ranking black Roman Catholic before to his resignation. Ms. Long, who has also said she had relationships with two other priests and a nun, claims she and Marino were married in 1988. A four-member panel headed by Coca Cola President Donald R. Keough is investigating the church's financial records to determine if church money was improperly paid to Ms. Long. Church officials have acknowledged paying about $15,000 in medical bills for Ms. Long, whose attorneys have sought additional financial compensation, claiming that she was sexually exploited by the archbishop. No legal action has been filed.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
East Germany Agrees to Oct. 3 German Unification Date
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details, quotes, background on merger, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: East German lawmakers ended their anguished and much-ridiculed battle over the date of unification and early Thursday voted to merge the foundering nation with West Germany on Oct. 3. Parliament burst into applause when Parliament's president, Sabine Bergmann-Pohl, announced the ``truly historic event.'' After an 11-hour Parliament session that lasted until Thursday's predawn hours, lawmakers voted 294 to 62 to make Oct. 3 the day the nation becomes part of a single Germany. Seven lawmakers abstained. The date was a compromise between the major factions in Parliament after weeks of battling that tore apart the broad coalition government of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere. Earlier, lawmakers rejected a proposal by the small German Social Union party to unify immediately. Parliament also passed a treaty that will allow all-German elections on Dec. 2. The West German Parliament is to vote on the same treaty Thursday. Easy passage is expected. East Germany in effect has approved a clause, effective Oct. 3, in the West Germany constitution that allows former German lands to accede to the Western nation. It is a major psychological boost to a nation troubled by economic and political chaos. De Maiziere urged lawmakers to accept Oct. 3 as the historic day of German unity and end the seemingly pointless squabbling over whether unity should take place in August, September or October. ``Many people have gotten the impression discussions over a date are more important to us than the solution of crucial problems,'' he told Parliament. ``A binding commitment and an end to the discussion are long overdue,'' he said. The weeks-long dispute was the result of a power struggle between the Christian Democrats of de Maiziere and West German Chacellor Helmut Kohl and the left-leaning Social Democrats in both nations. The two parties are jockeying for the best political advantage heading into Dec. 2 elections for a united German government. Many lawmakers acknowledged the convoluted wrangling in recent days seemed to have lost relevance as average East Germans struggle with rising joblessness and higher prices. ``I ask you, who even understands our desires?'' asked Gregor Gysi, head of the reformed Communists, the third-largest party in Parliament. The lawmakers met in special session to try to resolve differences over the date of unity. The Social Democrats insisted it occur Sept. 15. As East Germany's second-largest party, their approval is needed to pass a unification proposal. De Maiziere's Christian Democrats on Wednesday as a compromise proposed Oct. 3 as the merger date. Kohl's conservative government said earlier in the day that unity could occur on East Germany's Oct. 7 birthday or one day earlier. Kohl has been able to orchestrate most of the unity process. He and de Maiziere, his East German ally, previously backed merging the two countries on Oct. 14, but the Social Democrats balked. The Social Democrats want unity quickly so West Germany can more quickly assume direct responsibility for East Germany's failing economy. Joblessness has been climbing since East Germany converted to a free market on July 1. The Social Democrats also want early unification so that Kohl will be forced to admit the staggering costs of bailing out East Germany and its 16 million residents. This could cost the Christian Democrats at the polls in December. West Germany says it is crucial that unity not occur before the Oct. 1-2 meeting in New York City of foreign ministers from the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. The meeting will cap a series of negotiations between the four World War II Allies _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France _ and the two Germanys on the global aspects of German unity. West Germany has proposed that the results of talks on international aspects of German unity be presented at the this meeting. In those negotiations, the Soviet Union dropped its opposition to NATO membership for a united Germany in exchange for a promise its troops in what is now East Germany can remain there for up to four years. Also reached was an agreement that a united Germany would not try to claim lands forfeited to Poland after Nazi Germany's defeat in 1945. Unemployment has been climbing since East Germany converted to a free market on July 1. Factories have been unable to compete with an invasion of Western products. The debate over the pace of unification and the problems with the economy has led to the resignations or dismissals of six ministers in de Maiziere's Cabinet the past week and the decision by the Social Democrats to leave his coalition. In the end, the compromise was agreed to by the Social Democrats and another party that earlier had left de Maiziere's coalition in the dispute, the Liberal faction.

DOC.HEAD: Bye Bye, Bim Bom: Stranded Soviet Circus Members Go Home
DOC.TEXT: Members of the Great Circus Bim Bom dejectedly left for home Wednesday, 4{ months after the Soviet troupe ran out of money and was stranded. Thirty-five members of the troupe headed for New York, where a rival Soviet circus' promoter put up money to send them home. The group was to leave Thursday night for Leningrad and go from there to Moscow. They were part of a group of about 120 that arrived in this country in March but ran out of funds after two performances. ``Good country, good people, but for me very bad,'' circus musician Yudi Savouskin said in halting English as he boarded a Pan Am flight out of Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport. ``All of our dreams are broken,'' said Boris Rivchun, the Bim Bom music director. ``We have nothing.'' Not even their circus equipment. The Bim Bom entourage returned home without it, and members faced uncertain futures in the Soviet Union. ``I need my instruments back in Moscow,'' Savouskin said. Shortly after arriving in the United States, the circus ran into problems with its tour promoter and its financial backers pulled out. The group came to Atlanta in May, seeking to get its tour back on the road, and began living in a series of motels, college dormitories and church shelters while pursuing funds. The circus' animals were seized by creditors and are being held in New York. The group left Atlanta with airline tickets paid for by Steven E. Leber, a New York businessman who promotes the official Moscow Circus. He said Wednesday he is putting up about $50,000 to get the circus members home and take care of some of their U.S. financial problems. Leber said members of the Bim Bom circus asked him for help. ``They were starving,'' he said. ``They were at the end of their rope.'' Leber also said that Bim Bom was being confused by some people with his circus, and its troubles were threatening the reputation of the Moscow Circus. Leber said he previously had helped 27 members of Bim Bom, who had gone to Las Vegas, return home. Leber and circus members at the airport didn't know how many of their colleagues planned to stay behind and try to find work.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Lawmakers Reject Pardons for Publisher's Slayers
DOC.TEXT: Nicaragua's legislature on Wednesday defeated a bill from President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro asking pardons for at least five men involved in the 1978 murder of her publisher husband. The National Assembly rejected by a 51-30 vote, with eight abstentions, the bill submitted by Mrs. Chamorro last Thursday. She had sought the pardons as part of her campaign to pacify her war-scarred nation. Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, the popular publisher of the afternoon newspaper La Prensa, was ambushed and shot to death by gunmen on a Managua street on his way to work Jan. 10, 1978. The assassination set violent protests that rallied opposition groups around the leftist Sandinista National Liberation Front. The Sandinistas then overthrew dictator Anastasio Somoza in July 1979 and seized power. A decade of war between the Sandinistas and U.S.-backed Contra rebels followed in which tens of thousands died. Mrs. Chamorro succeeded Sandinista leader Daniel Ortega on April 25, after winning elections in a rout three months earlier. Five men were arrested, tried, convicted and sentenced from 20 to 31 years imprisonment for Pedro Joaquin Chamorro's murder, which was widely believed to have been carried out on orders from the Somoza regime. But Mrs. Chamorro's bill, as sent to the legislature, could also extend pardons to suspects from the Somoza regime who had planned the assassination. Until Mrs. Chamorro took office, La Prensa was Nicaragua's only opposition newspaper and her husband is still fondly remembered by people for exposing corruption and human rights abuses under Somoza. Although the Contra war has ended, Nicaraguans remain bitterly split over many national issues, the economy is still in tatters and the Sandinistas are the country's single biggest party. Assembly Speaker Miriam Arguello called for secret balloting Wednesday so that the controversial pardon issue could be voted freely across party lines. Mrs. Chamorro's 14-party United National Opposition coalition, ranging on the political spectrum from hard-line conservatives to Communists and Socialists, holds 51 seats in the 92-member legislature. The Sandinistas have 39 and the Revolutionary Movement Union and the Social Christian Party one each.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Black Panther Ruled Suitable for Parole, but He's Already Free
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with board finding Spain suitable for parole, possibility case could be reviewed again; CORRECTS that order freeing Spain was from state judge sted federal. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Former Black Panther revolutionary Johnny Spain, who was freed from prison by a court order two years ago, was formally found suitable for parole Wednesday by a state panel. But Spain's confusing struggle with state parole authorities isn't over. One member of the panel that voted 2-1 to ratify his earlier release said she would refer his case to the full state parole board for review. It is unclear what would happen if the parole board declared Spain unfit for release, since he has already been freed by a state judge's order. Board of Prison Terms spokeswoman Phyllis Scott said her agency was considering the matter, despite the court decisions, because ``the board has never made a decision on suitability for parole and the board is responsible for determining suitability.'' Spain, 41, who was originally imprisoned for a 1966 murder and was later involved in a bloody uprising at San Quentin prison, has taught at the University of California, Berkeley, and Stanford University, and lectured elsewhere in the two years since his release. He also works at a social service agency for the disabled and homeless in Richmond. Following nearly two hours of deliberation, David Brown, the chairman of the three-member parole panel, said the ruling was largely because Spain has functioned ``as a law-abiding and productive citizen'' since his release. A state judge ordered him freed in 1988 after he served 21 years of his murder sentence. Panel member Maureen O'Connell cast the no vote. Spain's attorney said after the hearing that O'Connell also referred the issue to the full State Parole Board, which triggers an automatic review of the panel's decision. During the hearing, the prosecution's representative, Deputy Los Angeles District Attorney Mark Vezzoni, argued that Spain shouldn't be paroled because he is capable of further violence. ``Americans are hopelessly romantic. They glorify criminals with time. The blood of their victims seems to turn to dust and blow away with time,'' Vezzoni told the panel. But Spain said he had demonstrated his suitability for parole. He told the panel members he was irritated with some of their questions because they appeared antagonistic. But he said he demonstrated his maturity by keeping his temper. Spain's original conviction was for killing a man during a robbery attempt at a bus stop. He allegedly was involved in an escape attempt on Aug. 21, 1971, with fellow San Quentin inmate and Black Panther leader George Jackson. Three prisoners, including Jackson, and three guards were killed. Spain was convicted in 1976 of the murders of two guards although he didn't directly participate in the killings. But the conviction was thrown out after federal courts found that Spain didn't get a fair trial. The state prison terms board, which had previously cited the San Quentin uprising in denying parole, was told by the courts that it could no longer consider that. Spain's attorney, Dennis Riordan, accused Vezzoni of making thinly veiled references to the San Quentin uprising at the hearing. Responding to questions from parole board members, Spain said he was remorseful about the murder, disputed the panel's characterization of him as a former drug abuser, and blamed numerous prison conduct violations in the 1970s largely on being forced to wear restraints every time he left his cell.

DOC.HEAD: Election Board Bars Ex-Dictator from Guatemala Presidential Race
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with Rios Montt seeking reversal, quotes. Picks up 3rd pvs, `Election board...'
DOC.TEXT: The national election board on Wednesday barred former dictator Jose Efrain Rios Montt from running for president in elections scheduled for Nov. 11. The conservative three-party coalition supporting the retired general's candidacy has three days to appeal through the courts, and Rios Montt said he will try to have the decision reversed. ``We didn't expect this. ... I didn't expect it but we are prepared to continue playing the game,'' Rios Montt told a news conference after the ruling was announced. He called it ``a decision by group of citizens who are unaware of what the true rule of law is.'' Election board director Felix Castillo Milla announced the decision at a heavily guarded news conference. He said the ruling was based on provisions in the Guatemalan Constitution. In its resolution rejecting Rios Montt's candidacy, the election board said ``neither the head and leaders of a coup, armed revolution or similar movement that has altered the constitutional order, nor those who have assumed the head of government as a result, can run for president or vice-president of the republic.'' The Supreme Court, in a nonbinding opinion sought by Congress last year, said Rios Montt cannot be president or vice president because of a constitutional ban on the holding of those posts by people who assumed power in a coup. Rios Montt took power after a March 1982 military coup that overthrew President Fernando Romeo Lucas Garcia. As president, he sent more than a dozen leftists before firing squads, including five during a visit by Pope John Paul II. Rios Montt ruled until August 1983 when the army replaced him with Gen. Oscar Humberto Mejia. Rios Montt was nominated to run for president by the Democratic Institutional Party, National Unity Front and Guatemalan Republican Front. A born-again Christian, Rios Montt campaigned on a tough law-and-order platform, making a good showing in early polls among voters concerned about the country's rising crime rate. Human rights workers have worried that Rios Montt's eye-for-an-eye brand of justice would lead to further abuses in a country already plagued with them. So far the only candidate qualified by the election board to run in the presidential race is former Guatemala City Mayor Alvaro Arzu Irigoyen of the National Advance Party. The election board has yet to rule on the applications of at least seven other candidates, including Jorge Carpio Nicolle, whose name was submitted by the National Center Union and the National Authentic Central. Nicolle, a journalist, lost in 1986 to incumbent President Vinicio Cerezo. Candidates have until Sept. 12 to register. The winner of the election will replace Cerezo, who succeeded Mejia after being elected to a five-year term in January 1986. There will be a runoff on Jan. 6 if no candidate wins a majority in the Nov. 11 election.

The Bush administration's decision to add more F-15 fighters and heavy tanks to Saudi Arabia's defensive shield against Iraq has an additional benefit, officials say: drawing the once-resistant Arab nation closer to the West. International cooperation in the bid to reverse Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has opened doors long closed to Washington, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Tuesday as he returned from a four-day trip to the Persian Gulf. ``I think the degree of cooperation today _ in terms of U.S. military presence and a collective security effort _ obviously is far greater than it has ever been before,'' Cheney said. Because the threat from Iraq is so serious to the moderate Arab rulers in the gulf region, Cheney said, ``Nations that previously have had sort of an arms-length relationship with the U.S. military are eager to cooperate with and support our efforts in the region, and the efforts of the other nations involved.''

The incidents are isolated, but the fears of the Arab-American community are pervasive. A young Palestinian in Chicago is attacked and told to go back to Iraq. An Arab-American newspaper editor in Detroit is warned in a phone call he will die if Americans in Kuwait are harmed. A San Francisco Arab-American professor receives death threats after telling a newspaper he favors a negotiated settlement to the Middle East crisis. In Cleveland, an Egyptian grocer involved in a minor dispute with some local kids is thrown in jail for a night, and police yell ethnic slurs at him. In Toledo, a white racist group beats up an Arab-American who refuses to sell his business. Arab-American organizations and leaders who related these incidents said they are symptomatic of anti-Arab actions that occur whenever tensions rise in the Middle East.

In Texas, near Fort Hood, the waiting period for marriage licenses is waived to accommodate soldiers shipping out to the Middle East. A Florida manufacturer of sunblock cream offers to make an unscented batch because, ``I'd hate to see 5,000 of our guys advancing across the desert toward the enemy smelling like a coconut.'' Perhaps influenced by the movie ``Dirty Dozen,'' 14 inmates at Cross City Correctional Institution in North Florida announce they want to fight in Saudi Arabia, redeem their honor, and gain their freedom. In thousands of ways, America prepares for war.

Nearly three weeks after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the first signs are showing of a gathering economic crisis in the developing world. In Nepal, there's a run on gasoline, and gas prices have increased 50 percent in Zambia. Sri Lanka is worried about access to the Persian Gulf states who are major purchases of tea, its principal foreign exchange earner. Scores of oil-poor and cash-strapped nations face inflation, slower growth and increased debt after Iraq invaded Kuwait, causing crude prices to rise from about $20 a barrel to more than $25. The worst hit are the smaller and poorer nations of the world, for whom increasing oil prices and U.N. sanctions on trade with Iraq and Kuwait will drastically disrupt their already tenuous balance of payments.

DOC.HEAD: Democracy Has Fragile Hold In Traditionally Violent Balkans
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: The fall of communism has brought a sense of unraveling to the Balkans, where the new democracy holds fragile sway over emotional peoples tormented by ancient ethnic hatreds. Long-suppressed nationalism and economic backwardness bedevil the transition throughout the former Soviet bloc, but nowhere is the danger of national dissolution or even armed conflict so great as in the Balkans. Balkan peoples have little tradition of democracy and have endured centuries of brutal outside domination. They are fiercely proud of their ethnicity and often settle scores in blood. Scars inflicted by the past are as fresh as if incurred yesterday. The thirst for revenge runs deep. ``The past hangs over the whole of politics, as elsewhere in Europe, with the difference that in the Balkans, there has never been a juridical arrangement of all these matters,'' said Nikolai Todorov, one of Bulgaria's foremost experts on the region. ``The heritage is very difficult to overcome, because there are compact masses of nationalities which were included in new states built on the national principle,'' he said, alluding to such minorities as Bulgaria's 1 million ethnic Turks, the 2 million Hungarians in Romania and the scattered ethnic groups of Yugoslavia. Before communism arrived, Balkan borders were shifted constantly by battles between outside rulers, often in the names of their religions: the Orthodox south Slavs; the Ottoman Turks, Moslems who dominated the southern Balkans for centuries, and the Hapsburgs, Roman Catholics from the north. In World War II, fought in most of Europe as a struggle between democracy and dictatorship, Balkan countries gained and lost territory at the whim of outside powers. In Yugoslavia, about 1 million people were killed in largely fratricidal conflict. As recently as 1989, old hatreds drove 300,000 ethnic Turks from Bulgaria. It was Europe's biggest emigration in 40 years. Balkan peoples _ accustomed to violence, far from Western Europe and often isolated in mountain valleys even from one another _ traditionally have felt secure only in the very ethnic consciousness that nurtures more conflict. Religion, a folk song, one's land or village exercise a greater hold because they have proved more lasting than the different masters of this strikingly beautiful region. Added to the mystical sense of ethnicity are the legacies of great empires. At one spot in central Sofia, an Orthodox church, a mosque, a Lenin statue and a sleek Sheraton hotel face one another. Bulgarians must untangle a complex heritage of Ottoman and Soviet repression and Orthodox acquiescence in the status quo in order to make reality of the very different jargon of democracy, human rights and market economy. New concepts of freedom, and the watchword ``Europe,'' are invoked almost as if they could magically overcome the burdens of history and economic backwardness, transforming the Balkans instantly into France. The political impossibility of such rapid change is obvious even in such tangibly European cities as Ljubljana, capital of Slovenia, the northern Yugoslav republic next to Austria and Italy. ``Nationalism is only part of the problem,'' a Slovenian journalist said, on condition of anonymity. ``There is also the politics of small nations.'' Among the Slovenes, who number just under 2 million, almost all prominent politicians, businessmans, journalists and intellectuals know each other. Graft and intrigue can flourish in such tight circles, as they traditionally did in the Hapsburg empire, to which Slovenia belonged for centuries. Circumstances like that make it difficult for the often Europeanized intellectuals of the Balkans to follow the East European tradition of doubling as far-sighted politicians. Romania, for instance, has suffered since its revolution in December from the refusal of most leading intellectuals to join any political party. An outspoken, independent media, virtually nonexistent in the Balkans, is just one aspect of democracy difficult to achieve. The media often inflame passions rather than soothe them, especially in Yugoslavia, whose fragile federation of six quarrelsome republics seems destined to dissolve. A print war many fear will lead to shooting is being waged between Serbia, the largest republic and the only one where Communist leaders refuse free elections, and Croatia, which elected a center-right government in March. Serbia has demonstrated a readiness to get tough by its actions in Kosovo, a southern province that was the heart of ancient Serbia and now is dominated by ethnic Albanians. Serbia claims they seek union with neighboring Albania. At least 60 ethnic Albanians have been killed in confrontations with security forces. Ethnic Albanian media and institutions have been virtually eliminated. Such tactics by Serbia have encouraged the efforts of relatively prosperous Slovenia and Croatia, both Roman Catholic parts of the old Hapsburg empire, to draw away from the rest of Yugoslavia. Repression in Kosovo also could prove dangerous if democratic reform took hold in Albania. The province's ethnic Albanians, about 85 percent of the population, then could press in earnest for union with brothers across the border. Romania and Bulgaria face the problem of sharing power with minorities at the political level, where daily life is largely determined. Bulgaria holds its first free local elections in October. Ethnic Turks are expected to win in Kurdzhali and other towns that were paralyzed this summer by strikes of ethnic Bulgarians who feared Turkish domination. In Romania, local elections scheduled for next year could give Hungarians control of Transylvania, the western region adjacent to Hungary. Whether the Romanian elections even will be held remains a question. There are increasing rumors in Bucharest that the army is preapring to take over. Economic chaos everywhere in the Balkans feeds fears of a rapid slide away from democracy. Ante Markovic, the federal premier of Yugoslavia, has curbed inflation but the newly convertible dinar is overvalued and prices in some areas are higher than in Austria, although pay averages only $280 a month. Reduced Soviet oil shipments and the latest Middle East crisis have caused an energy crunch in Bulgaria and Romania. Both introduced rationing of sugar and other staples in August, and everyone seems to expect a hard winter.

DOC.HEAD: Politics Built on Ethnic Tension Threaten Yugoslav Unity
With BC-Simmering Balkans
DOC.TEXT: Three friends whose ethnic groups hate each other were having coffee together, watching what little of the world passes by in this sleepy village on the Hungarian border. They chatted amiably _ a Serb, a Croat and an Albanian belying the centuries-old tendency of their fellows to be at each other's throats for ethnic and religious reasons. To Yugoslav media and politicians, the internal conflict is the culmination of a power struggle building since the death in 1980 of Josip Tito, who founded communist Yugoslavia and ruled it for 35 years. How it comes out will determine whether the six divergent republics stick together or Yugoslavia becomes the first country in postwar Europe to split up. For Mladen Kresic, the Serb, and his two friends, tension is more personal: who spits at whom and which old acquaintances turn their backs. ``At this point, it's a confrontation between individuals; it's not a confrontation between two groups,'' he said, speaking of Serbs and Croats. Kresic, a 44-year-old auto mechanic, said he could not recall another time when tension was so high in Branjin Vrh, a mainly Croatian village in a Serb-dominated area of Croatia. ``Anything could happen,'' he said, and sighed. Serbs and Croats are the two largest ethnic groups in Yugoslavia. Relations between them have grown worse since Croatia, the second-largest republic, held free elections in April. Elections in three other republics this fall are expected to exacerbate ethnic tensions and political divisions. The center-right Croatian Democratic Union won Croatia's elections. The Communist leaders of Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest republic, accuse the party of being too nationalistic. Abiding divisions lend heat to the debate. Croats, ruled by the Hapsburgs for centuries, are Roman Catholic and write in Latin script. Serbs, dominated by Ottoman Turks for more than 500 years, are Orthodox and use Cyrillic script. Media in the two republics argue everything from who killed who in the estimated 1 million deaths from fratricidal fighting during World War II to how to divide economic spoils, redraw borders or develop democracy. ``We have to solve several problems at once,'' said Stjepo Martinovic, executive editor of Fnesnik, Croatia's main daily newspaper. ``As in, say, Czechoslovakia, there are the questions of culture, parliamentary democracy and a market economy. ``But here we have two other big questions: the position of the republics and the national question, which hasn't been solved. During the Socialist period . . . it officially didn't exist.'' In Beli Manastir, a Serbian town down the road from Branjin Vrh, Judge Tihomir Stojanovic said: ``There is no democracy; there is only nationalism.'' Nationalist feeling, rising throughout the old Soviet bloc, is particularly dangerous in Yugoslavia, where pockets of one nationality, like Croatia's half- million Serbs, are scattered through the feuding republics. The idea of Yugoslavia as a federation uniting the scattered southern Slavic groups gave Stojanovic and other Serbs in Croatia a feeling of security. They could be Yugoslavs first, then Serbs. For Croatians like Neven Jurica, a leader of the Croatian Democratic Union, Yugoslavia was an institution that denied Croats full sovereignty over their affairs and money. He confidently outlined plans for a new Croatian constitution to be presented in October. He has no doubt it will pass the Croation parliament, which his party dominates. ``It's a complete change of Yugoslavia as it currently exists,'' Jurica said. ``The Yugoslav idea is only based on ideological theses. It is definitely dead.'' A new Yugoslavia can be based only on a new agreement of common interests, he said, echoing the views of the new center-right government in neighboring Slovenia. To protect themselves from what they see as rising Croatian nationalism, many Serbs living in Croatia joined a new political party. Slobodan Milosevic, the Communist leader of Serbia, even talks of demanding a border change to protect Croatia's Serbs. Milosevic and the Slovenes have quarreled for two years over democracy and Serbia's repressive treatment of the ethnic Albanian majority in its province of Kosovo, the ancient Serb heartland. Most political observers say the newer conflict between the Serbian Communist leaders and the new Croatian government will decide Yugoslavia's fate. In Branjin Vrh, 17-year-old Dalibor Hosovic, a Croat, said he wished there were no differences, but that weddings always make them clear: ``When they sing a Croatian song, you see who is Croat and who is Serb. It's the expression on their faces.''

DOC.HEAD: Many Ethnic Conflicts Simmer in Balkans
With BC-Simmering Balkans
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia and Romania each have about 23 million, Bulgaria's population is 9 million and 3 million people live in Albania. All contain potentially explosive mixtures of ethnic groups and religions. The main conflics: SERB-CROAT _ The Serbs, Yugoslavia's largest ethnic group, have a different script, religion and history then the Croats, the second largest group, although they have a virtually common language. SERB-ALBANIAN _ Serbs and ethnic Albanians confront one another in Kosovo, a Serbian province bordering Albania. Kosovo, the ancient center of Serb culture, now has an ethnic Albanian majority. BULGARIAN-TURK _ About 1 million ethnic Turks live in Bulgaria. They were subject to a violent assimilation campaign under the Communists and now are asserting their political voice, reviving memories among Bulgarian nationalists of more than 500 years of oppression by the Ottoman Turks. ROMANIAN-HUNGARIAN _ Romania's 2 million Hungarians demand more minority rights in Transylvania, an area ruled by Hungary for centuries and awarded to Romania at the end of both world wars.
