DOC.HEAD: After 20 Years, a Pilgrimage Back to Vietnam
LaserPhoto NY304-305 of Aug. 22
DOC.TEXT: The Vietnam War left Cherie Rankin a legacy of sadness denied and tears delayed. As a 24-year-old Red Cross worker confronted every day by death and suffering, she was unable to cry. ``When you're in a war,'' she says, ``you have to turn off the feelings in order to do the work.'' For more than a decade after she came home in September 1971, just thinking about Vietnam produced headaches, and she'd become sick to her stomach. At a reunion of Red Cross workers in 1984, she threw up. Until then, she says, she had no idea how Vietnam had affected her. Now, 20 years later, she is making a sentimental journey back to help restore some of what the United States destroyed, and to shed her tears. Ms. Rankin is part of a group of nine Americans paying their own way over to help rebuild a medical clinic near Hanoi destroyed by U.S. bombers. The team, which is leaving in early September, is the third to return to build badly needed medical facilities under the auspices of the Veterans Vietnam Restoration Project in Garberville, Calif. During September and October, they will work with former Vietnamese enemies who now are comrades in peace. Ms. Rankin, now 44, will revisit the fields where the men she knew died and walk the grounds of the Da Nang-area orphanage where she fed, clothed and played with the pitifully maimed children of war. ``While I was there, I never felt the sadness, and I carry around some pain for those children,'' she said. ``Being able to do the crying on the spot would be helpful _ being near firebases where many men who died I knew, whose faces I see in my mind, to do some crying for them.'' She remembers flying in helicopters to the American firebases to boost the soldiers' morale. She is in field hospitals holding the hands of mortally wounded GIs. They clutch her tightly. She is their last link to life. The baby-face of a young GI she met in Da Nang while he was awaiting his assignment is forever fixed in her mind. He was so new his boots still were spit-shined. A few days later, she saw him lying in a field hospital with tubes sticking out of him and the right side of his face blown away. ``I went over to him and held his hand,'' she said. ``I reminded him I had seen him the other day, and I think I said to him, `I'm sorry.' He flicked his eyes. He couldn't talk. But he gripped my hand.'' Within minutes, he was dead. ``That was my first death experience. I marked that as the period of time where I numbed out. When I saw that kid there, I really wanted to run. I wanted to go home. I wanted my mother.'' Sometimes, she still can hear the familiar whirring sounds of the helicopters and her mind drifts back. She now feels the fear she repressed, and she shakes at the thought of it. Dreams of Vietnam invade her sleep. If she doesn't remember them, there always are the pillows across her body to remind her. During the war, Red Cross workers pulled mattresses over their bodies to protect themselves during rocket attacks. ``I will wake up startled ... and all of my bed pillows are lined up the length of the bed,'' she said. ``Even if I don't have a clear memory of the dream, I'm acting as though I were experiencing it.'' Other images are of the children for whom she cared. They are scorched by napalm, blinded by bombs. Their arms and legs are missing. Among her poignant photos is one of an orphan, an Amerasian boy born to a Vietnamese mother and American father. He sits forlornly. A fly rests on his face. One of his legs is missing, blown away by a mine. ``He represents Vietnam to me,'' said Ms. Rankin. ``This is the child of the war and it says it all to me.'' But there were rare moments of joy amid the poverty and pain. A reminder is another photo, this one of three grinning orphan boys throwing their arms around her. One is blind, one is missing part of his leg and one is retarded. ``I love it,'' Ms. Rankin said. ``Just look at how happy I am to see those kids and how happy they are to see me, how much physical touch is being shared.'' Ms. Rankin, who originally is from West Palm Beach, Fla., went to Vietnam in September 1970, just out of Florida State University in Tallahassee. She did not believe in the war but had faith in the men who were fighting, like her younger brother, Doug, a Marine. ``I went to visit my brother,'' she said. ``Even though I had questions about the war, I really undertstood why the guys were there and I wanted to do what I could to help them. I also wanted the adventure and to find out why we were there, see for myself.'' Despite her reservations, and the sexism and sexual harassment she sometimes encountered, she didn't question the U.S. government's morality or motivation. ``I was so red, white and blue my blood was lavender,'' Ms. Rankin said. ``I think we fell into two categories in their mind. We were either virgins or whores, their favorite girlfriend or sister, or we were there to be propositioned. ``I feel I was a pawn of our government, coercing soldiers to fight. Red Cross women were held up as home and apple pie. `This is what you're fighting for.' The way the military used Red Cross women was sexist. We were there ... to be their decoration. ... We're flying out in helicopters in dresses.'' When she returned home a year later, the formerly gregarious woman withdrew into herself, seeking solace in solitude. ``For many years, I would be afraid to be in crowds. I did not like going to social events,'' she said. But that has improved through counseling at a veterans center. ``I've had therapy off and on for 10 years,'' she said. ``I figure it's the rest of my life, not necessarily anymore because I have impairment for any level of functioning, but it's a matter of growth, knowing yourself, learning about yourself. It's an ongoing process.''
DOC.NOTE: MORE
$Adv26
For release Sunday, Aug. 26, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: NORWOOD, Mass: ongoing process.
DOC.TEXT: She first went into therapy for help with some marital and childhood issues. ``I had no idea Vietnam affected me until around six years ago,'' she said. She and her husband divorced in 1983, partly due to the war. ``I closed the book on Vietnam when I got back like everybody else did,'' she said. ``My husband had been a war protester and we never talked about Vietnam. He was not comfortable talking about it. Neither was anybody else in the country.'' At the Vietnam reunion in New York City six years ago, ``the whole thing started opening up, everything started coming to the surface,'' she said. Just after she arrived, she got a throbbing headache that lasted for a day and a half until she threw up. ``I felt better after I did that,'' she said. ``It's taken me a long time. I would have physical responses to thinking about Vietnam or talking about Vietnam that would last sometimes for a couple of weeks. Now I have a little bit of an emotional response after I talk about Vietnam.'' Ms. Rankin herself is a psychotherapist. While in Vietnam, she will do some construction work, but she also will serve as the team shrink, co-leading a discussion group. She is one of hundreds of veterans returning in recent years to try to sort out the real war, as well as the war in their minds. ``It profoundly affected your life, whether you're conscious of it or not,'' she said. ``I think many of us who make that pilgrimage back become conscious that it affected our lives and there's something we haven't resolved, or haven't put to rest. I think people go back to do that.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Aug. 26

DOC.TEXT: The government ran up more red ink in July as the federal deficit jumped another $25.9 billion, boosting the shortfall so far this year 52.9 percent above the comparable period of 1989. The Treasury Department said Tuesday that the eighth monthly deficit in the first 10 months of fiscal 1990 pushed the year's imbalance so far to $189.1 billion, compared with $123.7 billion at the end of July 1989. The White House is forecasting a $218.5 billion imbalance when the current fiscal year ends Sept. 30.

Donald Trump escaped financial collapse when casino regulators approved his bailout plan, but he still must convince them his gaming halls are solvent or risk losing his licenses. The state Casino Control Commission voted 5-0 on Tuesday to approve Trump's plan to put up his three Atlantic City casinos as collateral for a $65 million loan he received in June to make a $43 million bond payment. ``This is obviously a situation in which there are no good answers for Mr. Trump or New Jersey,'' acting commission Chairwoman Valerie Armstrong said, adding that regulators had no choice but to approve the plan.

Six of the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet next week to discuss oil supplies in the midst of the Middle East crisis, petroleum industry sources said. Algeria, Indonesia, Iran, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela will participate, although the location was not immediately known, the sources said Tuesday. Saudi Arabia and Venezuela had failed Monday to convince a majority of OPEC members to agree to a conference on the Gulf crisis.

Companies are jamming goverment phone lines to find out what benefits they are obligated to provide employees who may be called to active duty as military reservists during the Persian Gulf standoff. Small business operators said Tuesday they would have the most difficult time filling the gaps created by absent reservists. ``I have no one to cover for me, and my patients would have to go elsewhere for treatment,'' said Ted Thomas, a dentist in solo practice in Clinton, N.C. ``It would almost be like starting over once I return.''

Wang Laboratories Inc., plagued by losses for more than a year, has received a government contract worth up to $841 million _ the largest in the computer maker's history. Under the contract announced Tuesday, Wang will provide a wide range of computers, software and other services for the U.S. State Department during the next five years. Wang called the deal ``a very significant hunk of business.''

National Semiconductor will close some facilities in Washington and Arizona and reduce its worldwide work force by about 2,000 over the next few months. The company said Tuesday that it will close the fabrication line in its plant in Puyallup, Wash., as well as its military-product assembly and testing facility in Tucson, Ariz. National Semiconductor expects to incur a one-time charge of about $140 million in its first fiscal quarter ending Aug. 26.

The agency created to handle the savings and loan bailout has given final approval to regulations covering the sale of thousands of homes to poor people. The Resolution Trust Corp. plans eventually to sell about 10,000 homes reposssessed by failed S&Ls to needy individuals, but it has come under criticism for moving too slowly to implement the program established by last year's S&L bailout legislation.

Two research scientists were indicted for allegedly conspiring to sell the trade secrets for two lucrative pharmaceuticals to an undercover FBI agent for more than $7.5 million. Bernard Mayles, 52, and Mario Miscio, 63, were indicted in federal court Tuesday on five counts of conspiring to sell patented information for ivermectin, a leading anti-parasitic drug, and interferon, which has shown promise in treating cancer and hepatitis. The FBI said it had unraveled ``a classic case of industrial espionage.''

Roy Rogers restaurants has again killed the most popular television ad it's ever run, after a repeat of criticism from the Institutional Food Workers of America. The advertisement features women serving plates of unappetizing food in a school cafeteria. The spot, with ``See You in September'' in the background, encouraged school children to come eat at Roy Rogers before they're faced with nine months of cafeteria food.

Stock prices fell sharply in heavy trading Tuesday as investors continued to worry about the prospect of war in the Mideast. The Dow Jones average fell 52.48 to close at 2,603.96, as declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by nearly 6-1. Bond prices tumbled and then rebounded to finish nearly unchanged Tuesday. The dollar finished mixed after falling overseas Tuesday, while gold prices slipped. On other markets, petroleum futures were mostly higher; orange juice was sharply lower; grain and soybeans were mostly lower; and cattle was mostly higher while pork declined.

DOC.HEAD: Casino Commission Approves Trump Bailout Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: With BC-Trump Finances-Excerpts
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: No sooner did Donald Trump win some time to restructure his troubled financial empire than the clock began ticking for his next showdown with gambling regulators in October. The Casino Control Commission voted 5-0 to approve a bailout plan that pledges Trump's three casinos as collateral for a $65 million loan he received to make a bond payment on the Trump Castle hotel and casino. But the commission decided to call Trump in early for relicensing hearings on all three of his casinos because of questions surrounding his finances. Trump wasn't scheduled for the hearings until the spring, but the commission wants to see him in October. ``We must hold a financial stability hearing as soon as possible,'' said acting commission Chairwoman Valerie Armstrong. ``The Casino Control Act requires all casino enterprises to maintain financial stability, integrity and responsibility. ``We have approved the pledges without inquiring into whether the three Trump properties continue to meet these standards, and it is surely our obligation to conduct that inquiry as quickly as we can,'' Ms. Armstrong said. The October hearing comes one month before Trump must make a $47 million bond payment due Nov. 15 on the Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort. The state Division of Gaming Enforcement, which reluctantly endorsed Trump's bailout, said the developer will not make that payment under present conditions. ``November is just around the corner and that's the immediate problem we face,'' said Thomas Auriemma, a deputy attorney general with the division. ``If the money had not been advanced, the whole Trump Organization would have faced, in our opinion, total collapse.'' Trump's attorneys also argued that his empire could have crumbled without the commission's approval. Ms. Armstrong said the commission shared the division's lack of enthusiasm for the plan, but would approve it as the best immediate hope for the solvency of Trump's three casinos. ``This is obviously a situation in which there are no good answers for Mr. Trump or New Jersey,'' she said. ``Whether we approve or disapprove this restructuring, our action will be fundamentally unsettling. . . . The risk of substantial economic disruption at the casinos will be less with the restructuring than it is without it.'' Trump _ wearing a blue tie, blue suit and blue-striped shirt _ whispered occasionally during the 30-minute hearing to his top executives, but otherwise stared straight ahead, unsmiling and with his lips pursed. He repeatedly told a throng of reporters and camera crews afterward that the ruling left him happy. He also restated his belief that his plight was not unusual because he feels the country is in a recession. Once the economy improves, his assets will rebound, he said. ``This is a big hurdle and I'm happy,'' Trump told reporters. ``Maybe you can focus on someone else now.'' Trump said the first task of the financial restructuring would be to focus on the Taj Mahal. Since its opening April 2, the Taj has either fallen short or just reached the $1.3 million a day in gross gaming revenues that analysts say it needs to break even. The Taj Mahal lost $14.4 million on gross revenue of $126 million in its first three months ended June 30, according to figures released last week by the Casino Association of New Jersey. Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino had a profit of $876,000 on gross revenues of $83.4 million, while Trump Castle lost $8.1 million on gross revenues of $63.4 million. In approving the bailout package, the casino commission cited the benefits of an immediate infusion of $65 million, deferred interest payments on outstanding loans, and a requirement that banks holding at least two-thirds of the loan find Trump in default before action can be taken against him. The approval also came with several reservations about the Trump Organization, which has compiled more than $3.2 billion in debt on Trump's casinos, Manhattan real estate, Trump Shuttle airline and yacht. The casinos bear responsibility for roughly $1.3 billion in debt. Ms. Armstrong said the agreement contains destabilizing features for the casinos, including a link between the three properties that could prompt foreclosure at two Trump gaming halls if financial problems arose at a third. ``Even more disturbing is the link the restructuring forges between the fate of the casinos and that of other Trump assets,'' Ms. Armstrong said, using a possible bankruptcy at the Trump Shuttle as one possible example. Trump faces $540.5 million in overdue debts, $240.5 million of which he has personally guaranteed, Ms. Armstrong said. He will face an additional $169.5 million in debt by the end of April. Commissioners and the division both said Trump's problems stand out as clear reasons why other casinos should avoid assuming huge amounts of debt.

DOC.HEAD: Businesses Brace For Reserve Recall; Small Firms Hit Hardest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Companies are jamming government phone lines to find out what benefits they are obligated to provide employees who may be called to active duty as military reservists. Small business operators said Tuesday they would have the most difficult time filling the gaps created by absent reservists called to support operations in the Persian Gulf. ``It can be hurtful. It's all I've been thinking about,'' said Ted Thomas, a dentist in solo practice in Clinton, N.C. ``I have no one to cover for me, and my patients would have to go elsewhere for treatment. It would almost be like starting over once I return.'' Thomas and others like him may request exemptions if called. But they would have to prove ``severe hardship,'' and even then there are no guarantees, military experts said. For big business, the impact is softened by bigger numbers. ``We probably have 9,600 employees total; probably 40 to 50 are involved in the reserves, so that small a ratio in essence wouldn't have that big of an impact,'' said Disney Reece, director of human resources for Memorex Telex Corp.'s storage systems group in Tulsa, Okla. Medical personnel as well as people with expertise in communications and electronics are likely to be in highest demand. At the Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Northport, N.Y., on Long Island, hospital officials are making plans to replace anyone called to duty. Administrative assistant Marlin Schuh speculated the impact will be minimal, ``unless they took some of the critical specialists, like a skilled surgeon.'' Though federal laws were put in place in the 1940s to protect reservists from losing their jobs, confusion abounds. The number of businesses seeking information on the law has tripled in the past few days compared with normal August activity, said Maj. Austin Smith at the Defense Department's National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserves. The committee is scrambling to get guidelines out in overnight mail to district offices that can work with businesses on a local basis. ``The vast majority of employers are perfectly willing to adhere to the law, but an awful lot of them don't understand what the provisions are because it is used so seldomly,'' said John Tieso of the Labor Department's Division of Veterans' Re-employment Rights. Under the law, reservists called out of the civilian work force must be treated like any worker on an unpaid leave of absence. When they return, businesses large and small must give them their old jobs back _ or ones of equal stature _ with full seniority. In addition, reservists are due any increase in pay or benefits that other workers received while they were gone. But the law also gives employers the right to lay off a reservist if it can show the job was eliminated while he or she was away at duty. Though employers aren't required to provide medical benefits, many allow reservists to continue coverage if they pay their own premiums. ``There's a good possibility that corporate coverage is better than government coverage,'' said one officer who asked not to be identified. Reservists who serve more than 30 days are covered by the military's medical plan. A potential problem arises, Tieso said, for those who serve under one month. Many businesses that have called the Labor and Defense departments to check on the law have indicated they'll continue medical benefits for reservists during the initial 30-day period. ``In a relatively unknown situation where they don't know how long it's going to be _ it could be five days, 15 days or 150 days _ some employers are simply saying, `Hey, don't worry about it. We'll take care of it until you get home,' '' Tieso said. So far employers aren't balking over the law, Tieso said. ``Most of them want to make it easier for these guys to go off to service. It's a nice way to do business,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Milk Hormone Safe, Doctors Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A synthetic hormone that can boost milk production in dairy cows by 10 percent to 25 percent has cleared all the safety testing it needs and merits approval for commercial use, doctors say in a medical journal. The hormone, bovine somatotropin or BST, has been banned temporarily in two states. But the doctors wrote in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association that it ``causes no changes in milk composition of any practical importance to consumers.'' ``The minor differences in milk composition shown between unsupplemented and BST-supplemented cows are well within normal biological variation in milk composition,'' they wrote. The authors, Dr. William H. Daughaday of Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis, and David M. Barbano of the Food Science Department at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., each have done consulting or research work under grants from one of its four manufacturers, Monsanto Co., the journal said. However, an editorial by an outside researcher concurred with their conclusions, saying ``milk produced from cows treated with bovine somatotropin is no different from the milk of untreated cows.'' ``It is both inappropriate and wrong for special-interest groups to play on the health and safety fears of the public to further their own ends,'' said the editorial, by Charles H. Grossman, an immunologist at the Department of Veterans Affairs in Cincinnati. Daughaday and Barbano noted that the Food and Drug Administration pronounced the hormone safe in 1985, and could approve its commercial use by next year, a possibility that has raised concerns among groups opposed to genetic engineering. The hormone is produced by a method similar to that used to make synthetic human insulin. Critics say not enough research has been done to be sure milk produced by cows injected with the animal hormone would be safe for people. Grossman said ``hysterical reaction'' produced laws in Wisconsin and Minnesota temporarily barring the use of bST for at least a year. However, in January, the chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., called for an investigation of the FDA's review of the hormone after allegations that the review had been inadequate.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Caps on Some Lawyers' Fees in Asbestos Litigation
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge supervising an overhaul of the Manville trust fund for the first time limited fees to plaintiffs lawyers for settling claims involving asbestos-related diseases. U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein, who has ordered an overhaul of the cash-strapped trust, Tuesday limited the amount lawyers can charge clients to 20 percent of settlements in emergency cases. Weinstein last month froze all payments by the trust pending a reorganization plan except to victims who can demonstrate financial or medical hardship. The freeze is in place until Sept. 6, when a financial restructuring plan is due. An estimated one third of more than $1 billion paid to asbestos victims since the trust was established in 1988 has gone to attorneys handling the cases. Limits on payment arrangements between attorneys and their clients was not ordered when the trust was formed as part of Manville Corp.'s bankruptcy reorganization. Weinstein has been highly critical of the amount received by lawyers, and had promised to reduce the payments so victims could receive more money in the future. ``The matter of fees is now being considered in connection with a restructuring of the trust's payment program,'' Weinstein wrote in his order. ``Ongoing discussions with representative plaintiffs lawyers are continuing.'' The fee cap applies only to hardship claim settlements, under which claimants must prove extreme financial need based on number of dependents, disease prognosis, prior settlements, assets and liabilities and other income. Under Weinstein's ruling, for settlements paid out over time, the 20 percent fee limit may be collected only as each payment is received so that victims or their families always receive 80 percent of each check. Attorneys were expected to challenge the cap. Many plaintiffs lawyers have argued they have earned the amount charged by virtue of more than a decade of work by some attorneys in the asbestos litigation. ``The judge had made it clear that he anticipated some type of reduction, though I think the reduction is more than is justified given the amount fo work that goes into these cases,'' said Stanley Levy, a leading asbestos plaintiffs lawyer. ``It also raises the question of whether he really has the authority to interfere in the contractual relationship between a client and the attorney,'' Levy said. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland, who presided over the Manville reorganization, refused to impose a limit on attorneys fees. No other judge has sought such a limit before. The trust to date has settled close to 24,000 claims for more than $1 billion from people with lung cancer and other respiratory diseases caused by inhaling asbestos fibers, mostly during shipbuilding and other construction. But the trust faces 130,000 more claims it can't meet and has paid only two thirds of the money it owes in settled cases. The reorganization order came after the trust said it was out of money to pay new claims it said would not be met until well into the 21st century. The trust also is under fire for a decision to hire a public relations firm on a $10,000 monthly retainer with a $15,000 monthly cap. The trust has paid the firm, Robinson, Lake, Lerer and Montgomery, about $30,000 so far. It is unclear whether the payments violate Weinstein's freeze on payments, but the judge has been notified about the public relations firm's hiring, one of his law clerks said Tuesday. The trust eventually is expected to be consolidated with a group of asbestos-making companies that say they can't meet asbestos claims into a single class-action lawsuit before Weinstein.

DOC.HEAD: Fortune Billionaires Club Worth Nearly Half A Trillion
LaserPhoto NY43 of Aug. 21.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Billionaires-List
DOC.TEXT: If you wondered why oil is worth fighting for, take a look at Fortune magazine's latest ranking of the world's billionaires. The two richest people on the face of the earth are oil barons, the magazine reported Tuesday. Sultan Haji Hassanal Bolkiah, oil-rich leader of the tiny Pacific sultanate of Brunei, retained Fortune's top title for the fourth straight year with an estimated worth of $25 billion, unchanged from 1989. Saudi Arabia's King Fahd and clan, a focus of the Persian Gulf crisis, ranked second with assets worth $18 billion, also unchanged from last year. Fortune spokeswoman Emma Dockendorff said those estimates were based partly on oil prices in mid-July, when one barrel of crude fetched about $18. Prices have since surged to about $28 a barrel following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and the U.S. move to protect neighboring Saudi Arabia. That price jump would make the sultan and the king potentially even wealthier. The ranks of Fortune's richest _ bankrolled by assets ranging from oil to sneakers to ball bearings _ swelled by 25 names this year to 182 individuals and families, controlling a combined empire worth $471.3 billion. That's up about 7 percent from last year and enough to erase the U.S. budget deficit, trade deficit and a good chunk of the savings & loan bailout tab. Fortune released the fourth annual ranking in its Sept. 10 issue. It said the average entrant's wealth was only slightly higher compared with last year after adjusting for inflation. But the average fortune was still worth about $2.6 billion, which if invested in 7.5 percent U.S. Treasury bills would earn $534,000 a day. ``True, you shouldn't feel too sorry for folks who have their own islands and castles, use Reniors for wallpaper and control, in the aggregate, $471.3 billion,'' Fortune said. As competitor Forbes magazine did in its annual list released last month, Fortune ditched the Sultan of New York, Donald J. Trump, whose real estate and casino empire is bogged down in debt. The magazine had estimated his holdings at $1.7 billion last year. Fortune placed Trump in a separate category of fallen tycoons, who also included troubled takeover strategist James Goldsmith and convicted financier Michael Milken. Ranked third on Fortune's list was the reclusive Mars family of the United States, whose holdings include Mars Inc. candy bars, Uncle Ben's Rice and Kal-Kan pet food, worth $12.5 billion. Fourth was Britain's Queen Elizabeth II, the wealthiest woman, with an untaxed personal fortune of $11.7 billion in riches ranging from 267,000 acres of Royal real estate to racehorses, crown jewels and a vast stock portfolio. Fifth was the Newhouse family of the United States, owners of a large media empire, worth $11.5 billion; sixth was the Reichmann family of Canada, with extensive real estate holdings valued at $11.1 billion; tied for seventh were Yoshiaki Tsutsumi, Japan's richest industrialist, and Arkansas retailing mogul Sam Walton, both valued at $7.3 billion; eighth was John W. Kluge of the United States, owner of media giant Metromedia Inc., valued at $7.0 billion; ninth was Tsai Wan-lin and family of Taiwan, owners of a construction and insurance empire worth $6.5 billion; 10th was the Thomson family, owners of Canada's biggest newspaper chain, at $6.2 billion. American newcomers included the Stephens family of Arkansas, owners of investment banking, energy and real estate holdings worth $1.7 billion; the Parfet family of Kalamazoo, Mich., owners of a large stake in the Upjohn Co. drugmaker, worth $1.5 billion; and Philip Knight, head of the Nike Inc. athletic footwear maker, $1.3 billion. Foreign newcomers included Alicia and Esther Koplovitz of Spain, owners of a $2.2 billion construction and banking fortune; Hiroshi Termachi, owner of a $1.8 billion Japanese ball bearing business; and John Spyros Latsis, European head of a Saudi Arabian shipping and oil-refinery network worth $1.8 billion. The magazine based estimates of net worth on what it called ``published information or appraisals of asset values.'' To qualify, each prospect needed a net worth of $1 billion or more after subtracting debt. Fortune said the United States remained home to the greatest number of billionaires at 58. Twenty were from the Persian Gulf, 15 from West Germany, nine from Italy, and eight in Japan, down from 12 last year.

DOC.HEAD: Pathe Delivers Another $50 Million on Its MGM-UA Deal
DOC.TEXT: Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti has paid another $50 million towards Pathe Communications Corp.'s $1.3 billion purchase of MGM-UA Communications Co. Tuesday's payment brings to $303 million the total of non-refundable down payments that Parretti has made since March, when Pathe began making monthly installments of roughly $50 million. Another $50 million deposit is due Sept. 20 and the agreement calls for Parretti, chief of Pathe, to come up with the nearly $950 million balance by Oct. 23. ``The company is confident it will complete the deal as planned,'' said Pathe spokesman Craig Parsons. Parretti and Kirk Kerkorian, who controls MGM-UA, agreed to the monthly installments after Pathe failed to come to terms with its major backer, Time Warner Inc. For the four-month extension granted Pathe, MGM-UA stockholders will get $21.50 a share from the deal, up from the original $20 a share. Time Warner had agreed to provide a $650 million loan to Pathe for the deal in return for a lien on the valuable United Artists film library and extensive distribution rights to Pathe and UA movies. But that part of the deal fell apart, and Time Warner has sued Pathe for $100 million, accusing Pathe of breaching its contract by, among other things, double-selling some distribution rights. The media conglomerate said Pathe apparently never was able to meet one of the terms of the deal: that it come up with the other half up with the $1.3 billion in money that was not borrowed. Pathe counter-sued for $500 million, saying Time Warner had breached its contractual duty to provide the $650 million loan.

DOC.HEAD: King Broadcasting Asking Price Well Over $500 Million
DOC.TEXT: The money to start King Broadcasting Co. came from timber, and much of the half-billion dollars expected from its sale will be plowed back into timber. The sisters who control the company said Tuesday they are putting the privately-held media company up for sale and plan to use the proceeds for preserving the environment. ``There are some real environmental crises right now that we have the opportunity to meet,'' Harriet Stimson Bullitt said. ``If we have a chance to contribute to the salmon coming back to a clean river or to see the sparkle of the water and smell the freshness of the air and the earth of the forests and to see the forests continue to grow ... that would be the most exciting prospect for us,'' she said. Bullitt, chairwoman of the executive committee of King, and Priscilla Collins, chairwoman of the board, said they expected more than $500 million from the sale. They said they wanted to put more money into their Bullitt Foundation's environmental efforts, and wanted to find a satisfactory buyer before either of their deaths forced a sale. Bullitt is 65 while Collins is 69. King owns six television stations in the Northwest and Hawaii, six radio stations in Seattle, Portland, Ore., and San Francisco, and 13 cable television systems in Washington, Idaho, California and Minnesota. King was founded by Dorothy Stimson Bullitt, mother of the two women. Dorothy Bullitt, who died last year at age 97, was the daughter of Seattle lumberman and developer Charles Douglas Bullitt. She founded King when she bought a struggling Seattle radio station in 1946 and renamed it KING. In 1948, she bought KRSC-TV and subsequently renamed it KING-TV. Stock owned by Collins and Harriett Bullitt, along with that left by their late mother and now controlled by them, makes up about 70 percent of the privately held company's shares. Puget Sound Business Journal has estimated King's 1988 annual revenues at about $150 million and said King has approximately 1,200 employees. The company could be worth as much as $650 million, said media analyst Bishop Cheen of Paul Kagan Associates in Carmel, Calif. He said the company may have to be sold in pieces, since credit has become tighter, and a buyer of the whole operation would have to obtain several waivers from the Federal Communications Commission to own radio and TV stations in the same market. King's properties include television stations KING, Seattle; KGW, Portland; KREM, Spokane; KTVB, Boise, Idaho; K38AS, Twin Falls, Idaho; and KHNL, Honolulu. Its radio stations are KING-AM and KING-FM in Seattle, KINK-FM and KGW-AM in Portland and KSFO-AM and KYA-FM in San Francisco. The company owns cable systems in Brooklyn Park and St. Croix, Minn.; Los Angeles, Santa Clarita, Riverside County, Lodi, Placerville, San Andreas, Mammoth Lakes and Mount Shasta, Calif.; Twin Falls and American Falls, Idaho; and Ellensburg, Wash. In all, the systems have more than 200,000 subscribers. King also owns Northwest Mobile Television, the nation's largest mobile production company.

The stock market edged upward today, mounting another attempt to rally after its steep summer slide. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose .74 to 2,604.70 in the first half hour of trading. DOC.HEAD: Hotel Whiz Tries to Save Trump's Empire
DOC.TEXT: Three years ago, Stephen F. Bollenbach saved hotel-gaming giant Holiday Corp. from a hostile takeover attempt by developer Donald J. Trump. Now he's trying to save Trump from himself. Trump recently picked Bollenbach as chief financial officer for his debt-swamped gambling and real estate holdings to satisfy a key creditor demand. Banks had agreed to loan Trump $65 million this summer on the condition he appoint a financial officer by Sept. 30, among other things. The loan was needed to help make a payment on junk bonds used to finance Trump's three Atlantic City, N.J., casinos, which were put up as collateral for the loan. Bollenbach _ who joined the Trump Organization several days ago after being CFO for Holiday spinoff Promus Cos. of Memphis, Tenn. _ will serve as a liaison between Trump and the banks. He says he's confident he can help his old adversary escape the clutches of borrowed money. ``We've got some really terrific assets _ like this hotel,'' the 47-year-old Bollenbach said during an interview at Trump's posh Plaza Hotel, Bollenbach's home in New York. ``But they draw their business from the Northeast . . . an area that's in an economic downturn.'' Bollenbach said Trump will have to overcome a dwindling pool of financing sources thanks to the collapse of the high-yield, high-risk junk bond market and stricter lending policies among commericial banks. ``It's put him in a bind,'' he said in a recent interview. ``We need to finance our way through the slow times. The solution is to make sure we keep costs down.'' But easing the flamboyant developer's $3.3 billion total debt burden will take some time, Bollenbach conceded. Bollenbach has begun by turning his attention to Atlantic City, which, like the real estate industry, remains in a slump. He said he's looking for cheaper ways to attract casino customers and increase gambling revenues. ``This is their (customers) selected form of entertainment. But like all selected forms of entertainment, you've got to make sure you don't spend more on getting your customers there than it's worth,'' he said. The New Jersey Casino Association said Atlantic City's 12 casinos recorded their first losing second quarter since gambling began there in 1978. Trump's recently opened Taj Mahal alone lost $14.1 million. Bollenbach, the son of a southern California milkman, is a personable family man with salt-and-pepper hair and a close-cropped beard. He and his wife, Barbara, share homes in Memphis and Greenwich, Conn. He said he hadn't meet Trump until this summer. But the two have known of each other for years. Bollenbach is credited with fending off Trump's takeover attempt of Holiday Corp. in 1987, a year after Bollenbach joined the firm. The company, which owned Harrah's casinos and smaller hotel groups in addition to Holiday Inns, had been considered undervalued. That prompted some shareholders, including Trump, to increase their stakes in Holiday. Bollenbach was behind a $2.4 billion recapitalization plan that ultimately raised Holiday's debt and made the company less attractive as a takeover target. ``We borrowed $2.8 billion, paid a $65 dividend to shareholders, and over the next couple of years, we sold real estate,'' he explained. The plan kept Trump away but it also made him between $18 million to $30 million richer, Bollenbach noted. Holiday was sold to British brewing giant Bass PLC last spring. Promus was spun off after the sale. Bollenbach's business career took off in 1968 when he went to work for Daniel K. Ludwig, a Phoenix, Ariz., shipping magnate and industrialist who also owned a chain of savings and loans. He worked his way up through Ludwig's company and was its chief financial officer when he was hired by Marriott Corp. in 1981. Bollenbach said Marriott's then-chairman, Gary Wilson, broadened the role of CFO to make it more involved in the total business. Although there was a certain comfort in working at Promus _ ``a great job with people I like to work with'' _ Bollenbach says he's ready for his next challenge, one that is likely to raise his public profile. ``I keep thinking of what Andy Warhol said about everybody being famous for 15 minutes,'' he said. ``I'd settle for four or five _ maybe even two.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Weaker, Gold Rallies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with close in Europe, midday quotes in New York.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell in European trading Wednesday amid growing uncertainty over the Gulf crisis. Gold recovered some ground lost overnight but prices were still lower and dealers said trading remained cautious. Dealers in London said there were no significant developments in the Gulf to move the foreign exchanges. Anticipation that U.S. interest rates would be eased to prevent a deep recession was drawing attention to currencies of countries where interest rates are expected to stay firm, dealers said. One of the main beneficiaries was the Swiss franc, dealers said. The Swiss currency has been seen as a safer investment than the dollar after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait prompted the U.S. to send a major force to the region. Speculation about U.S. interest rates was heightened by Wednesday's meeting of the U.S. Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, a body of monetary officials due to debate the issue of rate cuts. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 146.92 Japanese yen, up 0.37 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar retreated to 145.85 yen, and in New York, the dollar was quoted at 145.905 yen at midday. DOC.HEAD: Dalkon Shield Trust Fund Still Contains $2.3 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Although more than half of the 195,000 Dalkon Shield claimants have been paid, more than $2.3 billion is still available to women who were injured by the birth control device, a trust fund official said Wednesday. The fund contained $2.5 billion when it was established last year. But a significant portion still remains because of the size of payments thus far and the fact the fund is drawing $500,000 per day in interest, said Julie Freeman, the fund's manager of claimant relations. Ms. Freeman said the trust fund would shrink more rapidly as more large claims are paid. The Dalkon Shield intrauterine device, manufactured by the Richmond-based A.H. Robins Co. in the 1970s, was used by nearly 4 million women around the world, said Linda Hightower of Atlanta, director of the Dalkon Shield Victims Association. Lawsuits filed by women who claimed to be injured by the device forced Robins to file for bankruptcy reorganization in 1985. Women who used the product reported a variety of injuries, including sterility, miscarriages and pelvic inflammatory disease. Robins later was acquired by the American Home Products pharmaceutical company. Ms. Freeman said most of the claims paid so far were filed under an option that limits payments to $725. Under that option, claimants do not have to document their injuries. A second option allows claims of up to $5,500, while a third provides for ``substantially higher'' payments, Ms. Freeman said. She said the fund was not releasing a figure on how high those claims could reach. Ms. Hightower said the largest settlement she has heard about was $195,000. ``The trust won't say how many option 3 claims they've paid,'' she said. ``They say they're three months ahead of schedule. I don't know what their schedule was, but it must have been real slow.'' Ms. Freeman said she is satisfied with the progress in settling the claims. She said about 81,000 claimants still must decide which of the three options to pursue before payments can be made. Women have until next July 1 to make a decision. Payments are pending for about 15,000 claimants who have chosen an option. Women who have not yet filed a claim still may do so, Ms. Freeman said. However, late claims will be the last ones considered, she said. Ralph Pittle, a Seattle lawyer whose firm represents more than 900 claimants, said his company continues to receive calls from women who were injured by the device but did not know they could file a claim. ``Granted, there was an extensive advertising campaign, but not everyone watches TV, listens to radio or reads newspapers,'' he said. ``Some people just have a hard time surviving.''

DOC.HEAD: Reuters Chief Executive Sells 20 Percent Of Personal Holding
DOC.TEXT: Glen Renfrew, managing director and chief executive of Reuters Holdings PLC, has sold 20 percent of his personal holding in the company for 1.72 million pounds, or about $3.3 million, the company said Wednesday. DOC.HEAD: Kuwait Oil Tanker Co. May Charter Idle Tankers
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait Oil Tanker Co. hopes to charter some of its 30 oil and products tankers that have been idled by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, oil industry sources said Wednesday. The tanker company, an affiliate of the state-run Kuwait Petroleum Corp., wants to offset the losses it's incurred because of the Aug. 2 invasion. Oil industry sources said one chartering deal is already under discussion and could be completed next month. The tankers have been on charter to Kuwait Petroleum, and would now be subchartered, said the sources, who spoke on condition they not be named. None of Kuwait's fleet of oil and products tankers was caught in the country at the time of the invasion. Some are still delivering crude oil loaded before the invasion to the Kuwait Petroleum International network in Europe. The 30 tankers have a total of 2.56 million tons capacity. But the cutoff of Kuwaiti oil installations and refineries leaves Kuwait Petroleum with substantial excess tanker capacity, industry sources said. With the oil installations and refineries in Kuwait cut off by the Iraqi occupation, KPC is concentrating on the refining and marketing operations in Europe, which are run by Kuwait Petroleum International.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Post Co. To Enter Market for Pocket-Sized Phones
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Post Co. on Wednesday said it has joined with American Personal Communications Inc. to develop a new pocket-sized, wireless telephone service for the Washington area. Maryland-based AMC is the general partner in the limited partnership, which expects to begin testing an experimental phone system by the end of the year and be fully operational by the end of 1991, the companies said. Initially, the system would allow only one-way, outbound calling in Washington and its Maryland and Virginia suburbs, much like pay phones. Such service already is in use in Great Britain. The companies could jointly invest up to $6 million in the testing phase, Post spokesman Guyon Knight said. He would not speculate on what the overall development cost would be. The system is one of a number of Federal Communications Commission-sanctioned experiments in ``personal communications networks'' that proponents hope eventually will replace existing cellular and wired phone systems, particularly in office buildings. These proponents envision that someday all calls will be made not to locations, but to people, wherever they are, who would carry tiny phones with them. Wayne N. Schelle, AMC's chairman, said these new types of wireless phones are expected to be smaller, lighter and less expensive than today's portable cellular phones. ``Every member of a family or employee of a business will be able to carry a phone in their pocket in the same way they currently carry their keys or wallet,'' Schelle said in a statement. The folding phones, which will resemble a travel alarm clock, may be sold for as little as $75, AMC says. Customers would be able to make calls whenever they are in range of refrigerator-sized transmitting stations that would link callers with the public phone network or to other users of the wireless system. The system will use digital ``spread spectrum'' technology that allows a single call to switch back and forth continually to whatever frequency is available. The low-power radio signals will have ranges of only a few hundred feet, which means they will have less tendency to interfere with each other. This approach should dramatically increase the capacity _ and thus lower the costs _ for a personal communications network compared with today's cellular systems, which use more power to operate over longer distances on a relatively restricted number of channels. However, the low-power devices do not work well in moving automobiles. AMC received permission from the FCC earlier this year to test the new phone service for up to 2,000 users, but the FCC is still deciding whether to allot precious radio airspace to these new types of services. The companies said that if the FCC approves full development of the new service, it will consider expanding to other U.S. cities. The Washington Post Co., whose holdings include The Washington Post newspaper, in 1983 won a cellular phone franchise with AMC for the Washington-Baltimore area. The Post no longer is in that partnership, Knight said.

DOC.HEAD: Middle East Crisis Is Not The Cause For Low Interest In Gulf Sale
DOC.TEXT: The federal government's sale of oil and gas leases in the Gulf of Mexico on Wednesday drew few participants, but officials said the low turnout had nothing to do with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``Many people might expect the Middle East to affect the sale, but oftentimes big oil companies have already developed their bidding strategy,'' said Ed Cassidy, deputy director of the Minerals Management Service of the Department of Interior. One of the oil company representatives, who asked that his name not be used, said most companies had already budgeted this year's exploration before the Iraq-Kuwait invasion, which has pushed crude prices up 70 percent and made exploration for untapped reserves much more attractive. Shell Offshore Inc. offered the high bid of the day, $6.37 million for a tract off Cameron, La. Wednesday's high bids totaled $162.4 million. In all, 70 companies put up $240.9 million for the 4,792 tracts offered. Each tract is about 5,000 acres and most lie off the Texas coast. Cassidy said the area has traditionally yielded more natural gas than oil. ``That's another reason why the Middle East crisis is not directly affecting this sale,'' he said. Officials said the area held potential reserves of 100 million barrels of oil and 1.48 trillion cubic feet of gas. ``Today's sale is a bit smaller that we expected, but there's no direct correlation to the Middle East situation,'' said Charlie Howell, a Mobil representative. ``It's just a matter of generating the prospects.''

DOC.HEAD: Trial Begins in Boeing Toxic-Waste Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co. has taken its insurance companies to court in a bid to settle an $80 million dispute over who should pay to clean up toxic wastes at two Seattle-area sites. The insurance companies have refused to pay for cleanup closts. They contend Boeing knew it was polluting Western Processing in Kent and Queen City Farms in Maple Valley. But during opening statements in court Tuesday, Boeing attorneys told a U.S. District Court jury that the aircraft manufacturer never expected its practices would cause widespread pollution at the sites. Boeing ``believes its insurance policies should have been honored, and they have not been,'' said Robert Sayler, an attorney for the company. Boeing has told its insurers it could be liable for cleanup costs at 13 sites in six states, which could run into hundreds of millions of dollars. Boeing dumped 24 million gallons of liquid wastes into pits at Western Processing and Queen City Farms. In the 1980s, the company agreed to pay the bulk of the cleanup costs _ more than $80 million _ at the sites under court-ordered consent decrees with the federal Environmental Protection Agency. Sayler said Boeing began using Queen City Farms in 1957 because it preferred a ``remote lagoon'' over dumping its wastes in the Duwamish River or Puget Sound. Boeing had been barging its wastes to sea for dumping before 1957, said Charles Gordon, another company attorney. In 1964, Gordon said, Boeing began taking its wastes to Western Processing because that company was recycling. The state also recommended the move. Boeing never anticipated the problems that would occur at the sites, and the company's decisions must be viewed in the context of environmental standards that have evolved over the years, Sayler and Gordon told the jury. The insurance companies named as defendants include Aetna Casualty & Surety Co., Hartford Accident & Indemnity Co., Insurance Co. of North American and Ronald E. Smith & Cos., an association of syndicates that includes Lloyds of London.

DOC.HEAD: Playskool President Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Stephen A. Schwartz, president of the Playskool division of toymaker Hasbro Inc., has stepped down in a management shakeup that would have moved him down the corporate chain of command. Hasbro's announcement Tuesday said Schwartz, 41, resigned ``to pursue other business opportunities.'' Under Schwartz, Playskool was Hasbro's fastest-growing division during the past two years, taking on the Fisher-Price unit of Quaker Oats Co. Playskool, whose products include Mr. Potato Head and Tinkertoys, generated about $352 million in domestic sales last year, or about 25 percent of Hasbro's $1.4 billion in worldwide net sales. Under the new arrangement, Schwartz would have reported to Alfred J. Verrecchia, who has been made chief operating officer for Hasbro's domestic toy operations. Schwartz had been reporting directly to Alan G. Hassenfeld, Hasbro chairman and chief executive. Paul H. Valentine, toy industry analyst at Standard & Poor's Corp., said Schwartz, who joined Hasbro in 1978, was ``one of the guiding lights of Hasbro through the 1980s'' when the company grew rapidly. But recently Hasbro's sales have lagged, and Verrecchia may have been appointed to oversee domestic toy operations because he has more of a financial background, analysts suggested. Hassenfeld did not comment in the statement about Schwartz's departure and was not available for comment. The management restructuring cuts in half the number of people reporting to the chairman and will allow Hassenfeld to concentrate on strategic plans for the company, Verrecchia said.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Over $30 Per Barrel, First Time Since '85
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures soared above $30 a barrel for the first time in nearly five years Wednesday, as traders reacted to fears of military escalation in the Middle East showdown. Nervous trading also pushed unleaded gasoline futures to a record high closing price. Analysts said world supplies were starting to feel the crunch of 4 million barrels of crude lost each day through the boycott of Iraq and Kuwait. The Saudi Arabians also curtailed some previously arranged sales of jet fuel and other products to accommodate the massive military buildup on their soil. ``The main factor here in the crude market, apart from a concern of hostilities, is simply the fact that OPEC continues to drag its feet in getting higher production,'' said Bob Baker, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Indications that Saudi Arabia and Venezuela want to increase production have not materialized into any more oil. The price of October contracts for light, sweet crude shot up $2.51 per 42-gallon barrel to close at $31.22 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Oil last traded above the $30 threshold on Nov. 26, 1985. Unleaded gasoline prices on the Merc closed at $1.043 per gallon for September delivery, up 2.99 cents over Tuesday's record close of $1.013 per gallon. The near-term contract has closed higher for six straight trading days. Those following the industry said consumers will be paying even more for gasoline at the pump, although analysts said there was no firm way to translate the rise in futures prices to a predictable rise in retail prices. One analyst said a 1-cent rise in unleaded futures can mean a 1-cent increase at the pump. Wall Street traders were generally surprised by the abrupt jump of crude over the $30 per barrel mark. ``As long as this standoff continued, I had expected pretty volatile markets in the $25 to $30 range,'' said Stephen Smith, an oil analyst with Bear Stearns & Co. Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., said markets shot up partially in reaction to news that Saudi Arabia was cancelling some of its sales contracts in a move to supply oil products to the international military forces that have converged on the Persian Gulf. ``The concrete news that came into the market this morning was the cutback in Saudi Arabia's product export availability,'' Hittle said. ``First, we lost Kuwait: 690,000 barrels a day. Now, the Far East and some U.S. majors have lost volume from the Saudis on top of that. There is also a lot of concern that this situation could get worse.'' Traders had no firm numbers for the size of the Saudi cutbacks, Hittle said. While markets were still open Wednesday afternoon, President Bush announced he was ordering military reservists to active duty in the Persian Gulf, telling a news conference that the United States will not retreat from the hard line it has taken against Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. ``The conference was not reassuring to the market,'' Hittle said. ``What the market is looking for at this point is a clear sign that there will not be any military escalation. It's still nervous. Everybody is still buying. If there's a change in the political or military situation, then we'll see a change for sure, but I can't predict that.'' Inventories of oil available to the world market have declined by about 80 million barrels, from the 250 million barrel range, since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, Smith said. ``The Saudis and the Venezuelans and the United Arab Emirates have been talking about increased production to offset the missing oil, but so far it's been mostly talk,'' Smith said. In other products traded on the Merc, home heating oil rose 7.64 cents per gallon to 91.35 cents for September delivery, while natural gas moved up from $1.420 to $1.428 per 1,000 cubic feet.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Continues to Slide, Gold Prices Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar continued to weaken Wednesday as the foreign exchange markets remained nervous about events in the Persian Gulf. Gold prices were mixed. Analysts said the dollar fluctuated in a narrow range as traders awaited new developments from the Middle East. Earl Johnson, an assistant vice president at Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago, said the dollar had some support from fears that war would break out, but lost ground on continuing concerns about the slowing U.S. economy. ``It's basically a nervous market,'' he said. Investors were reluctant to make major moves in any direction, Johnson said. Overseas dealers said traders continued to buy currencies of nations where interest rates were expected to remain high. The markets believed U.S. rates would be eased to prevent a recession, analysts said. The British pound, one of the currencies supported by high rates, continued to climb against the dollar. Sterling rose to $1.9235 in New York from late Tuesday's $1.9113. In earlier London trading, the pound rose to $1.9275 from $1.9215. The dollar fell to 146.15 Japanese yen in New York from 146.80 yen late Tuesday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar closed at 146.92 yen, up 0.37 yen from Tuesday, and the U.S. currency was quoted at 145.85 yen in late London trading. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5575 German marks, down from 1.5645; 1.2775 Swiss francs, down from 1.2900; 5.2390 French francs, down from 5.2635; and 1.13535 Canadian dollars, down from 1.13985. The dollar did manage to post a slight gain against the Italian lire, rising to 1,162.25 lire in New York from 1,161.75 late Tuesday. In Europe earlier, the dollar rose to 1,159.00 lire from 1,155.75. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.5535 German marks, down from 1.5545; 1.2735 Swiss francs, down from 1.2855; 5.2260 French francs, down from 5.2325; 1.7500 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7530; and 1.1363 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1437. Gold prices were higher in New York after falling in Europe. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce of gold rose $3.60 to $411, while Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $412.50, up $5.60 from Tuesday. Overseas dealers said fluctuations in the price of gold reflected the market's nervousness over the Gulf. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $410.25 a troy ounce from $413.25 late Tuesday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $410.25 from $414.75 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.24 to close at a bid $408.69. Silver rose on the Commodity Exchange, picking up 3.8 cents to close at $5.129 a troy ounce. In London earlier, silver fell to a late bid price of $5.15 a troy ounce from late Tuesday's $5.20.

DOC.HEAD: Thrift Head Accused of Embezzling Over $1 Million
DOC.TEXT: A former savings and loan president has been charged by federal prosecutors with embezzling more than $1 million from the thrift. Richard Kukielski, who headed West Town Savings & Loan in suburban Cicero, was accused Tuesday of accepting 212 worthless checks from a customer between 1982 and 1987 to conceal his misappropriations of the S&L's money. Prosecutors said Kukielski cashed the checks with money from the vault and hid the processed checks in his desk drawer. Then, prosecutors said, he juggled the S&L's ledgers to conceal his activities from auditors. If convicted on all three counts he faces, Kukielski could be imprisoned for 15 years and fined $750,000, prosecutors said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Trump, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are selected excerpts from the New Jersey Casino Control Commission's ruling Tuesday allowing Donald Trump to use his three casinos as collateral for a $65 million loan:

There are two essential restructuring documents, the credit agreement and the override agreement. Under the credit agreement, seven banks will grant a $65 million line of credit to Trump. The initial draw will be $40 million, $20 million of which will replace $20 million previously loaned to meet an interest payment on the Trump Castle bonds. The remainder is to be used in accordance with a business plan. Interest on borrowings under the credit agreement will be payable currently. Principal repayment will be deferred until the agreement expires. The agreement is for three years, extendable to five years at Trump's option if he satisfies various conditions, including supplying a new business plan acceptable to the seven banks covering the additional two years. The override agreement is between Trump and the nine banks which hold the $1 billion in restructuring debt, $840 million of which hold the $1 billion in restructuring debt, $840 million of which affords potential recourse for Trump because it is guaranteed by him or is debt of a partnership in which he is a general partner. The nine banks include the seven signatories to the credit agreement. The principal and, in most cases, the interest on the $1 billion will be deferred for five years. In addition, the banks will observe a five-year moratorium on recourse against Trump. For his part, Trump has agreed to pledge all of the equity in his casino companies.

As long as there is any outstanding loan under the credit agreement, the seven signatory banks may declare a default, by a vote of the holders of two-thirds of the outstanding amount of the loan, upon the occurrence of an ``event of default.'' Events of default include: _ A payment default under the credit agreement. _ The breach of any term of the credit agreement. _ The failure to keep any loan document in full force and effect. _ A payment default on any indebtedness of Trump or his affiliates, other than the Trump Shuttle, of over $5 million. _ A bankruptcy or other judicial declaration of insolvency by Trump or any of his affiliates. _ The failure of Trump or any of his affiliates to make payments to certain employee benefit plans. _ Any judgment of over $5 million against Trump or his affiliates, other than the Trump Shuttle, which remains unpaid for 80 days. _ Any material adverse change in the condition, financial or otherwise, of Trump or his affiliates. _ Any governmental action which materially and adversely affects the ability of Trump and his affiliates to operate the casinos. _ Any restructuring of the equity of any casino company. _ Trump's death or incapacity. If a default is declared following any event of default, the seven banks may take any action provided in the credit agreement, including foreclosing on the equity in the casinos.

If the commission is in fact convinced that the restructuring will leave the casinos more stable than it found them, petitioners' contention that we need not conduct a full stability hearing at this point is persuasive. Whether the record establishes the salutary effect of the restructuring is, however, a difficult and troublesome question. It is obvious that the restructuring will confer substantial benefits on the Trump Organization, and on the casinos as assets of that organization. There will be $65 million in fresh capital and the debt service on $1 billion in existing loans will be deferred. There will also be a moratorium on recourse against Mr. Trump, which will have the effect of protecting his assets, including the equity in the casinos, from creditors. On the other hand, there are features of this restructuring which could be extremely destabilizing to the casinos. Absent the restructuring, if one of the casinos were to default on its existing debt, it would presumably attempt to reach an accommodation with its lenders, such as a debt-for-equity exchange. Failing that, it might suffer a foreclosure of the casino hotel and a sale to a qualified buyer. ... In the alternative, it might go into bankruptcy. The commission has dealt with all of these alternatives in the past, and could surely deal with any of them again with respect to a Trump property. As of today, none of these alternatives with respect to one Trump casino would necessarily have any effect on the other two. If the restructuring is effectuated, however, each of these alternatives will be an event of default ... and could lead to a foreclosure on the equity of all three properties. Thus, the restructuring links the fate of the three properties, and increases the likelihood that financial problems at one would lead to foreclosure of the others. Even more disturbing is the link the restructuring forges between the fate of the casinos and that of other Trump assets. If, for example, the Trump Shuttle goes into bankruptcy, or employee benefit fund payments are not made at the New York Plaza Hotel, or real estate taxes are not paid on the Penn Railroad Yards, the credit and override agreement banks could calla default. We are thus being asked to tie the fate of the three casinos to a host of events which have nothing to do with their individual or collective financial condition. We are being told that foreclosure on the casino equity, whether through judgments or bankruptcy of the Trump Organization, is a virtual certainty without this restructuring, but may be avoided if the restructuring is consummated. This is obviously a situation in which there is are no good answers for Mr. Trump or for New Jersey. Whether we approve or disapprove this restructuring, our action will be fundamentally unsettling. It is clear that, absent some form of restructuring, the casino equity will be reached by creditors holding liens on the non-casino assets. Second, in view of the enormous time and effort put into this proposal, and in view of the absence of non-casino assets in which the Trump Organization has substantial equity, it is highly unlikely that rejection of this proposal will lead to another restructuring which will not include a pledge of the casino equity. The risk of substantial economic disruption at the casinos will be less with the restructuring than it is without it.

DOC.HEAD: Pork Futures Turn Lower
DOC.TEXT: A growing supply of pork and a break in cash market prices combined Wednesday to send hog futures prices skidding at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork bellies also were big losers, with the contract for delivery in August falling the limit 2 cents a pound for the second straight day. On other markets, petroleum futures surged ahead strongly, grains and soybeans were mostly higher and gold advanced. Hog futures were dragged lower by the nearby October contract, which was down as much as 1.10 cents a pound. ``That contract reflected a fairly substantial break in fresh pork loins this week and in cash hogs,'' said Charles Levitt, senior livestock analyst for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. In addition, there's a seasonal increase in hogs being brought to market that's causing some supply problems, he said. Bellie futures were undercut by two days of sharp declines in the price of fresh pork bellies. An added problem for pork prices may appear Friday when the USDA issues its monthly cold storage report. ``This report could show a very large supply of turkeys in storage,'' Levitt said. ``If it does, there could be some cheap turkeys around that could compete with some of the pork products during the fall and winter holiday seasons.'' Cattle prices settled higher, rebounding from losses suffered after a government report last week showed a large increase in cattle placed on feed lots. The big increase was in July, and these animals won't be coming to market until the end of the year. ``We'll still have some tightness this fall,'' said Levitt. Live cattle settled .15 cent to .42 cent higher with the contract for delivery in October at 78.22 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .35 cent lower to .35 cent higher with August at 89.52 cents a pound; live hogs were .75 cent lower to .02 cent higher with October at 48.55 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were .60 cent to the limit 2 cents lower with August at 45.72 cents a pound. Deepening fears on the Middle East crisis sent oil futures soaring past the $30 mark on the New York Mercantile Exchange for the first time since Nov. 26, 1985. West Texas Intermediate crude oil advanced the limit $1 on the distant contracts to $2.51 on the October delivery, which settled at $31.22 a barrel; heating oil was 4.31 cents to 7.64 cents higher with September at 91.35 cents a gallon; and unleaded gasoline was 2.95 cents to 5.66 cents higher with September at $1.0411 a gallon. Precious metals futures advanced on the Commodity Exchange in New York, but lacked the volitility of previous days, despite sharp movements in oil prices. The situation in the Middle East is too uncertain, said John O'Connell, manager of futures research for Refco Inc. in New York. ``Most of the guys (trading in gold) have turned a little cautious,'' he said. ``Any fall in crude could hurt them as well.'' Gold futures settled $3.30 to $4 higher with the August contract at $411 a troy ounce. Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly a little higher on the Chicago Board of Trade. Trading was mixed and sluggish through much of the session, but prices improved on the belief that the Soviet Union is in the market for cooking oil. ``Rumors surfaced late the day that the Russians were buying, or interested in buying, bottled vegetable oil from South America,'' said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Wheat futures were 2 cents to 3\ cents higher with the September contract at $2.82\ a bushel; corn was 1{ cents lower to 2 cents higher with September at $2.53} a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1 cent lower with September at $1.16} a bushel; and soybeans were 3\ cents to 7 cents higher with August at $6.15\ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Automakers Handing Over Proposals to UAW
LaserPhoto DT4
DOC.TEXT: Each of the nation's Big Three automakers on Thursday are expected to give the United Auto Workers union comprehensive proposals for new three-year contracts. It's likely that the UAW will not have much immediate reaction as they compare the documents from General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. The proposals will help the union decide, probably on Tuesday, which company will be chosen as the union's target in this round of talks. If tradition holds, the union will use a contract reached with the target company as a pattern for contracts at the other two automakers. Most of the speculation about the target company centers on GM. ``What happens here at these tables and at General Motors and Chrysler in the next few days will have a direct bearing as to who that target company will be,'' UAW President Owen Bieber said Wednesday during a visit to Ford. ``Since all of them have indicated they would like to be the target, they have a decision to make of whether they would be the quarterback or the substitute sitting on the bench.'' Automakers like to be the target since it gives them an opportunity to form a pattern agreement to their liking rather than one meeting the needs of a competitor. Chief Ford negotiator Jack Hall declined Wednesday to discuss the upcoming proposal, saying only: ``We think it is going to be responsive to the needs the union has expressed to us.'' Bieber has been making the rounds at each of the Big Three this week, reminding negotiators that less than four weeks remain in the lives of the current agreements. The three contracts cover more than 450,000 active workers and expire Sept. 14. Bieber on Wednesday visited Ford, where the atmosphere at the main bargaining table and in subcommittee meetings is less charged than at GM or Chrysler. As he did at GM on Monday and was expected to do Thursday at Chrysler, Bieber said he was disappointed that Ford had not offered a comprehensive proposal before now. ``If I had my druthers, I would wish that we would be further along than we are,'' Bieber said. ``However, I would also say that I'm convinced that there is ample time left to conclude an agreement provided that the pace picks up considerably now.'' The UAW has been irritated at Chrysler chief negotiator Anthony St. John talking about contract proposals with the media before describing them to the union. St. John said the company was interested in an employee ownership plan for the company, forming a multi-employer health-care trust to cut medical care costs and a new way to figure profit sharing. UAW Vice President Stan Marshall, who's in charge of the Chrysler Department, has said each of the proposals are as good as dead. Tensions rose at GM earlier this month, when members of Local 659 at a Flint parts plant walked off their jobs for six days in a local contract dispute. That strike, which affected production at seven assembly plants and a variety of component factories, was unopposed by UAW national leaders. It resulted in a contract guaranteeing the size of the work force at the plant for years to come. The UAW has said job security is its top issue.

DOC.HEAD: Air Fare Increases Slowed By Several Carriers
DOC.TEXT: Pressure from competitors prompted several airlines Wednesday to hold off fare increases, even though the price of jet fuel keeps rising because of the Persian Gulf crisis. American Airlines, Continental Airlines, Delta Air Lines and USAir all said Wednesday they would delay raising fares until Aug. 30. American's 5.3 percent fare increase originally was to have gone into effect Thursday. American, based in Fort Worth, Texas, cited competitive pressure for its delay, the third since fare hikes were first announced Aug. 10. ``If one airline decides to do something different, they would gain a competitive market position and other airlines simply cannot allow that to happen,'' said American spokeswoman Mary O'Neill. Delta, based in Atlanta, first planned to raise fares on Aug. 15, and then this Thursday, but delayed the move to Aug. 30 in a ``competitive response'' to other airlines. Other major airlines have also responded to the Middle East standoff by announcing a mixture of fare increases and discount rates designed to lure more passengers.

DOC.HEAD: Control Data: Export License Approved for Soviet Computer Sales
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Commerce Department has granted Control Data Corp. an export license to ship the most powerful computers ever sent to the Soviet Union from the West, the company said Tuesday. Control Data will ship six CYBER 960 mainframe computers worth a total of $32 million to the Soviet Union beginning in September, the company said. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev visited Control Data during his June stop in Minnesota and viewed a demonstration of the CYBER 960 computers. Gorbachev also spoke on the need for greater technological and commercial cooperation between the United States and the Soviet Union. The computers were ordered by the Soviet Research and Development Institute of Power Engineering and will be used to analyze safety factors in the operation of civilian Soviet nuclear power reactors. The company applied for the export license last November and announced the Soviet order on Dec. 12, 1989. Control Data worked with the U.S. Departments of Commerce, State, Defense and Energy to put in place safeguards that the computers will be dedicated to safety analysis of civilian nuclear reactors, the company said. The Soviet Union's civilian nuclear power program is one of the largest in the world with about 50 plants in operation, according to a Control Data statement. Last year half of the Soviet Union's nuclear-generated electricity was produced by plants designed by the institute that has ordered the Control Data computers, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Transmits Complete Stock Options Free
DOC.TEXT: Atlanta Journal-Constitution has started offering to fax stock option tables to its readers. The new service, which began Tuesday, is part of the newspaper's Extra Fax program. The program, launched in June, permits readers who dial the Extra Fax number _ 222-XFAX _ to get more information over their fax machines. It's all free of charge. The service had been used only for advertisements and allowed readers to dial the fax number, put in the advertiser's code and receive price lists, coupons or sales announcements. The new service provides figures for options and index options traded on the Chicago, American, Philadelphia and Pacific exchanges. The service is the newspaper's first effort to expand its daily news report using facsimile, said Chris Jennewein, director of information services. Jennewein said the system was developed by Marietta-based AudioFAX Inc.
